Fassbender masterfully summons the powerful gravity that pulled other objects into Jobs' orbit-as well as the icy, distant chill that pushed most people away.

Is it parody with heart, satire that jabs with a funny bone, or a south-of-the-border rom-com? (The biggest audience response, for what it's worth, comes from Bullock's bare buttocks hanging out an open bus window.)

A moving, lyrical meditation on love, imagination, bravery, strength, happiness, home, holding on and letting go, looking back and moving on, and the unbreakable, unshakeable bond between a mother and child.
The 24th movie since 'Dr. No' began the franchise in 1962 may reflect on the past and even gaze into the grave, but it's vibrantly, expressively, emotionally alive and very much in step with today.
An all-star cast fumbling around in a deep-dish holiday goo of dumb dialogue, silly shtick and artificial sweetness.

Does everyone look "over it" because they're tired of fighting for the revolution-or because they really are? As Mockingjay flutters and flaps to a close, this victory lap looks and feels like a slog.
Star Wars has come roaring and soaring back with a fabulous, bountiful, richly rewarding payoff for anyone who's been waiting, patiently or otherwise.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Somehow grownup jokes Christmas-gift-wrapped by these two smart, classy leading ladies makes the dirty seem merely naughty.
There's a soft, sweet spot in the middle of the yuks, about parents and kids and the realities of divorce---about how families take teamwork, how parenting is hard and no two dads are the same.
Smith is outstanding as he tackles what might be his one of his trickiest, juiciest roles---a crusading underdog with a potentially life-saving message that falls on mostly deaf ears.
The screen swells with earth, air, sky and water. You don't just watch it, you feel it---the cold, the wet, the pain, and the primal emotions that drive the characters.
The banter-y jokes are lame, the writing unimaginative, the plot thinner than a thong bikini and the performances so limp and lazy they seem to evaporate in the Florida heat.
This clam-chowder winter drama won't win any awards, but it does stand as a stirring tale of Greatest Generation heroism 'rescued' from obscurity by the big screen.
Murray, the scruffy, gruff-y glue, holds it all together and keeps it from flecking off into granules of sugary-sweet cuteness.
The beats are fly, the story is nitty-gritty and the timing is spot-on, reminding us of just how shocking, raw and impactive N.W.A.'s music was 25 years ago---and how powerfully it echoes even today.

Nazi fascists, Italian playboys, speedboats, femme fatales, fast cars, double crosses, old-school spy do-daddery and gorgeous, eye-popping fashions. It sometimes looks like the cast of 'Mad Men' left Madison Avenue and went into Euro undercover work.

There's a lot to like and more to love about this movie, but most of it comes down to Jordan, whose performance as Adonis is raw and rousing, and to Stallone, who at 69 does some of his best acting in years.
Above and beyond the brutal, visceral slaps, jabs, and upper cuts is a bigger, softer story of a father and a daughter on a journey of emotional homecoming that packs quite a punch of its own.
Move over, James Bond. Some new supercool spy guys--and gals--have just laid claim to the multiplex, and they make just about everything that came before them look old, slow, tame and even lazy.
It's determined to get dirtier, darker, grosser and more all-around ickier than any 'Vacation' before.
Costner may be the star, but the high school athletes also shine. After all, this "based-on-a-true-story" movie is their story, too.
It has so much eye-candy razzle-dazzle, and it looks so fabulous, you forget its flaws and get lost in its cool, groovy vibes and its long-con gamesmanship, and-hey, where's my wallet?!!
This sub-par scare-flick entry in the "back from the dead" genre starts smart but gets dumber as it goes.
Large interior scenes seem designed, propped and photographed less like dystopian drama and more like a Broadway musical---I halfway expected someone to break into a song called "Beyond the Wall."
Ferrell and Hart work tirelessly to stay on their feet as the comedic ground crumbles underneath them and their talent.
A masterful cavalcade of carefully orchestrated vehicular mayhem, a dose of high-octane escapism ramped up to ridiculous, fantastical extremes.
Like the big bowl of mac and cheese Luke says is his favorite dish, it's all mostly a bunch of squishy, deep-dish goo---but hey, it does look pretty good.
A human comedy of people growing up and growing older, finding out who they are and what they want out of life, and learning that every age--and every stage--has its joys as well as its jolts.
Delivers some truly unsettling jolts with a minimum of effects and what was surely a micro-fraction of the budget of much bigger, bloodier, more bloated horror flicks.
The cast is top-notch, and Whedon packs the script and the screen with cleverness as well as ka-pow. But even at 141 minutes, things still feel jammed and crammed.
A clunky misfire that chokes on the fumes of tired lowbrow gags, worn-out stereotypes, shrill slapstick and lazy, predictable, sub-sitcom writing.
Branagh makes this familiar tale feel so fresh, even though you know exactly where it's going, staging it with the full-scale splendor of a period drama rather than a bedtime story.
Not quite as fresh as the original, but still a bright, light, fem-centric frolic of music and goofy fun.
It made me think of the Three Stooges recast for the modern age as pint-size, goggle-wearing, butter-hued niblets. It may not be high humor, but boy, it sure made me laugh.
Dano is nothing short of phenomenal in an Oscar-worthy performance that captures and channels the drive, innocence, obsession and brilliance behind Wilson's masterpiece, Pet Sounds.
Give into it, go with it and let it take you where it leads you---and don't caught up in thinking that you already know where that will be.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The brain, science tell us, is one of the most complex things in all creation, and the movie's depiction of it is a thing of ingenious splendor, a mix of fantastically cartoonish sight gags and sublime comedic riffs.

The underlying theme of man's hubristic drive to control-and commercialize-nature's primal power never gets in the way of its full-throttle fun and its cavalcade of chills, thrills and stupendous state-of-the-art effects.
An almost nonstop parade of crude jokes, celebrity cameos and gurgling bong hits-but I can't say it's not funny, and some of it is downright hilarious.
Johnson can rappel out of a helicopter and leap from a plane, hotwire a truck and pilot a boat through a tsunami, and even bring someone back from the dead. He's the Rock AND the Man.
Maybe it really is a small, small world, after all. Now I'm super-curious about the secret purpose of Mr. Toad's Wild Ride.
Makes most other blockbusters, superhero sagas and special-effect blowouts look like they were made with doodles, doodads and trinkets from a toy box.
Like an R-rated, 100-minute Viagra commercial shot inside a VIP strip club operated by light-depraved leprechauns.
It's all very complicated and convoluted, a muddled sci-fi haystack of past, present and future that looks even denser and darker-as many movies do-in 3-D.
Hardcore romance fans may enjoy parts of this. It's watchable, but overall, it's disappointing.
It's fun and gives this genre a new twist.
Rampart about the performances, most notably Woody's. The movie on the whole is just okay, leaving you with a unsatisfying ending and doesn't add up to a whole lot.
Overall, this is an okay time waster when it comes on TV or DVD, but it's certainly not worth full price at the box office, despite, some entertainment provided by the always reliable Guy Pearce.
There are some sappy moments, but overall it's exciting, with a good story and a credible, charismatic performance by Lawrence that makes the whole thing work.
The filmmakers offer a few interesting moments, but the overall picture doesn't really add up to much.
It's never boring, and although some of this is flawed and kind of ridiculous, including the implausible ending, if you go along for the ride, there's fun as well as some suspense to be had here.
At best, it's a late-night HBO watch or a cheap DVD rental, which is where I imagine this movie will wind up quite soon.
It's not fun, it's not funny, it's not realistic. It's beyond boring.
It's all over the map and all that's worth watching, in the end, is a great performance by Meryl Streep.
The emotion that was found in the play is gone, the heart is missing and what's left is just technical beauty.
Overall, it's not really the actors or the director who are to blame. It's the lousy material. The saving grace is that it's only 80 minutes. But even that felt too long.
Knightley does an adequate job and fans of Farrell, while they might admire his performance, will probably be disappointed with the overall film.

Perhaps writer/director McQueen thinks by showing all this explicit stuff, he's doing something daring when in reality he should have paid more attention to his script and his characters, which are tedious and ultimately come up empty.
The wedding might delight fans the way some people marvel at watching a royal wedding. But that's another phenomenon that I don't quite understand.
Except for the storyline, which lacks emotional depth, there's so much here for film lovers to make this a joyous experience.
It's too long and it lags a bit in spots, but overall there is still a lot of fun to be had here.
A very good movie, filled with precious, small, touching moments. I suspect that it will stay with you long after the credits fade.
Stylistically it has some things going for it, but the characters and plot are so slipshod that you won't really care after about a half hour what's going on.
It's dark, and won't be everyone's cup of tea. But I liked it and give Goldthwait props for having the guts to make a film like this.
Overall, it is not a total misfire, as some kids may like it. However, Sandler, who is talented, needs to start making some better movies.
Sonnenfeld should be proud of himself for reinvigorating this series and making it a witty, entertaining, joy ride from start to finish.
As a document of homelessness, it's well done, and Gere is incredible as George. But as a movie with a dramatic arc, it's not engrossing or captivating, so on that level it fails.
There are a couple of humorous moments, but not many.
An overproduced, baffling movie that falls flat.
I enjoyed spending time with these characters again and if you loved the series, you'll like the movie.
A pleasant, welcome surprise.
Incredibly expensive action scenes full of destruction go on for way too long with little context behind them, leading to overkill and boredom.
If you want to see stuff blowing up for two hours straight and don't care about a story or character development, then this is the movie for you. But I need a lot more out of a film.
Overall, Inside Out is well worth seeing, offering up lots of food for thought.
Bottom line, I didn't laugh as much as I wanted to.
Overall, it's a well-done film that offers up pointed social commentary as it also delivers a thought provoking history of the group.
The finely nuanced script takes a sensitive look at this disease and its effects, not only on the person afflicted, but also on family members who have to deal with it.
It's a witty, heartfelt and engaging film that's elevated by the performances.
Using archival footage, including what appears to be home movies, a fascinating picture is painted of this obnoxious opportunist who, in his own way, changed the face of television.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: By the end, as hokey as this might seem, I found myself getting caught up it in emotionally and overall, it somehow manages to work.
It's still all too familiar. And that's basically my gripe here and it's a big one. I don't want to see this same story again.
It's not brilliant like Ratatouille or Finding Nemo but it's not a total dud either, like Cars 2.
The best movie I've seen so far this year.
Even with flaws, Kessler does manage to paint a portrait of a talented guy who seems to be a lot happier with his life now having finally found himself.
One day, it may become a bad movie/cult classic -- the kind of film that people go to laugh at, like Showgirls. But for now, it's so boring it feels endless.
Elmo's enthusiasm and love is so infectious it's hard not to smile whenever this Muppet is on the screen.
It's an authentic New York slice of life, and the "coming of age" story has depth. The main character is at a crossroads and you'll be rooting for him all the way.
This thing is tons of fun to watch and kids ages 10 to 15 are going to love it.
If you want to experience Bill Hicks' best cutting edge, controversial comedy and then decide for yourself if the praise he did receive was warranted, this documentary achieves none of that.
This did not grab me, whereas the original did.
Gyllenhaal is quite engaging here, there's plenty of suspense filled action and you will be intrigued the whole way through.
Even though it doesn't break any new ground, The Lincoln Lawyer is an intelligent mystery.
Visually bland, unconvincing CGI, an inane script, wooden, one note, cartoonish characters and too much boom, boom, boom; bang, bang, bang.
If you have kids, aged five to 10, they'll have a rollicking good time, but anyone over that age might marvel at the look of the film, but after about 20 minutes, will be bored.

If you're looking for some laughs and teen comedies are your thing, or in this case comedies involving twenty somethings, having one last fling at being teenagers, for what it is, Take Me Home Tonight fits the bill.
Avoid Hall Pass at all costs.
There is a good story here. Too bad this filmmaker didn't know how to tell it.

It's good, clean entertainment and if you have children and are looking for a night out with them, where they won't be rolling their eyes, they'll have a good time and you might even enjoy yourself, somewhat, as well.
Sassoon, himself, is engaging in the film, but this documentary -- although interesting at times -- is too fawning of its subject, loses perspective and often wastes good opportunities.
Weir has made an admirable work, but he should have created more interaction amongst his characters.
The acting across the board is excellent and this group of four Oscar-winning actors substantially elevate the level of the material.
The movie completely goes off the rails.
There are some laughs and pleasures to be found here.

This film, which shows Ochs' life -- flaws and all -- offers up a history lesson to those who are not that familiar with his musical work and societal contributions, and for Phil Ochs it provides some overdue recognition.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The joy that these creative types experience when their work is successful and the seriousness with which they approach their craft comes shining through. Along the way, viewers get caught up in their exuberance.
A nice little film that is peppered with several mild laughs.

It's the kind of movie that when it comes on HBO or Showtime, it'll be a semi-satisfying diversion, that despite its implausibility, will fit the bill, But it's definitely not worth full price at the box office.
With such talent at work, one might figure it would be a halfway decent movie. Well, think again.
There's no real surprises here, but if you like this sort of thing, this romance under the big top, for what it is, gets the job done.
Basically, it's a little better than okay -- but nothing more than that.

By the end, it does manage to grab hold of your emotions, but it's a long way to get there and not really worth it in the long run as there have been other films that have dealt with this subject matter in better fashion.
Refn has made a movie where the main characters barely speak and take themselves so seriously, that a little levity, at times, might have helped.
I don't why they made it.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I'm shocked that this movie, which opens next week, even got a theatrical release and didn't go straight to DVD. Even more amazing is that it got made in the first place.
For what it is, 30 Minutes Or Less works.
Keep an eye on Green, as he knows how to write dialogue, gets the most out of his actors and makes a most promising debut.
What a pleasure to see an intelligent, grown-up comedy with substance, amongst so many cartoonish, action films that have littered theaters this summer.
Overall, it's a lot of fun before it gets somewhat bogged down. But it does redeem itself with a great surprise ending and it's one of the better comic book movies to come along in a while.
An intelligent film made for adults with sophisticated, universal themes.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 is everything any Potter fan could want and more. It brings one of the most successful movie franchises to a thrilling conclusion.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The supporting cast provides a few laughs and it's easy to watch. But it's the kind of film that's more suited to late night viewing on HBO.
Young kids will like this, but that's about it.
If you're a New Yorker, it's a mesmerizing story and for the most part Battle For Brooklyn, provides an engrossing history lesson on this controversial project.
Somehow it kind of clicks.
It's the lame script, awful direction and total lack of heart or intelligence that makes this extremely agonizing to sit through.

Owen Wilson, an unusual choice, is fine here and the great supporting cast, from the present day characters to the actors who play the noted writers and artists from yesteryear, all relish their roles and are a joy to watch.
You can't help being uplifted by kids, trying to honestly express themselves through this unique medium.
It's been a while, but finally there's a good comedy out there that's worth a trip to the movies.
The script has some good lines, the premise is quite enjoyable, the execution is solid and the performances, by all actors involved, put the film over the top.
It is intelligent and highly entertaining for a while, but if they cut a half an hour out of this film, it would have been great.
Well done, highly entertaining and funny.
It is nice to see a summer family film, where, for a change, the emphasis is as much on thought-provoking story as it is on action.
Mature, sharp, insightful and funny.
Despite some clichéd moments, it is enjoyable, and I would recommend it for the acting and the historical significance.

Streep is fun to watch, singing badly and being oblivious to her headache inducing sounds. Hugh Grant is also quite good, making sure Florence lives a sheltered life and never finds out the truth that her voice stinks.
The narrative is unsatisfying as it leaves lots of unanswered questions.

Most of the characters are superficial and underdeveloped, while the film itself is filled with predictable scenarios. Strong performances by the cast elevate the material, but it's simply not enough.
It's very smart and entertaining, and if Coogan, Brydon and Winterbottom want to do a third film, I'd be more than happy to take another ride with them.
Ultimately the surreal concept is half-baked and poorly executed, which will take audiences out of the movie all leading to an unsatisfying conclusion.
The stellar cast is first rate, elevating whatever weaknesses there are in the material, and the overall result is an endearing, dysfunctional family that you'll enjoying spending a few hours with.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Lewis does some nice work here, but the film itself, written and directed by Daniel Noah, is maudlin and a downer.
The entire cast all turn in first-rate performances, as Reitman has given us a finely executed and fascinating cautionary tale that leaves lots of food for thought.
The production values are quite good, and so is the fun, pop music score. But there's a lot of action scenes, and that shortchanges the storyline. It could have also used more doses of humor.
Fans of the series will enjoy the chase scenes, but story-wise it's nowhere near as satisfying as some of its predecessors.

If that's what you're looking for -- basically a shoot 'em up set amongst the stars -- then it's fun and fits the bill. But true Star Trek fans will not really be satisfied, as the higher, thought provoking ideas are missing.
Pets is basically a by the numbers, pretty predictable, perfunctory movie that will appeal to kids aged eight to twelve. However, adults will be pretty much left out in the cold.
The fault lies not with the new cast; it's the lackluster script and the mediocre movie that they're saddled with.
The two-hour running time drags as this Spielberg misfire winds up being uninspiring and tedious.
It's bland and boring.
It is not in the same league as Toy Story 3, Up or Ratatouille, but it is still a worthwhile effort, worthy of bearing the Pixar name, and an admirable sequel to its predecessor.
Novelist Flynn nicely adapts her book to the screen, remaining predominately faithful to her source material.
Overall, it's a one note premise, where the characters, stuck up on a lift, have nowhere to go and quite fittingly the movie in turn, goes nowhere.
As Sully, Hanks is perfectly cast. It's a well-crafted, understated performance as a man who's haunted by the incident, cool and calm under pressure and uncomfortable in the role of hero.

The emotion and heart of the movie gets lost in an all the action. But the stars make it kind of entertaining at times, and if all you're looking for is a violent shoot em' up Western with a high body count, it fits the bill.
What makes this new movie a must see is the walk itself, which is an eye popping spectacle.
Overall, they've done a decent job, it's just not the masterpiece that the original was.
If all you're looking for is visually impressive non-stop action, and you don't care about story, dialogue or characters, then go. But I need a lot more out of a movie.
Maybe it doesn't quite gel into a perfect film, but it's still worth watching as the storyline and fate of the main character do manage to grab you, along with several captivating scenes.
If you think you deserve a break today, see this movie.
Ultimately, Patriots Day looks at how the city and its law enforcement officials came together in the face of this horrible tragedy.
Ultimately, it is a very satisfying movie, with historical significance, and it is great to see these women finally get their due.
From a visual standpoint it's stunning, as the production values are a real knockout. Plus the battle scenes are really well executed. That said the plot is not always that engaging.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For Beatles fans and as a history lesson for kids, should you take this ticket to ride? I say 'Yeah! Yeah! Yeah!'
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Damien Chazelle, whose last film was Whiplash, has made a movie that's visually amazing, awash in vibrant colors, while the camera magnificently swirls around the stars as they sing and dance.
The film is lensed beautifully, while attention to period detail is superb in all areas, from the costumes to the production design, expertly evoking the era.

If it wasn't based on a true story you could easily dismiss this film. But the fact that this really did happen sort of changes everything, and watching Vinny's remarkable comeback, along with sensational acting, gives audiences a lot to root for here.
Sadly, the historical significance of the event gets somewhat shortchanged in the low-key approach that this filmmaker has taken, making Loving, for the most part. a missed opportunity.
The Paperboy doesn't deliver.

Filled with an abundance of film clips from Lumet's vast body of work and interesting behind the scenes stories from Lumet, the movie will mainly be of interest to film buffs and fans of the heralded directors movies.
The supporting cast, which includes JK Simmons, Jeffery Tambor and John Bernthal are fine, and it's intriguing and fun for a time. But the ludicrous ending kind of ruined the whole experience for me.
The movie should be seen. It manages to involve you, makes a powerful statement and it's a story that needs to be told.
Judged strictly as a big-budget action film, we've seen it all before in dozens of other movies, and it's boring and uninvolving.
Director Garth Davis has taken this incredible, real life tale and made an emotionally involving film that pulls on your heartstrings every step of the way.
What Abrams has given us is the gravy without the meat and potatoes.
It's a touching film that sensitively explores one person's search to find out who he is.
It is a smart idea and it is ambitious. It is just too bad that it wasn't funnier.
Overall, The D Train is a wacky, welcome and very funny surprise.

Crowe, a former journalist for Rolling Stone, does know music, and the soundtrack is good. The on location Hawaiian settings are also nice to look at. However, there is little else here worth recommending.
If you liked the first Ted, you're going to really enjoy Ted 2.
It reminded me of how just good this Oscar winning actor could be when he shed himself, on screen, of his unique comedic gifts. He is certainly missed.
There are some funny one liners, the plot, although derivative, will have you engaged from start to finish and overall it's an enjoyable ride.
This is not worth full price at the box office on any level. I can make a slight case to see it when it comes out on On Demand, but it won't be a strong one.
As far as Helms and Applegate, they seem to be straining with the mediocre material and the harder they work, the more forced and desperate the entire movie seems.
Maybe if this was balanced with a personal story that one of the characters was going through, I would have taken the spoon-fed lesson. But we know the outcome in advance.

Writer Patrick Tobin and director Daniel Barnz have a made a movie that, despite the clichéd template, manages to hold your interest. The main reason for that are the fine performances, mainly by Aniston who pilots this thing.
The action scenes are excellent, the special effects are superb and there's good doses of humor, suspense and drama all along the way.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I did like the performances, even though Blanchett was a bit stagey. However, with this paper thin storyline that is overly drawn out, I did not care about the fate of the two main characters and the whole thing left me emotionally cold.
A brilliant, absorbing film.
Overall. this is a good comedy, just not a great one.
It's the engaging acting and expert direction that manages to rise well above any of the script's deficiencies.
It's an ingenuous screenplay that's marvelously executed by Singer, whose return to the series is more than welcome.
It is an interesting film for people who have seen many of the other movies and TV specials about Jobs. This one is a different take and a very worthwhile and interesting one at that.
It's a fascinating documentary that debunks the myth as it tries to separate fact from fiction and in the process offers up an eye opening history lesson.
It's not really what I want from a 007 film. It has its moments, some of the action scenes are well-shot, and it's not as bad as the last entry, Quantum Of Solace. But it's no Casino Royale.
Overall, it's alright. I do recommend it for children, but there's no real humor in it, and I've just come to expect more from the folks at Pixar.

The first half of the film... is somewhat entertaining, and some of the comedic dialogue in that section also periodically hits. It is the second half of the film, set three years later in Buenos Aires, where things fall very flat.
Simply put, I loved this movie. I can't wait to see it again, and it's easily one of my favorite films of the year.
They [the actors] are all defeated by a movie that ultimately has little to say, offers up no thrills and, at a bit under two hours, seemed a lot longer.
Overall, Neighbors 2 is not as good as the original, but fans of the first film will still find enough humor here to make it worth a look.
Fassbender, Lawrence and McAvoy class up the proceedings, and along with a cast of younger mutants and a surprise cameo, make it a lot of fun.
The movie is predictable and obvious, and it also feels a bit long, but who cares? It is a fun action flick with Neeson, doing what he does best these days - yielding satisfying results.
It wears out its welcome after about an hour. It also raises a few questions that are left unanswered. But there's still enough here to make it worth a look for fans.
Kidman gives one of her best performances in years.
What director Jon Favreau has done here is dazzling and spectacular.
The movie does have a few brief, bright spots, and the actual 20-minute battle between Batman and Superman offers some enjoyment. But overall, this film should have been way more satisfying.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It can be uplifting for kids and teens, telling them to follow their dreams and never give up. The fact that it is based on a true story makes that message stronger, even though the movie Rudy did it much better and with more heart.
The entire cast is first rate, but Keaton's performance is one to relish and might just put him back on top.

If you look past the laughs, partying and hijinks, you will see that Linklater is going for something more; a philosophy of being in the present and not trying too hard to figure out your entire life when you are only 18.
Hail, Caesar! is a bit disjointed and the story fall apart by the end, but who cares? It is an often-hilarious valentine to movie making in another era, and a good one at that.
By focusing on a small story, the sarcastically titled A Perfect Day becomes more relatable and in the process tells us more about the big picture, in this case the Bosnian conflict.
The whole thing has a retro swinging 60s vibe that I enjoyed. The actors all commit to both the lunacy on screen and its premise, and the result is a good natured and entertaining film.
Director Francois Girard, who has made several other musically themed films, including "The Red Violin," has made a predictable movie here, with a by-the-numbers storyline.
Is it realistic? Sure. But does that make it something you want to see? I say no.

Filled with incisive interviews... director Douglas Tirola does an admirable job of telling the Lampoon's story and offering up an inside look at how it launched huge careers and went on to change the face of contemporary comedy.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Isaac elevates the proceedings and I did enjoy his performance in a movie where there is little else to recommend.

There are dozens of entertaining pop culture references, and even the opening credits have a self-mocking tone. It starts off flat, but then, about 20 minutes in, takes off. The end result is surprising and a lot of fun.
This is not David O. Russell's finest work. It's no American Hustle or The Fighter. But it's still a solid effort worth seeing.
The dynamic dance sequences have all the right moves, but there's precious little to hold the attention once the music stops.
It's good to know nominal lead Kal Penn now has something more substantial on his resumé than Harold & Kumar Get The Munchies
Cliches notwithstanding, this trippy fantasy always keeps you watching, even if it is with open-mouthed bemusement.
The script won't win any stars for originality, it's all put across with enough sincerity to make the corn easy to swallow.
Sadly, it's all a bit of a Boer about 20 years past its sell-by date and tells us little we didn't know already.Catch a Fire's sluggishly paced plot refuses to come
Younger viewers might be able to make sense its overly-complex plot - but I fear that everyone else, alas, will soon be suffering from a case of shell shock.
Together, though, [Ferrell and Heder] strike enough sparks to earn a 5.8 for artistic interpretation and a 6.0 for effort.
Another depressing example of a cult 70s slasher being cynically retooled for MTV-reared thrill-seekers.
Leaves you wondering what it wants to say and whom it's supposed to be aimed at.
This wearisome tale of a lonely orphan who travels through time has a wacky exuberance small children will no doubt appreciate. Anyone older, though, will merely find it noisy and obnoxious.

Convincing period detail provides scant consolation in a histrionic pot-boiler that is as entertaining as a sermon and as thrilling as tea with the vicar. It will be a miracle indeed if anyone goes to see it.
Three Eddie Murphys is three too many.
An old-school crowd-pleaser in the best Hollywood tradition, Dreamgirls is only let down by its piecemeal structure and nominal leading lady.
Ben Stiller cameo apart, something's wrong when a proven comedic property and two well-matched stars can scarcely raise a titter.
Things don't really add up in The Number 23, but you can count on some queasy chills and trashy thrills all the same.
It's a game of two halves, and both of them suck in a flat-footed follow-up that doesn't bode well for the inevitable Goal! 3.
If music be the food of love, Music and Lyrics is a recipe for indigestion.
If they'd stopped yammering for just a few minutes, White's heartbreaking ending might have retained its poignancy. As it is, it's little more than a blessed relief.
If you can ignore the script's gaping plotholes this is an acting showcase to savour, with Dame Judi on imperious form.
Besson's labour of love is a feast for the eyes but leaves the imagination distinctly undernourished.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: On its own terms, this is an elegant, stimulating homage to a singular talent. Compared to Capote, though, it can't help but feel wanting.
For all its contrivances, Babel offers a gripping treatise on fate, chance and language with an epic sweep that leaves you marvelling at its ambition.
Given the personal nature of the material, though, it's a shame Weiland resorts to the kind of coarse ethnic caricatures one hoped had died with Mike and Bernie Winters.
A low-key sci-fi that has an offbeat charm all its own.
'My stupidity astounds me!' chortles Danny DeVito in Deck the Halls, a line that pretty much sums up this tale of warring neighbours with very different ideas about celebrating Christmas.

"This thing is screwier than Courtney Love!" whimpers Hilary in her usual chihuahua-on-helium whine. Even she, however, manages to shine next to her aggravating older sister, saddled as she is with all the comic timing of a mortally wounded elephant.

Without the aid of mind-expanding narcotics though, El Topo can't help looking laughably ramshackle, the combination of bad dubbing, shoddy camerawork and over-the-top performances making it pretty much unwatchable by modern standards.
Why pay to see someone cycling when they do it on the pavement for nothing?
Where's Mulder when you need him.
'It's like Lord Of The Flies in here!' cries nerdy teen Spencer (Dyllan Christopher) when he sees the film's quarantined crew, which is as clever as Paul Feig's movie gets.

Though not yet up to Hayao Miyazaki's lofty standards, this sword-and-sorcery yarn at least shows his boy is on the right track. Makes you wonder what he'll do when not strait-jacketed by someones else mythology.
As well as potty humour, this canine Backdraft has its share of adult moments. Mostly, though, it's family fun, with Hutcherson showing he's the go-to kid for sensitive loners.
Welcome emotional gravity.
Waters' trashy sensibility combines with some good old-fashioned Broadway pizzazz to create an irresistible, deliciously subversive entertainment.

Ultimately, though, it's just a load of sound and fury, indifferently played by a Neighbours-lite cast and fatally compromised by graphic violence that makes Roman Polanski's 1971 version seem tame by comparison. Strewth...
Grief, voyeurism and latent necrophilia make a beguiling brew in Hallam Foe, a smart coming-of-age tale from the director of Young Adam.
It's hard to imagine anybody's spine being chilled by a relentlessly average spooker as empty-headed as its wooden villain.
The director fails to breathe any sort of life into a piece practically carbon-dated by its flailing assaults on political correctness.
Unlike the original's many imitators, this follow-up at least tempers its atrocities with satirical humour.

There's no doubt Shrek The Third will make potloads of money. Pity it shortchanges the audience with an underwhelming plot and characters you sense are just going through the motions. When it's good it's great. Overall, though, the magic is lacking.

A paucity of pedal power and an abundance of cliché make this Jock-on-a-bike yarn an uphill climb from false start to weak finish. Miller's brooding hero may well be Flying, but the film never gets off the ground.

Marion Cotillard's majestic, uncannily accurate portrayal is the main reason to see a film that makes heavy going of an exceptional life. For all Dahan's lofty ambitions, you leave wishing he'd chosen a more straightforward way to retell Piaf's story.
No way to make poker cinematic.
A tough slog.
Tailored towards the small-screen.
McGinley, as it happens, is the film's only trump card, his madcap multi-tasker stealing every scene he's in and leaving the movie's nominal star for dead.
As tigers go, it's all growl and no teeth.
Though its arguments are somewhat woolly and its use of dual narrators (David Morrissey, Ashley Jensen) dubious, this remains a powerful call-to-arms against an insidious foe.
Goodbye Bafana should keep you locked in for most of its generous running time.
A strong performance from Fiennes and excellent period detail can't energise a sluggish biographical drama.
It's as dull as the proverbial ditchwater.
A grandstanding performance from Joan Allen is the main attraction in this suburban dramacom.
Entertaining but flawed look behind suburbia's twitching curtains.
Allen's imperious turn and Costner's affable charm go a long way to ensuring you'll look back on Anger with affection.
Cage has yet another bad hair day in a Dick-based actioner that repeatedly breaks its own rules.
Stunning scenery and superior thesping result in a period romance that combines the intimate with the epic.
Cage's paranormal powers enable him to dodge arrest, assassins' bullets and even an avalanche.
Christmas cheer is in short supply in The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause, a feeble festive farce that's more no-no-no than ho-ho-ho.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A ribald, risqué yet surprisingly warm-hearted vehicle for Steve Carell.
Deserves to be hanging in the nearest meat locker.
Undemanding punters are guaranteed 90 minutes of dopey, derivative and gloriously disposable entertainment.
Despite thoroughbred work from Dakota Fanning, by the time the movie hits the final furlong it's only good for the glue factory.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cusack in particular seems to have embellished his role with an assortment of verbal quirks that suggest he wasn't too happy with what was on the page.
Swiftly dissolves into a litany of brutally sadistic acts knotted together by a feeble whodunnit plot.

While originality is hardly the film's strongest suit, its agreeable mix of knowing spoof and kid-pleasing fantasy makes it considerably more engaging than some of the 'straight' superhero blockbusters we've suffered recently.
A well-intentioned but ultimately calamitous attempt to analyse the so-called 'English disease.'
Not good, not bad, just deeply, depressingly average.
A generic duffer that's as exciting as a hole in the ground.
Seems to take pride in being as loud, obnoxious and moronic as humanly possible.
A fun and zesty frolic.
Full of explosive mayhem and pulse-quickening aerial combat, this high-flying action romp offers polished, if derivative entertainment.
... a winning combo that could herald a new lease of life for this surprisingly resilient franchise ...
An enchanting, magical fable with a twisted vein of surrealism that makes you wonder exactly what they're smoking over there in the Land of the Rising Sun.
The only thing Mysterious Skin will do is make yours crawl.
Evokes a bygone age of deliciously divine decadence.
Its script is pure corn, drenched in syrupy sentiment and topped with prize ham in the shape of Billy Bob Thornton's tub-thumping coach.

Through it all Keaton furrows his brow with impressive intensity. But his efforts are hampered by a script which requires him to do the exact opposite of what any right-minded individual would do in his circumstances.
Overall the film is as static as its star's face which -- given the large amount of scantily-clad female flesh on display -- is really quite an achievement.
The film will keep children amused without proving too much of an ordeal for grown-ups.
Radford's gloomy film is a long and slightly draining haul, but the intensity of Al Pacino's central performance justifies the effort required.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A breezy caper that will entertain children without testing their parents' patience.
Over long and deeply manipulative, Coach Carter should nonetheless be praised for its far-from-fashionable celebration of personal advancement through academic achievement.

Ripe with boxing movie clichés and slow to the point of distraction, this melancholy tale of an ageing trainer and the girl pugilist he takes under his wing nonetheless packs a stunning emotional punch.
See Joe Roth's movie and you'll understand the true demeaning of Christmas.
A startling rite-of-passage drama from Polish-born writer-helmer Pawel Pawlikowski.
It's a thin, tedious caper only notable for its impressive Outback locations and a cameo from Christopher Walken that proves the word 'no' isn't in his vocabulary.
It's virtually impossible to root for a protagonist so shamelessly duplicitous.

This macabre follow-up to 2004's low-budget horror smash can't rival its predecessor's fiendish ingenuity. But it makes up for it with a deliciously devious plot and enough gory shocks for a dozen Halloweens.
We Shall Overcome is a well-made, refreshingly unsentimental fable, reminiscent of Dead Poets Society and 2005 Swedish potboiler Evil.
Crammed with moppet mayhem, mawkish sentiment and bruising slapstick, it's a flat-footed retread only Right to Lifers could love.
Alas, no amount of pop-culture in-jokes and cutesy characters can conceal the fact there isn't enough story to sustain a film even of this limited duration.
'This sport is a total joke!' fumes the spunky gymnast heroine of Stick It, a sentiment that will be shared by anyone who wastes their hard-earned on this silly teen comedy.
To his credit Cage plays it with an admirably straight face, even when mugging a woman for her bear costume. But then he must have known from the beginning he was backing a loser.
ick strikes a blow for every independent filmmaker who has ever been forced to comply with its restrictive mandates. Some of his underhand tactics, however, make one pause.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Statham brings his usual hardnut conviction to his ludicrously named protagonist, while the pic contains what is easily the best car chase through a shopping mall scene since The Blues Brothers.
As much a fantasy as Lord of the Rings.
Where it triumphs, though, is in sending a message of hope from a continent too often associated with tragedy and despair.
Just another bug movie.
While it might not bring the house down, there's enough here to suggest this Monster won't be moving out of cinemas any time soon.
Saddled with cheap-looking animation and a far from stellar cast, this Shrek clone is a diverting but hardly memorable addition to a dangerously overworked genre.
[At its best,] Stormbreaker gets the balance right, managing to be both playfully humorous and genuinely exciting.
Not to be catty, but did we need another Garfield movie?
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Stuttering like a busted console, the film's lack of invention is only rivalled by a paucity of gore which will seem positively comical to gamers long since inured to cyberspace slaughter.
Logical progression, intelligent reappraisal, and nostalgia trip all in one, Superman Return is better than we dared hope.
Lin's enjoyably stupid action flick keeps the thrills coming thick and, er, fast.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Lack of a decent plot or memorable characters starts to show around the hour mark.
What's so aggravating here is the grievous lack of wit, imagination and plain old story.
Flabby, dull and overlong, it's a B-grade movie with A-list talent and an inflated idea of its own importance. Think Tsotsi crossed with Clockers with the imagination of neither.
Fast-paced, tense and intermittently exciting, Donner's latest will keep genre fans engaged with its polished blend of tried and tested elements.

Carlos Saldanha's mix of race-against-time action and eco-friendly propaganda is actually an improvement on the original, not least for giving its funniest character -- acorn-hunting rodent Scrat -- a lot more to do.
Bynes tackles her part with gusto, while Tatum underplays his to striking effect.
A flea-bitten farrago which bears only a fleeting resemblance to the 1959 film that inspired it.

Not that [Harrison Ford] deserves our sympathy. The increasingly wrinkly veteran seems determined to age gracelessly, taking roles he's clearly too old for in a desperate attempt to maintain his leading man status.
The dogs take the biscuit in Eight Below, an enthralling fact-based tale of man's best friend struggling to survive a harsh Antarctic winter.
It's really just a ploy for some more flaccid fat-suit antics that are as short of inspiration as Big Momma is of breath.
Preposterous, pretentious and surprisingly dull...
An affectionate portrait of a real-life Kiwi record breaker that took director Roger Donaldson 30 years to bring to the screen.
The combination of everyone's favourite canine and eye-catching Irish and Isle of Man locations ensure this nostalgic shaggy-dog story sends you home with your tail wagging.
A sci-fi spin on 1995's Jumanji, Jon Favreau's fast-paced fantasy is an enthralling, imaginative romp that does everything its predecessor did and more.
It still offers 85 minutes of spirited, satirical amusement.

It may feel a bit like CSI: Riyadh, but The Kingdom earns its keep when it addresses thorny political realities in the Gulf States through the milieu of a culture-clash thriller. Hard to excuse that banzai finale, though.
If the summer holidays find you with hatchlings to entertain and time to kill, this is definitely worth checking out...
It makes you want to climb on screen and give the big, eco-friendly lug a hug.

It takes a special talent to wring so much warm, humane comedy out of such a screwy premise. But the real triumph is how Gondry uses it to champion no-budget indie filmmaking, salute cinema's unifying properties and thumb his nose at the Hollywood system.
Packs enough shocks to keep you gripped, not to mention a conclusion that refreshingly refutes the genre rulebook.
The story rattles along at such a lick there's little time to ponder the plot holes -- no mean feat in a film of this length and with so many fine actors competing for our attention.
For all its delicious moments, though, you can't help feeling there are a couple of ingredients missing from this frustratingly insubstantial confection.
Partnering its ursine heroine's progress with that of a female walrus calf, Adam Ravetch and Sarah Robertson's documentary combines stunning wildlife footage with an environmental message.
A thoroughly derivative, boringly ordinary affair in desperate need of a hockey-masked psycho or razor-gloved ghoul to liven things up.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Hypnotic, poetic and often downright strange, the remarkable result is every bit as combustible as the black stuff itself.
A desperately unfunny farce that doesn't need an audience so much as an exorcist.

Two fine performances, a subject close to all our hearts and a screenplay that manages to be both brilliantly witty and almost unbearably poignant add up to the best family comedy-drama since Little Miss Sunshine.

Where Lions For Lambs stumbled, Haggis' latest succeeds in putting dramatic form to the disquiet over US policy. Tommy Lee Jones' performance, meanwhile, is impressive enough to make him a decent bet in this year's Oscar race.

Election-year pertinence turns to mush in a winsome feel-gooder that wastes no time ramming its wholesome message down our throats. Oh, and did we mention that Kev gets to sing with his band Modern West? What a load of ballots...

"It's a jungle in there!" sighs Hanks as he counts the millions visiting the movie's kill-view website. But for all its scaremongering, Untraceable is best viewed as an above-average thriller with a tech-savvy hook.
Powerful, downbeat drama with an anti-war message.
Saucy sex scenes apart, however, it's hard to get drawn into a slow-moving, drawn-out story that takes two-and-a-half po-faced hours to reach its jarringly abrupt and confusing conclusion.
Isolated moments of high drama and some startlingly intimate sex scenes sadly fail to galvanise a turgid and overlong whole.
A compelling documentary that leaves you wondering if there is nothing sacred in this stinking world.
All those years making wine have clearly impacted on Coppola's storytelling abilities. Let's hope he recovers them before his next directorial outing.
Given the implausible contrivances that link these disparate protagonists, though, it's hard to care much about any of them in a chilly drama whose sleek aesthetic masks a hollow soul.

The kind of movie you feel you've seen before when you're watching it for the first time, Gray's latest never once surprises. But it's intelligent and well-crafted enough to make you prepared to give it the benefit of the doubt.
For the most part this is a perky delight that takes a cheeky glee in biting the gloved hand that feeds.
You leave the cinema not just saddened anew that such an iconic artist was so pointlessly killed, but amazed that it doesn't happen more often.

With McCarthy and Davis also playing two further roles with suspiciously identical initials, The Nines toys with issues of identity, duality and alternate reality certain to appeal to anyone who's experimented with the virtual avatars of Second Life.
For old-school Hollywood movie-making at its most polished, literate and sophisticated there is really nothing to match it.
A little self-consciously kooky but with an ace soundtrack that combines gypsy punksters Gogol Bordello with real-life plug-pullers this sure beats putting your head in the oven.

If the picture doesn't ultimately live up to the raw vitality of Cheadle's performance, it remains an uplifting snapshot that broadcasts its message with zero distortion. Tune in and you won't be turned off.
An all-star cast and Pegg's larger-than-life turn can't stop this offbeat yarn being a bit of a snooze.

For all the sleights of hand its director conjures up, this is an undeniably slight affair. But it's still a sublimely entertaining one from a maverick confident enough in his abilities to make fun of his previous work and his agent provocateur persona.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that manages to be both brilliantly witty and delightfully subversive - not least for reportedly entrusting all its cinematography to a computer.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A retro pastiche that, like The Good German before it, will be of limited interest to all but the most ardent film buff.
A movie that blandly goes where too many Star Trek pictures have gone before.
Cut from the same cringe-inducing cloth as The Office and Napoleon Dynamite, this low-budget comedy about a clueless Tae Kwan Do tutor punches, chops and karate-kicks above its weight.
Banish all memories of the original and you'll find this a slick throwback in the Doomsday mould. Tearing across the screen with all guns blazing, it's disposable, enjoyable trash.
A funny showcase for rising star Danny McBride, if not quite the second comedy coming it's being marketed as.
All in all, not quite as good as it gets.
A moving tale of working-class travails in modern Brazil that puts the carnage of City Of God and its ilk in sharp relief.
This harmless but charmless caper will have everybody except the most undemanding tot fidgeting.

It's not quite da bomb, but this nostalgic throwback to the recent past still has enough phat acting (especially from Sir Ben) and slammin' scenes to seem both fly and fresh. Worth catching? Damn skippy.
After the major triumph of This Is England, Shane scales things back with an unassuming rites-of-passage drama featuring another top turn from Turgoose. Even in miniature, Meadows makes magic.
If you really want to get smart, you'll avoid this tiresome time-waster like the proverbial plague.
A gentle period piece that will look more comfortable on the small screen.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Barry Levinson's career slump continues apace with a wannabe black comedy that's neither dark nor funny.
A classy cast and production design to die for are the only features of note in an underpowered tale of adultery and intrigue in '50s America.
The visuals are eye-popping, the score (by Ennio Morricone) magnificent, the Civil War set-pieces both stunning and haunting. If you're going to end a trilogy, this is the way to do it.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)

movie_review_blurb: A mannered comedy of manners that, in its eagerness to be all things to all people, ends up being nothing much of anything.
Jersey Girl marks a low point for the tubby New Jersey auteur.
Surrender to its exotic oddity and guttural throat-singing and you'll be entertained by a sweeping saga that's like a Mongolian Braveheart.
A powerful, provocative and excellently acted thriller that could literally have been torn from today's headlines.
There's no light at the end of the tunnel in this misguided romp whose solitary redeeming feature is its quality cast.
With every twist of the second-hand plot telegraphed far in advance, you don't need to be clairvoyant to see where this is going.
Ralph Fiennes is no Sexy Beast and writer/director Martin McDonagh is stronger on dialogue than story, but this is still a laugh-out-loud dark comedy, giving Colin Farrell his finest role in ages.

"Are there any square cops out there?" says a supporting character in David Ayer's actioner. The answer, of course, is no - and this violent yarn is all the better for it. Next time out, though, he should probably assign himself a less familiar beat.
In the end, though, there's only so much slack you can give a film that wears its cheapness and ineptitude like badges of honour.
Given the true story that inspired it, 21 really should have been a sure-fire bet. As it is, it's a split hand that only pays off thanks to Fishburne and Spacey. Still beats Lucky You, though.
Viewers who stick with it will be rewarded by an arresting tapestry that is considerably more than the sum of its parts.
Little more than a Disney cash-cow entirely wasted on anyone old enough to smoke, drink or vote.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ridiculously entertaining.
Too often the film crosses the line between recording his subjects' illegal activities and aggrandising them.
No amount of visual flourish, sadly, can compensate for the woeful lack of chemistry between the leads or arch dialogue that sounds more like a Pinter parody than the man himself.
Don't expect too many surprises from this low-key story of a Bangladeshi woman who learns to stand on her own two feet after years of stultifying arranged marriage.

Monica Ali's best-selling debut novel about life in London's Bangladeshi quarter gets a sensitive treatment from director Sarah Gavron, deftly condensing its sprawling narrative without sacrificing colour or texture.
It's Keith Thompson's script that struggles here, his sub-Little Voice histrionics leaving next to nothing for the cast to work with.

A fitting tribute to courage under fire and stoicism in the face of senseless brutality, Winterbottom conjures up a perfect marriage of subject and technique. Good also to see Jolie acting for a change...
Thanks to its sneakily subversive tone (the plot, with heavy irony, involves gun control) and grandstand performances, the flashy result mostly hits the target.
Rather drab, revolving as it does around the boys' twin quests to get adopted and catch an oversized fish. Where's Voldemort when you need him?
Bawdy, demented and gloriously feel-good, Superbad is as super as comedies get.
Fine performances from Glen and Mackintosh elevate this touching tale of friendship, loyalty and broken dreams.

Part costume drama, part war epic, Joe Wright's follow-up to Pride & Prejudice is above all a touching love story with a potent sexual charge. Some viewers may feel cheated by the ending, but fans of the novel won't be disappointed.
A poignant character study with a pleasing mid-Atlantic sensibility, Niall Heery's debut feature is ultimately as inconsequential as one of Glen's clichéd compositions.
Has any screenplay combined so many quotable lines with such tear-jerking pathos or blatant homophobia?
What begins as a straightforward tale of adversity overcome, however, takes some unexpected detours en route to its defiantly non-formulaic ending.
Thanks to bold performances, evocative cinematography and a trippy pop soundtrack, this richly entertaining tale of adolescent angst ends up being one of the most striking Brit flicks of 2007.
Sharply written, neatly performed and frequently hilarious comedy that manages to be warm and witty.
Rarely likeable on screen, Zeta Jones has a hard time making us empathise with her Ramsay-style ballbreaker.
The combined know-how of Jamie Oliver and Gordon Ramsay couldn't salvage the unappetising concoction that is No Reservations.
The writer-director's real talent is in showing that we're all freaks and geeks in one way or another. It's just that some of us are better at hiding it than others...
Slow-burning and sombre, Breach won't be for everyone. But it's worth catching for Cooper's performance, while its fact-based tale of treachery will strike a chord in today's climate of suspicion.

Get past the goofy animated titles and you'll be captivated by a coming-of-age tale with a subversive edge. The hero may be have a few hang-ups, but Jamie Bell's an ideal star for such defiantly off-kilter fare.
Despite a career-best turn from Chris Cooper, however, Breach is a weirdly muted affair.
About as arousing as Ann Widdecombe in a thong.
Rob Roy pursues James Bond in an old-fashioned Western that's cripplingly short on action.

From the seemingly helpless geriatric who gets up to push his own wheelchair to the genial brother who constantly mimics movie stars, however, Taika Cohen's film seems nothing so much as Little Britain Down Under.
The Graduate comes to London in this thoughtful Britcom.
As wooden as a piano stool.
Like the wrinkled buttocks he flashes at Kruger, however, this portrait of the artist could use some tightening up.
The biggest letdown, is Williams, whose manic improvisations now bear all the hallmarks of a pub bore.
ntertainingly presented as a mockumentary a la Best in Show, this CG caper is ideal if you have time to krill.
An embarrassingly flat-footed caper.
Unremarkable take on the Bard's cross-dressing comedy, ostentatiously relocated to 19th-century Japan though wholly shot in the Home Counties.
You sense that inside this meaty, 157-minute opus there's a six-hour mini-series just itching to get out.
It's not just homosexuals who will be outraged by this crass farce.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An old lady takes a long time to die in this po-faced literary effort as a bed-ridden Redgrave looks back to the golden summer when her young self (Danes) found love.
A drippy chick-flick about six Sacramentans who find their lives mirroring the English novelist's fictions.

Scott's best film since Gladiator is a classy cops 'n robbers thriller where the latter outclasses the former. Crowe tries to redress the imbalance with a committed performance, but you can tell he knows it's Washington's movie.
Francois Girard's film proves a cross-cultural yawn, as if taking its cue from Pitt's blank-faced blandness and Keira Knightley's anaemic support.
An unpleasant sex romp of the kind Robin Askwith made in the 1970s.
As dire a cum-com as ever shot its load on a cinema screen.
Full of memorable dialogue and sharp performances, it's let down only by its perfunctory climax.
Sienna Miller as an airhead celeb more famous for her sex life than her movies? Quite a stretch for the British actress.
Take away the Four Weddings and you get this dismal Brit-com.
Oh, brother! Firing blanks in every direction, this tedious vehicle for two hard-to-like comedians is stillborn from the off.
An ingenious heist drama that views its familiar noir elements from an unexpected angle.
An apologetic-looking cast treads gingerly over the resulting wreckage, though only the guy in the coffin emerges with his credibility intact.

A lesser movie compared to its 1998 predecessor, this sequel nonetheless delivers the sort of stirring drama and sweeping spectacle its subject demands. Blanchett, meanwhile, shines brightly enough in the title role to make Elizabeth III a certainty.

Retooling Memento with a hip young cast, Frank's debut feature steeps its familiar elements in graveyard humour and indie cool. Plot quibbles aside, the result both grips and moves; it'll be your lookout if you miss it...

You'll be wishing this weirdly uneven tale came with its own government health warning - if only so you come prepared for an assortment of incongruous musical numbers and performances that couldn't be broader if they tried.
A cut above the usual Bollywood fare, though ultimately too slight to justify its rather exorbitant running time.

Like the Borscht served on Semyon's Trans-Siberian menu, Promises is filling, flavoursome and full of dead meat. Thanks to its compelling story and a powerful performance by Mortensen, it's also as hard to shake off as one of Nikolai's tattoos.
A tender and moving Britflick that's sure to land a couple of Bafta noms next year.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A misogynist tract masquerading as a cheeky sex romp.
Long before its howling bogeyman has savaged his last victim you'll be wondering if the movie has anything else to offer besides self-conscious homage.
Simplistic in the extreme and riddled with clichés, the quality of its execution can't excuse the dubiousness of its premise.
The real triumph is Clooney's, his award-worthy work confirming his status as this generation's most watchable leading man.
A witty, touching and offbeat spin on the coming-of-age genre that also offers an amusing look into the surprisingly cut-throat world of high school debating.
Foster keeps us gripped with a convincing display of steely determination and moral ambiguity.
It's too long, and the ambitious imagery (strawberries turning into bombs?) occasionally misses the mark. But it's a fun ride all the same.
It will be a major injustice if Jolie doesn't receive an Oscar nod for channelling Mariane's heartbreak with such dignity and compassion.
Kenneth Branagh directs this pedestrian spin on the Shakespearean comedy that proves stubbornly resistant to his boisterous brand of all-star panto.
If you're making a film about a stand-up, it helps if she has at least one good gag in her routine.
A supernatural thriller with much to say on the greed and venality that underpins new Europe, Christian Petzold's German drama is spookily intriguing.

Thanks to strong performances and some bracing one-liners, O'Donnell makes a convincing case for equality for disabled people in society, though casting able-bodied actors as his wheelchair-driving protagonists unavoidably weakens his argument.
Pretentious, overlong, and visually unappealing.

While the rambling storyline and extended time-frame betrays the script's novelistic roots, soulful performances from Farrell, Sissy Spacek and newcomer Dallas Roberts make this a rich and emotionally rewarding experience.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Devil's Backbone reverses expectations by telling its doom-laden Gothic narrative in broad daylight and baking sunshine.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
A great send-off for one of Hollywood's unlikeliest double acts.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Hilariously inept showcase.
Though the lackadaisical style becomes tiresome after a while, the film is ultimately held together by star-in- the-making Adebimpe.
If you leave your prejudices at the box office, you may find it rather invigorating -- if a little on the lengthy side.
If you want a giggle and are not too fussy, you could do much worse than surrendering to its shamelessly puerile brand of smutty schoolboy humour.
Amenábar racks up the tension to unbearable levels in a spooky shocker that's worthy of any comparison with M Night Shyamalan's The Sixth Sense.
The result will leave serious cinephiles cold and bore those in search of lurid cheap thrills.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Guaranteed to put a smile on your face and a chanson in your coeur.
The film belongs to Zahn, who turns his two-dimensional slacker character into a truly heartbreaking portrait of disillusion and guilt.
Guédiguian paints a vivid portrait of a city divided between an indolent elite and the disenfranchised poor.
movie_title: The Town Is Quiet (La Ville est tranquille) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A supremely satisfying blend of Hong Kong mayhem and Gallic flair that can only bolster Li's escalating reputation.
The only sin committed here is the cardinal one of boring us to tears.
Quote not available.
A visceral, high-octane, Formula One of a flick that puts the pedal to the metal in the opening minutes and does not take the foot off the accelerator until the end credits.
The Forsaken is positively anaemic.
It's a ripping yarn that recalls such early Hitchcock classics as The Secret Agent and The Man Who Knew Too Much.
A moribund melodrama which starts intriguingly before becoming utterly banal.
Where the film falters is in its tone.
Mick Dundee is not so much a fish out of water these days as terminally behind the times.
A frenetic, scattershot satire on the music biz and the youth's obsession with labels, brand names, and status symbols.
An intermittently hilarious vehicle for British TV star Steve Coogan.
A sequel that is every bit as satisfying as its predecessor.
Bargain basement caper.
movie_title: Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Breillat has fashioned another characteristically raw and honest portrait of sexual relations.
Quote not available.
There's surely something wrong with a comedy where the only belly laughs come from the selection of outtakes tacked onto the end credits.
Full of poetic imagery, dazzling photography and heartfelt performances from a mostly unknown cast.
Doesn't so much need a heart as a brain transplant.
Quote not available.
Real-life strongman Ahola lacks the charisma and ability to carry the film on his admittedly broad shoulders.
The inspired pairing of Channing and Stiles creates real dramatic fireworks.
Reynolds' remake brings nothing new to the table, but it's still an enjoyable throwback to the swashbucklers of old.
Hugely accomplished slice of Hitchcockian suspense.

Though Cantet's clinical direction and the unsettling Jocelyn Pook score make Time Out a rather alienating experience, the lanky Recoing brings a wealth of humanity and pathos to his tragically mediocre hero.
It's not particularly bad, just deeply, painfully average.
Goes some way towards explaining how the tragedy occurred and its enduring legacy today.
It's Uli Hanisch's prison design that emerges as the film's real star, its antiseptic confines subtly heightening the prevailing mood of desperation and malevolence.
Delivers more than its fair share of saucy hilarity.
Substitutes the original's goofy camp for an orgy of gore, noise and mindless mayhem.
As frothily entertaining as this caper is, it's unlikely to prove as popular with grown-ups as Shrek and the Toy Story movies.
Ingenious thriller, which draws on urban legend to fashion a spooky supernatural yarn in the best traditions of The X-Files.
Jensen paints a vivid portrait of quirky eccentricity and uncommon dedication to a seemingly irrelevant pursuit.
A hugely creative, fast-paced romp that will keep both children and their parents thoroughly entertained.
Intense, superbly acted chamber piece.
Five stars don't do it justice.
Hilarious in parts, sickeningly sentimental in others, Shallow Hal has the Farrellys trying to expand their range, with only mildly successful results.
There's plenty of rip-roaring action to distract us from the more unpalatable elements.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984)

movie_review_blurb: A brilliant coup sees the film kick off with an extended flashback to Indiana's early days and our young hero (Phoenix) having his first taste of adventure during a scout trip in Utah.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Brian Tufano's handsome widescreen photography and Paul Grabowsky's excellent music turn this fairly parochial melodrama into something really rather special.
Quote not available.
Dench and Winslet inhabit the role of Iris with such intensity it's hard to take your eyes off them.
The result is inaccessible, pretentious, and infuriating, yet you can't deny it's the work of a master who was not afraid to twist form and structure to suit his highly critical political message.
movie_title: 2 ou 3 Choses que je Sais d'Elle (Two or Three Things I Know About Her) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.

Murphy himself is rather dull in the straight man role, and the jokes are pretty coarse for a family film. But it's certainly better than the lacklustre sequel, which finds Eddie playing second fiddle to a performing bear.
A cheap and forgettable romp which is unlikely to trouble filmgoers for long before finding a more suitable home down your local video store.

You'll need an awful lot of Christmas cheer to forgive Arnold Schwarzenegger for his fourth, and hopefully last, venture into comedy, a turkey that needs stuffing on the most inaccessible shelf of your local video store.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The fresh-faced cast of newcomers and edgy, restless camerawork make up for the script's inherent predictability.
Quote not available.
Altman's black comedy perfectly expressed the anarchic, rebellious spirit of the 1970s with its blistering anti-war message and contempt for authority.
The only sequel to win an Oscar for best picture.
It's Hugh Grant, cleverly cast against type as a scheming love rat, who steals the laurels.
Quote not available.
We get nauseating homilies on the values of friendship, family, and parenting and a soundtrack full to bursting with vacuous pop acts.
While Born Romantic won't win any prizes for originality, it's still a charming diversion.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Writer Jimmy McGovern avoids easy sentiment by investing his story with an almost documentary-style veracity.
Quote not available.
A highly personal, rigorous, and thoughtful analysis of a truly troubled genius.
Leiner's lame-brained travesty shoots for wacky but instead ends up being intensely irritating.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Lucifer has been poorly served by Hollywood's current penchant for Satanic shenanigans.
A five star hoot.
It's Rodriguez who gives the drama its punch.
Quote not available.
Once you succumb to the picture's gentle rhythm and quirky sense of humour, you're sure to find it beguiling, intriguing and over too soon.
Full of dreadful turns and awful dialogue ("There's been a breach in my most secure area!" mutters Al at one point), 88 Minutes is 107 too long.
Annaud is all at sea, scuppered by a directionless and tension-free script and wooden performances from his British leads.
The build up is terrific, with enormous spaceships emerging from the clouds to hover silently over the world's major cities.
Writer-director PJ Hogan has some unexpected twists in store before his quirky farce reaches its uplifting conclusion.
Take away the CGI mayhem and what emerges is a rather touching tale of second chances and innocence prematurely lost.
Simply too inane to be anything more than a formulaic Hollywood blockbuster.
Compared to some of this summer's blockbusters ... this is better than average.
If not exactly enjoyable, then at least halfway tolerable.
A thrilling espionage adventure chock full of iconic characters, set pieces and one-liners.
Worth catching for Griffiths' warm and winning central performance.
A preposterous drama that falls well short of the Hollywood thrillers it slavishly emulates.
An enjoyable caper that might be a little too intense for kids.
A feast for the senses.
A lacklustre start to what is nonetheless sure to be an extremely lucrative franchise.
Nauseating amount of glucose sentiment.
Few old TV shows have been brought to the big screen with such élan as Brian De Palma's majestic adaptation of the 60s small screen classic The Untouchables.
Quote not available.
While the shocks come thick and fast, the real pleasure comes from the knowing humour and ingenious spoofing of genre tropes.
For sheer eye-popping spectacle, makes Titanic look like a kiddies' bath toy.
A minor British classic and a valuable record of the hedonistic Swinging 60s.
Basically an Antipodean reprise of When Harry Met Sally that sets its sights too low to be anything more than a pleasant diversion.
Freeman always gives good value and the result is never less than watchable.
Anderson dominates proceedings as DMX's loud-mouthed accomplice.
It's impossible not to succumb to its lush romanticism and irresistible fusion of contrasting musical styles.
Coppola's masterpiece reveals something new every time you watch it.
Filled with twists, stunts, and witty banter, Romancing the Stone is a breathlessly enjoyable action comedy.
Quote not available.
Goodfellas is a tour de force that brilliantly evokes both the seductive glamour and moral degradation of organised crime.
A masterly distillation of Tinseltown foibles which also works as a compelling moral thriller and a commentary on the cult of celebrity.
Anyone with memories of The Godfather and its 1974 sequel will shudder at how Coppola reduces their powerful iconography to the level of a daytime soap.
A savagely entertaining neo-film noir.
17-year-old Kate Winslet made her film debut in this compelling blend of true crime and dark fantasy...
Quote not available.
While this gentle and affecting melodrama will have luvvies in raptures, it's far too slight and introspective to appeal to anything wider than a niche audience.
Quote not available.
Though Tom Shadyac's film kicks off spookily enough, around the halfway mark it takes an abrupt turn into glucose sentimentality and laughable contrivance.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A sparkling blend of sci-fi and comedy that affectionately spoofs every Star Trek cliché known to man, Romulan, or Klingon.
Quote not available.
It's a bracingly subversive story told with tongue firmly in cheek.
All about the music, and you'd have to be truly tone-deaf not to respond to its soaring harmonies and spirited spirituality.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
For once the 3-D is more than just a gimmick, transporting the audience to a Borneo rainforest so lush and verdant you can almost feel the sunlight on your eyelids.
A fantasy fable that should keep everyone in the family entertained.
Veers erratically between sugar-coated romance, broad farce, and risible melodrama.

movie_review_blurb: Awash with silliness - gun-toting chickens, performing Dachshunds, Jim Broadbent in charlady drag - yet weirdly bereft of mirth ...
Ignore the chit-chat ... and the CG critters wow.
Surrender to its rhythms and you'll find poetry in its anthropological austerity.
An instant classic and a massive hit, it emboldened Michael Eisner's outfit to go further, weirder, darker.

As Aretha might say, respect.
A solid outing for a re-Bourne hero that could, with a few key tweaks, generate another round of vehicles for the Clancy cash cow.
Marvel's man with the mallet does all that's required of him in a breakneck sequel that's never dark for long.
Green fashions a slow-burn charmer that's a million miles from Pineapple Express in tone, pace and content. But just like that film, the odd couple interplay is beautifully judged.

Squeezing every drop of tension from wet-ink recent history, Phillips only falters when making its protagonists mouthpieces in a broader geopolitical debate. Otherwise, it's full steam ahead to the Oscars.
Fun when Jones is around, dull when he's not, it's all just a little bit of history repeating.
Twists pile as high as corpses before an overcooked ending sends things spiraling into silliness.
