movie_review_blurb: Makes for [an] entertaining watch before succumbing to the same bombastic overkill.
Washington and Wahlberg are an effective double act in an intermittently exciting thriller with more twists than it needs.
Divine inspiration's in short supply in the sophomore outing for the teenage demigod, here afflicted with a crisis of confidence Thor Freudenthal's so-so sequel seems to share.
What really raises the hackles are its tatty attempts to update the character to a modern New York filled with mobile phones, surveillance cameras and robot cops.
It's the same sappy drivel as before ...
Though it doesn't have the vibrant wit and zip of an Avengers Assemble, or the allegorical grandeur of a Dark Knight, it's a step up from the garbled silliness of Wolverine's first solo outing.
Can't decide if it's a broad farce or a poignant portrait.
Potts does the singing himself, but that doesn't stop Justin Zackham's contrived script from sounding bum notes throughout.
Shana Feste's bland and timid remake will be lucky to be remembered beyond this paragraph.
There's more than enough to keep you entertained and diverted.
John Jencks' drama boasts some nice Cornish scenery, but it's not enough to offset the clunky dialogue, overwrought performances and Richards' inability to convince us she's a violin-playing prodigy.
Adapting her own savagely funny play Posh, Laura Wade betters it by adding an additional female presence (Holliday Grainger) who sees these Bullingdon bullies at their worst.
A feel-good charmer with an important message, Pride will have you clutching your sides, wiping your eyes and punching the air in triumph. Could this be this decade's Full Monty?
Tuneful flashbacks supply fantastical punctuation to a film that sees Chomet pay elaborate homage to everyone from Jacques Demy to Marcel Proust.
The twists lean towards the glib, but any time in Leonard's world is rarely time wasted - especially now he's no longer around to share it with us.
A moving documentary ...
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The only thing missing is a sequel.
As its title suggests, this is pretty much the last throw of the dice for a dance saga that more ran out of juice a couple of sequels ago. The set-pieces, though, still deliver the requisite pizzazz.

Slattery's flick depicts its close-knit, blue-collar community with economy and insight.
Makes as little of its furry leads as it does of its '50s setting.
It's a bold take on a swords and sandals staple, yet it's one that pays unexpected dividends.
Writer/director James DeMonaco appears to have developed some delusions of grandeur since the first film hit paydirt.
A flick that has about as much use for his former co-star, trainer Ashleigh Butler, as it does for originality, wit or subtlety.
High camp and low trash make an entertaining combo in an overdue homage to a fearless trailblazer.
Sadly, this Goddess falls a long way short of divine.

Bigger, braver and even more visually rewarding than the original, it's an ambitious attempt to extend the scope of its predecessor without sacrificing the charm, humour and excitement that made that so appealing.
A film that might not always make sense, but is never dull.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Though friendly and humorous in his jaunty nautical cap, Steadman seems reluctant to give much away about his private life. Fortunately his work - scabrous, anarchic and utterly merciless - more than speaks for itself.

movie_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, alas, it's the viewer who will leave feeling conned.

Steph Green's thoughtful debut feature builds on the success of her Oscar-nommed 2007 short New Boy, largely by retaining its eloquent empathy for the outsider.
More glum than gripping.
Having trashed one icon in The Legend Of Hercules, Kellan Lutz shafts another with vocals admittedly well-suited to the muscle-bound mannequin.
Mohawked rich kid Chunks (Sean Teale) is alone in leaving an impression, though only by being the most obnoxious one.
A serious subject receives a simplistic treatment in an ill-conceived thriller in which the emotive (and timely) issue of honour killings becomes just another plot device.
Our host's lilting voiceover remains an acquired taste, but his boundless passion is never in question.
movie_title: A Story Of Children And Film (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A joyous portrait of an unformed personality that should strike chords of recognition in all who watch it.
If two and a half hours in the company of quarrelsome, self-absorbed New Yorkers don't sound too punishing, there's much to like.
A film of lazy days, sleepless nights and mellow moments that will likely test the patience of those unwilling to resign to its unhurried pace.
James DeMonaco's blood-splattered thriller begins well before expiring slowly from multiple improbabilities.
[A] sparkling cartoon ...
Hoffman's film couldn't offend if it tried. Age, however, has yet to wither its veterans' undimmed star appeal.
Will send the devoted home happy and likely demonstrate to the few uninitiated what all the fuss is about.
Bleak as it is, its rigour proves darkly compelling.
A film stocked with more atmosphere than action.

Visually spectacular montages of ice floes receding that will make you gasp and move you to tears.

movie_review_blurb: There are plenty of laughs and a host of memorable songs crooned by everyone from Miss Piggy to Statler and Waldorf.

Unforgettable.
Forceful and arresting, Ayer's follow-up to Harsh Times and Street Kings sees him confidently playing to his strengths.

Untold? Hardly. Yet as Skyfall appetisers go, this thorough survey of how Ian Fleming, Cubby Broccoli and Harry Saltzman created a phenomenon could barely be bettered.
It's left to the leads to keep us engaged, a tall order given their film's old-fashioned, fusty feel.
Shoot-outs, lovers on the lam, a villain with dreadlocks: yes, this hit-and miss comedy sure does want to be True Romance.
Its talented lead is reduced to being just another scantily clad babe getting stalked by a psycho.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The boulder has never looked bigger, the guns have never sounded louder and Indy's whip has never cracked sharper than they do here.
Taken was no masterpiece and was often thoroughly objectionable. But it still had a drive and a sense of urgency that's absent here ...

Rather than involve us in the story Wright's grandiose concept keeps it at arm's length, forever highlighting the smoke, mirrors and meticulous stage management that have been pressed into service to make his big idea a reality.
More lukewarm haggis than piping-hot broth, Pixar's 13th feature might fall short, but is still head and hair-covered shoulders above most of its CG competitors.
The attention it calls for pays off down the line thanks to riveting performances and tense, water-tight plotting.
[A] highly likeable buddy movie.
movie_title: The Brooklyn Brothers Beat The Best (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [An] airless saga of university toffs building themselves up to run for God and country at the 1924 Summer Olympics in Paris...
The slick production values impress and Barbara Carrera and Klaus Maria Brandauer are good value villains, but Irvin Kershner appears to have nodded off in the director's chair.

Eran Riklis' road movie - its title means 'olive' - neatly juxtaposes the beauty of the landscape with the enmities it engenders, locating an optimism in the central relationship that subsequent history ... would cruelly dash.

Breathlessly tense, thrillingly orchestrated and intellectually complex, this damn fine piece of rigorous, meticulous filmmaking enhances Kathryn Bigelow's status as one of her generation's most accomplished directors.
"We have to find a product that's appealing to people!" says Garcia Bernal at one point. And that's just what Larraín's created with this Latin spin on Mad Men.
Mike Leigh in miniature, without the caricature.

The emphasis placed on indoctrination, enslavement and superior alien intelligence brings the film troublingly close to subliminal propaganda, while the script is so banal you'd have to be brainwashed to enjoy it.
Wedding isn't telling a story so much as selling a lifestyle - one that, rather like Heigl's morning sickness, makes you want to vomit.
A stylish and moody mood piece infused with an intriguing feminist slant.
Some day, God willing, there will be a moratorium on films about plucky kids putting on talent shows to save their schools/parks/yoof centres from predatory developers.
Had Merchant Ivory ever gone Down Under, they'd probably have fashioned something in the vein of this mannered chamber piece.
A laughter vacuum whose race to parody the likes of Mama and the new Evil Dead remake didn't stretch to writing actual jokes.
It's a frothy affair ... albeit one that still manges to be rueful and sombre when occasion demands.
Sex, suspicion and unmanned drones make for an intriguing mix ...
The leads make sweet music in an affecting four-piece that, if not note perfect, plays well to their individual strengths.
Peter Ho-Sun Chan's frenetic, high-kicking thriller runs a full 20 minutes shorter than it did at Cannes in 2011 and feels all the better for it.
The doltish, messy and frequently incoherent result bears all the hallmarks of a botched and compromised endeavour.
An insightful portrait of the Austrian auteur that combines footage of him piecing together scenes from Amour, The White Ribbon and Code Unknown with typically brusque interviews.

Chances are that a younger audience with little knowledge of the '39 The Wizard Of Oz will find much to captivate them - and if it makes them curious enough to check out the original (or the books), then that can only be for the good.
There's enough artistry on display here to leave even the uninitiated grudgingly impressed.
The result believably charts a girl's coming of age but is eventually capsized by lurid melodrama even Brookside would have found excessive.
Turtley average.
Gere's charm offsets his character's amorality in what's both slick entertainment and cautionary fable.
Whether you return to Casablanca for a nostalgia fix, a guilty pleasure or for the waters, you can be certain there'll be something you didn't notice last time out.
Despite its technical assurance and some strong performances, this is a film that favours spectacular landscapes over emotional depth.
Starting off in one place and ending somewhere else entirely, Soderbergh's sleek mystery takes pot-shots at Big Pharma while still delivering a polished genre product that's rarely hard to swallow.
Good Day in a nutshell? Father-son bonding with heavy artillery, a lot of big bangs, a triple-figure body count and little else.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Only comes to life during a Texan steak-eating contest that has Babs ingest a mountain of meat.
No amount of fiscal ingenuity can excuse the wooden acting and crummy dialogue in what is a feeble offering.
Doesn't even count as a missed opportunity.
[A] glacially paced indie from Treeless Mountain director So Yong Kim, a Sundance special whose muted emotions take a while to access.
Craig Viveiros' witty, grisly Brit flick about a weary assassin reluctantly mentoring a cocky upstart.
For all its mealymouthed dialogue and often comical solemnity After Earth at least delivers consistently diverting entertainment ...
Marcel Carné's masterpiece of French poetic realism ...
Lovingly assembled ...
If it was indeed Niall Heery's aim to transplant The Royal Tenenbaums to suburban Dublin, he's done an OK job - Nesbitt's even wearing Ben Stiller's tracksuit.
A relentlessly taut thriller, a cautionary tale on the folly of starting wars you can't finish.
This tale of two sisters trapped in a shark cage on the ocean floor serves up some undeniably tense moments ...
Has star power (Brendan Gleeson and Emma Thompson), and some handsome visuals, but is otherwise too solemn to keep us invested in its heroes' mission or fate.
Diane Keaton and Brendan Gleeson are an odd couple in this genteel charmer about a widow who champions a man facing eviction from his Hampstead Heath shack.
The animation earns brownie points for its digital recreation of 1880s Paree. The rest, alas, is pretty pointe-less.
A war movie about indecision? Not the greatest hook. Yet Cox's sturdy performance makes it worth your time.

Jim Sheridan's first Irish movie since The Boxer has trouble unpicking its mysteries, opting for a romantic soap that sees Rooney Mara's heroine face ostracism after falling for Jack Reynor's RAF pilot in '40s Sligo.
Chastain stalks the corridors of power with steely aplomb in Madden's coolly compelling incursion into House of Cards territory.
A bemusing crossbreed of sentimentality, Buddhist philosophy and poo jokes.
Irish politics made accessible with the help of a playful script, two fine performances and 11 years of hindsight.
A rib-tickling homage to the gumshoe shows of yesteryear, with an endearingly daffy mindset.
Madame Bovary meets Thérèse Raquin with a splash of Lady Chatterley in a pared-down drama that packs a real punch.
Hawkins shines in a touching biopic that will make you laugh, cry and Google its subject afterwards.

Sabine Krayenbühl and Zeva Oelbaum's elegant mix of voiceover, archive footage and talking heads lets "the female Lawrence of Arabia" largely speak for herself, illuminating the pivotal role she played in shaping today's Middle East.
Larraín gives equal screen time to the detective on his trail (Gael García Bernal): a Clouseau-esque bumbler whose determination not to be a footnote lends tragi-comic heft.
Øvredal ruthlessly ratchets the tension - with no little assistance from Olwen Kelly, conveying menace without moving a muscle.
A senseless outrage is handled with sensitivity in a stirring film that doesn't need an A-list hero.
Its war-is-hell platitudes are as unconvincing as the Destiny's Child lookalikes its protagonists find themselves supporting.
Denzel Washington and Viola Davis excel in a well-crafted drama that's sure to bring the late August Wilson's words to a much wider audience.
An entertaining, if frenetic, vehicle for Arnett's Bale-inspired Bats that packs plenty of laughs.
Maitland's harrowing doc offers a minute by-minute chronicle of how the day unfolded.
McConaughey's sweat-stained swagger of a performance in Stephen Gaghan's comeback ensures Gold rocks.
T2 Trainspotting won't leave you floating on air. But it will leave you with a smile on your face, a tear in your eye, and a trickle of its predecessor's old adrenaline coursing through your veins.
Entertaining but ultimately disposable.
This is a Shyamalan movie through and through. And it's his best in some time, thanks to a magnetic McAvoy.
Portman's Oscar-worthy work crowns an unconventional study of an icon, while Mica Levi's score is sublime.
A classy ensemble (Charlotte Rampling, Harriet Walter) supports Jim Broadbent's amusingly tetchy lead, while youthful flashbacks evoke a mood of romantic yearning.
Two characters, who you won't like, insulting each other for two hours. Give it a miss and rewatch Midnight Run instead.

The 'city symphony' genre that flourished in the '20s is made over in a monochrome montage from director-editor Alex Barrett, offering a view of London life spanning the city's architecture, wildlife, religions and nightspots.
A tedious sermon that's preaching to the converted.
Strong performances across the board elevate a small-scale tale that's easy to admire but hard to get excited about.
A moving doc about the things we remember and those we choose to forget.
Has much to say on America's racial melting pot that feels pertinent.
The story is predictable, but Simmons' tighty whities and Delpy's fish impressions compensate.
The shadow of subsequent events looms oppressively large, but Greg Barker's film still speaks eloquently for diplomacy and selfless public service.
A solid if far-fetched thriller that still entertains, even as it goes off the rails. Terrible title, mind.
We've seen Stiller do 'exasperated malcontent' before, but this remains a perceptive portrait of fortysomething angst.
Waugh's film conveys the kill-or-be-killed rationalism that inexorably draws Coster-Waldau's 'Money' towards a life of violent crime.
One of this sequel-slash-reboot's key deficiencies: the lack of any significant connective tissue with its forerunner.
An outlandish high concept is a recipe for hope and humour in a film that bears viewing more than once.
Humbug? You said it, Ebenezer.

The life and work of British primatologist Jane Goodall would make a fascinating subject for a documentary even without the reams of previously unseen footage of her interacting with chimps in Tanzania that director Brett Morgen had at his disposal.
The odd chuckle of recognition helps paper over technical deficiencies.
An '80s classic full of still-thrilling action, quotable one-liners ("Get to the chopper!" "Stick around!") and sly digs at Uncle Sam's penchant for unwinnable jungle wars.
Backdraft clichés notwithstanding, this is a stirring fact-based tribute to public servants putting it on the line.
State-of-the-art effects combine with playful, generous storytelling in a feelgood sequel only marmalade haters could resist.
A western as inept as it is preposterous.
It manages to be both tongue-in-cheek and achingly sincere.
Some of the FX haven't aged well, and nine more Hellraiser movies flayed the franchise, but this is a key '80s horror.

Despite some appealing lensing and an edgier tone than a lot of Christian dramas (nudity, swearing, and in one memorable moment, self-cannibalism), this is a movie with zero subtext and even less subtlety.
Enjoyably acted by a fine ensemble cast, it crisply skewers the hypocrisies of its left-liberal, middle-class characters.
Entertaining, engrossing and at times genuinely unnerving, Bruckner's bad trip is one for horror fans to relish.
Despite dialogue and accent issues, this is a breathtaking homage to van Gogh. There has never been a film like it.
Tots will enjoy, but there's no denying the pieces don't quite click together. Best giant moggy since The Goodies, mind.
Writer-director Justin Edgar establishes a bleak mood from the off, while the Tom Hardy-like Frederick Schmidt brings a brooding purposefulness to his role as the redemption-seeking Marley.
Well worth a watch.
It combines an astute character study with some of the most jaw-dropping images captured on film.
As potty as its premise and as endearing as its leads.
A watery diversion in the Brazilian rainforest apart, this noisy, repetitive, nonsensical franchise-extender is a turtle waste of time.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Joe Stephenson's adap of Freddie Machin's play offers a brief respite from miserabilism in the appealing friendship that develops between Richard and new arrival Annabell (Yasmin Paige).
An intriguing story told in generic fashion, Infinity gets good value from irons and a dignified swansong from the late Richard Johnson.
After too many live-action turkeys, it's a pleasure to have the Gauls back in 'toon form, as one of their more satirical stories is recreated with its waspishness intact.
movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (Astérix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The stories heard in Steve Hoover's film are as harrowing as the track marks on their arms. For all his noble intentions, though, 'Crocodile' Gennadiy sure loves the limelight, forcing us to speculate whether he works for God's glory or his own.
There's an undeniable charm here that, allied with the picturesque locations, results in a nostalgic throwback to a gentler age.
Julia Hart's script has perceptive things to say about race relations and women's role in wartime.
Rather more plodding than a story involving an invisible fire-breathing wyvern really should be, all things considered.
The result is an always diverting, never dull fantasy that rarely stays still long enough for the viewer to pick holes.
Lucys football remains unkicked in a charming pic that gives you everything you expect in glossy new packaging.
No instant Disney classic, but a fast and furry-ious caper with endless gags, a fizzy fox-bunny double act and Shakira as a singing gazelle.
Bloodthirsty, derivative and xenophobic nonsense.
For all its shock tactics, some involving animals, Grimsby is a so-so addition to the Cohen canon whose daring doesn't extend to writing its female characters a single funny line.
No lurid exploitationer but a thoughtful, at times poetic meditation on how one endures and makes bearable a nightmarish dilemma.
Though the women could be stronger and the accents occasionally jar, cooper's study of moral corruption enthrals.
A Despicable Me spin-off so busy, witty and all-round entertaining you won't have time to pine for the absent Steve Carell.
Missteps apart, however, Monster remains a compelling dissection of a diseased young mind.
It doesn't exactly soar and the lack of levity grates, yet the Spooks movie still delivers some appealingly old-school mayhem ...
Ambitiously staged and impressively shot, Monsters: Dark Continent makes a bold stab at mounting a franchise but lacks the vision and surprise of its predecessor.
This is not, we'd wager, the film its director intended. Yet it's worth watching ...
Kids should be royally entertained, provided they're not inspired to recreate the film's running gag of having its fresh-faced heroes electrocute themselves with a portable car battery.

Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh create their own sizzle as Rhett Butler and Scarlett O'Hara in a lavish four-hour epic that juxtaposes scenes of jaw-dropping majesty with moments of elegant intimacy and playful verbal jousting.

Dujardin replicates the polished urbanity of Douglas Fairbanks, while his Argentine-born co-star is so puckishly charming that, had she been born 100 years ago, she would have given Clara Bow a run for her money.
Cooper's performance grounds a solid, authentic drama - Eastwood's best since Letters From Iwo Jima - that is less about one single field of combat than the price of war itself.
Liam Neeson cuts a rather sorry figure in what's less a final flourish for the series than a prolonged death rattle.
"We're making a terrible mistake!" somebody yells during this sequel's '30s prologue. What follows proves that dire prediction to be unfounded.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Arthur is at its best during a world tour that takes McAvoy, his granddad and their sleigh from Toronto to the Serengeti. But often it seems familiar.
Rarely has watching paint dry been so fascinating.
Handsome production values notwithstanding, Bier's drama is all bark and largely trite.
Admirable intentions are no substitute for a compelling storyline.
A road movie with heart, humour and a lead prepared to give his youthful co-stars their share of the limelight.
Part Of Me deserves kudos for allowing an element of unpredictability to intrude upon its tween exploitation and sugary vulgarity.

In the hands of directors Robert Cannan and Ross Adam, though, this bizarre footnote in the annals of international cinema exerts a queasy fascination -- as does the sound of a megalomaniacally ranting Kim.
This attempt to expose Scientology's secrets - primarily through the recreation of some of its alleged infractions - comes across as flippant.
Sammy Fain's hummable tunes and Paul Francis Webster's lyrics merit full-throated accompaniment.
A David-Goliath battle that keeps us invested, for all the film's circuitous longueurs and a score that seeks to steer our emotions rather than stir them.
This visceral, harrowing distillation of Wares seven years on the front line may not break any new ground. But it certainly brings that chaos to life ...
This is ultimately a by-the-numbers issue pic stubbornly televisual in style and scope.
Kids unentranced by such touchy-feely moonshine at least have a playful gekko to tickle them. Adults, though, will be longing for a sea of tranquillity.
It does spend an awfully long time idling in the sidings.
Riggen charts the cave-in and ensuing rescue efforts to stirring if conventional effect, abetted by one of the late James Horner's final scores.

Watching his campaign derailed by yet more salacious revelations is like a slo-mo car crash, a queasy pleasure we're spared little of thanks to Josh Kriegman and Elyse Steinberg's ever-present camera and Weiner's insatiable thirst for the spotlight.
For all its attempts to expand the original's ensemble and embellish its themes, Dory is cod in batter beside Nemo's smoked salmon. But still tasty.

Despite flaws -- plotting and characterisation are template; skater Jonas Hoff Oftebro is insufferable -- it's easy to see how this might have scored Norwegian director Uthaug's next gig: the Tomb Raider reboot with Alicia Vikander.
The portrait that emerges is that of a mercurial talent who would not be pinned down, even by a film as adulatory as this one.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sibling co-directors Alex and Benjamin Brewer have fun establishing their Ocean's Eleven-esque scenario, one that gives Cage plenty of room to lend comedic and sinister shadings to his unlikely criminal.
Cranston shines in a fact-based yarn that treads well-worn ground with enough panache to excuse the déjà vu.
By the end, [Marguerite will] have you crying like Pagliacci.
Transformers-lite for Finding Dory fans who can't wait to drive.
A-list sad-faces abound in a film where absurd concept is rivalled only by banal execution.

Co-directors Nick Read and Mark Franchetti present a compelling if ultimately somewhat dispiriting study of the sacrifices required to be part of this world-famous institution and the competitiveness that underpins its artistic supremacy.
This follow-up to direct-to-video title The Rise Of The Krays revels sickeningly in the East End siblings brutality and treats their various slayings and beatings like a veritable greatest hits.
The clips are a delight, as are the cameos from two of Aladdin's voice actors. Best of all, though, is the mini-animation fashioned out of Suskind's Walt-inspired scribblings.
Craig brings a spiky wit and a warm-hearted, nerd-friendly finale to a comedy that wants for nothing but a little substance.
Benjamin Ree's pic has the suspense of a sports story as it shows this diffident newcomer dispensing with opponents.
Charting 30 years of Napoleon's life over five-and-a-half hours, Abel Gance's 1927 silent epic demands serious commitment.

[It's] more about the ebbs and flows of friendship than it is about the walk. And when the friends in question are a brace of ageing Hollywood heavyweights brimming with charisma, its no hardship to share time in their company.
Singleton was only 23 when he made this urgent state-of-the-nation drama. But his skill with the camera, handling of actors, and raw dialogue suggests a seasoned pro.
A free-wheeling road movie ...
[An] amateurish Brit-flick.
Having already taken two rides on the Dan Brown merry-go-round, shouldn't this have been the one where Ron finally got it right?

The 2010 BP oil disaster receives stirring, pyrotechnic if somewhat un-nuanced treatment in Peter Berg's latest, which replays one of the worst environmental catastrophes of recent years as a straightforward salute to courage under fire.
The best movie about dudes disrobing since Brokeback Mountain.
[An] overwrought period drama, which doesn't want for notable names but does cry out for a script rejig.
Its simplicity is both effective and deceptive-a testament to the script's intelligence and to the actors' beguiling (if slightly histrionic) performances.
A complex, compelling brew, enhanced throughout by Egoyan's hypnotic style. Sadly, it's also weirdly remote and agonisingly slow.
A sudsy remake that soft-soaps its tougher inspiration. The A-list stars go for it, but are 10 years off doing the story justice.

Witty, pertinent and moving, this is a sophisticated treat from a director who gets exponentially better with every picture. But it's Clooney that makes it soar with his most accomplished acting to date. Think of this as his Jerry Maguire.
Denzel's latest is a sluggish affair weighed down by its lofty themes. It also comes with a preposterous twist and a paying-the-rent performance from Oldman that's pure cured ham.
Serkis shines in a warts-and-all take on a figure who'd relish its anarchic stance. Some may find its approach wearing, however, and prior awareness of the music is pretty much a pre-requisite.

Surprisingly believable as a preening hotshot - who'd have thought it? - Ashton Kutcher is ultimately undone by a disappointingly moralistic script that can't quite allow his easy-cum, easy-go hedonist to go unpunished.
One bland, listless slog.
A film that flails about wildly in search of at least one half-decent joke. Tragically, the closest it gets is having a dog hump Colin Firth's leg.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So-so scoring and the sense you're watching filmed theatre rather than a movie proper. But whether or not you care about Day-Lewis' tortured auteur, it's another magnetic performance, backed by displays of motion and emotion from a bevy of icons.

Die-hard horror fans may find this a little on the tame side, while Pucci's survival rules have a lot in common with Jesse Eisenberg's in Zombieland. But it's still a well-crafted gripper, with a nice line in gallows humour.
You go in expecting a jaunty caper. What you get, disconcertingly, is a bleak, rather sad study of an unraveling mind.

Had Emmerich whittled down his overstocked cast and downsized the soap opera, this really would have been a case of Apocalypse Wow. If you've an appetite for destruction, though, it'll still send you home with a smile on your face.

Gibson proves he's still not to be messed with in a film that reasserts him as a sturdy, if rather grizzled leading man. A pity, though, this required Campbell to cookie-cut his masterly '80s TV series into a formulaic actioner.

The hero might be Brown, but Harry is black and white in its treatment of inner-city blight. When all the bullets are spent you're left with the dubious aftertaste of exploitation, but Sir Michael's charisma keeps you watching.

It sounds like a creepy tale of a teenage schoolgirl seduced by a pervert. But it's also one of this year's most captivating British dramas, with a breakthrough turn from an actress we'll be seeing a lot more of.

A concert doc without the concert, this airbrushed vision of Jackson's final months doesn't really tally with the tragic reality. Still, it's hard to take your eyes off the King of Pop as he struts his stuff one last time.
A beautifully understated story of an unconventional friendship.

A coming-of-old-age story that breaks the heart, tickles the funny bone and fires the imagination, Up is a captivating, exuberant delight. And did we mention it contains The Greatest Moment In Movie Animation? Oh.
An entertaining sequel with a political subtext that doesn't get in the way of the wall-to-wall action.
There's no denying 3D adds extra texture to Pixar's seminal 1995 buddy movie, emphasising Buzz and Woody's toy's-eye- view of the world.
This worthy, timely portrait will no doubt figure prominently in next year's awards season. Would that it had more of the revolutionary daring of Darwin's writings.
Lesley Manning's film never shakes off its theatrical roots but still manages to be sharp, funny and engrossing.

The simple plot is as overextended as a compulsive eater's waistline - but any movie bold enough to warn popcorn-munching filmgoers about obesity has to be applauded. Hell, they might not even finish the bucket...
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A frockumentary bound to end up on every fashionista's must-see list.
This polished affair is easy on the eye but cold to the touch. You end up wondering why it was made at all, beyond giving lazy schoolkids a pre-exam crib.
Entertaining enough with visuals to die for, but definitely not as emotionally rewarding as some of this director's other recent pictures.
Easily the funniest movie ever to feature a goat-slaying psychic.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Disney's attempt at an instant animated classic will impress the kids, but leave older Mouseketeers wistful for former glories.
Fun, colourful and full of action, David Bowers' 'toon will have little trouble diverting those of a similar age to its perky, wide-eyed protagonist.
A clearly affectionate homage to the Canvey Island foursome whose incendiary R&B paved the way for punk.
Both spirited road movie and existential journey.
Mouglalis lacks Audrey Tautou's feisty pluck but makes up for it with Gallic froideur, while Mads Mikkelsen broods as a tortured artist.
"I've never seen such energy!" gushes Stone of his new best friend, setting the tone for a film as "fair and balanced" as the right-wing media it so roundly castigates.
A gifted iconoclast brought low by his demons, addictions and inability to compromise.
A conceptual coup that, in dealing with the shifting logic and fractured reality of dreams, frees itself from the need to satisfy any conventions, formulae or expectations.

As close to unwatchable as cinema gets, Harmony Korine's latest stab at alienating his audience seems perversely designed to test the loyalty of those who stuck with the underground auteur through Gummo and Mister Lonely.

One of the best films of the year, Pixar's long-awaited latest scores in every department. Funny, affecting and dramatically fearless, it's as fine a threequel as you could hope for. Bring tissues -- lots of tissues.
An intimate tribute that pays as much attention to Bill the man as it does to Bill the stand-up.
Steeped in the same hallucinatory qualities as Apocalypse Now, The New World and Aguirre, The Wrath Of God, Refn's latest casts a hypnotic spell throughout.
Peddles banal truisms ("Love is fragile, and we're not always the best caretakers!") as if they're freshly minted.
It's a fine idea that could have made for a devastating critique of consumerism had Borte chosen to follow it through to a cynical, nihilistic conclusion.
A hugely entertaining first act is let down by a lacklustre second in a sequel often more concerned with setting up future Marvel efforts than delivering on its predecessor's promise.

An all-star cast flails about to no discernible purpose in Duncan Ward's Altman-esque satire, a flaccid take on the London art scene that doesn't appear to have benefited from having Damien Hirst as consultant.
West's macho swagger makes a neat complement to Fassbender's steely resolve, while Kurylenko compensates for her lack of verbals with a feral ferocity only hinted at in Quantum Of Solace.
A lavish Italian melodrama with echoes of The Godfather and The Leopard, I Am Love is sweeping, operatic and more than a little silly.
A sleepy weepie with an 11th-hour reveal which is a trifling reward for enduring the soapy slusher that precedes it.
Big sets, wall-to-wall mayhem and hi-tech pixelry only go so far in a movie sure to leave anyone with fond memories of the original feeling shortchanged.
Well acted if somewhat stodgy, this bleak drama argues justice isn't only blind, but also pretty dumb.
Judge's latest doesn't linger long in the memory, generating more gentle chuckles than outand- out belly laughs. But it goes down smoothly enough...
Some may find it emotionally distant and cold to the touch, yet that's no slight on its superb construction and fine ensemble cast.
Breathless action and complex intrigue ensure we are hooked throughout an expertly orchestrated war-zone thriller.
Hancock tugs at the heart strings and wrings the tear ducts with the same ruthless efficiency as a Superbowl playbook.
Undemanding and unoriginal, this is all swagger and no substance.
Fresh yet familiar, with such elaborate stylisation you'll need the DVD to take it in, Micmacs finds Jeunet back in his wheelhouse. It won't win new fans, maybe, but converts will love every frame.
Crazy Heart is a B-grade movie elevated to A-grade status by Bridges' nuanced, heartbreaking performance. Gyllenhaal is terrific too as a smart woman who can't help loving that man.

While you suspect it's really just a big Clash Of The Titans spoiler, there's enough action in Jackson to make it succeed on its own terms. Lerman's a likeable lead, though it's the game supporting cast that keeps you watching.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not just Avatar that Aristomenis Tsirbas' film suffers in comparison to - even Planet 51 looks good beside it.
Tonally different to its predecessor but just as engrossing.
Mean-spirited and coarse with a shallow girl at its hollow heart, Beth Cooper is Superbad without the super.

You'd go mad unpicking the paradoxes in this convoluted brain scrambler. (If you thought Schwentke's Flightplan was bonkers, try this one on for size.) Better to surrender to its implausibilities and revel in the lush, sudsy silliness of it all.
It's the scenes of immigrants heading north atop moving trains which resonate the most - a testament to Adriano Goldman's brilliant, expansive cinematography.
Part psychodrama, part Italian travelogue, Michael Winterbottom's latest is the progeny of an A-list film-maker and B-movie material.

Strong turns from Cheadle and Pearce elevate an ambitious suspenser with a keen eye for the duplicities that propel the War On Terror. The risible ending, alas, is pure wish-fulfillment hokum, while the solitary female character is barely a cipher.

After his playful turn in Mamma Mia!, Firth cuts an altogether more sombre figure in this thoughtful study of bereavement. With no shock twist or homicidal dwarf up its sleeve, though, Winterbottom's film seems a little self-defeating.
Knowing has a far more insidious agenda: to convince non-believers like Cage, an embittered, alcoholic atheist since his wife's death, there is intelligent design in the universe.
Criminally overlooked this awards season, this modest indie is a treat.
Things aren't what they seem, however - something Lynch tries to hide by steeping her tale in wacky humour and over-ripe acting.
No amount of local colour and effects-heavy fisticuffs can save Paul McGuigan's film.
It's a shame director Darnell Martin depends so heavily on the clichéd conventions of every other rags-to-riches biopic.
Having given us Che the icon, Del Toro now gives us Che the man: an asthmatic, flawed individual, powerless to prevent events spiralling out of his control. The film itself is far less compelling.
British director McGuigan clearly hoped to make more than a dopey, effects-laden actioner. Unfortunately, he's made an uneven and pretentious one instead.

More Topshop than Top Gun, this Bruckheimer effort sees Fisher finally make good on her Wedding Crashers promise in a film that manages to be both a frothy romcom and a cautionary tale on the perils of plastic splurgery.
A hagiographical whitewash.
Someone, please make it stop!
The animated title sequence is fun. Besides one set-piece involving a burning restaurant, the rest of the movie isn't.
If you lapped up Beverly Hills Chihuahua, this canine caper about two siblings who turn a derelict hotel into a refuge for stray pooches will no doubt be the mutt's nuts.

Though Shanley's first film as director since 1990 flop Joe Versus The Volcano never strays far from its theatrical origins, his unfussy direction and compelling script provide a perfect platform for his talented cast.
If a little twee for grown-ups, this is riotous fun for kids. Even if it's not Pixar-perfect, it'll definitely do until Up touches down.
Too long by half, it's still a well- crafted mix of tragedy and black humour.
Part mystery, part horror, it keeps us wondering what the hell is going on, while the sombre lensing ups the air of menace. The silly finale undoes a lot of the fine work, though.
Will make you see the Muscles from Brussels in a new light.
Younger audiences will adore this canine caper, though grown-ups might feel its one joke is stretched too far.
The swaggering acting and profanity-rich dialogue, alas, make Neil Thompson's film feel little more than an excuse for Guy Ritchie-esque posturing.
It's put across with enough brio to excuse the inherent stupidity of the premise.
mith's charisma holds the interest, even if this and his other recent movies (I Am Legend and Hancock) suggest the only thing bigger than his ears is his Messiah complex.
Vivid, moving and breathlessly exciting, this enthralling mingling of fable, travelogue and social commentary sees Danny Boyle at the top of his game. Phone a friend and tell them not to miss it.
It's impossible to take his didactic diatribe as seriously as it takes itself.
A superbly crafted yet oddly unmoving film that's easier to admire than to genuinely like.
A sudsy potboiler with a twist you can see coming from the title.
Some of the worst acting, action and dialogue you'll endure this year.
A globe-trotting conspiracy thriller that is a little too complicated for its own good.
A ticking-clock thriller turned full-blown horror, Alex Proyas's film isn't the first to feature Cage wandering about bewilderedly. At least I Am Legend had a dog.
A silly, cheesy, ineptly executed blockbuster that's unlikely to spawn a series.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What follows is episodic enough to make Instinct resemble a TV mini-series. But each fresh incident serves to embellish Mesrine's reckless character and inch him from man to myth.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not just the land that feels lost in Ferrell's lumbering latest. After Bewitched, you'd have thought he'd have learned to leave old TV shows well alone.
Too rude for kids and too dumb for grown-ups, this laboured romp is a dino-snore.
This Jerry Bruckheimer production is a surprisingly light-footed caper for cinema's reigning king of bombast.
Only the conventional storytelling detracts from a film that serves both as poignant family saga and potent allegory.
The grim result might stretch credibility, but that doesn't make it any less entertaining.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Leo and Upham make an unlikely double act in a finely written, well-played film with a striking plot and setting. Hunt's clearly a name to watch; Leo, meanwhile, can look forward to finally getting the recognition, and roles, she deserves.

Full of clunky voiceovers, corny music and maudlin montages, this manipulative yarn plays with issues of medical morality and parental duty only to discard them in favour of a manipulative paean to valuing life and accepting death.
Taking his cue from his leading man's minimalist, self-effacing performance, director and co-writer Matt Aselton has fashioned a wry homage to eccentricity.
Succeeding equally well as rowdy romp, what-happened mystery and man-crush comedy, /The Hangover/ is an unexpected winner.
Hoffman's undimmed star power papers over the script cracks in an otherwise polished vehicle for his and Thompson's talents.
Methodically detailing every stage of his daring plan, director Fred Cavayé serves up a taut tale that tantalisingly leaves the question of his incarcerated heroine's innocence dangling.
With their fresh-faced image, it's hard not to snigger when they start spraying the audience with foam guns... Insert your own Freudian interpretation here.
An impressive ensemble lends heft and humour to this sprawling potboiler. Watchable if never truly memorable, it's a mid-range work for most involved that still affords the odd guilty pleasure.
To its credit, Awaydays does not glamorise its hooligans the way The Football Factory and Green Street did.

Atoning for The Da Vinci Code's cardinal sin - thou shalt not bore - this superior sequel zips along at such a lick you can almost forget the story is utter bollocks. At this rate, The Lost Symbol should be a doozy.
Awash with ideas, imagination and structural daring, Kaufman's latest is an audacious experiment that repays multiple viewings.
Endlessly inventive and impeccably realised, it's tough to find fault with this freaky, feisty fable.
With its kid-friendly mix of tunes and chaste romance, this is sure to leave its target demographic grinning widely.
As much as you'd love to hate it, this jaunty supernatural romcom remains a polished, amusing, surprisingly sweet diversion.
Moving, gripping and funny, this is a homegrown gem you can't help taking to your heart.
Outlandish would have been a better title for a film that's great fun and quite exciting before eventually outstaying its welcome.

Thanks to Castro's creepy turn, this offbeat tale of a loon locked in his own disco inferno is strange enough to give anyone the heebie-Bee Gees. That said, some may find it hard to take an anti-hero without one redeeming feature.

Slick action, hot hardware, shame about the screenplay... Still, it's the best since the original TFATF, and fans of Diesel's gravel-voiced swagger will get a kick seeing him reprise the role that put him on the map.
A snappy script and some neat 3D make for an above-average romp with plenty of in-jokes for cineastes and fan-boys alike.
The result is fascinating yet troubling.
A sombre, intelligent affair with superb performances across the board.
Director Imran Naqvi evokes the requisite air of dread but is let down by an ending that neither surprises nor satisfies.
Cheerful family-com.
A gruelling suspenser told in real time, flecked with a darkly comic sensibility and a smattering of class-war critique.
Clooney and Gosling will poll well in this sleek peek at how politicians really get elected, staged with a smart nod to the classic conspiracy yarns of yesteryear.
An absolute must-see for fans of roar footage.
Tense if rather monotonously bleak, it's a shame Jason Isaacs and David Tennant didn't co-star as originally planned.
What it lacks in abundance, alas, is élan, panache or joie de vivre.
Proves you really can have too much of something that wasn't particularly amusing in the first place.
Well worth another look, though it's a pity they're saving the newly made bloopers for the upcoming Blu-ray.
Smart and suspenseful, The Debt packs in enough surprises to make you forgive its last minute collapse. Chastain, meanwhile, shows why everybody's talking about her.
Star and co-writer George Russo clearly has an ear for swaggering male patois.
Not seen it? Time you did.
For the most part, alas, this only goes to show that in space, no one can hear you yawn.
A bold choice of director, striking visuals and a Rochester to rival Orson Welles' ensures this doesn't feel like just one more highbrow period piece or stodgy great-book adap.
Affection for the characters will bring fans in. But many will leave wishing the makers of one of the most enjoyable programmes of recent years had left well enough alone.
Full of affection for the late Dr T, this droll if bitty frolic is destined to form a triple bill someday with Fear And Loathing and Where The Buffalo Roam.
A dull and desultory affair that'll leave you feeling as cheated as Arnold Schwarzenegger's missus.
Bier's yarn offers an involving narrative, strong acting and fine location work on both sides of the equator.
Cooper's Uday to remember is enough to make Lee Tamahori's blend of fact and fantasy highly watchable. But it's more for Tony Montana fans than those after a more balanced account of Saddam's shame.
Mills allows one half of his story to subtly shape the other in a way that makes for a more coherent and rewarding tale than its disparate elements suggest.
There's more going on than there was in Cars and the globe-trotting's a gas. But compared to the pick of the Pixar pack, this is some way down the grid.
Owen and Keener give excellent performances, while newcomer Liberato is a significant find. Yet for all its power and understatement, Trust is only a few clicks away from sexploitation.
[It] might struggle to equal the sheer exhilaration of Bay's 2007 trilogy-starter, but it's a whole lot more coherent and fulfilling than Revenge Of The Fallen.
It's no Scum or Shawshank, but on its own modest terms, Ghosted is an engrossing watch that wrings new blood from old clichés.
A thoroughly disheartening affair that looks like it was shot through gauze...
Oliver Litondo brings a quiet dignity to the role, even clad in school uniform, while Naomie Harris exudes positivity as the teacher who champions his cause.
Never less than intriguing, but this is really little more than The Young Ones with a prayer mat.
It's uneven, unwieldy and overlong, but if it's yucks you're after you'll find them in abundance in a side-splitting comedy that lifts the veil on every wedding's unsung heroines.
Ignore the stats and surrender to the emotion in a movie where there's always something cool just around the corner.
Glorified karaoke it may be, but there's no doubt Glee's mush of pop covers and show tunes fills a kitsch niche for millions.
A bizarre coda turns what begins as a playful exposé of the British media's sensationalist excesses into a surreal voyage into a warped mind no reporter could invent.
Tarsem Singh may well be an artistic visionary. Unfortunately, his sense of storytelling here is vision-impaired.
There's some great stuff here... What's missing is the delightful Britishness of Nick Park's films.
A coming-of-ager that doubles as a salute to the Northern Soul movement of the 1970s.
Though more forgiving than previous Solondz films, Dark Horse is too slight to herald a wholesale change of direction.
Smart nods to Psycho, Kubrick and German expressionism suggest Mills has done his homework, which is perhaps to be expected from his lineage.
Proves an inspiring watch, even if it does rather gloss over how his wives and children fit into the picture.
In a summer hardly starved of comic-book properties, this redundant extension of a series that ran out of gas a decade ago doesn't need a neuralyzer to be forgettable.
A virtual object lesson in the law of diminishing returns, director John Gulager displaying little of his predecessor Alexandre Aja's flair for juggling gory mayhem with sophomoric silliness.
An opinionated motormouth reveals sociopathic tendencies in an Irish micro-budgeter that's the very definition of a hard slog.

Its status as a national treasure is assured, thanks to Roger Livesey's protean lead turn, Deborah Kerr's three incarnations of his ideal woman and the mastery of the medium that typified The Archers at their height.
movie_title: The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp (1943)

movie_review_blurb: Delpy's attempts to be France's Woody Allen continue apace with an appealing if variable exploration of her customary obsessions that finds Rock in rare deadpan mode.
Reaches a level of artistry, sophistication and musical excellence that's still to be bettered by the Mouse House - or indeed its rivals.
McGregor and Blunt make fetching lovebirds, while Kristin Scott Thomas is off the scale in a rare comic outing.
[A] workmanlike slice of sub-Bourne hijinks...
To borrow a line Roberts spits at Collins, there's something about Mirror that's incredibly irritating.
It'll be worth a case of doubloons to anybody with little ones to entertain over the Easter hols.
The homegrown appeal of StreetDance gets lost in a sequel with one foot across the pond, the other over the channel.
[A] flashy hodge-podge of biopic, mystery and gorno.
After the flak they took in Martha Marcy May Marlene, it's nice to see at least one film give cults the benefit of the doubt.
Some will balk at Pinto's passivity, but Trishna again shows Winterbottom to be one of the few directors today who are liberated, rather than constricted, by classic literature.
Even in our cynical age, it still manages to impress.
Bring earplugs and you'll enjoy an efficient vehicle for Denzel that makes good use of its South African scenery. Espinosa nimbly combines flash with Paul Greengrass-style flair.
"You're not as easy to hate as I thought!" Barrymore says to Danson. Those initially resistant to Big Miracle may reach the same conclusion.
Theron gives a fearless performance in a dark comedy of no manners that's as acerbic and mordant as Juno was warm and embracing.
It's hard to fathom who this 3D combo of horror, musical and twinkly retro nostalgia is aimed at.

With no Michael Sheen this time around and Charles Dance stepping in for an AWOL Bill Nighy, there's a distinct sense of sloppy seconds to a film that's humourless throughout and, thanks to murky 3D, visually dull to boot.
Madonna's second outing as director only gives ammunition to her critics with a movie destined to join Body Of Evidence in the bargain bin.
A fast-paced, globe-trotting adventure that offers blasts, brawls and buildings of equally spectacular scale.
Faster, funnier and even more bromantic than the original, this far from stately Holmes delivers piping hot entertainment at a furious lick.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Arrive two hours late for Bekmambetov's overcooked noise generator and you'll have a fantastic night.
It's good to see the respectability Araki won from 2004's Mysterious Skin hasn't sapped his subversive streak.
With simulated simians authentic enough to make Project Nim look almost phoney, allied to an involving, evolving story, Rise is the Planet we've been waiting for.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: For all its killer choreography, alas, it's clear this genre urgently needs some new moves of its own.

There's a sneaky sense throughout that too much significance and import has been put on what is not much more than a shaggydog tale. Yet when the old dog in question is Robert Duvall, you can hardly begrudge the filmmakers for giving it a pat.
A forgettable trifle about a struggling breakfast TV show.
A big idea reaps small dividends in a comedy fantasy that's only likely to score laughs from the tiniest audience members.
Oozing class from start to finish, Howard Hawks' 1946 noir isn't just a Hollywood classic.
Everybody's clearly in it for the money in a follow-up that, sporadic chuckles aside, proves the law of diminishing returns.
A compulsive, propulsive study of relationships virtual and real.
Schnabel's latest doesn't want for ambition, but had it tried to do less, it might have achieved more.
A good cast tries in vain to elevate a workmanlike script in a film that ends up as dead as Joe Gillis.
A befuddling muddle that sees a starry cast up to their necks in reheated clichés.
[A] dreary pot-boiler...
A glum, navel-gazing affair that asks us to invest in self-absorbed protagonists living absurdly narcissistic lives.
Funny as a funeral and as entertaining as an autopsy, this clumsy caper is more DOA than LOL.
Both stars loathed the experience yet turned in two of their most enduring performances.
[Leigh has] made another funny, perceptive, moving human drama.
Corbijn's bold stab at reviving the minimalism and mystery of '70s cinema has its strengths but ultimately overreaches itself.
A compelling insight into a challenging woman, given an extra dimension by some brave if occasionally dubious directorial flourishes.
Has enough charm, colour and humour to win us over by extra time.
It's pleasing to see something from the Nordic countries that doesn't involve police procedure and chunky jumpers.
Elliot's record of an unconventional friendship revels in grotesque detail and scatological humour, but yields unexpected depth and poignancy.

Balanced a tad uneasily between action fantasy and redemptive heart-tugger, this frenetic CG animation has an identity crisis as big as its hero's inferiority complex. That said, it'll do until Megamind arrives.
Shame it's so slow and contradicts its own strained logic, ending up in the same listless limbo as The Time Traveler's Wife and The Lovely Bones.
In truth, alas, it's the film itself that's short of ideas.
A slickly satisfying genre exercise with sufficient thrills, spills and frills to keep you hooked.
In trying to dramatise the causes and consequences of the 2008 collapse, Stone slightly misses the boat.
If you're going to make a biopic about an abused child who grows up to be a bare-knuckle boxer, it might help to hire an actor who looks like he can actually handle himself in a scrap or two.
After dull period misstep Chéri, Stephen Frears finds his mojo again with a frothy diversion that makes no great claims but succeeds brilliantly as polished entertainment.
It wasn't going to be Anchorman 2 but we still expected more from Brick Tamland's reunion with Brian Fantana.
Its charms remain undiminished after five decades, despite Mickey Rooney's Mr Yunioshi...
Swank and Rockwell elevate a solid drama that tells its tall tale with, yes, conviction. It's not exactly the whole truth, though.
An inept black farce about two 19th century bodysnatchers that couldn't be more lifeless if it was one of their victims.
Wavering between affecting dramedy and goofy asylum- com, this is an enjoyable but superficial placebo that soft-soaps the realities of psychological disorder.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A thriller which begins promisingly before descending into a slough of old lag clichés.
Though tonally uneven, Hornet nonetheless works as breezy, irreverent entertainment that makes a virtue of its unlikely elements.
Sumptuously photographed and elegantly stylised, Heartbeats' exterior is as seductive as Schneider's R-Pattzalike. Dig beneath the surface, though, and there ain't much there.
Two sequels are planned, God help us.
Hattie Dalton's direction is sensitive but ponderous, making our own third star more than slightly grudging.
While it's easy to sneer at the tweens and their scary parents, you can't ignore their dedication to their dying art, nor their kinetic energy.
The most problematic hurdle in The Avengers' path is cleared with ease and some style by a film that makes a virtue of its inherent silliness. You're up, Captain America.
Guess you can't go back, even if your name is Christopher Robin.
A bright flight of fancy that makes an hour and a half fly by.
It's something of a relief that, even at 70, Sheen remains a commanding presence who holds our attention throughout every stage of his seemingly endless trek.
Populist fare from across the channel that will amply repay those ready to put the time in. The scenery, meanwhile, makes you want to run out and buy a timeshare.
Comes with preposterous embellishments - a criminal subplot here, an assassination attempt there - and a lily-livered eagerness to depict Bono as the nicest singer ever to walk the earth.
A clever, classy and affecting thriller that never goes off the rails.
It's a tough job but someone's got to do it in a moving look at one of the armed forces' most harrowing details.
Canny enough to stand comparison with coming-of-age Brit-flicks like SoulBoy and Cemetery Junction.
Despite having characters as shallow as its caves are bottomless and a plot as predictable as 127 Hours, this suspenseful actioner delivers seat-edge thrills in accomplished goggle-vision.
Better than Grown Ups? Sure. Then again, that's not much of a recommendation.
Slow and laboured to start with, this sober spooker gets better once it realises its true calling and lets its star off the leash.
It's left to the actors to lend gravitas and depth, with varying levels of success.
It's probably cameraman Jack Cardiff who deserves kudos for turning this odd-couple romance into such a colourful escapade through east Africa.
The strangeness is off the scale in a kooky concoction that might have been hatched at the bottom of a bong. Then again, what do you expect with Johnny involved?
A surprisingly entertaining animated caper...
Imagine Black Hawk Down with ETs instead of Somalis and you'll have the measure of an explosive if functional actioner that will do while we're waiting for summer's big guns to arrive.
Take the Buena Vista Social Club, add some wheelchairs and you have Staff Benda Bilili...
With endless shots of underwater landscapes propping up an episodic narrative, this is less Finding Nemo than one long screensaver.
You want to be moved more than you are by a film that doesn't tap the emotions half as much as the facts. Loach shows promise, though.
The ending, much copied, is justly famous. But it's the implacable build-up that seals its classic status...
Gorgeous cinematography and inspired performances are thrown off by clunky editing to make 'The Lost City of Z' an unbalanced, but fascinating watch.
Don't be surprised to hear about award nominations on this one, and make sure to add it to your watch-list as soon as it's out.
Clearly there's not much left to explore in this 'Alien' world and fans would be better off revisiting the first two classics to find their screams again.
Needless to say, it's an absolutely essential and thoroughly enjoyable spectacle to watch!
The world of 'Ghost in the Shell' is truly a sight to behold, with an amalgamation of a neo-noir landscape along with a gritty, greasy cyberpunk underbelly.
Fortunately, the writers are well aware of their inspirations; enough to avoid certain clichés.
If Shyamalan continues to bring his A-game to the big screen, he's more than welcome to jump on the franchise bandwagon.
Bound to result in polarizing opinions, Silence is one of Scorsese's most intimate works that cannot be ignored.
This is undoubtedly the strongest DCEU outing till now, one that will add a new world of (female) fans to the franchise, and for all the right reasons.
As 'The Space Between Us' resorts to generic pandering by catering to its core demographic of teens and young adults looking for a date movie around Valentine's Day.
There's much to enjoy when cars are flying around the screen, even if logic takes flight with them.
[Rahul] Bose is as comfortable in front of the camera as he is behind it, allowing for an ebb and flow to the narrative that keeps you totally engrossed during its taut runtime.
Charlize Theron has created her own version of 'James Bond' - one that could easily last a few more rounds down the line.
Owen Wilson is cheerful as Lightning McQueen, enough to watch him running around in circles on and off a race track.
The first entry in Universal Pictures' monster franchise comes across as a desperate attempt by the studio to capitalise on Hollywood's current world-building frenzy.

War for the Planet of the Apes is a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant film that balances action and special effects well enough to make it stand out from all the blockbusters seen so far this year.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If nothing else, it is yet another landmark achievement by one of the most important and skilled storytellers in the present generation of filmmaking.
Denis Villeneuve is fast approaching the upper echelons of modern-day directors, and his vision here is so well-defined and executed that it wouldn't be a far stretch to say he has already arrived.
If only it was a tighter story - Hitman's Bodyguard would be a crisper and much better film. But don't let that detract you from checking this out and enjoying it for what it is.
Rest assured - King's nightmare is alive, freaky and endearing at the same time. If you're a horror fan, don't miss It!
Even if it doesn't raise the stakes of the genre, there's enough potential to turn this funny and smartly written caper into another entertaining Soderbergh franchise.
What American Assassin lacks in originality, it makes up in breathtaking action that is often brutal.
The cast, and director Matthew Vaughn, seem to have had a lot of fun making this movie and that essence translates well on screen too.
'T2' truly stands the test of time with a great story combined with smart, and efficient special effects that complement the narrative

The Crew lands somewhat short of hitting the emotional mark as some of the beats are lost in translation (read 'dubbing'), yet top-notch effects and an uncompromising second half puts it on par with some of the best action-adventure flicks.
Clearly, third time is a charm for Thor as Ragnaro is the best film on the Asgardian till date, and another entry from Marvel you simply cannot miss!
There are enough crowd-pleasing moments to distract you from a predictable plot and departure from logic.
The visual sugar-high never killed anyone, and as far as escapist blockbusters go, Valerian and The City of A Thousand Planets is as imaginative and spectacular as they come.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Watch it, but unless you'd like to get fired, or even arrested for criminal behavior, don't follow its examples at your upcoming office party.
It is now a great starting point for someone new to this franchise. To quote one of the familiar lines from this space opera - "the Force is strong with this one"!
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Tomb Raider does enough to reignite the franchise onscreen by giving its protagonist a timely and relevant overhaul to confidently launch Alicia Vikander as this generation's Lara Croft.

Hostiles captures constant threat beautifully, with riveting moments of action and drama making it hard to predict who will make it out. But amidst great performances and cinematography, it misses the mark with just an overview of its subject matter.
Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is an unassuming film that surprises you with its provocative subject matter and evocative performances that are hard to forget.
Aiyaary has measured performances that resound louder than its bombastic score, and they alone make it a worthwhile watch.
Inspiring and empowering in equal measure, Black Panther is a richer & deeper experience than most comic book fare.

Paul Thomas Anderson weaves a mystery of romantic obsession around the lead pair. The journey until the final unveiling would not be half as engaging if it weren't for the brutally raw and sincere performances by the actors.
Granted, it could do with a tauter screenplay and shorter run-time but Padmaavat is an entertaining, large canvas experience, brought to life with Sanjay Leela Bhansali's stroke of visual brilliance.
Darkest Hour is pretentiously flawed in its obvious award-baiting, but well produced and rousing enough thanks to Gary Oldman in one of his most impressive performances.
This sequel is funnier, more charming and heartwarming than the original; one you'll enjoy tremendously, with or without kids in tow.
The Post goes beyond chastising clickbaity media sensationalism and serves as a stark reminder of the purpose of the press in any democracy.
The main reason to watch All the Money in the World is the last-minute character revamp by Christopher Plummer that makes this film worthwhile.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The chemistry between the lead cast is evident and the script makes the most of this by giving each actor moments to shine and showcase their skills while they clearly enjoy playing their characters.
Just like the protagonist, Lady Bird is awkwardly funny yet bittersweet, making it one of Hollywood's most original and refreshingly honest films about growing up.

Unfortunately, while their performances are intriguing at best, they all appear to be misplaced in this biographical drama. Blame it largely on shoddy writing and direction by Peter Landesman, who appears to be out of his depth.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The true purpose of these intelligent extra-terrestrial beings is a jaw-dropping reveal that warrants a repeat viewing to find all the breadcrumbs left in the lead up to the crescendo.

[There is] apparent lack of interest written on the face of the lead star Kate Beckinsale - she's not even the most interesting character in a series built around her, and it's obvious she's simply going through the motions to collect another pay check.
Doctor Strange elevates yet another relatively unknown Marvel character to top tier status, making it well worth a dizzying watch in 3D.
Resorting to mostly practical effects helps maintain a degree of realism that serves the movie well and yet, the inevitable violence isn't nauseating.
The less said about the performances, the better. The three main leads seem to be going through the motions with barely any investment into their characters.
All in all, audiences new and old alike are treated to an endearing adventure with the promise of more to come from J.K. Rowling.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Aided by a fine score courtesy Clint Mansell, your patience will be rewarded as long as you focus on the presentation beyond the slow pacing and all the conjecture.

The essence of this story is 'Main Kar Sakti Hai', and with such a refined and affable actress as Vidya Balan in the lead, it is lovingly captured in Tumhari Sulu making it an entertaining watch for the whole family.
Replace your skeptical lens with 3D glasses, and cheer along with your childhood heroes; Justice League is made for the fans, and if you're one, you'll have a lot of fun.
There are points when you will reach out for some tissues but they're peppered with enough laughs along the way to make it well-balanced, extremely relevant and combined with a strong message.
As long as you don't expect fireworks, enjoy this sweet film that will leave you smiling.
The Last Jedi is everything a Star Wars film should be, and so much more. Johnson weaves an emotionally rewarding tale while balancing all the essential sci-fi action expected.
Nowhere Boy delivers a definitive account of Lennon's pain-wracked adolescence.
An intimate, shocking but ultimately exhilarating portrait of suffering and dignity.
Stunningly filmed, the landscape's harsh beauty provides a tactile, overwhelming backdrop to a terrifying but ultimately transcendent experience.

It's Wilko's peremptory, offbeat monologues that provide Oil City Confidential with its through-line and several of its funniest moments, not least when he describes the clouds and flames of the Shell Haven Refinery as "Miltonic"

Andy Serkis delivers a spellbinding turn as Dury. Replicating Dury's cheeky chappie onstage persona is admirable enough; more astonishing is Serkis' uncanny incarnation of Dury in person, variously charming, belligerent, foul, pathetic and awesome.
300 is just a silly, yet melodramatic, cliched, comic-book version of Gladiator with Frank Miller art direction.
The story does have its moments, but for the most part it's a paint-by-the-numbers affair.

An intriguing but overly demanding portrait of rural Montana that concentrates on sheep and their herders.
Talky analysis of modern-day relationships and insecurities can't quite shake its self-satisfied air of modish inconsequentiality.
An octogenarian French auteur looks back on her life, times and movies in this engagingly jaunty documentary.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Animated semi-documentary takes a wry backward glance at an unorthodox childhood with sometimes affecting results.
movie_title: Couleur de peau: Miel (Approved for Adoption) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A fanciful project that's tantalizing on paper but largely DOA on screen.
Solidly effective addition to Britain's social realism tradition, elevated by excellent performances by the young leads and some unexpectedly poetic touches.
Tiresomely frenetic crime-comedy-romance.
Engaging documentary tribute to the craggy character-actor and his five-decade career is elevated by classy visuals and a nicely relaxed, casual tone.
Efficient found-footage collage is more evocative than revelatory.
Likeably unassuming, good-looking US indie may exert offbeat appeal to the foodie crowd.
A luminous central performance from Golshifteh Farahani distinguishes an ambitious if somewhat monotonously wordy adaptation of a prize-winning best-seller.
Nicely elegiac, proudly old-fashioned tale of wartime passions, with veteran French star Jean Rochefort a likely award-magnet.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Gimmicky chiller lacks the robustness and distinction needed to support its social-commentary ambitions.
A lukewarm examination of a hot-potato political issue.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Canadian documentary skilfully deploys some ambitious creative gambits to explore the director's own family background.
Love streams and bloodstreams messily cross in a steamy but clunky plunge into vampire lore, hipster-indie style.
Acclaimed Mexican auteur's self-indulgent exercise in exquisite pseudo-profundity commits hara-kiri on his own reputation.
Sensitive subject-matter is handled with tact and intelligence in this tart if talky US indie.
Poignant animated feature about senior citizens is one the year's best Spanish films.
A high-seas hostage-taking and resulting negotiations are absorbingly dramatized in this low-key Venice standout from Denmark's hottest new writer-director.
A sobering, ultimately numbing peek into the living hell of 1970s Cambodia.
Accessible documentary serves as useful introduction to and informative update on an artist who's seldom out of the headlines for long.

The parallel tracks of railways and cinema profitably converge yet again in J.P.Sniadecki's outstanding, semi-experimental documentary The Iron Ministry, a pungently immersive evocation of traveling on Chinese trains.
A stunning misfire.

Alternating between the urban jungle of Manhattan and the rain-forest of Africa with metronomic aplomb, award-winning German journalist and author Michael Obert effects an belated, auspicious transition to film-making with Song From the Forest.
A steady, austere treatment of a notoriously and riotously rambunctious subject, Set Fire to the Stars takes a non-incendiary, safe-hands approach to potentially combustible material.
Meru is an engaging and cumulatively exhilarating debut from wife-and-husband team Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi and Jimmy Chin.

This is very much Alexander's show. Despite moments of audition-piece excess, the young actor... almost single-handedly keeps We Are Monster watchable, exuding a malign charisma that dominates the screen and compels our appalled fascination.
Its title may be a Spanish word meaning "knife wound", but Ricardo Silva's pseudo-apocalyptic, sophomorically provocative debut Navajazo is much too surface-skimming to draw blood.
Quote not available.

Chaitanya Tamhane emerges as one of the world's most accomplished and promising film-makers under 30 with his quietly steely legal drama Court, a bluntly-titled chronicle of politically-motivated injustice.
At 90-odd minutes, it's more exhausting than illuminating -- there's not much time for anything resembling proper analysis.
Strikingly good-looking if somewhat narratively uneven.
A semi-waterlogged confluence of the submarine and heist sub-genres which seeks to evoke a testosterone-soaked, 1970s feel.
An upbeat chronicle of very hard rock in a very hard place, Death Metal Angola is one of the livelier and more enticingly exotic additions to the ever-burgeoning music-documentary sub-genre.
Brazil's Marcelo Gomes leaps to the front rank of South American filmmakers.
Old-school charm and expert performances elevate a somewhat creaky theatrical adaptation by the tireless centenarian Manoel de Oliveira.
What we're left with is an odd, only fitfully engaging hybrid of The Quiet Man and Footloose, which neither packs much of a punch nor is particularly nimble on its feet.
An essentially hollow contrivance, more concerned with pushing hot buttons and sparking discussion than organically developing characters or probing complex issues.
E even within the context of such unevenness, Costa's commitment to chronicling and implicitly dignifying the sufferings of the oppressed and the exploited provides Horse Money with a solid core.

Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.

As a fiercely intelligent but helplessly self-destructive mathematician who's a bit too chummy with her teenage nephew, Dalle shows that, in her mid-40s, she's lost little of her dangerously feral allure.

Ambitious adaptation of a fable-like feminist novel provides an impressive one-woman showcase for lead Martina Gedeck.
