movie_title: Adventures in Odyssey - Go West Young Man (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Very British blend of quirky character-comedy and homicidal violence has all the makings of a midnight-movie cult classic.
Award-winning examination of migrant labor would have worked better as a documentary.
Decade-hopping metaphysical romance descends into overwrought histrionics.
[A] slow-burning, distinctive second feature from Russian-born, Colorado-raised writer/director Julia Loktev.
Remaking Alain Corneau's 2010 French noir Love Crime proves less a comeback for De Palma and more what economists call a 'dead cat bounce.'
Quote not available.
A superb calling-card for the skills of cinematographer Diego García, hour-long docu-fiction hybrid Fogo is otherwise austere high-art cinema of the most exquisitely patience-sapping kind.

When the music stops and the dialogue has to carry the burden of character and narrative development, Villegas is a little too restrained and laid-back to ever properly engage us with the cousins or their volatile, decades-old relationship.
Murky tale of infidelity, revenge and guilt makes heavy weather of torrid emotional material.
As is often the case with directors who adapt their own life-histories, there's the sense that Avila is a little too close to his material.
It is - for all its charms, and despite Hong's trademark formal experimentation -- ultimately rather lightweight stuff.
Overall, this is a handsomely-mounted period picture which transcends the stuffiness of costume-drama with sufficient aplomb...
Informative, ire-stoking but formally conventional...
movie_title: Garbage in the Garden of Eden (Müll im Garten Eden) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Miniature rumination on reincarnation and romance overstays its welcome even at 59 minutes.

While its techniques are manipulative -- it's certainly no margin-call to say that Vangelis's two-dimensional score barely lets up from start to finish -- the picture ultimately swerves pitfalls of hectoring preachiness.
Quote not available.
Cavalcanti -- an occasional TV performer whose considerable musical gifts the guitar-strumming Jean shares -- makes for a consistently engaging and intriguing protagonist.
The basic premise stretches credulity from the off.
[Lucija Stojevic's] film really comes alive with the archive materials - the irresistible power of La Chana, even in black-and-white stills, palpably bursting from the screen. Brava!
Bunker77 is yet another paean to a reckless, instinctive ground-breaking whose own stylistic stance is familiar to the point of cliche.
Mansfield 66/67 seeks to channel the effervescent fizz of its subject with entertaining but haphazard results.
This fitfully engaging affair only really passes muster as a potential pilot for small-screen continuations.
Blood proves thicker than (holy) water in writer-director Daniel Kokotajlo's debut Apostasy, one of the year's strongest British films.

Questions of gender underpin Rosell's lean, smart and surprising screenplay in this Chilean co-production, which confirms his status as one of Latin America's most quietly distinctive cinematic voices.
New wine in old bottles, then, but the steely taste is nevertheless undeniably potent.
A feast for the eyes but something of a trial for the ears, the film is simultaneously cutting edge in its technology and thuddingly old-fashioned in its gee-whiz tone.
A finely etched miniature of quietly cumulative emotional impact.

... strong performances and outstanding cinematography aren't enough to rescue an unfocused and episodic screenplay, which will leave many stranded in a purgatorial cinematic-halfway house between bliss and despair.
Melanie Thierry leaps towards the front echelons of current French actresses with her riveting turn as Marguerite Duras in Emmanuel Finkiel's slow-burning Memoir of Pain (La Douleur).

It takes a certain kind of nerve for a director to entitle his debut feature-length work Rat Film, but there's much more to Theo Anthony's richly informative essay on the planet's most-maligned critters than its bluntly confrontational moniker.
Pallaoro plays the slow-cinema game with slick, calculating skill, but now flashes of serious substance can be glimpsed beneath the exquisitely steely style.
An unruly, polymorphously perverse river of sensations, plunging the willing viewer into a roiling mass of pungent evocations.
While Gal Friday, Hazel Honeysuckle and the Schlep Sisters are unfailingly lively, articulate and sympathetic company, proceedings take on a repetitive, even monotonous air after a while.

Wet Woman in the Wind isn't likely to land anyone in anything remotely hot water - though the upcoming installment by perpetual provocateur Sono may yet elevate pulses both inside cinemas and further afield.
movie_title: Wet Woman in the Wind (Kaze ni nureta onna) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... Cuba and the Cameraman is sustained by the strong bonds of trust which the gregarious [director Jon] Alpert has evidently been able to maintain with Cubans from various echelons of this theoretically classless society.

Accessible, informative and wryly humorous, the film uses Srbijanka's tastefully-decorated residence as a prism through which to view the woman, her turbulent times and the complicated history of the former Yugoslavia.
movie_title: The Other Side of Everything (Druga strana svega) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Solid, topical, dutiful, but always content to retread well-trodden turf.
Quote not available.
A claustrophobic character-study of a cash-strapped, resourceful young woman which works best as a showcase for lead Sofia Brito's offbeat charisma.
A plod through enervatingly arid cinematic terrain.
There are enough moments of beauty, charm and dry humor along the way to maintain engagement and interest.
Primarily a work of simple and unapologetic humanism, happily in love with people ("We're as we are," one remarks).
The Big House works both as an observational chronicle of one particular stadium - and the myriad people who come there for work and play - and as an anthropological snapshot of the country ...
An engaging and harrowingly topical drama.
Greenberg, whose previous output has primarily been for television, develops potentially fascinating storylines and characters in frustratingly two dimensional fashion.
A work which shows occasional flashes of talent on various fronts but is ultimately a hollow rehash of well-worn stylistic tropes.
movie_title: Tower. A Bright Day. (Wieza. Jasny dzien) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: And while very much a film of two unequal halves, there's more than enough cinematic chutzpah on display here, especially in the early sections, to confirm the Floridian writer-director as a name to watch.
Nightmarish but rewarding for all concerned.

An admirably audacious feat of documentarian access, Of Fathers and Sons is of obvious topical and anthropological interest as a glimpse into the gradual radicalization of young males and the deep community ties which underpin the process.

Wajib gives an unfussily illuminating snapshot of modern-day Nazareth, where a majority Arab population - most seen here are Christian - has found ways to get along under the fiddly, capricious restrictions of the Israeli state.
With her first feature-length documentary Over the Limit, Polish writer-director Marta Prus does for rhythmic gymnastics what Damien Chazelle did for drumming in Whiplash.

Wilmont sensitively dramatizes the unique pressures that come with living adjacent to a war zone, presenting the physical and psychological impacts of such an upbringing on impressionable, malleable young souls.
Sensitively examines the palette of clashing colors along Russia's political spectrum.
Infinite Football has moments of nicely deadpan humor and some deft little touches of insight along the way courtesy of Porumboiu's offbeat protagonist; but major league it certainly is not.
[The film's story] may skirt credibility towards the latter stages but whose finale concludes matters in a persuasive, wickedly witty and provocative manner.
Gets an F.

The huge canvas becomes an inadvertent self-portrait of this most self-effacing of auteurs, whom one senses entirely shares the NYPL's noble aims and belief in the power of education, community and hard work.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Occasional wobbles of characterization apart, Thousand Cuts generally sustains its mood of steady, brooding swagger.
movie_title: Thousand Cuts (Le serpent aux mille coupures) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Long-awaited, much-delayed and disappointingly redundant ...

An enjoyably blood-soaked thriller with unexpectedly lyrical interludes -- made very much in the shadow of classic genre forebears and on what was clearly a constrained budget -- this is a strikingly impressive calling-card.
A persuasively partisan example of old-school investigative journalism.
A lovely, upbeat, even life-affirming film.
Intriguing but ultimately underwhelming.
A wryly amusing peek into Buenos Aires' bustling Jewish quarter.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A solid example of low-key, well-observed, humanistically sympathetic ethnography.
Quite original, highly improbable and curiously cool.

Sometimes all a documentary needs is one strong, charismatic personality to keep things watchable: Garnet's Gold boasts two in the form of the middle-aged eponymous protagonist and his feisty octogenarian mother.
This metaphysical French-Portuguese gabfest boasts the uncompromising intensity that has often been Zulawski's hallmark but leavens the stew with welcome streaks of off-kilter humor.

Primarily a showcase for the spiky charisma of star Rhys Ifans, it's a low-key study of strained family relations that creates and sustains a certain wryly flinty mood up until a disastrous 11th-hour lurch into violent melodrama.

Built four-square around Ariane Labed's engaging turn as eponymous sailor Alice, this feature debut from actress-turned-writer-director Lucie Borleteau strikes a delicate balance between the sensual and the matter-of-fact.
A raucously entertaining if slightly overlong romp which borrows liberally from existing sources but has more than enough character and brio to stand foursquare on its own two hairy feet.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This persuasive paean to sheer bloody-minded persistence flies by over the course of 136 engrossing, often hilarious minutes.

Strikingly shot, edited and scored, with convincing and vivid performances from a youthful cast, the picture loses its footing in the final stretch but should still take high rank among U.S. debuts of its ilk this year.

A nightmarish experience in more ways than one, Sanal Kumar Sasidharan's improvised, nocturnal Indian road movie Sexy Durga forces protagonists and audience alike through a grueling ordeal with questionable rewards.
A sophisticated French melange of The Ghost Writer and House of Cards, The Great Game (Le grand jeu) is a steadily engaging slow-burner that somehow never quite manages to catch fire.
The sky-high Himalayas and the aftermath of civil war cast equally dark shadows in White Sun (Seto Surya), an impressively accomplished second feature by Nepalese writer-director Deepak Rauniyar.
This French co-production has a streak of convincing authenticity in its smaller details, likely traceable to the criminal pedigree of its ex-jailbird co-director/co-writer Francois Troukens.

Dealing in an intelligent and original manner with antisemitism and nationalistic propaganda in the context of "ordinary" folks' lives, it deserves wide exposure at documentary-oriented festivals and far beyond.
A hybrid of art-house and genre cinema, combining sharp social commentary with grand guignol fantasy.

Rodriguez ... is simply irresistible here in her first screen role, shouldering the bulk of the dialogue (co-written by Florence Seyvos) and navigating a wide range of emotions without ever striking a false or artificial beat.
movie_title: Tomorrow and Thereafter (Demain et tous les autres jours) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A spectacularly assaultive, borderline incoherent neo-Western that will recruit few new converts but is also guaranteed to leave no spectator indifferent.
movie_title: Let the Corpses Tan (Laissez bronzer les cadavres!) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A semi-digestible collation of stew and sauerkraut, Irish-German comedy Halal Daddy never quite cuts close enough to the funny bone.
Passes muster strictly as a showcase for Hurt and Dance.
Zahler borrows knowingly and liberally from key cinematic forebears, but with a dark humour and bloodthirsty chutzpah all of his own.
A quietly absorbing true-crime tale.
Editor Eva Hillstrom pieces together what was presumably a mass of video-diary reportage into a coherent, brisk whole.
Contrasting wavelengths of humor and seriousness come through with impressive clarity in director/co-writer Babak Jalali's sophomore outing Radio Dreams.

Ostensibly documenting a year in the life of Headfort School... the Spanish co-production instead quickly reveals itself as an irresistibly admiring portrait of long-married couple John and Amanda Leyden, both staff members for over 40 years.
Wryly amusing, intriguingly stylized.
It's chiefly notable for Cara Seymour's nuanced supporting turn as Anna's sometime best friend, Kate.

Ni Chianain and co-director David Rane make no attempts to reinvent the documentary wheel here, crafting a solid showcase for the charming idiosyncracies of their well-chosen, well-matched protagonists.
As Kostis' neurosis shades into psychosis, the limitations of Papadimitropoulos and Tzoumerkas' increasingly blunt, tonally wayward and two-dimensional screenplay become apparent.
Struggles to evoke the atmosphere of its setting - Manchester, 1976-1982 - and to bring its tantalizingly enigmatic subject into satisfying focus.

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Even though Lawrence's act is getting repetitive, it's still good enough to make for an amusing time.
A retread of an oft-used Hollywood plot.
Still, although the subject matter is sophomoric it has enough of a plot and key performances to humor more sophisticated moviegoers too.
It succeeds beautifully at capturing the inner life of girls.
The set pieces, most often provided by rather hammy and two-dimensional, if not straight-down offensive, 'foreigners' were like something from low-budget Malyalam comedies.
This tale of wealth, horse-breeding and good old Christian faith is just about as hammy as a study of commodified horse sex can be.

Sinister, tense and at times ridiculous, The Box is a warped genre piece - Kelly's homage to 1970s science-fiction, with all the wobbly effects, timid housewives and pseudo-religious imagery that suggests.
This is more accurately a film about a revolution against innocence and the vacuum it leaves behind.
Sweet turbo mother of fuel injections, what is this?
If this all sounds rather like déjà vu, then consider yourself one step ahead of the game.

Gorgeous cinematography from Caleb Deschanel (The Black Stallion) and wonderfully intricate production design from James D. Bissell create a believably magical world of dusty tomes and toothy goblins.
"The Business of Being Born" is messy and amateurish but heartfelt and compelling.
Halfway through Kevin Kline shows up in a performance of such vitality and honesty that it shows how two-dimensional the rest of the movie is.
This movie is paced for an audience that grew up multi-tasking and its aesthetic sensibility and depth of story-telling is equivalent to a beer commercial.
The story may be old, but these kids act -- and dance -- as though they are telling it for the first time.
This pea-brained vanity production does not have the energy to remember from one scene to the next what it is about or why it is on screen. It is attention-deficit film-making.
This is a fine family film, filled with imagination and heart.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Wachowskis have taken the iconic but decidedly low-tech 1960's Japanese cartoon character and put the pedal to the metal with dazzling effects and electrifying action.
Romantic comedies...need twinkle. Her character wears twinkly dresses and does twinkly things, but Swank delivers her lines as though she is still slamming into that heavy bag.
Ultimately, as it should be, what carries the day is the power of the arguments and our recognition that it is forming these positions that will lead to the foundation of the civil rights era.
There are a lot of outrageous, raunchy, and insulting comments from caricatured family members, but, surprisingly, considering that most of them are played by stand-up comics, very few actual jokes.

movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (Astérix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It feels like a Christmas TV special that could have been broadcast 10 years ago. But as Christmas TV specials go, it's a very funny one.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's just like old times. Once again, Bourne hurtles from one grey and gritty European metropolis to another at breathtaking speed... And once again, Greengrass stages the action with bone-jarring immediacy.
You go along with the charismatic cast and atmospheric shots until, ultimately, it gets on your nerves.
It's possibly a little too gentle and a few jokes might have made it even better but, these days, Hollywood films as quietly humane as this one are almost as rare as dragons.
Thanks to Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie, Zoolander 2 is no longer 2016's most disappointing fashion-industry comedy comeback.
It is daringly progressive, and it is a landmark in mainstream entertainment. It's just a shame that it isn't a bit funnier.
Lights Out has the best horror gimmick since Paranormal Activity.

As with the Golden Age American B-movies Bozon admires, Tip Top's primary concern is not with identifying the bad guy, but with smuggling in as much additional information as possible, including televised images of the unfolding Arab Spring.
... unnecessary but genial ...
Matt Shepard Is A Friend Of Mine is a moving eulogy to a life lost but not forgotten.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, "Meru" is a flawed but deeply riveting account of what happens when men walk right up to the edge of madness.
"Death Metal Angola" is engrossing, entertaining and, above all, deeply true - here's to hoping more people find a way to see it.
"Love and Terror on the Howling Plains of Nowhere" is a kooky, uneven, mostly entertaining case of real-life weirdness, a gumbo of disparate elements that never quite congeals.
movie_title: Love and Terror on the Howling Plains of Nowhere (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It shouldn't even begin to work, and yet, strangely, it does, sort of, thanks to the assured handling of writer/director Holland.
Redgrave's performance is superb and she's ably supported by Holm, Dench, and Hamilton in particular.
The injection of humour into HP Lovecraft's 1922 tale is what saves this splatterfest from being mere fodder for gorehounds.
It's all good scary fun.
The film follows a group of Muslim-American comedians on a stand-up-and-public-relations tour who try to win over those skeptical of Muslims, one audience at a time.
Broken Lizard has a way to go to match the absurdity and conceptual genius of Monty Python or Kids in the Hall, but Super Troopers has promising moments of oddity.
With its simplistic perspective, Long Way North risks being merely a nice gesture instead of a poetic, ice-breaking guide that points towards progress.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Dog metaphors prove to be only one of Jason Lew's problems, as his debut The Free World is riddled with more than a few unfortunate directorial choices.
More in-depth history report than a piece of art, Maya Angelou and Still I Rise is a collection of fascinating information without style.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While empathy is first to go in the tasteless When the Bough Breaks, there is nothing good in its place.
Even if Chan no longer wants to put his life at risk as a martial arts Buster Keaton, he still has the ability to turn a joke and get a gasp out of an action sequence.
The big problem throughout Uncle Kent 2 is that while it can offer some amusement, it all feels like an inside joke.
A very wise movie with brilliant performances and no answers, one that presents the impossible stability of love like scientific fact.
The humor of this rambling film runs dry to the point of unpalatable.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In its greatest achievement, the writing and directing of Tallulah articulates the intangible sacrifice and stresses of motherhood.
Debut writer/director Julian Branciforte eventually loses control of his tricky pitch, especially as his generic vision can't support the story with a distinct tone.
Whether joking about the shallowness of the fashion industry or veering to an inverted riff on Some Like It Hot, you can never say this romp doesn't go for it.
A movie that wants viewers to fondly laugh about surviving puberty, but is more concerned with horniness than cleverness.
Proves to be more layered than its promises of shenanigans may expect, especially as this is the rare sex comedy that doesn't glorify the male gaze.
While Gondry calms his creative instincts to toy with the ordinary, he indirectly errs on making "Microbe and Gasoline" his first forgettable film.
A welcome surprise for sports cinema, "The Phenom" handles itself like Robert Redford's "Ordinary People" when exploring the psychology of a Lebron James or Johnny Manziel-like sports sensation.
"Seoul Searching" is unforgettable in how it boldly presents adolescence, specifically here from a minority's perspective, not just as a life passage, but a type of performance.
Lacking personality or insight, "King Jack" is a ho-hum tale of young aggression-been there, bruised that.
In its distinct offering to a field of musician bio documentaries, Kerslake's film offers a raw body-and-soul tale of fighting addiction.
movie_title: As I AM: The Life and Times of DJ AM (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With profound results, "Pervert Park" is eye-opening about the lives of convicted sex offenders, as inspired by a degree of empathy we need not be afraid of.
The ambitions are there in Rønde's film and are exciting to witness, as is the evocative imagery. But "Bridgend" feels imbalanced.
The overall package is a bit scattered editorially, but it does serve a greater purpose: to share excitement about the Earth, and further stoke any interests in not destroying it.
In a sea of grimy indie Westerns, especially ones that started with the same genre canvas, "Outlaws & Angels" is a thoroughly ugly example of when "Tarantino-esque" is the most generous compliment.
Another global warming warning sign, more honorable in its intentions than in having a distinct voice to ultimately make a difference.
Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween made me more anxious.
This movie should be taught in film school-just as Hitchcock movies can teach filmmaking, so can their failed imitators provide us with elementary examples of when technique goes horribly wrong.
This movie is more than politics, just as much as it is more than poetry.
The Good Postman is the best kind of microcosm documentary, one that boasts an expansive worldview.
It's not a movie so much about idol culture as for it, with Miyake trying to knock idol culture back into reality.
The Zoolander 2 of global warming documentaries.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A big whiff of a Chilean dramedy that continues to only exist rather than barely amuse.
It's frustrating to watch a director take on so many ideas, but pursue none of them with clarity.
It's played out casually, never lunging for big laughs or revelations-and it charms often because it's cozy with just enough surprises.
It presents so many important images-racism, hatred and so much love-and dares you not to be moved.
Displays Palka's unique power as an actress while simultaneously showing her weaknesses as a writer.
Colossal is one of those movies with the amount of creativity that some directors never produce in their whole lives.
Strikingly ambitious, even when it can be as formal as a church service.
A loaded but effective piece of inspired artistry, including two sharp performances working from Mike White's tight script.
Inserting itself almost immediately into hip-hop movie history, this is a passionate restoration of Roxanne Shanté's story.
After struggling to find some narrative direction, the movie takes its shitty mixtape and lumbers toward a lazy climax.
With their second success, Howell & Robinson continue to treat mainstream log-lines with unique emotional and intellectual tenderness, offering a fresh take on our inherent need for closure.
With little to grab onto-and despite all that it offers-Railroad Tigers is far slower than a goofy action movie that mostly takes place on a locomotive should ever be.
For a human being who had to achieve so much through tried-and-true intellect, making President Obama into a symbol doesn't best serve his origin story.
For intimate narratives that are about incomplete or in-progress healing, and the elements of lives that are changed forever, the approach can feel too tidy.
A project that many history documentaries should aspire to, Blood on the Mountain has much to think about, learn from and never forget.
Foiled by a weak imagination and clear limits to its awareness, Rainbow Time doesn't become the strong feminist statement it wants to be.
In 80 minutes, Sky Ladder teaches you through sight, sound and dialogue about a new artistic language, while making you an expert on one of its masters.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Here's a reasonably-sized star vehicle that finds exciting purpose in presenting an existential crisis.
However far-fetched and theatrical Kingsman: The Secret Service may be, it's a tepid throwback.

Aside from being as funny as it is elementary, it will remind you of how this masterpiece character transcends age, and instill hope that he'll have more adventures before he can no longer leave his playhouse.
Even if an uncredited editor were hired to make clear sense of these pieces, the film wouldn't work.
A fantastic story that touches upon all-American notions of celebrity, redemption, family, justice, class, meme culture-all which came together with a kooky news segment.
A fantastic story that touches upon all-American notions of celebrity, redemption, family, justice, class, meme culture-all which came together with a kooky news segment.
A midnight movie for those fine with dozing off about twenty minutes in, once the charm of its single sentence log-line has worn off.
It's a smooth variation on the type of tale we've heard before, but especially with characters like these, it can still have something new to say.
Williams and director Dito Montiel are in tune with a pervading sense of tenderness, as the movie distinctly ruminates on connection, not love.

If a film based on author Nicholas Sparks' work is like an over-produced power ballad with a 128-piece orchestra, writer/director Ami Canaan Mann's "Jackie & Ryan" is the non-ironic acoustic guitar cover of the same tune.
Nachman's documentary does a great job of showing the many pieces that came into place for Miles' moment, but it doesn't look much at what's underneath it all.
Who said that a political film can't be sweet, too? In its grandest triumph, "The Yes Men Are Revolting" is an activist doc inspired by more than just its topical issues.
Lined by an amicable sense of dark humor and a sporadically amusing bloodlust, this hit-or-miss compilation could bring Halloween cheer to genre fans ...

Director Bill Pohlad's biopic Love & Mercy captures Wilson's singular mind at two ventures in his life, creating Pet Sounds and the Landy years, with filmmaking that's far more harmonious than its contrasting performances.
Equally bloated and scatterbrained.
A tale of mistaken killers and coincidence becomes tediously tangled in Kriv Stenders's Kill Me Three Times, a suicidal experiment with narrative.
...a bland salute wrapped within a tepid plot that also owes itself to Mike Nichols' The Graduate.
The Salt of the Earth is too stagnant on its own terms...
In spite of its generic plot and lead actor's blandness, Tracers has enough going for it to make it worth a look...
...3 Nights in the Desert is a thoroughly unpleasant homecoming of three friends getting the band back together...
...the ugly attitude within The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel is well-deserving of some humbling, especially as it strives to put people in their place, and not in a guest management way.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: ...even when Carolla is on-stage and performing with some type of emotional subtext, this definitely ain't Lenny.
As I am sure it will when the film stuns viewers beyond those at Sundance, Icarus relies on the element of surprise for one of its most rewarding attributes.
"Uncertain Terms" finds some substance within its ideology of evaporated ambitions, though there's plenty of empty space in which the film is still able to limit itself.
"What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy" wields a power that towers above many other small movies. It may not be the large definition of cinematic, but it is still a true film.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Entertainment completely owns the mundane, and gives it a new name.
For those looking for a sports film of basic quality and genuine narrative, "My All American" is definitively useless.

Unabashedly pro-choice, "Trapped" is not a debate itself, but it has no need to be. Taylor's film does not just have the law on its side, but extraordinary, human elements of character and compassion.
Mavis is by all definitions a rock star, but this is not a regular rock star documentary.

The movie fails to create a full character out of Doug beyond his disability and general social awkwardness. Mitte's broad performance matches filmmaking that paints a muddy picture of the hero's specific disability.
[This is] for the tiresome cynics who think that many films aren't about anything anymore, and would rather a film be definitively about something, than any good overall.
A movie (essentially) made by teenagers, with a teenager's intelligence, and for teenagers.
A LEGO Brickumentary is a business move, not a movie.
Relying on a flat center performance and horror cliches, the film is unable to think outside of its confines.
Ricki and the Flash proves to slack in the crowd-pleasing entertainment this exciting triumvirate is slumming for.
In its more sophisticated aspects, The Gift is the triumph of an acting-writing-directing triple threat who knows what an audience wants, but also just how much they need.
A Eurotrash hood movie, ineffectively placing a post-80s costume design and pastel color palette inside script elements as old as Mean Streets or something like Juice.
Return to Sender is an equally repulsive and dreadful movie that deserves to be more than spoiled -- it should be murdered, buried, and never discussed again.
Grandma is a crowd-pleaser potent with Tomlin's DNA, from the razor-sharp wit in dialogue to the way the movie itself speaks to sometimes pointed, but necessary ends.
No Escape is a visceral slice of anarchy that honors the terrifying unpredictability of violence.
Roth's charcoal sense of humor is missing, the cruel irony lacking its hellish zing.
How often do we see movies where characters are given the freedom to just walk and talk?
Thiago's film is a delightful showcase of gentle protagonists and their intricate yet seemingly breathless harmonies.
movie_title: This is Bossa Nova (Coisa Mais Linda: Histórias e Casos da Bossa Nova) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The ethereal essay provides a bounty of poetry, in the form of a measured narration by international treasure Tilda Swinton, and an extensively labored assembly of 200 black-and-white film clips.
A Dorff sideshow first and foremost, "American Hero" is far too casual with Melvin's character arc, and the appeal of superhuman abilities.
In the feat of any great storyteller, especially one who thinks outside of the rules, Silver maneuvers his story and characters to emotional climaxes with profound authenticity.
Berardini's doc vigorously proves that despite their marketing, Tasers are not the answer. They are only means to a bigger, deadlier problem.
movie_title: Killing Them Safely (Tom Swift And His Electric Rifle) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A hollow experience, emotionally stifled by its plotless nature and lack of any visual edge.
"Ktown Cowboys" often lacks an original voice or the wit for which it's aiming, especially regarding musings on friendship and identity.
The scenes with Manana's relatives are masterful presentations of family as an overwhelming experience.
A film with a subject that it achingly wants to share, but has little idea how to best talk about it.
The sporadic magic of The Polka King largely comes from its casting, and the hammy performances that follow.
Dano aces the formal requirements that make a good film. But there's so much that is great in this debut, and not enough that feels original.
Being in the same room with Nadia says enough in the very powerful On Her Shoulders, even when she is alone with her thoughts.
The Last Race captivates enough with its quiet moments, but its lyricism struggles to say much that is new or impactful.
Clara's Ghost more often feels directionless and tedious.
A shoulder shrug of a movie about a shoulder shrugging artist.
The movie peddles in paranoia, but is too tedious to make a lasting effect.
Hands down the best movie of its kind since Inside Llewyn Davis.
But for a movie that wants to tell you this unbelievable story about a smart guy, "The Catcher Was a Spy" shows its hand with faux-intellectualism.

Throughout the messy experience of "Yardie," [Idris] Elba's interest in storytelling gets ahead of his lacking visual instincts. Though I'm curious to see what story he tells next, Elba proves to not yet have an original voice behind the camera.
Nancy has an intellectual savviness to its sadness that works, as it challenges viewers on their compassion and ability to recognize something within someone who is so lost.

As if its sole goal was to take the heavyweight title of Nicolas Cage's Craziest Movie Ever, "Mandy" exhibits what Shakespeare called "vaulting ambition" in producing the nuttiest ways for Cage to get into one phantasmagorical showdown after the next.
Beyond Skyline tends to be goofy in the un-fun way.
This loving tribute of a documentary essentially aims to expand Sonia's audience.
Unless the ambition of Psychopaths is to motivate Michael Haneke to remake Funny Games for a second time, its efforts are gravely misplaced.
By the end of The Disaster Artist, Wiseau is still a joke.
In spite of its shortcomings, Destination Unknown has a cumulative power in upholding people who survived by believing in life and love.
It can be hard to disagree with the heart and events of this true tale, except for when the movie reveals itself to be mighty self-congratulatory.
movie_title: Same Kind of Different As Me (2017)

movie_review_blurb: About as close as documentaries come to putting us inside the mind of someone who society easily overlooks.

Chavela is presented as a grandiose enigma, the kind that inspires more research afterward and seeking out her music, but the film is too ordinary to feel like it does her legacy complete artistic justice.
A special kind of botched sci-fi film experiment.
Father Figures is not just painfully anti-charming, it is transparently desperate.
Burnham's accomplished debut offers plenty for viewers of all ages, along with a filmmaking vision that is well beyond many of his comedy peers.
The people in this story are flesh-and-blood examples of a tragic emotional Stockholm Syndrome that should not be. I just wish the story did more with them.
It's best when relying on its performers, as these men provide the type of inner debate that Monsters and Men too easily simplifies with its script.

While your comedic milage with its loose goofiness may vary, this movie succeeds in contributing a filmic time capsule that all generations need; Wobble Palace aptly shifts between cathartic and uncomfortable, but it's always recognizable.
Take Leto out of the picture and you have an even less noteworthy movie, a yakuza tale with an originality deficit.
While Hondros prevails with its intimate POV, it also makes for a wide-scope tribute to the profession of photojournalism.
Shot in the Dark truly takes viewers on an emotional journey, one in which there's so much to root for, on and off the court.
I can't give the film my most immediate recommendation, but for anyone concerned about the case of the missing modern buddy cop comedy, Detective Chinatown 2 is a noteworthy placeholder.
An inspired-enough take on a woman's horror, where the fear of losing her other baby becomes a terror itself, as expressed through an excellent performance.
The Cleaners prevails most by shining a light on those whose existence has all but been erased by a flawed system, all so that everyone else can still be heard on social media.
Though it is a slow burn, the doc is rewarding for the incredible, historic events captured within.
As a period film that's more than ready for 2018, Colette embodies the power of thinking forward in more ways than one.

Through her dedication to other people's lives, and with such open-book storytelling of her own, Greenfield is able to make a stunningly deeply resonant documentary about notions as seemingly obvious as the value of love over wealth itself.
Tan presents her multifaceted life story-vibrant, unbelievable, and full of such incredible women-as a dazzling tapestry that's unlike many narrative or documentary films.
An automatic type of action movie, often only challenging its predictability by getting goofier and goofier.
Skate Kitchen exists in a time when it's still not normalized for men to see women on skateboards, but the crystal clear coolness of Moselle's film proves they should get with the program.
[Helena Howard] is the center spectacle, and the movie plays like a fever dream inside her new, fascinating mind.
Displays the type of roller coater experience that can be achieved from crafty writing and a canvas as simple as a blank screen.
The film is best as a showcase of [Good and Hardwick's] talents, but only when it gives them something to say.
movie_title: A Boy. A Girl. A Dream. (2018)

movie_review_blurb: For a directorial vision that wants to challenge what we do and don't see, Eklof also adds complications to trauma that make Holiday a searing character study.
A little ditty of an indie romance, with scant lyricism to get stuck in your head.
Jim Hosking's An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn is terrible, but I bet the outtakes are incredible.
movie_title: An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Its narrative focus leans the movie toward having more of a white-savior complex, even though that does make Garrett Hedlund's portrayal of Burden a very complicated type of hero.
In its strongest passages, Monster is about establishing the humanity of a young black man. But it hardly expands beyond a timely Law & Order episode, albeit with more of a focus on racial politics.
Indivisible ponders, to a limited extent, what would happen to such siblings in a world that values celebrity, religion and sex to selfish ends.
To paraphrase Bill Murray's famous line from Tootsie, the long-delayed Tulip Fever is one nutty 17th century melodrama.
A strikingly tender handling of such a tough albeit totally human tale. The amount of empathy within Night Comes On is a spectacle itself.
Its limited point-of-view says enough to the original horror and poignantly makes humanity a non-political issue.
Hand-in-hand with its bleeding-heart nature, Collide has the ballsy idea of making a serious action movie about a fool in love, but that just becomes one of its many bungled stunts.
The three leads all give solid performances, it's just that the narrative puts their clear-cut dynamics on an expected dramatic course.
A family adventure of the classic variety, with fresh talent in control, especially director Freeland.
Dayveon stands out with its vision, regional flavor and overall personality.
A gorgeous ode to everyone's inner screw-up.
An instant classic that specifically feels like a product of 2017, the kind of bizarre culture treatise that could only come from fresh talent.
An example of a survival movie that just isn't dangerous enough.
It's thrilling to see such an original, mature story seek to fill its big heart with poetry.
movie_title: I Dream in Another Language (Sueño en otro idioma) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Cracks the code of how to make a documentary about a specific cause that connects with viewers, making them share the filmmakers' passion in the process.
Never feels like more than a malnourished Adam McKay movie that lacks even in laughs.
Heineman pulls no punches on showing the brutality that is enacted by the radical group, and it makes for an extremely effective doc with such a personal core.
[Gook] has the air of someone working through ideas, but damn if you can't see the passion in every single frame of this movie.
Once it sheds the immediate air of imitation, L.A. Times vastly improves and even becomes charming.
Haley's movie is marred by a clear limit to its poetry, and the way it has little tact with references to the title star.

Former high-schoolers might be a bit bored by the movie's ultimate goal of teaching a lesson, but for the viewers that need this type of story, I can't deny its strong articulation of a worthy message.
To the Bone has a concrete sense of place, people and perspective, all of which makes the movie stronger than its faults.
The rare comedy-one of a very special sense of humor and a big heart-that has the ability to connect with anyone wondering what else is out there.
As the story works visually but becomes emotionally incomprehensive, Bragança proves that he's far more of a filmmaker than a storyteller.
movie_title: Don't Swallow My Heart, Alligator Girl! (Não Devore Meu Coração) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A political thriller based on a true story, but it needs the real life context to give it some energy (usually, it's the other way around).
I Do... Until I Don't marks a strange turn from the characteristic creativity of Bell's previous efforts. It isn't as painful as breaking up, but it gets close.
A tribute to freedom of speech in journalism, and also its eulogy.
movie_title: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While Suntan is more than just a tale about an older man becoming involved with a younger woman, it's unfortunately not as profound when it later claims to be a statement on the movie you think you're watching.
A special documentary that gives you a great sense of the personal questions that its filmmaker, and his family, will be wrestling with for many kitchen table conversations to come.
In spite of the technical and emotional exercise that this becomes for Smith, it comes off as amateur, a stream of conscious journal entry without an established voice.
The Queen of Spain can only offer scant entertainment for movie buffs and non-movie buffs alike.
movie_title: The Queen of Spain (La reina de España) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A busy, precious epic of profoundly limited imagination, where it doesn't have a vision so much as a shiny color palette.
A low-key trippy sci-fi movie about booty calls with an unwieldy space squid, but I wish I could say it was much more than that.
As a piece of entertainment that primarily aims to distract and delight, it's can't-pass-up goofiness.
With a movie like this, it's hard to tell where the good idea ran out, as it seems to have been lost many drafts ago.
There's always something to ponder with this film, which gets stranger and more polarizing as it goes along.
All Eyez on Me is one of the most useless music biopics ever made-it'll be too confusing for newcomers and too underwhelming for those familiar with the work and the life of rap prophet Tupac Shakur.

As it becomes so busy without anything interesting to say, this extreme operation only unwittingly embodies the vacuousness of energy drink marketing.
Hermia & Helena presents a unique anomaly -- it's able to capture life at its most low-key but still manages to exemplify style over substance.
Treat-sized food-for-thought from a wonderfully silly director.
An example of both the compelling passion and polarizing fallibility that can arise when a director works primarily from the heart.
An incredibly tactful tragicomedy from debut writer/director Asaph Polonsky.
movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's Tramps' attitude to be short and sweet that proves definitive, vital.
A compelling emotional display, one that captures masculinity at its most innocent and leads to profound displays of compassion.
Looking just like a dressed-up Neil Breen joint, Salt and Fire becomes, at its best, Herzog's version of camp; at its worst, unwitting self-parody.
Only worthwhile storytellers could take an elevator pitch like this one (the last two people on Earth) and produce long-lasting curiosity about its inherent beauty and horror.
Walk with Me makes for a unique documentary spectacle, especially as it explores the power of silence and clarity.
A charming look at a group of people and fading tradition we may not have heard about otherwise.
Assuredly, and productively, a project made from the modern persona of Nye.
The special kind of history project that can expand your film knowledge as much as it might warm your heart.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One of those sparse projects where you wonder what excited the filmmakers through each stage of the production process, and why the answer to that question isn't more obvious.
I didn't like the movie enough to wonder about it too long.
A warm and curiously engaging film despite many flaws and the sloppiness of its construction.
Quentin Tarantino is starting to remind me of late-stage Kubrick.
You wanted some three-act plot structure with your movie? Sorry, they only serve straight adrenaline and dread here.

For me, that low-tech, Fifties, camp charm wore a mite thin by the second half-hour, but then, I'm not the target audience, am I?

Unless you are taking a child, there is absolutely no reason you should put yourself through this almost perfectly mindless exercise in canine celebration (exception: if your favorite comic strip is Marmaduke, this may be the movie for you).
This may be the grimmest movie I've ever seen.
[A] beautiful, complex, massively layered adaptation of the Alberto Moravia novel.

Visconti returns to Milan, the city of his birth, in this story about the politics of class involved in the move to the big city of a family of impoverished southerners.

Clash of the Titans is and always will be a thoroughly entertaining film.
Batman Vs. Two-Face is a very entertaining piece of animation, it has all the hallmarks of the '60s series, the performers are on top form.

Nice as it would be to report that Ang and his co-writer/producer James Schamus had regenerated the summer blockbuster, we gotta poop the party.
Not a complicated film, but warm and clever.
Gag by gag -- and there's a stream -- it's merrily irreverent, visually and vocally. The bigger picture, though, is rather more conventional.
Writers Ganz and Mandell go pleasingly light on the syrup and sentimentality.
Cohen keeps the vehicle cruising in fourth gear, hoping the audience won't get too impatient with the familiar scenery. Big, efficient, mindless entertainment.
You're left with flashes of mis-spent promise: the feline mysticism; the cosmetics-industry intrigue; the idea of electrocuting Lambert Wilson's unctious corporate cad.
There's little noteworthy.
It's Tom Stoppard's witty, intelligent script which proves so satisfying.

Charmless, sexless, passionless and robot-humoured, it's preposterously uninvolving.

movie_review_blurb: Few people can be so big-hearted as to tolerate Ed's agonizing brand of pedantic humour.
A veneer of potty mouth barely buffs the surface of this vanilla romantic comedy from Compton writer-director Van Elder.
A merry analogist, Makhmalbaf draws a wealth of parallels, between ages and eras, hopes and fears.
If you can separate yourself from the buzz of higher-pitch cinema, the film's beauty, wit and charm come as a breath of fresh air.
It's stark, daring and often astoundingly dynamic.
