From the standpoints of technique, interpretation, cultural sensitivity, and narrative integrity, Maria Full of Grace is an astute and unforgettable work.
They never lived anywhere: the protagonists of this drama of marital stalemate embody a widespread social institution without ever reminding us of Earth as we know it.
This basic dichotomy of honest, urgent intentions and desultory, cheapskate expression marks OutFoxed from a fairly early moment and never really changes.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Plays, hilariously, like Revenge of the Nerds directed by David Gordon Green... It's legitimately funny and fresh, and it doesn't glom onto any obvious formula.
Shaun of the Dead is either a zombie flick masking as a comedy, or a comedy masking as a zombie flick, or Beautiful Girls masking as a zombie comedy.
It's dispiriting to see such a pandering and clunkily written picture get so puffed up with a belief in its own integrity; the movie has a Shins CD where its heart should be.
Going Upriver is lucky enough to have at its disposal a genuinely charismatic figure whose sense of his own citizenship is rigorous, questioning, and articulate.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Motorcycle Diaries progresses from a film that's too eager to please into a document that's too wise to settle all of our questions or silence all of our longings.
Noujaim has done better than most of us at being in the right places at the right times to catch the imperial machinery in its most vulnerable, damning moments.

An ideal movie for DVD: you can pick and choose moments and lines to revisit while ignoring, or trying to ignore, the thematic compromises, hectoring impulses, and structural handicaps that start to engulf the film.
Elegantly shot, admirably acted, and well-scored... but when The Sixth Sense leaves the character-study path, its weaknesses and essential arrogance are most obvious.
Dawn of the Dead feels well-plotted, well-designed, and well-executed, the best American movie from Spring 2004 short of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.
I guess 1929 audiences knew a stinker when they saw one coming. There is very little to criticize in Coquette, because there is so little in it, period.
The great neglected movie of 2003, a rambunctious, provocative, genre-defying, and constantly surprising experiment.
So inoffensive and so insignificant, it makes you wonder why a film version of Emmet Lavery's play was either desired or delivered...there's just no apparent motive.
A stunning and deceptively sophisticated picture...squarely in the tradition of Brecht. Monster deserves to keep winning awards, but the film is the real treasure.
The style and mode are a little too heterogeneous to come together right, even though some images have a pared-down majesty, and the main line of the film is tough.
When Iris catches its main character's disease, our opportunities for edification are needlessly but summarily forfeited.
A film whose signal virtues are its focus and inherent tension still manages to trip itself up in a clutter of gratuitous details and easily avoidable blunders.
Gibson hews to a style that is visually elaborate without ever being visually complicated, scraping away the traces of any irony or dimension from every shot, every scene.
Shock Corridor undercuts its own authority by ham-fisting its protests into a banal plot structure and a totally undisciplined tonal register.
The Ladykillers just feels indulgent, without imparting any notion of whom it might be indulging. Everyone in it looks as though they're punching a timecard.
Ingmar Bergman's own little Tempest in a teapot... Hardly light material, but it's pretty frisky stuff for Bergman.
Character arcs leap, plunge, spiral, and tie themselves into knots, yet somehow they still emerge as definable arcs, with real emotional punch... A rare and precious thing.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This is a warm movie told in the temperature of almost-recognizable life; it's a believable love story, joked up a bit but not too much.
For a movie with such bold visual designs and high-flown rhetorical ambitions, it seems almost reactionary to say that it works because the performances are so good.
What Dumont expresses is too guttural and inchoate to even be called despair. It's not there yet, or else it's way past that.
The film has a kind of airless, artificial quality that made it seem much longer than it actually was.
Simultaneously slick and sloppy....For all of The Mission's back-to-nature trappings, it's actually a perfect film for the Reagan-and-Thatcher era that produced it.
The Bourne Supremacy is an exceptional thriller that is a sequel to a good one... Power runs through every frame, making the smallness of the world itself seem scary.
Grace isn't a confident or resourceful enough actor to withstand the film's lopsided focus on Tad, or Duhamel's unexpectedly warm and cheerful presence.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Lange is wonderful, and provides a searing, tremendous reason to see a film that would otherwise collapse under even a moment of analytical pressure.
What will this studio think of next? A remake of The Red Balloon set in Tikrit? How about Sunday in the Park with George relocated to Guantánamo?
Reader, I laughed and laughed... It took two tries to get the recipe right, but the Shrek franchise is finally about real beauty.
A put-on disguised as a turn-on, but a healthy reminder that the work of a brilliant director can be enthralling to watch even when he hasn't fully decided what he's doing.
A hulking tyrannosaur of a movie, lusty and fierce, crashing around for all the world to see, majestic in its size and scope though it's also an instant anachronism.
Osama manages to surprise you with its story, even though we have no right to be surprised....Already ranks among the best films of the year.
It's like Deep Impact as made by Michael Moore, and that's a good thing, or a good enough thing.
A stirring but self-contradictory movie, a valuable time capsule as well as a supercilious party trick, a once-in-a-lifetime phenom as well as a missed opportunity.
I was aglow after The Travelling Players, which honestly strikes me, in all its alienation and opacity, as a thrilling and important and good motion picture.
A genuinely creepy thriller, humble in scope and lacking some polish, but executed with ghoulish intuition.
A gutsy, surprising piece of work, a bold political tract that doubles proficiently as an interpersonal drama.
Troy panders to the viewer and flatters the Academy as baldly as Cold Mountain did last year, and to exactly the same unwitting effect.
The Stepford Wives willingly dispenses with a strong conceit in its unbridled urge to be ridiculous, taken here as a synonym of "entertaining."
At its worst, the film prioritizes its own seriousness (which it never achieves anyway) over any form of audience appeal (which is the best this material can aspire to).
If Russell is erratic with plot and the slightest bit smug in attitude, he makes up for these flaws by drawing fun, inspired performances from his ace cast.
You know the movie is bound to be swill: imperialist daydreams indigestibly stewed together with limp Oedipal anxiety and unpersuasive pacifist lip service.
Shame draws the rutted map of war's psychology, in bold and grievous strokes recognizable to any audience, and liable to frighten and humble them all.
An adult vision of two complicated people converging, finding an ointment but not a cure for the ways in which they have been hurt.
Even with its limping screenplay and general drift toward competence rather than excellence, Birdman does pull us well enough into its fistful of compelling characters.
Contrary to the most famous nugget of showbiz wisdom, the movie leaves us wanting considerably less than we're given.
Silkwood achieves impressive credentials as a drama of human character, not just as a screed against intolerable public practice.
As The Descent draws to its close, or rather shreiks to a halt, you may well admire how many thematic reads the movie has kept in play.
Stettner keeps using Donna's evident disabilities, both physical and psychic, as opportunities for schlocky thrills.
These Hills might have eyes, but they could have used some brains, or at least a steadier hand and a less contemptible sensibility to guide the grisly proceedings.
The best bad movie of the year so far, or the worst interesting movie...certainly the most esoterically constructed blockbuster that ever donned a $150-million price tag.
The patchy, overly earnest screenplay as well as the typically shapeless direction of William Dieterle keep calcifying the movie into an arid diorama.
When you absolutely, positively got to thrill every mother****er in the room, accept no substitutes. Jackie Brown is the AK-47 in Tarantino's arsenal.
The Hours totally engrosses me... It somehow deepens the [book's] themes to see the bodies, scrutinize the faces, smell the money, feel the flatness of the screen.
The climax retains its inchoate power, throwing you off balance.... From the glittering heap of a failed film rises the zesty aftertaste of something unexpectedly special.
Has a spirit and an ostensible shapelessness that are pure Cassavetes, enveloping a script that only seems to reach for the precise calculations of 1930s screwball comedy.
A film of Artaudian cruelty, and a boundary-breaker in the cinema's exploration of its own erotic and artisanal id.
Never makes a case that Reeves' death is worth probing, or even mourning; as on Superman, his humanity is utterly stifled by lousy production values and unrewarding stunts.
The backloading of the film's intelligence isn't sufficient reward for having made it through 100 minutes of capricious indulgence.
The obvious, meticulous deliberation with which Ceylan has framed his images and timed his edits does not conceal the banality of what he produces.
An unusually patient and good-natured portrait of rural/urban crossover...of clinical, spiritual, and popular perspectives, of romance and absurdity and barely voiced grief.
These questions are richer than they might have been in Hud because Newman...creates Hud as a sum of conscious choices, not an animal or an icon.
Thematic ambivalence and episodic structure start to feel like major virtues: Cool Hand Luke is one of our most lived-in and pleasurably paced odes to nonconformity.
Singleton strips his art of almost all ambiguity in the service of thematic and emotional and political transparency.... A tragic purgation of pity, anger, and fear.
A web of death-drives, false devotions, lofty pretenses, auto-plagiarisms, sound but inarticulate craftsmanship, and lowest-common-denominator provisions of trauma as entertainment.
Black Snake Moan finally, is a comedy of faith and faithlessness, in their religious and also their sexual dimensions...A consummate act of jerking our collective chain, and making us love it.
Breach builds toward a few crucial moments where we get inside the mind of a turncoat long enough to sense his arrogance as well as his acrid despair.
The formal mechanisms are so obvious and impersonal that they flatten our modes of thinking and feeling almost as much as the propaganda films that a regime like East Germany's would have approved.
As it happens, not all dogs to to heaven. Some go straight to hell, and Alpha Dog gets there faster and stays there longer than most.
Beautiful and engaging, if factually dubious... Built, shot, and scripted to entertain literally anyone, from a 4-year-old to a nonagenarian member of its own original audience.
movie_title: Chang: A Drama of the Wilderness (1927)

movie_review_blurb: The film is simply too inconsistent in its writing and inadequate in its playing to click with an audience, or even to click with itself.
The movie makes the characters worse than enigmas; it makes them the last people imaginable from which you expect or even desire to learn anything.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Plays as a veritable autopsy of itself; to watch the movie is to watch it go wrong, to observe the tempting gleam of the film that might have been grow ever dimmer.
Trite and opportunistic in its feints at intellectual weight... Best, in fact, to mine from the crumbly ore of Vacancy a drinking game plated in gold.
It's the Lord of the Rings of modern documentaries: epic, vivid, wise, well-paced, expansive%u2014the kind of movie that makes you want to do more with your life.
An arresting and lucid study of how gay men and straight women often compete for the same objects of lust, the same velvety nostalgias for a certain vision of love.
Wholly absorbing... subtly trapping us in the perspective of a beleaguered protagonist, who himself is trapped in an inchoate state of grief and fantasy.
Like a quiet child whose primary virtue is that he doesn't make any waves, Tender Mercies is so muted and obedient that it's hard in good conscience to praise it.
At all moments, Ray is a blend of the workmanlike with the unresolved, the piquant and the tendentious, the stuff that do right and the stuff that do wrong.
Vera Drake is soul-stirringly good, but it's occasionally a little overt in staging its themes and insights.
I can't tell whether the last sequence is part of the storyline or if it's footage from the wrap party; in either case, I can only report that we aren't really invited.
Of course I liked it a lot, I almost loved it. I mean, I often felt like I loved it, but I'm not sure I really did or I'm not sure why. It's, like, a hard movie to argue with.
M$B sometimes recalls a silent movie where the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune play out in a concentrated circle of light that goes opaque around the edges.
The best thing about the film is also its most nagging liability, which is its absolute commitment to the addled past and continued unwellness of Bruce Wayne.
The laconic minimalism never seemed piquant or probing to me; it just feels minimal, except in its moments of creaky exposition and frustratingly overt finger-pointing.
More than a curio.... The awkward style and portentous structure of Nichols' film astonishes possess an integritiy that commands attention. Formidable, and memorable.
Nothing comes alive at you. Nothing roots us to the Delaneys, and in turn nothing grounds them in any world except that of Inge's creaky schemata.
The film is much more interesting for its traces of Davis' own future roles and images than for its decoy status as a GWTW consolation prize.
Persuasively alive... The movie is sufficiently at odds with itself to be both frustrating and intriguing.
However eager to entertain and even to model some ways of living life, the film doesn't wheedle us for our love or our devotion, and perhaps for that reason, it earns both.
There are reasons why The Exorcism of Emily Rose works as well as it does, and why it recovers itself rather capably even when its foundations start to shake.
The delicate insinuations of competing amorous and cultural allegiances provide the movie with some of its best and most technically assured sequences.
The modern age is not the death of sex or friendship, and perhaps art and love will also survive, but they need to be recognized in new ways, hustled up from often unpromising elements.
movie_title: Les Rendez-vous d'Anna (The Meetings of Anna) (1978)

movie_review_blurb: The conception doesn't work perfectly.... Still, the film is muscular, persuasive, and necessary without being exploitative.
For all of the film's ambitions and technical complexity, and for all the apt reasoning behind its storytelling decisions, the narrative is never particularly engrossing.
Breaks new ground in Shyamalan's cinema of looniness....The present of the movie is never interesting; meanwhile, its past is never illuminated and its future never arrives.
The city becomes a living emblem of the tense coexistence of art and corporatism, an uneasy relationship which Almereyda emphasizes as the core conflict of his picture.
Exemplifies its own themes of honest diligence and warm-hearted communalism, making it much more memorable than some grander, fussier productions of the same period.
Satisfied neither to be honestly frivolous or sincerely ambitious, Same Time, Next Year winds up giving a bad name both to comedy and to drama.
Like Shaun of the Dead as rewritten by Eugène Ionesco.... Has the surface qualities of a spoof, but none of its comfy core.
movie_title: Dellamorte Dellamore (Cemetery Man) (Demons '95) (Of Death, of Love) (1996)

movie_review_blurb: You can watch Bullets Over Broadway with the sound off and have a thrilling time. You can listen to it from the next room and achieve total bliss.
Macdonald seems to continue the pattern of hiding the soil and fertilizing process of political crime beneath the more obvious sights and symptoms of that crime's most putrid expressions.

Paradise Now gets a little frantic and lost near the end, which is infinitely preferable to the bourgeois accessibility of its beginning. I would love for the film to have gone much further, cut deeper.
The film spooks you: you have to give it that, and it makes a powerful case, if only by default, that we've already lost our mutual endgame with capital and treachery.
A serious historical epic that boldly remanages the usual priorities of that form, and a fractured family saga that, at least in my experience, accumulates power as it continues.
movie_title: Trilogia: To livadi pou dakryzei (The Weeping Meadow) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A stout, muscly heart of a movie whose rhythmic, colossal beats are echoed by murmurs of plangent nostalgia, both for the original movie and, in an odd way, for itself.
Operates not from the vantage of social critique but of utter evasion: the sacralization of the filmmakers' own ignorance.
Chronically Metropolitan is a quirky romantic indie about life in New York City; though not perfect, it's reasonably enjoyable.
The film's fantastic eye for detail, both in its writing and visuals, makes this a rich, invigorating and ultimately extremely moving experience.
Samuell's naivety and inexperience lead to this being an uncomfortable, if intriguing, mess.
Director Julie Bertucelli's film works so well because of its adherence to the basics of good writing and strong acting.
Not only a celebration of the body, but also of the moving image and its unifying power.
Vibrant, visually exciting and emotionally resonant.
As involving and intellectually rich as all Tarkovsky's work.
A gripping and disturbing ride, it marks out Woolcock as a major talent for the future.
Anyone stumbling into the cinema halfway through would think they were watching a documentary, as Manic dispenses with all cinematic flourishes, instead aiming for and achieving absolute realism.
Massively throwaway, but funnier and more likable than the first entry. Mainly that's due to an A-list pairing that's as inspired as it is demented.

While not a disaster, this isn't the claws-out, rampaging adventure we hoped for. No-one cares where Wolverine found his jacket - a spin-off with him kicking ass in Japan would have been way more fun.
A super-sized second helping, but the novelty factor and some of the charm's gone. Hey, at least there's more Megatron / Starscream squabbling this time round.
The novelty factor stops and starts at the 3-D specs: this is a horror movie on tracks, not going anyplace new. Still, there's some inventive grue-splashing as always.
Fox is fun as a demonic harpy, but sadly the meeting of Hollywood's two rock'n'roll queens is closer to safe studio product than slash-and-burn envelope-pusher.
Heralds the launch of a new big-screen comedy axis to challenge Wright, Pegg and Frost - we can't wait to see what King and co. come up with next.
Miyazaki's back, and still a force of nature. A weird, wonderful aquatic romp, Ponyo is also a meditation on the state of this blue planet. Catch it.
Could have been T2 with seraphs, or Assault On Precinct 13 crossed with Revelations. Instead, it's a lazy genre bore. Doesn't bode well for Priest, the next Stewart/Bettany film in the pipeline.
With flying pigs and magical nannying, this will charm children -- but it could have been a little more charming for adults.
Carell and Fey are good company and work hard, but this is still a formulaic tale that will look most at home on the back of an airplane seat. In other words, A Shawn Levy Film.
Rourke and Rockwell make satisfying, complementary villains, while Downey Jr. delivers again. Shame this sequel feels inessential.
Often inspired but patchy overall, Ferrell's horse opera could have benefited from a sharper, even more out-there script.
More Pistachio Disguisey than Austin Powers, this cheapjack comedy is nowhere near as ingenious as the man it sends up.
Smug and lazy comedy that barely raises a chuckle.
A brutally intense indie that commits to its bleak premise and doesn't back down. Tarantino will cackle as he watches.
A triumph of art direction, sound design and Gallic phat beats, but could do with a script upgrade and fun.exe patch.
A gross-out comedy to make the Jackass posse look like clergyman. If only it was actually funny.
Workmanlike suspenser, with plenty of cold water but sparse chills. When it comes to James Cameron scuba thrillers, The Abyss still has the edge.
The wee'uns may enjoy the forest-based capers but for adults this is no pickernick.
One of those sunny-natured indie comedies that comes out of nowhere to put a smile on your face.
This episode has the highest velocity and lowest IQ yet. See it on the biggest, loudest, dumbest screen you can find.
According to Phillips, the 'Part II' in the title is a nod to the second Godfather, which matched the genius of its forerunner. Ironically, his own sequel offer is one you should refuse.
Some sparks of comedy and fun but largely a flat and unrewarding comedy.
Despite the promise of the title, this a fairly stale offering, plodding through the beats of a well-worn subgenre but failing to add much more than a foul mouth.
The execution is second to none; taut, claustrophobic and overwhelming.
A welcome return to form for Eddie Murphy and an even-more-welcome turn by the ever-excellent Alan Alda.
Carnahan's best work since Narc, with a powerhouse performance by Neeson and real emotional heft.
As you'd imagine this is not exactly a laugh a minute, but whilst a little shapeless in places, it manages to engage and inform on many levels.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The first and third acts are over-busy; the middle one moves like an arthritic house-elf. Still, a decent smattering of magic moments and tension's pumped up sky-high. Bring on Part 2.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of Hollywood's forgotten masters and one of its brightest new actresses team for what could well be an Oscar wild card.
Believe the bad buzz on this houseflies-become-astronauts CG animation, which is lousy with lazy jokes and irritating characters.
The script really should have been given a trim, as it tries to cram in so many characters that few are given the time and space to develop.
A self-absorbed sugar rush of a movie, this might please small girls but will leave a sour taste in everyone else's mouth.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The banter is tighter and funnier, and Calvin's musings on the importance of community seem more heartfelt.
The big screen adds extra impact to inspiring images which capture all the brutality, camaraderie and absurdity of the ocean.
It's undoubtedly good-natured, old-fashioned family entertainment, but Two Brothers never quite manages to strike a successful balance between fantasy and reality.
The laidback stars are funny and sweet, but they're let down by a patchy script which squanders some potentially priceless set-ups.
A sharp documentary that has comedy, tragedy and, yes, a glimpse of Linda Lovelace's party trick.
Like its title (will there be a worse one this year?), Lucky Number Slevin isn't as clever as it thinks it is.
O'Donnell should be lauded for offering a sensitive portrayal of disabled people without ever being patronizing.
You'll soon be sick of digital furballs, but there's plenty of fun here - and Hammy is up there with Ice Age's Scrat in the pantheon of lunatic movie rodents.
Very puerile humour and a pretty lame storyline.
This is an intense, stripped-down ride that goes places you'd never expect. Edgy and outrageous, it should get the fearless Statham some deserved attention.
More Shadow Conspiracy than In The Line Of Fire, this suffers from serious quality control issues. If you're looking for superior suspense, buy a 24 box set instead.
A warm-hearted, smutty comedy that, if predictable, has a likeable cast and plenty of zip.
Almost disturbingly unfunny.
Formula rules, as Ferrell applies his schtick to another sport. But there's enough silly spectacle and eye-popping costumes to compensate.
This stripped-down chiller has some decent jump-frights, but a dearth of memorable moments.
Like Lethal Weapon, this franchise has become lazier and less thrilling with each instalment. Hopefully, unlike Lethal Weapon, they'll stop at Part Three.
Not up there with the best King adaptations, but a fun Gothic yarn that, like all good ghost stories, is simple and dripping with dread.
Well worth checking out, then, if you like your comedy supremely silly, but ultimately memorable only as a series of great skits mixed in with some dead patches.
While this is the Grindhouse film that suffers most from being presented solo, it's still the most fun. Watch with beer in hand and tongue in cheek for optimal effect.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Frightfest regulars and hungry gorehounds will get a kick out of this, but those who hailed Williams as a Brit-indie visionary after London To Brighton might be left scratching their heads.
The Karate Kid meets Fight Club but it's no way near as good as it sounds.
A tropical sex comedy that's a little unfocused, but Segal and co throw plenty of funniness at the wall - and most of it sticks.
The directing's lazy, the love interest is a smarmy douche and the dialogue is flatter than Winstead's toned tummy.
An unlikely buddy comedy that comes to life whenever Kingsley appears - he doesn't so much steal the show as roll it into a fat blunt and smoke it.
Some of the tension drains from a slow middle act, but it remains a gripping tale of sleuth-work and moral awakening.
A satisfying mix of puerile humour and genuine satire, believe it or not.
A huge, bulging disappointment.
Some nice comic beats and a sinister Andy Garcia turn make this far more watchable that the fratty conceit might suggest.
The first one offered the novel sight of Oskar Schindler going Commando. Unfortunately, this half-hearted sequel is low on novelty and lower on fun.
It has a strong, game cast but this is karaoke filmmaking, trading on nostalgia rather than breaking new territory. Affable but forgettable.
There are moments that make the whole enterprise worthwhile, and introduces an intriguing new Batman. But it's also cluttered and narratively wonky; a few jokes wouldn't have gone amiss, either.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It strives to be a rousing tale of rebellion, but the over-earnest result is more slow shuffle than kicky capoeira.
An absolute blast, with a frenetic strike-rate and songs that will worm their way into your ears for days. Like Conner, this comedy's for real.
It sounded like the dumbest movie of all time, but it's actually smart, subversive and packed with famous voices saying wonderfully unspeakable things. In fact, it's a banger.
A thinking person's Bad Boys, this off-kilter indie crime comedy introduces two deliriously warped lawmen to the screen. Here's to a Cuba-invading sequel.
A crowd-pleasing oceanic musical with big tunes and beguiling characters, Moana is likely to thwack a big smile on your face.
Essentially Parabolas & Prejudice, it isn't the most nuanced piece of work out this month. But nuance be damned - an uplifting plea for equality, this is a story calibrated for maximum effect.
Those who predicted this wouldn't hold a talking candle to the animated original will be pleasantly surprised. The tale may be as old as time, but it's retold with freshness, brio and flair.
Even if this wasn't the third Smurfs movie from Sony in seven years, it would feel uninspired, with a first-base plot and nondescript animation.
Made on a budget that would just about cover Kong's left bicep, Colossal is cool, smart filmmaking, with plot developments that will be talked about for a long time to come.
The mark Baywatch should be aiming for is 21 Jump Street. Bad news: it's ended up more like 21 Chump Street.
This is a misshapen venture, a horror-comedy without much in the way of laughs or scares.
The characters and scenarios are familiar, but this is a loose, cool, funny remix that makes them feel fresh again. Plus, it's mercifully short on life lessons from Aunt May.
Iannucci's brand of political satire is applied to one of the darkest chapters in modern history, with sensational results.
Given the story is based on reality, it's understandable why the makers of 6 Below didn't want to throw in embellishments, but a bear attack really wouldn't have gone amiss.
An ultraviolent Korean crime film with plenty of swagger and visual brio, but still too generic to really stand out from the pack.
The lesser of 2017's two Wonder Woman movies, this attempt to explore a complex three-sided relationship is let down by bland storytelling.
Powered by a taciturn, soulful performance by its young star, this meditation on fear, shame and sexual repression packs a wallop.
A film about a cult that might well attract a cult following itself. But it's only moderately successful, with the early scenes hinting at a bolder, more satisfying tale that could have been.
Two men in their 80s power the month's most pulse-pounding thriller. Who could have seen that coming?
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A droll and vigorous psychological study of an everyday egomaniac, but we've seen Stiller do this sort of thing before, and better.
A well-meaning look at the issue of arranged marriage, garnished with some Hollywood star power, but it's too meandering and sluggish to grip.

If you're playing Wes Anderson bingo, you can tick off 'droll whimsy', 'visual pizzazz' and 'Bill Murray'. Yet, thanks to the Far East setting and a rollicking story, this is a fun and fresh-feeling experience.
As satire, it's hit and miss; as a Nicolas Cage mayhem delivery system, it's highly effective.
An exhilarating, audacious, lunatic rocket-ride. Hop on board.
Effectively one enormous, stunningly rendered and thunderously intense set-piece stretched to feature-length, Dunkirk thrusts you into a pressure cooker and slams the lid on.
Stream at your peril.
Spies, terrorists, remote-controlled bombs... Unlocked's components are all too familiar, and it doesn't put nearly enough effort into making them feel fresh.
Shyamalan finds freshness in familiar horror tropes. After some big budget misfires, it's great to see him go back to his smaller, scarier roots.
Sean Penn's not been this fun since Jeff Spicoli and there's plenty of rip-roaring action, but Gangster Squad proves a minor entry in the annals of LA noir.
DiCaprio's raw performance helps elevate what could have been just another man-versus-nature drama, The Edge with furry hats, into a powerful ode to resilience. But this is Iñárritu's show.
Long-delayed. Arguably not long enough.
A grippingly brutal first act and strong cast can't stop this turning into a Steven Seagal film well before the end.
Black proves the perfect blacksmith, forging smart new tech and scenarios for the swaggering super-genius. If this does turn out to be Downey Jr.'s final solo outing, it's a very strong exit.
This nightmarish travelogue is coy about gore, but it's still an effective thrill-ride.
Lincoln meets Sudden Death: a corny but raucous throwback to when Planet Hollywood was hip.
If you want to see Paul Giamatti as a snail - and who doesn't - you've come to the right place.
Flat as day-old beer.
Another to airbrush out of the De Niro back catalogue.
Middle-earth's got its mojo back. A huge improvement on the previous instalment, this takes our adventurers into uncharted territory and delivers spectacle by the ton.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An idea that must have sounded good on paper looks a lot less smart on the screen.
Frost's solo movie lacks the inventive madness of his Cornetto team-ups, but it's still a heartfelt blast of fun.
This movie's title, translated from the director's native language, means "No, stop." Which is apt.
Get through the plot and you'll be rewarded with 30 minutes of whirligig mayhem.
What we do get here is largely fantastic, not only re-energising old-favourite characters but introducing intriguing new ones.
A bulkier, slower beast than Evans' first film. But when it enters combat mode, it's more raucously bloodthirsty than anything you've ever seen.
Do the right thing - take a break from summer spectacle to check out this assured and eloquent indie.
Messy and unlikeable.
A disappointingly tame and unimaginative effort, which throws away much of what was best-loved about the original and fails to find worthy replacements.
Full-force performance form Ryan Reynolds but not as funny as it hopes it is.

This is maximum-gloss entertainment with its fair share of tricksy rug-pulls. But, like one of the neon-coloured cocktails Smith drinks in it, it's more of an immediate rush than something you'll remember in a year.
There's a certain thrill to seeing humans face off against Frogger. If only as much care had been put into the living characters as the pixelated ones.
A clear-eyed celebration of a giant of film writing. We'll refrain from the thumb jokes, but consider this a hearty recommendation.
Here's 74 minutes well spent.
Some inspired grace notes elevate a thriller that's more De Palma than Hitchcock.
The action's bigger, Ice Cube's angrier. Another silly treat.
Overlong and underpopulated with gags that really land, there's still moments of mirth for devotees of the original.
This may not be Aronofsky's most accomplished or original film, but it is a visceral and visionary take on an exciting and under-explored genre.
The film is undeniably his [Cianfrance], and yet it is so powerfully enriched by the output of his extraordinary stars.

This is not so much a dramatic narrative as a portrait of an artist as a young(ish) man. It is a story reminding us that stories don't really exist, and not even movie stars in Hollywood are living the fairytale lives we see on screen.
This is not a film that takes itself too seriously, but it is also not a 'comedy' in the strictest sense.
Rowan Joffe is an extremely talented artist and one of the jewels in the crown of British cinema at present, but this film is pointless and uninspiring, and far from his best work.
The courtroom sequences serve the dual purpose of showcasing 'the hot guy from Mad Men' and providing a pretentious and didactic platform for the filmmakers to broadcast their views on censorship.
If there were a Dummies Guide to winning an Oscar, this film would make a great case study.
In the end, the title of the film contains an irony that may be lost on the filmmakers: this is kind of a funny story, no more, no less.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Joanna Hogg is the shining light of the UK Film Industry. She has saved us from another embarrassing LFF, and she has done it all without the help of the incompetent UK Film Council.

Another Year is filled with hilarious quirks and moments that punctuate the melancholy of Mary and Ken's loneliness and promise that, no matter how sad life may sometimes seem, there is always someone to turn to and some reason to smile.
Mulligan is the lynchpin of this film; her doe-eyed softness and melancholy smile perfectly encapsulating our heroine.

The 'lonely assassin who falls in love' is too familiar a story to be interesting in its own right, and somewhere along the line Corbijn, Clooney, and writer Rowan Joffe forgot to imbue Jack with enough of intensity and conflict to keep the story flowing.

There is really no way to describe the playfulness and exquisite timing of the comedy in this film. It is partially Herzog's zany artistry, and partly Cage's masterful control of facial expressions and comic timing.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Sfar has not attempted to entirely understand Gainsbourg or have the final say on his image; he has simply provided a fascinating and refreshing perspective on this overlooked and enigmatic icon.
Undoubtedly one of the finest films of the last year.
The whole film carries a sort of documentary aesthetic (unsteady camera movements, uncomfortable close-ups, inconsistent sound, etc.) but it remains subtle and unobtrusive throughout.
A beautiful and languid testament to the importance of remembering how powerful our childhoods really were.
If you arrive at the cinema looking forward to a frivolous, expertly produced, and very funny movie with a few cracking performances, then I think you might just be in luck.
nobody can deny that this was a Herculean task, and Anderson has succeeded where so many filmmakers would have failed.
There are so many things about the film that could have been annoying (...) but the story is so refreshing and honest that it would be almost impossible to find anything annoying here.
The relationships between the characters are perfectly conceived, performed, and captured.

This is not a biopic in the mould of Walk The Line or Ray; it is the story of a troubled childhood and a determined and strong-minded young man who uses his love of music to overcome a bitter and uncomfortable domestic past.
If DeNiro was the John Wayne of New Hollywood, then this is his The Quiet Man.
Del Toro should have been perfect for The Wolfman, and it is his involvement in the project that attracted most critics to it, but his performance is mostly disappointing.

Whether the vignette concerns a bitter spinster, a depressed cuckold, or a lovelorn teen; the whole film is imbued with a tender-hearted hopefulness that makes this a must see film, especially during the festive season.
This is a mature and thoughtful drama that absorbs the viewer into the world of the family, and leaves you as emotionally bruised and drained as the characters themselves.
The real draw of the film is obviously based around the revelations at Abby's farm; but I don't want to spoil the surprise, so just go and watch this film.
Combining elements of a 'music video' aesthetic with subtle, intimate moments and epic John Ford vistas, Boyle never gives the audience a moment to tire of the difficult subject matter.
In the end, this is a travesty of a story and a failure of a sequel, but an absolute triumph for CGI... it is to the original TRON what Avatar is to Ferngully.
Let's not mince words; The Tourist is one of the most outstandingly atrocious films of the year.
It's familiar. We see the tale unfolding before our eyes from the beginning. But that doesn't make it any less enjoyable. It's a fast-paced story, confidently told.
Sharp editing, a masterful attention to pace and wonderful performances.
The film is certainly a visual delight, and does a better job than any film this critic has seen of reflecting how it feels to be at an electronic dance event of that size.
Beneath the clinical, sarcastic wit, there is a depth to her treatment of the story that builds gradually into a poignant, mature understanding of her central characters and the world they inhabit.

Wolfe's singular vision of hopeless destruction finds its muse in this charming and powerful young actress (Ahmed). Her strength will pull out what is left of your breath like a vacuum, and leave you stumbling for the exits in need of respite.
a well-rounded dramatic film taken from a refreshingly uplifting perspective.
We are left with an entertaining but hollow story filled with entertaining but hollow characters.
It's a treasure to revisit a place with so many fond memories, even if the memories aren't technically real... or ours.
This film isn't going to stick in your mind because of a stirring and original narrative or heart-wrenching lead performance; it's going to stick there because it is just good fun, plain and simple.
How Eastwood has managed to create so dull a film is actually quite stunning.

So in much the same way that 'Transformers' is essentially a robot war with a few humans stumbling around trying to get laid; this film should really have been called 'Alien Bracelet Vs. Aliens... With Some Cowboys Falling Off Their Horses'.
The film is worth watching just to see Isaac's performance grow through the final third: as misery, grief, and hate fuse together in a tumultuous, hopeless climax.
The hiccups of comedy genius feel like hollow victories in a generally average film.

Marsh is too content framing the entire film around the narrative spun by its subjects, rather than stamping his own authorship on the film, and as a result it lacks the power and depth of his previous work.

Bale's performance is so good it almost collapses into mimicry, but his twisted and terrifyingly accurate ability to portray the quirks and simmering undertones of difficult characters ensures that his performances always transcend such claims.
At just thirteen years of age, Heilee Steinfeld delivers one of the most memorable performances of the year.
There is a flippancy and incorrigibility to the style and pace of the storytelling that matches perfectly with our lovable, pig-headed hero.
A meandering and meaningless pile of drivel that does a disservice to its many fine performances.
Roger Michell's film is a straight forward romantic comedy, refreshingly strong on the latter and sparing with the former.

The zipping speed of the storytelling even drips down into the minutiae of the editing, with cuts occurring on opening doors, or using visual cues with dialogue: the story never calms down for a second.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Somebody, somewhere, is proud of the art direction and animation that brings this city to life, but it just looks like a Lord of the Rings fan film.
But somehow, despite the simple and sometimes obtuse storytelling, there is something strangely intimate and mesmerising about this film.
This film channels the haunting fantasy of the Brothers Grimm, with the hazy, colourful power of Lolita, and the thumping action of a Bourne film.

A life shouldn't need to be heroic, controversial, or glamorous for the wider world to take notice of it, wonderful little things happen every day, and finally a film has come along that celebrates every single one of them.
There is not one moment in this film that astounds the senses, tickles the solar plexus, or surprises our expectations.
It's not a movie about saving the world, even though the world needs saving, but rather the small, personal actions that can build bridges.
Thrilling, exhausting and ultimately devastating.
The effects are good. The film is well shot. But the performances are awful.
It's a retread of Jurassic Park with extra corn and less suspense.
Inside Out is as helpful as a session of therapy, and a lot more fun.

At two hours 24 minutes the final Hobbit movie is the shortest of all of Peter Jackson's Middle-earth epics but it still feels like butter scraped over too much bread.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: When most cinema these days pedals nothing but the crushingly predictable, a movie like Holy Motors cannot be recommended highly enough.
It's worth seeing for [DeHaan's] performance alone.

Let's just say that the film is a self-reflective essay on the different way we look at the future in 2015 than we did in 1955. It also has some stern things to say about ignoring climate change -- in a very Disney sort of way.

Directed by Isabel Coixet, and based on a magazine article by the feminist writer Katha Pollitt, this is a little film but there is a lot of craft in it. To make a movie about human connection that is funny without being mawkish is no small achievement.
If you need another reason to go see it, it's Collette. Glamorous, outrageous and brave, her Milly is full of life and enormously engaging.

Hugh Grant is underused as a British intelligence chief but Cavill picks up the slack when it comes to suave comedy. He's way more fun in this movie than as the Man of Steel, and Ritchie's dark sense of humour frequently stops boredom from setting in.

It's a pity Fleming never lived to see Craig's hyper-masculine yet vulnerable Bond: he's well on his way to being the best of them all.
This is not a subtle film. It's not even unpredictable. But it is an awful lot of ghoulish, melodramatic fun.

If only the malevolent spirit of the bush were a satisfactory explanation for the enigma being spun here.

While the coming-of-age narrative is familiar enough -- separated from his family a young dinosaur must rise to a series of challenges before he can claim his place in the natural order -- the parallel universe in which it is set is nicely realised.
This sweet little tragicomedy about life's absurdities plays out as a buddy movie in which two damaged men from opposite sides of the world find unexpected common ground.
The best moments satirise the grand action sequences we've become accustomed to in these tentpoles.
How much you enjoy the movie depends on how much mass destruction you can deal with and how much cheese you can stomach.
The script by Nelson Greaves leaves the cast of teenage archetypes vague and underdeveloped, even for this kind of horror flick.

Whedon's strategy is to keep the action constant, the banter clever, and to switch between characters before we have time to think about anything too deeply. When it comes to engineering plot, he's a genius who could give Stark a run for his money.
It's a good bit of romantic escapism with lovely visuals.
The film pays tribute to a great performer, leaving little doubt that she possessed one of the great jazz voices of all time.

Dialogue is witty and performances are first-rate. While it's Cumberbatch's show, Knightley is very good as a woman thrilled at being able to put her intelligence to use.
Luckily, the film finds its feet to end up an undeniably affecting portrayal of a landmark civil rights battle.
While the movie comes on like a crowd pleaser, it leaves a highly acrid taste.
Apparently, this is the first of a new trilogy. One can only hope it improves.

Rachel Ward's directorial debut is well acted and handsomely shot by Andrew Commis, but it goes nowhere.

We're left with a deep sense of admiration for those who are prepared to face rejection routinely in pursuit of a dream.

A beautifully understated movie about family ties and the sadness and nostalgia that objects can evoke.
[Williams] doesn't have to say much to convey the deep wells of hurt that Wendy's carrying around, and they're all the more poignant for remaining unspoken.
Although Zack Snyder's Watchmen is as lovingly detailed a facsimile as there's ever been of a graphic novel, there's still something lacking.
X-Men fans may disagree, but this is Singer's best work since The Usual Suspects.

Has the moral overtones of an EM Forster story, but is curiously lacking in emotional force.

Girl, just pick the werewolf now so we can all go home.

The hero of the hour is Reynolds, who gives a hugely compelling performance mostly lying on his back. His spine probably deserves its own Oscar for sheer endurance.

Come in Lindsay Lohan: your time is up. Ever since you went off the rails we've been on the lookout for a feisty, freckled ranga with a straight-bourbon voice and killer comic timing, and we've found her in the form of Emma Stone.
This is Boyle's best since Trainspotting.
Beattie has made a rousing directorial debut that could and should become a monster international hit. Marsden has written a further nine books about Ellie's exploits: bring them on as films, I say.

Boy is one of the most successful films of all time in its home country and it's not hard to see why. It's about that moment every child experiences when they realise their dad or mum is not a hero but just a human being.
Be warned: this is the blackest comedy you'll see all year. Some may find it in bad taste. Then again, if there is one thing that fanaticism hates it's the sound of laughter.
Phillip Noyce directs Kurt Wimmer's script, which rockets along with chase sequences and confounds with double-crosses but it can't hide its essentially facile nature.
In every respect, this is an exemplar of the art of the thriller. Directors like Polanski are a dying breed. We need more of them.
The Special Relationship doesn't have the emotional impact of The Queen but it's a sharp examination of a brief time when the UK occupied a dynamic place on the world stage.
This is a lovely film: droll, endearing and poignant, with an intoxicating sense of place that seeps into your pores
Me and Orson Welles has plenty to offer fans, be they of theatre, old movies, or High School Musical. If you can tick at least one of these boxes then you're in for a good time.

Watching this gives new meaning the phrase 'cultural cringe'.
The film grips utterly for its two hours and sets forth nothing less than a polemic on the dangers of religious extremism.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary will certainly appeal to kids with its colour, movement, clarity and humour. Adults, meanwhile, will take pause at the knowledge that the food industry has exploited our hard-wired love for sweet things to sell us unhealthy products.
At more than the two hours, The Five-Year Engagement outstays its welcome like a drunken, microphone-hogging best man.
Subtexts aside, Hounds of Love is also an expert exercise in suspense, taut as the wire of a Hills Hoist.

It's all a bit low stakes,
Here's a true story, honestly told, that will see audiences genuinely moved.
It's the sight of kids having their horizons expanded that uplifts the most.

This debut feature deftly weaves together a host of surreal scenarios into a consistently funny and surprising package, as performed by a top-notch cast that includes stage luminaries Kate Mulvany and Damon Herriman.
Schlock it may be, and sticklers will complain about plot holes, but there's no denying the mood of dread conjured up here, nor the strength of the performances.
You'll laugh all the way to the sperm bank.
[Fifty-Two Tuesdays] is the rare Australian film that actually has something to say.
The best scenes reteam him with Margaret Pomeranz, as they recount highlights from their 28-year on-screen partnership. Their easy chemistry is a reminder of what we've lost.
These Final Hours sets up a simple redemption tale and convincingly stages mass panic on the sunny streets of Perth.
Flamboyantly gay, the man who became Bette Davis's favourite costume designer emerges as a flawed, workaholic visionary, an Australian movie great.
As a portrait of contemporary Australia, it's an antidote to just about everything else out there.
[Berlin] promises an unforgettable journey, but delivers only a slideshow.
Well acted and beautifully photographed, the movie offers a window into both modern urban and traditional Chinese life.

movie_review_blurb: Ali's Wedding by contrast gets its big laughs from authentic insights into the complexity and contradictions inherent in Islamic communities, with a wisdom about human nature that hits a universal sweet spot.
The tension is non-stop and the dialogue, fiendishly good.
This is cerebral sci-fi with a strong emotional undertow, largely thanks to Snook, who gives a heart-tugging performance as the gender-addled person of mystery.

Australia now has its High Noon.

[Woody Allen's] new movie is one of his better efforts of late, despite being one of the darkest.

Rupert Wyatt delivers on the giddy pleasures - climbing, leaping, swinging, plus the irresistable high of an upward-rushing learning curve.

movie_review_blurb: Still, as a story of dysfunctionality begetting dyfunctionality, it packs a blackly funny punch, and Streep's performance is a thing to behold: a venomous arachnid at the centre of a web of familial cruelty.
There are laughs here as well as moments of devastation, thankfully, and genuine joy.
This is an effective story of war, peace, forgiveness and revenge.
[Submarine] is a wry coming-of-age comedy.
Ultimately the film is a testament to moxie of the arts scene in the Sunshine State.

movie_review_blurb: It's about how grandparents are important even though they say weird things and make bad jokes and try to get you excited about boring things, like baseball.
There are unusual rewards for viewers willing to climb ev'ry mountain with this deranged guide.
Devotees of the novel will find this a faithful rendering.
Battleship is logic-free Michael Bay-style fodder where nothing's at stake and even the jingoism is hard to take seriously. Everyone loses.
[Gatsby] is a canonical tale given a fresh spin.

Sheridan's ear for fatalistic dialogue is bang on.

There is spectacular scenery and architecture to admire and footage of some of the world's best restaurants (tip: don't watch this movie hungry), but the main drawcard is as always the celebrity impressions.
Haynes has forged a drama that's wonderfully intimate and subtle while generating considerable emotional power.
Jack Black gives one of his more enjoyable performances playing the writer as a Frankenstein figure -- the creator of creatures that he can't control.
Point Break? More like Point Miss.
This very sad film hits home with the force of a rebuke.
The Road Chip hardly qualifies as great cinema. And really, no adult goes to these films because they want to. But it is a perfectly serviceable accompaniment to a choc top and bag of popcorn.

movie_review_blurb: While the director's favourite leading lady, Jennifer Lawrence, gives the lead character everything she has, and that's plenty, the world inhabited by the ironically-named Joy remains strangely flat.

The dialogue is funny and the film moves quickly between its various storylines, wisely realising that none of the main characters has much capacity for engagement or development. That's with the possible exception of Piven's Ari.
A well-meaning, worthy and, at times, moving ode to Gallipoli.
The performances are fine, and it's no mean feat to derive warm-hearted laughs from mental illness.
It's the kind of film where he'll gun somebody down and then look sad and soulful, as if he might be write a poem about it.
A very tame live-action retelling of a story everybody already knows.

Its theme of cherishing love when it comes your way couldn't be blunter, but on the whole this is one of the better Sparks movies, with even a neat twist in the tale to reward those who last the distance.
A movie that's crazy fun, and every bit as good as the first one.
