Depicting the thorny relationship shared by pop star and fan, Backstage radiates not the nostalgic sentimentality of Almost Famous but raw, pathetic, obsessive desperation.
A preachy, liberal-courting slog.
"Grief is messy," says McShane's anguished dad. We Are Marshall's disingenuously tidy portrait of it, alas, is not.
Buried within its turgid solemnity lies the potential for entertaining extravagance.
A skimpy Cliff's Notes for both the eponymous Vaseline-loving sculptor-filmmaker's career and, specifically, his most recent act of cinematic self-infatuation, Drawing Restraint 9.
Lattuada ... crisply addresses relevant issues of national and personal identity while never neglecting his film's underlying humor.
Like a mouse on a spinning wheel, it's a film that moves at a breakneck pace but ultimately goes nowhere.
Eragon's fantastical milieu may be third-class Lord of the Rings, but its story--in what may constitute the most shameless act of plagiarism known to American cinema--is pure Star Wars.
The finale is an extended tour de force equal parts Bruce Lee, Tony Jaa, and Donkey Kong.
Lacks the one quality that Marshall's sub-par Best Picture winner Chicago had going for it - an invigorating, irresistible, knockout score.
Juan Carlos Rulfo's In the Pit is a documentary defined by symbiosis.
In spite of its cases of explanatory handholding, there remains a stirring potency to Letters' exploration of loyalty, responsibility, and nobility.
Nick Nolte's grizzled, alcoholic recluse mentors Trevor Morgan's unhappy teen in Off the Black, a heartwarming tale that's been told a thousand times before, and with considerably more spark.
The first Bond film to actually prize three-dimensional characters and moral dilemmas over action-film flash.
Overflowing with hackneyed but thrilling blockbuster-familiar moments, the majority of which, in another context, could have proven entirely comfortable in a mid-'80s Schwarzenegger vehicle

Zwick may as well have titled his newest action-adventure The Constant Gardener II: Diamonds Are Forever, as it peddles the same distasteful, condescending attitudes toward Africa as did Fernando Meirelles' 2005 fiasco.
The film becomes, in part, another Michael Moore-ish conspiracy theory endeavor in which damning, wholly unsubstantiated accusations are bandied about as fact.
Li...prov[es] so over-the-top imperial that she almost singlehandedly elevates the film's heightened drama into something epic.
Lack[s] an essential, gripping spark of self-destructiveness and ardor.
From its class warfare premise to the presence of Juliette Binoche, Breaking and Entering plays out like a softer, more cuddly version of Michael Haneke's Caché.
To list all the contrivances strewn throughout The Holiday would require more words than are warranted by Nancy Meyers's latest batch of cinematic maple syrup.
It's a political tale with no significant contemporary reverberations, a turgid espionage-tinged romance with no soul, and a play-it-again aesthetic showpiece without a point.
With Turistas, director John Stockwell cements his status as contemporary Hollywood's most accomplished exhibitor of the female behind.
10 Items or Less is a hybrid of Nacho Libre and Spanglish directed by Moonlight Mile's Brad Silberling, and yes, it's as unbearably cloying and uplifting as that description sounds.
This rasping relic of a WWII "message picture" is hackneyed to its noble core.
Has a sumptuous visual creepiness that contributes to its affecting portrait of shattered childhood innocence.
Could ... have turned out to be a guilty pleasure were it more uninhibited and less rushed.
Range's aesthetic trickery isn't nearly as seamless or as clever as that found in Kevin Millmott's C.S.A.: Confederate States of America.

One of the most polished and inventive horror flicks of the still-ongoing year, a synthesis of classical supernatural and sexualized imagery that expands upon, rather than simply regurgitates, its celebrated predecessors.
Hong paints a piercing portrait of impetuous, confused, selfish masculinity in which the thrill of the chase repeatedly proves more enticing than the rewards of triumph.
Just as its intro's slaughterhouse apparatus violently destroys pigs, so too does the crushing poverty of the Philippines crush the titular heroine of Insiang.
A Nightmare on Elm Street is a movie defined by its dual legacies.
In requiring only passivity from its audience, whom it shovel-feeds faux-erudite lessons, it's the Academy Award-baiting version of Don't Ask, Just Tell cinema.
You've got to give it to the Jackass crew: their commitment to their crass craft is awe-inspiring.
So incompetent it should be used by film schools as a manual on how not to make a movie.
The film functions not only as a loving tribute to the past, but as Weerasethakul's attempt at experiential preservation.

The protagonist's message rings true and its battle sequences prove gripping, but Jet Li's Fearless is both slightly ham-fisted in its efforts to have its individual and political narratives mirror one another.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A stinging rebuke to both do-gooder white-man's-burden fantasies and the disingenuous, Africa-exoticizing movies that promote them.
At its best when unabashedly celebrating its milieu's decadence
At least Boog's infatuation with using toilets means that Open Season is an ideal film for small tykes still undergoing potty training.
Nails the tale's particulars but not its soul.
An intimate, intoxicating chamber piece.
Asked only to regurgitate prior performances, Heder dutifully performs his bumbling Napoleon Dynamite shtick and Thornton berates people with caustic Bad Santa/Bad News Bears nastiness.
Mama, don't let your babies grow up to be Eric Roberts.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sleeping Dogs Lie pulls off the not-inconsiderable feat of tackling one of cinema's last taboo frontiers--bestiality--with sincere sweetness.
Almost single-handedly resuscitates the moribund serial killer genre.
The superfluous story is so muddled that it becomes a pesky distraction from the proceedings' graphical virtuosity.
With The Aura, Fabián Bielinsky replaces Nine Queens' flashy Mamet-esque posturing with downbeat Melville/Antonioni noir existentialism.
Were it not already taken, Angels with Dirty Faces might have been an apt alternative title for this TRUE STORY.
Repackages messy human dilemmas into something neat, tidy and oh-so-manipulatively inspiring.
In the competition for cinema's worst genre, the Quirky British Comedy About Eccentric Countryfolk Learning Valuable Lessons In Outrageous Circumstances truly has no rival.
Rather than catching Feast during its limited midnight-movie theatrical release, one can enjoy comparable B-movie goofiness via any Saturday-night Sci-Fi Channel offering.
Mirren's intensely, imposingly regal even when the visually competent, narratively unaffecting The Queen proves only pedestrian.
Never amounts to more than a case of hardcore triviality.
Little more than a CBS Sunday night movie that peddles inspirational fairy tale schmaltz and middling humor by the coffin-full.
It's the moralistic tenor of A Bronx Tale that's ultimately most off-putting.
An Australian rendition of Requiem for a Dream in which pretty people live in filth, steal from their relatives, and turn tricks in order to satiate their narcotics cravings.
Part vanity project, part image rehabilitation.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A creaky history-class lecture.
The Nightmare Before Christmas is a veritable bounty of visual delights.
Underneath the film's tantalizing stratagems lies little more than mundane truths.
The Grudge 2 merely confirms that the series (and, perhaps, the J-horror genre as a whole) has finally run its course
Cocaine Cowboys' in-the-moment kicks are, after the lights come up, apt to leave one with something of an ashamed and remorseful hangover.
Actress-turned-filmmaker Joey Lauren Adams's cookie-cutter contribution to Sundance-style cinema.
Director Tahani Rached's documentary These Girls exudes empathy and respect for its destitute Egyptian teenage subjects' plight.
Fittingly ending with a train wreck, Tideland careens about wildly to only slightly rewarding effect.
Becomes far more enthralling ... the more one simply surrenders to the awe-inspiring beauty of Kon's images of flesh, metal and unhinged mental delusions.
A powerful depiction of rebellion, as well as a portrait of communication as a force capable of eradicating personal and cultural barriers.
There's nothing about Man of the Year that's quite as fantastic as its depiction of moribund Saturday Night Live as culturally and politically relevant.
Deliver Us From Evil proceeds with a sober clarity that lends credence to its devastating case.
Meanders forward with little apparent direction and virtually no interesting drama.
Bong Joon-ho's The Host delivers high-octane thrills while cannily exploiting contemporary political fears.
What begins as a breakneck descent into blunt cruelty and moral turmoil soon morphs into a cat-and-mouse game encumbered by self-consciously overcooked extravagance.
Frat boys and KKK members will surely love this.
The title eloquently speaks to the film's fractional success.
Reducing the iconic brute to a victim of childhood neglect and abuse? That's not, as The Beginning's tagline boasts, "The Birth of Fear." It's the death of it.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A saga of adventurers driven headlong into annihilation by their own hubris and desire for immortality.
movie_title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God (Aguirre, der Zorn Gottes) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Has little to say about friendship other than that it's sometimes maintained by less-than-kind motives and reciprocated with equal coldness.
Lynch's epic about the movie biz and identity seems less a depiction of the dark recesses of the human mind than an actual product of it.
The ingredients that have increasingly defined Wes Anderson's films seem, with The Darjeeling Limited, to have become something like limitations.
Thrilling and touching in equal measure, it's on the short list of great superhero films.
Take some notes, Dubya: Jamie Foxx has the anti-terrorism tactics you've been craving.
Doesn't make much of a lasting impression except as a case study in the dreariness of style-over-substance filmmaking when said style is the height of derivativeness.
Big budget, big stars, big concept -- surprisingly little payoff.
HBO's 1990s cartoon series Happily Ever After multiculturalized traditional fairy tales, and Year of the Fish may as well be a live-action episode of the now-defunct program.
Often eyes-averting nasty, delivering visceral thrills that are evocatively matched by more unreal images of Dalle's psycho cloaked in darkness like a bedtime story specter.
The conception and execution are top-notch low-budget trash.
A slapdash affair largely lacking in laughs.
Might have been brilliantly funny had the film found a way to suitably lay the groundwork for its premise.
Cube opts for dramatically earnest pathos rather than simply seriocomic shtick.
A serviceable, forgettable genre film marked by leaden performances, even more leaden dialogue, a few sterlingly gruesome images, and a supremely campy performance from Joan Allen.
A wealth of creative talent can't alter the fact that Rocker is merely a passable goof-off, and one less challenging or fun than a night spent playing Rock Band.
The nadir of homophobic frat-boy humor.
Miike's homage is devoid of pretention and teeming with insanity.
A slab of shoddy, hollow rubbish that can't be bothered to concoct imaginative frights or even tenuous bonds between its supernatural terror and its characters' human drama.

Inconsequentiality is a pox upon the proceedings, draining any trace of narrative tension from countless large-scale conflicts that soon overwhelm the screen with stormtroopers, droids, explosions and laser blasts.
Fly Me to the Moon is in 3D because, without the glasses-required effects, not even a three-year-old would sit through it.
Never makes more than a surface impression, albeit a fitfully amusing one.
[The film] captures relatable 21st-century truths in small, excruciating moments.
A thorough, level-headed examination of the Bush administration's failure to properly prepare for, and execute, the war.
For every unsubtle moment ... there are two or three that forcefully resound.
Infused with ragged unpredictability, What We Do Is Secret's wild concerts are its high points.
The film's climax ultimately seems less an example of its protagonist's irrational fury than of cockeyed storytelling.
The second wave of fawning Tarantino imitators commences with Hell Ride, a wannabe badass biker flick that plays like a Kill Bill-Death Proof hybrid minus the genre-deconstruction angle.
Taut, thoughtful and inventive.
Aaron Rose and Joshua Leonard don't properly contextualize this mini-scene within the larger art world, nor provide basic background on their speakers.
Seems simply like the aftermath of an artistic apocalypse.
For every scene that goes nowhere -- and there are more than a few -- there's some comedy gold lurking around the corner.
The director's parade of self-conscious compositions and pushy musical cues ... prove most repellent of all.
Aside from a few choice sequences, Gregg's script largely comes up short on the transgressive or poignant front.
Contrived corniness abounds.

The animation serves as a distancing device akin to the way that Folman's mind used concealment to shield him from horrific traumas, a canny marriage of thematic and aesthetic concerns that nonetheless can't cover up the unsubtle redundancy of his story.

Sometimes, however, empty, contrived fantasies are just empty, contrived fantasies, as is certainly the case with this embarrassingly phony cross between Grace Is Gone, Home of the Brave and, believe it or not, Twister.
Friction is of a schematic sort that all too often seems mainly intent on recalling spiritual predecessors Midnight Cowboy and Five Easy Pieces.

Director Anthony Leondis peppers his tale with a host of leaden cinematic references children will almost surely miss, which is just as well since virtually every film-related gag directed at adults feels like a pitiful attempt at knowing cleverness.
Gervais's steady stream of cutting bon mots and regular bouts of indignant stammering keep Ghost Town more dry and sharp than broad and squishy.
The surface foolishness of the Coens' latest feels like a carefully designed bit of misdirection aimed at masking another tale of lonely, aimless people.

Though it doesn't feature Old Joy's Air America radio call-in Greek chorus, Kelly Reichardt's follow-up Wendy and Lucy is nonetheless a somber politicized lament for hardscrabble lives struggling to exist on the economic precipice.
Jessica Yu's film, a 180-degree tonal shift from her previous Protagonist, diligently retreads Adam Sandler and Napoleon Dynamite territory.

Are we really supposed to stomach a thriller in which the root of all evil is intelligent black men in power who can't stomach, to the point of going full-on psychotic, the sight of a white man married to a black woman?
Fictionalized drama frustrates, rather than facilitates, understanding about the 1999 World Trade Organization (WTO) protests in Battle to Seattle.
Offers up a call-to-arms against bottled water conglomerates that, in its structural sloppiness, feels like a high school student's tossed-off research paper.
At this saggy point in their illustrious careers, De Niro and Pacino seem less like Beatles and more like Monkeys.
First and foremost a grotesquerie.
As they did with their original, the Pangs steal liberally from John Woo without ever replicating his shootout-choreography inventiveness or proficiency.
[Sets] up hackneyed relationships, conflicts and resolutions with such a lack of imagination and subtlety that paying attention to narrative particulars quickly becomes a waste of time.
[The film's] intellectualized sexuality stirs neither the head nor the nether regions.
A tough, cynical, blistering fictionalized study of the Camorra crime organization that controls much of Naples.
August Evening may not be on par with the work of Yasujiro Ozu, but the late Japanese master's influence can be felt in the patient rhythms and thematic preoccupations of Chris Eska's film
Padilha succumbs to monotonous, hollow flamboyance with his City of God clone.
Modest in the least engaging sense of the term.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Hamri's film barely incorporates the pants into any of its primary storylines, so busy is it struggling to keep track of the many peripheral characters and subplots which crop up around each corner.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Boasts an endearingly idiosyncratic, unfussy vibe.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Makes the first two Mummy films seem like The Godfather I and II.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A succession of tepid gags tethered by a flimsy narrative.
Peralta's presentation is so concise and efficient that it often overshadows the fact that some of his doc's contentions aren't particularly novel.
movie_title: Crips and Bloods: Made in America (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Shyamalan is far better at setup than payoff, and the Sixth Sense director's latest once and for all cements that reputation.
A real-life romance to put all those rom-com fairy tales to shame.
No fondness for crummy old television can obscure the general faintheartedness of this saga.
A bleakly humorous romantic character study, Quid Pro Quo is appealingly offbeat until its narrative takes a wayward detour into pat simplifications.
Swinging from solemn drama to farcical humor at a moment's notice, the proceedings rarely feel surefooted.
Offers an experience that is best summed up by a phrase seen carved in a McMurdo wood banister: "I sink into bliss."
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Makes up for its lack of informational depth with stirring poignancy.
Kung Fu Panda is generally content to simply coast along on a few Zen platitudes and regularly scheduled Po pratfalls.

Locating both Claire's loneliness and Jay's anger as partial outgrowths of their detested profession handing out parking meter violation tickets, Expired coasts along on a distinctively odd wavelength.
Another of the horror maestro's futile attempts to recapture the magic that made his seminal '70s giallos so bewitching.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Zohan is, against all odds, Sandler's funniest effort in close to a decade. Not exactly a monumental feat given the junk he's recently made a mint foisting on the American public, but still.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A low-key Big Fish minus the whimsical fantasy.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Saying The Promotion's tone is all wrong would imply that it had a tone to begin with.

Bodrov whips up enough wild, unruly energy and, in his depiction of sex as a Mongolian female's most vital commodity, sociological scraps to help overshadow the somewhat cheesy dubiousness of his myth-making project.
Julianne Moore is some kind of great in Savage Grace, but the film? Not so much.
Gordon shoots his material's descent into grotesqueness (of both a physical and ethical sort) with jagged briskness that amplifies his scenario's mordant humor.
Stays doggedly true to its idiosyncratic off-kilter vibe.
As with last year's lean, mean B movie Vacancy, Bryan Bertino's The Strangers is a white-knuckle thriller in which a couple going through relationship difficulties is terrorized by psychos.
Addresses its complex topic with both humor and intelligence.
A TV movie in disguise.
More content to hang out with Ellison ... than systematically pick him apart and put him back together like a jigsaw puzzle.
Sweet November for the nursing-home set, Elsa and Fred is sentimental mush cooked up with extra syrup.
A clumsy mash of Leaving Las Vegas and Hardcore.
Rigorous and wrenching.
Less a vitriolic critique than a considerate, despairing depiction of the intractable sway exerted by long-held, unpleasant traditions.
[Carter's] reasonably firm grasp of thriller mechanics can't enliven a tale that amounts to simply a mundane, overlong one of the show's stand-alone, mythology-free episodes.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What ultimately reverberates is [the film's] potent central association between Petit's endeavor and the Twin Towers' erection.

There's something brilliantly stupid (or stupidly brilliant) about the sight of Ferrell and Reilly in vintage '80s t-shirts smacking each other around like steroidal kids, though it's the little things that make their complementary performances thrive.
Conjuring up memories of happier experiences gone by is the prime means of enduring such across-the-board ineptitude.

The Dark Knight resounds with a throbbing topical undercurrent, its superficially good-versus-evil setup slowly revealed to be a complex examination of the ways in which democracies can, and must, combat zealotry.
A decidedly limited, functional aesthetic affair.

To and Ka-fai's widescreen lensing is both elegant and sharp, its distorted angles and flaring white lights generating a sense of unease that complements Bun's instability and Chi-Wai's fractured self.
Transsiberian eventually reveals itself to be scatterbrained thematically.
Oliver's climactic twist merely nullifies any engagement with the characters' prior plights.
Felon flounders in convincingly resolving its protagonist's plight.
While the mood is spot-on, the dubbed dialogue is so persistently lousy that it besmirches the proceedings' otherwise-entrancing beauty.
Special effects have come a long way since Jurassic Park, but you wouldn't know it from Journey to the Center of the Earth.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Hartnett does windbag cockiness well, yet the overriding conception of his character and the Dot Com phenom in general is so straightforward and unrevealing that his effort goes for naught.
Full Battle Rattle often seems content to merely work its way toward the concluding notion that, if our armed forces can't cut it in fake Iraq, they'll never be able to handle the real deal.
More impressive than its ecologically minded message is its modestly profound portrait of loneliness, obligation and the desire for reciprocated affection.
Pure, unadulterated mediocrity.
Hitchcock's "Wrong Man" scenario gets an invigorating French update in Tell No One, a long-winded but gripping thriller based on American author Harlan Coben's bestseller.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sheds essential exposition in a mad, foolish dash to the finish line.
Its indictment ultimately feels like a secondary issue to Polanski's apparently incontrovertible guilt, which makes him--in this instance--still more victimizer than victim.
The Last Mistress' fervent energy is derived from its titular mistress' explode-at-any-second volatility.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hasn't got a joke worth laughing over.

Speaking of bodies, Jolie's is here front and center, her svelte frame slinking across the screen with an alluring animalism magnified by the steamy twinkle in her eyes and sensual gestures as small as a wave of the hand or a shrug of the shoulder.
A magnificently deranged study of overboard pop-culture fandom and authoritarian rule's destructive effect on its citizenry.
Boasting a clarity and consistency of vision that's as bracing as its naturalistic performances, [The Class] is vigorous, incisive, immediate.
[Leigh's] legitimately uplifting film benefits from its own refusal to unduly sentimentalize or moralize.
A stirring autobiography-by-proxy.
Since Keanu Reeves has all the expressiveness of a toaster, why is he starring in the new The Day the Earth Stood Still as human-looking alien Klaatu rather than giant robot Gort?
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Would be trying if not for the confidence, grace and subtlety with which José Luis Guerín handles his deliberately open-ended material.
movie_title: En la Ciudad de Sylvia (In the City of Sylvia) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from awkward, often ill-fitting tilted camera angles, the writer/director adapts his stagey work with a modicum of aesthetic theatricality.
You'd be forgiven for thinking, while watching What Doesn't Kill You, that it was still 2007.
Nothing Like the Holidays may be less repulsive than The Family Stone, but that's simply because it wields its strikingly similar story with slightly more subtlety.
Dark Streets may only be a quasi-noir and quasi-musical, but that doesn't stop it from being a wholesale slog.
Director Stephen Daldry and screenwriter David Hare exhibit a continued inability to thrillingly translate literary forms to the screen.
An absolutely abysmal crime flick.
Elissa Down's semi-autobiographical film always manages to counter its indie clichés with a sober sense of the volatility that comes from living with an autistic individual.
In terms of condescending narrative handholding, Frost/Nixon has no 2008 rival.
Its preoccupation with the burden and self-destructive ramifications of violence is given acute resonance by Eastwood's presence.
Distills genre tropes (and their consequent pleasures) to their lean, potent essence.
A Christmas Tale's expansive stew of physical and psychological illness, death, betrayal, longing, religion, and ritual ultimately proves invigoratingly lush.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Four Christmases is defiantly conservative on the issue of adult happiness.
Beleaguered by a general dearth of energy.
That rare, heartfelt biopic disinterested in egregious chronological compression or psychological reductiveness.
Dutifully goes through the sweeping-swoony motions.
A character study drowning in liberal guilt.
Your move, Anne Rice!
Bolt is perfectly amiable but rarely brisk, with neither its premise nor its execution quite inspired enough to elicit more than faint admiration.
A brisk, grim story that might as well have been called Monotony of Tone.
This fantasy battle between good and evil is merely a cute, minor idea with little depth and even less conscious purpose, fit for a 15-minute short rather than a feature-length narrative.
Visually and narratively flat.
In a post-Ratatouille world, an animated film about rodents and fine cuisine is the exact opposite of original.
That stink emanating from the vicinity of Yes Man is desperation.
A deliberately muddled bit of inspirational pap.
A neorealist noir gem.
Concluding on a fittingly less-than-happy note, the promising but uneven film knows what it wants to say, if not, ultimately, exactly how to say it.
A scraggly, messy, often aimless, and yet consistently amusing and engaging work of black comedy-cum-social-realism.
Arriving at least two years after the Asian-horror-remake craze subsided, The Uninvited delivers a spooky-stepmom saga free of invention.
Deviates not an inch from its rickety template.

Like the odious stepchild of Fargo, New in Town gleefully offers up citizens of rural, snowbound New Ulm, Minnesota as a collection of funny-speaking, Jesus-loving, tapioca-making misfits deserving of nothing less than outright mockery.
Despite its interest in creative expression, Inkheart's hurried pace, shorthand characterizations and regularly scheduled set-pieces obliterate all but the faintest traces of lucid thought.
So aware of genre conventions, manipulations, and symbolism that it functions more like an intellectualized primer than an actual terrifying experience.
Mildly proficient as far as throwbacks go.
Paul Blart tepidly goes through its motions, but that doesn't mean you have to.
If there's something praiseworthy about Notorious, it's that it pulls off the remarkable, ignominious feat of making its deceased subject less likeable than one remembers.
The most lamentable thing about the dismal Bride Wars is the total absence of fatalities.
The year is only a week old and already the cinema gods have bestowed upon us a candidate for most awesome catchword of the year: Jumby!
Yonkers Joe confirms that writer-director Robert Celestin knows his way around a local cash-stakes game of craps. It also proves, unfortunately, that his scripting skills need substantial honing.
Balabanov imbues his uncompromisingly matter-of-fact horror show material with a shrewd politicized consciousness.
Smacks every clichéd note with maximum gusto.
Adam Shankman's holiday adventure has a big central concept and next to no desire to follow through on reasonably--much less fully--exploiting it.
Hell is Marley & Me.
Decidedly blunt and unaffecting.
Feigns serious interest in the trickiness of later-in-life love while indulging in corny humor and even worse bathos.
Dutifully reproduces incidents and particulars while only rarely glancing at the underlying element of self-deception, of acting a part, that defines said moments.
Incongruous vocal intonations aren't even the most significant problem plaguing Bryan Singer's film.
Benjamin's very blankness gives the film a beguiling measure of dreamy, fabulistic wonder, one that entrances even as Roth's script regularly missteps.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Homophobia in Muslim families and communities is a topic ripe for exploration, but as its eye-rollingly lame titular pun makes clear, I Can't Think Straight isn't the film to do it.
Insidious baffles from the get-go, but the truly impressive feat pulled off by Jerry Schram's directorial debut is that it manages to become exponentially more incomprehensible as it progresses.
The film's plentiful complications aren't necessarily unique ... but they're given corkscrew verve by taut plotting and correspondingly fleet, no-nonsense direction.
Crafted with considerably more heart than skill.

Ember is a superbly crafted environment, recalling not only the dreamlike nocturnal landscape of City of Lost Children but also the self-contained, sub-aquatic art-deco setting of last year's superlative videogame Bioshock.

While action-adventure conventions take precedence over socio-political analysis, visceral kicks are in short supply, a situation that throws the film's tendencies toward stale misdirection and goofy melodrama into sharp relief.
So affected and emotionally inaccessible as to be borderline intolerable.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Characteristic of Melville's crime canon, the film's rigorously mannered aesthetic creates a decidedly artificial environment, and yet that environment is so meticulously, thoroughly realized that it's breathtakingly immersive.
Le Doulos roots itself in traditional noir themes of providence, of loyalty and betrayal, of male codes of honor, and ultimately of man's inability to escape his lot in life.
Everything is literally and figuratively black and white in The Express.
Alas, Guy Ritchie seems to have lost even what little touch he once had, his latest a typically convoluted saga about strangely named big- and little-time crooks that's fatally deficient in verve.
There are three or four movies competing for attention within Changeling, and unfortunately for Clint Eastwood, they're all equally dreadful melodramatic drivel.
A strikingly constructed, handsomely HD-filmed museum display piece.
Assayas expresses the melancholy of childhood's ultimate end as well as globalization's reconfiguration of traditional notions of self, family and history.
There's a whole lotta healing in The Secret Life of Bees. Big Racial Issues too. And down-home heartwarming platitudes set to acoustic guitar ballads by female singers.
Annihilation and resurrection are the twin axes upon which The Wrestler turns.
Affects an air of expressionistic realism but has no interest in actual believability.
Especially during his opening sequences, McQueen's visual eye proves sharp.
Makes one urgently crave what its title promises.
movie_title: Tiro en la cabeza (Bullet in the Head) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Once made ... Afterschool proceeds to regurgitate its thesis with all the grace of a lumberjack leveling a redwood.
Employs a debilitating brand of smug disingenuousness, feigning interest in discussion while arrogantly and speciously preaching in the very same manner that its subjects are ridiculed for.

What little tension exists in Flash of Genius stems not from its ho-hum narrative, but from its attempts to fashion a heartwarming tale from a true-life story that, in many respects, wasn't all that heartwarming.
Genuinely understands and tenderly expresses how messy, complicated, troubled and compassionate familial relationships can be.
[Crafts] a portrait that's at once highly specific and yet effortlessly attuned to life's inherent disorder.

Determined to remake himself into a mini-Michael Bay (replete with military hardware fetishism!), Caruso shoots primarily in shaky, glossy close-ups that obliterate any sense of spatial proportion, scale or lucidity.
There's little room for genuine emotion in this turgid romantic fantasy adapted from a novel by slop-meister Nicholas Sparks.
An unfunny, uninventive live-action variation on animated Disney animal adventures Lady and the Tramp, Oliver and Company and The Aristocats.
Another of Kiyoshi Kurosawa's chilling portraits of micro and macro alienation, a family drama as chillingly controlled and despondent as the horror films that gained him international recognition.
[The film's] finest attribute is its scraggly, empathetic portrait of close-knit Londoners trying to make a go of things in haphazard, messy, always true-to-themselves ways.
This action saga is driven into unintentionally self-parodic territory only a seven-year-old boy could reasonably stomach.

Slumdog Millionaire is fantasy yet its hyperactively effervescent (if still personal, intimate) portrait of both ingrained social barriers and altruism's ability to demolish them is genuine and sweet.
How the dynamic between inspiration and creation operates is a topic that We Are Wizards tantalizingly puts forward but fails to fully examine.
A manipulative, tearjerking thriller that, functioning as a sustained, anguished primal scream, is as emotionally devastating as any film, fiction or non-, released this year.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The tendency to exploit lurid material for dramatic purposes is something [director Harris] can't avoid.
Directors Darnell and McGrath's follow-up would undoubtedly have benefited from more innovation or daring, but its vibrant animation and innocuously rollicking comedy remains endearing
The greatest respect Gini Reticker's Pray the Devil Back to Hell pays to its war-battered Liberian subjects is simply an unwillingness to embellish.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Rips off heavy metal and horror aesthetics to absolutely dismal effect.
A passably conventional rom-com squishfest decked out with Smith's usual pop-culture references.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With low aspirations come low expectations comes modest surprise.
For those who find bloody noses and whispered voices bone-chilling, heeeeeeere's The Haunting of Molly Hartley.
[Melds] genres with a haunting poignancy that's mildly undercut by a script that, during its last act, bounces around like a jeep on a dirt road.
Exactly what a B-movie should be.
The filmmaker's deftness at evoking theme and sentiment through editorial montages within individual dramatic scenes reaches an apotheosis here.
The complexity of [Zhangke's] postmodernist formal gambit nonetheless gets at something pressing.
One-note insider navel-gazing with no aspirations except to excite its adoring base.
Deadly traps may remain the bread and butter of the Saw series, but the real trick has become keeping these fetid sequels moderately fresh.
Solely predicated on its twist ending.

It's hard not to see the rabidly popular series's deliberate insubstantiality, its desire to address teendom in juvenile ways, as a depressing commentary on the dwindling standards of young entertainment consumers.
Kaufman's meta-meta mind-boggler is, ultimately, far more heady and haunting than maddeningly egocentric.
A limp, unfunny time-waster.
Pride and Glory's commentary on law enforcement vice and decency is far less immediate and realistic than its gritty aesthetic and tone would have one believe.
A collection of superbly wrought black-and-white animated vignettes.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Oliver Stone of the 1990s might have found something epic in the strange saga of George W. Bush, but he undoubtedly would not have made W., the contemporary Stone's incomplete rush-job of a portrait of our embattled 43rd president.
If ever there was a paradigm of insufferable European art-house pretentiousness, this is it.
movie_title: Das Haus der Schlafenden Schönen (House of the Sleeping Beauties) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although the title is imposingly big, producer George Lucas and director Steven Spielberg's first installment in the adventure saga since 1989's The Last Crusade is, in many respects, disappointingly diminutive.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Having already demonstrated the worst that the horror, action and fantasy genres have to offer, Uwe Boll tries his hand at political/cultural satire with Postal and comes up with something smelling awfully similar to feces.
C.S. Lewis meets Teen Beat.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An obnoxious fantasy vision of teendom slathered in self-satisfied snark.
While it's unclear if this nonsense is propaganda for Madonna's Kabbalah dogma, there's absolutely no doubt that Revolver achieves a higher plane of badness.
Chris Weitz crams his story full of magical terms and concepts with a rapidity that leaves things confusing and thus meaningless.
Though colorful, cheery and energetic, there's something missing from this song-and-dance routine.
Has quite a bit going for it, which makes its eventual reliance on inane genre gimmicks that much more disappointing.
Tim Skousen was first assistant director on Napoleon Dynamite, and he does little other than mimic its slightly off-kilter comedic tone and bizarre misfit characters.

A miniscule budget is probably at least somewhat to blame for Be My Oswald's dull sets, audio in which voices are drowned out by reverb, and digital video that frequently looks worse than my MiniDV-shot home movies.
Often as overwrought as it is heartrending.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of the year's most stunningly feeble offerings.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Savages naturally invites comparisons to Away From Her--all of them unflattering.
Raymond De Felitta makes amends for 2005's intolerable The Thing About My Folks with this involving inquiry into the career of the late jazz crooner Jackie Paris.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The title of this nonfiction examination into JFK's assassination implies that its focus is the legacy of Lee Harvey Oswald and his infamous crime, but the truth is far more mundane.
It's the Paul Haggis version of National Lampoon's Vacation.
Paranoid Park's triumph ... is its aesthetic design.
[Its] off-the-charts screwiness obscures virtually all shortcomings.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Plays like a music video without the music, a spectacle of shiny weapons, spurting blood, and Jesus Christ poses that would have benefited from more overlaid songs and less blabber.

Eventually peddles the same old ass-backwards messages, equating physical beauty with goodness, and positing that a woman's greatest dream is that a hunk will materialize out of thin air and make her a contented homemaker and wife.
After early hints of potential Schwarzenegger-ish goofiness, Midnight Eagle settles into near-complete torpor.
A holiday melodrama suffering from severe bloat.
Frank Darabont ditches the warm and fuzzies for out-and-out cynicism about mankind's capacity for goodness and altruism with The Mist.
The type of film one would expect from Marc Forster -- banal, trite and apt to ramrod simplistic symbolism down viewers' throats.
It's debatable whether Cage's supernatural ability is any more interesting than his strange coiffure.
The director treats his material as if it were Last Year at Marienbad, yet his story's particulars are too goofy and too incompatible to result in something haunting or beguiling.
Jia's empathetic close-ups -- thanks to Yu Lik Wai's masterful HD cinematography -- ground the film's portrait in individual experience.
Paul Schrader blends lethargic self-referentiality with anemic political jabs in The Walker.
Just a more superficially sober version of Death Wish.
Takeshi Miike's original 2003 One Missed Call was second-rate techno-phobic J-horror tripe, meaning that Eric Valette's even lousier American remake is something like the next generation of suck.
Makes one want to assume a state of mind opposite to the film's title.
Marion Cotillard is the only reason to sit through La Vie En Rose, a biopic that compounds its basic tediousness by fracturing its narrative in a vain effort to mask a stale rise-and-fall arc.
Since Book of Secrets doesn't take its faux-intricate story seriously, there's no reason this review should either.
An electric, inventive amalgam of gonzo violence and lyrical sentimentality.
The odiousness of [Baumbach's] protagonists ... isn't as problematic a factor as is the redundancy (and occasional mean-spiritedness) of his psychological portraits.
A complex, confessional examination of [Jean-Claude Brisseau's] twisted, thorny and ultimately ambiguous feelings toward women and sex.
A trio of superb cat-and-mouse sequences ... more effectively pinpoint Bourne's psychological anxiety and confusion than Damon's robotic, one-note performance.
There are many good actresses unsuited for romantic comedies, and Hilary Swank, despite her considerable talents, is one of them.
Neither [Roberts] nor her illustrious co-stars can compensate for a facile screenplay without many laughs or insights into our government's inner workings.
The perfect marriage of artist and material.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Water Horse's framing device lends just the right measure of nostalgia and fairy-tale wonder.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Without unpredictability or the possibility of an unhappy ending, how can a film truly inspire?
Steep provides a skin-deep history lesson on extreme skiing.
The film gets some mileage out of mocking fatuous biopic conventions.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Thomas Anderson's loose adaptation of Upton Sinclair's 1927 novel Oil! finds the director exhibiting newfound maturity and restraint without sacrificing any measure of artistry.
Singing Revolution eloquently illustrates that, once granted, even a smidgen of freedom can transform into an unstoppable weapon against oppression.
Unwise use of CGI is eventually no more debilitating a defect than I Am Legend's wayward third act, which begins with Neville cornily reciting lines from Shrek.
Comprised of confused, conflicting recollections, and opinions that lead to no concrete truths, the film proves a case study in unknowability.
movie_title: A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A lushly shot, proficiently performed, and largely stultifying period piece that invites only mild, detached admiration.
Benefits immeasurably from a cast of colorful supporting players, as well as a taut narrative that builds to a surprisingly tense climax.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A tender, poignant allegory for Arab-Israeli tensions that never makes a single overt gesture toward articulating its larger concerns.

The thread binding these unrelated folks is a common disconnect between public facades and private conduct, though the notion that people aren't always who they appear to be is hardly some sort of revelation about society or human behavior.
There's barely a trace of substance to Kelly's fiasco, nor anything like a so-bad-it's-good vibe.
One of the year's funniest theatrical releases, [but] it's also tough to shake a feeling of mild disappointment.
Sexualized to the point of absurdity.
A holiday fable far too safe and toothless to take advantage of Vince Vaughn's ribald strengths.
Employs a warm and leisurely, though never sluggish, pace that's upfront about Bogdanovich's intention to take his sweet time tackling every topic of relevant interest.
movie_title: Runnin' Down a Dream: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Confirms that Rickles's enduring popularity as the high priest of putdowns can be chalked up to an admirable national trait to not take ourselves too seriously.
movie_title: Mr. Warmth: The Don Rickles Project (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gandhi, My Father weakly opts for lionization at precisely the moment it should go in for the killshot.
In The Final Season, high school baseball gives a small town its pride and identity. And quells teenage rebellion. And helps foster two separate romances. And cures cancer.
Lars and the Real Girl is an SNL sketch reconfigured as quirky-corny Sundance pap.
Righteously infuriating in its comprehensive portrait of a system that values public approval ratings and a high conviction rate above the truth.
movie_title: I Just Didn't Do It (Soredemo boku wa yattenai) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Coens' first film since their leaden remake of The Ladykillers is an exceptional return to their Blood Simple roots, offering up a crime saga in which money is almost as irresistible as bad choices are inevitable.
Feels like the work of a director so righteously angry and so pleased with his formal experimentation that he doesn't realize how painfully, inelegantly obvious he's being.
Go Go Tales' sleazy energy, sense of community, black humor and bittersweet nostalgia are infectious.
"Hanging out with you is pretty depressing," says self-proclaimed dream expert Mel to Gary, a similar reaction aroused by Jake Paltrow's excruciatingly tone-deaf writing-directing debut.
Pushes things into violent, hardcore territory all too similar to Danny Boyle's zombie-outbreak flick 28 Days Later and its 2007 sequel.

There's sincerity in Gilroy's belief in man's aptitude for recognizing the error of his ways, as well as in his acknowledgement that realignments of one's moral compass often require great application.
Doesn't have much to say about marriage other than that it's complex, and often fraught with disappointment, deception and conflicting urges.
Chabrol's familiar critique of the bourgeoisie is dispiritingly lethargic and simple.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's rare to find a film with such an ignominious reputation actually living up to the hype.
It goes without saying that the film is pretty awful. But that doesn't mean it's not pretty funny too.
A remixed version of Elvis's "Rubberneckin'" is an apt credit sequence number, since the movie is itself a similarly trivial, jazzed-up version of a standard.

Hou Hsiao-hsien's trademark long takes call attention to the passage of time, and as such they're intimately attuned to his ongoing thematic interest in the bonds between the past, present, and future.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely has a message movie been as noxious ... manages to be not only contrived and culturally offensive, but also exploitative of the illicit practice it theoretically opposes.
The style-over-substance Scott's only substantive text.
Moviegoers beware: nausea is a prime side effect of consuming Feast of Love, an extraordinarily inane multi-character saga about the complexities of love from Robert Benton
A film whose own wisdom about the world seems principally derived from innumerable coming-of-age tales.
If its critique sometimes lacks grace, it's nonetheless bolstered by a shrewd understanding of the way pop culture exploits minority differences for entertainment purposes.
Redundant, artless, and lacking anything approaching directorial restraint.
Laughably melodramatic and agonizingly inert.
Run, Fatboy, Run is the type of romantic comedy apt to be described as "nice" or "sweet," both of which are codewords for "unexceptional" and "useless."
Lions for Lambs is, to put it mildly, beyond stagey.
Once again finds Gray breathing gritty, electric life into a conventional tale.
Fugit ably keeps this superficially controversial, and yet actually rather conventional, film from devolving into obnoxious oddness.
Jerry Seinfeld returns to the mainstream spotlight with Bee Movie, which proves as awkward and ineffective as George Costanza's attempts to wear a toupee.

The primary obstacle to enjoying any moment of Martian Child is Dennis, a little creature whose habits never feel like anything other than groan-worthy screenwriter contrivances aimed at cheaply eliciting audience waterworks.
Fat Girls' portrait of its small town high school milieu feels immediate and authentic even when the story's perfunctory machinations don't.
A Western-tinged adventure whose innovations are so scant that the only things keeping the enterprise afloat are clumsy references to its predecessors.
Mungiu's fascination with modes (and codes) of behavior gives his period piece a resonant universality.
I've never cared for Joe Strummer and The Clash, but Julien Temple's Joe Strummer: The Future is Unwritten is, for the most part, some sort of incredible.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Not only is American Gangster dumb as a rock, but it's also far too convinced of its import to be any fun.
An excessively convoluted rehash of its predecessors.
Straight-up bonkers.
Shrewder than it initially lets on, primarily because it refuses to schematically pigeonhole its characters.
Steve Carell's pursed-lipped awkwardness and sweet buffoonery are both in fine form, but those endearing qualities aren't nearly enough to salvage Peter Hedges's incorrigibly hackneyed film.
A triumphantly brisk, bleak B-movie.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: To hell with equivocation or beating around the bush: Terrence Malick's 1978 Days of Heaven is the greatest film ever made.

This low-budget horror film charts the fallout from a mysterious media transmission that cognitively rewires people into killers, and eventually turns out to be an imbalanced project that delivers increasingly diminishing returns.
Sawalich's TV movie-grade direction isn't up to the task of enlivening material that eventually settles into a predictable, torpid narrative structure.
Marc Levin may avoid outright idol-worship, but any restraint exhibited by his film is disingenuous.
Gentle preaching is still preaching.
In the Bedroom redux, but squishier and stupider.
An intellectual whirligig lacking depth or soul.
Provides gruesome, incontrovertible images to complement its deliberations about morality.
A fluffy cotton candy confection that can't be bothered to manufacture any legitimate dramatic tension.
If I had a choice between suffering through a Dane Cook film or the outtakes from Carrot Top's Chairman of the Board, I'd go with the latter.
A supposed investigation into America's attitude toward childbirth, The Business of Being Born quickly turns into a propaganda piece for midwifery before closing on a fortuitously complex note.
On the basis of First Sunday, it would seem writer-director David E. Talbert has been keeping close tabs on the creative recipe for success concocted by Tyler Perry.
Smart People is a borderline-excruciating exercise in trying to replicate the eccentric charm of Little Miss Sunshine.
Aside from depicting American academia as a cutthroat environment that can inspire deadly resentment, there's not much going on.
The film's depiction of deteriorating-under-pressure group dynamics comes to an abrupt end just as it gets going
Like My Blueberry Nights, [Jones' Elizabeth] is a looker with depressingly little going on beneath her striking facade.
Expresses how globalization has yet to completely change the fact that the world remains an enormous, imposing, largely foreign place.
The only wonder eventually elicited by Nim's Island is of a mystified variety.

It's nice to see The Facts of Life's Mindy Cohen working again, but crawling along in clunky, directionless fashion, Waters's pseudo-rom-com ultimately dies a slow death.
The Unknown Woman begins the same way director Giuseppe Tornatore's last film, Malena, operated throughout: by ogling a fine female form.
Tuya's Marriage can feel a tad overwritten, but in terms of its cultural and emotional portraits, the film's neo-realist authenticity is nonetheless striking.
Young@Heart's worst enemy is its director, Stephen Walker, whose incessant pushing and prodding strives to manipulate in ways both needless and trite.
21 is a mini-Ocean's Eleven about, and for, people who are the age of its title.

Largely avoids sharply delineated portraits, with its focus on the scene at the expense of individuals, ultimately resulting in a documentary that doesn't rise above the functional.
Director Voulgaris puts considerable effort into making Valse Sentimentale as aesthetically hideous as possible.
A Korean ghost story that alternates between being confusing and dim.

It may not be as insensitive as Blood Diamond's inane examination of the diamond industry and its accompanying slave trade, but Flawless's utilization of the issue as a mere diversionary plot point is nonetheless plenty distasteful.
At one point, Chapman confesses that he doesn't enjoy the movies because they're "so goddamn phony," and with regard to the superficial, ugly-as-dirt Chapter 27, he's right on the money.
Is the golden age of Judd Apatow already waning?

Remaking Rocky Balboa as a comedy isn't a half-bad idea; remaking it as a comedy starring Adam Carolla, the dreadfully unfunny former host of Loveline and The Man Show, most certainly is a terrible one.
Megane is the type of cutesy-quaint foreign import that's just about insufferable.

Director Benson Lee makes sure to serve up his topic's key points, but only in easy-to-digest bites that eschew any real investigation into the movement's history, pioneers, influences, and multicultural variations.
Quaint and slight.
Bra Boys is a carefully manicured PR video for the infamous Bra Boys surfer community.
So soul-crushingly vapid it makes one hate high school all over again.
Forbidden Kingdom serves up convoluted mythology with mild indifference.
That rare debut in which self-conscious formal daring proves exhilarating rather than excruciating.
Far less concerned with character development than with bludgeoning clues to the drama's true nature.
Comparable to dousing one's eyeballs in a sugary hyper-digitized Skittles soup.

As unsophisticated as ... Brian DePalma's Redacted, although at least Broomfield forgoes spurious aesthetic shenanigans.
For all its sensitivity, thoughtful sobriety, and sound performances, though, Boy A finally permits itself an excessive number of contrived and/or clichéd gestures.

Mechanical through and through.

An amplification of scale and subject matter that isn't, alas, accompanied by an upgrade in humor.

movie_review_blurb: Chang gracefully juxtaposes the country and the metropolitan to express the knotted-up mixture of anguish, anger, hope, and trepidation of those in the dammed river's wake.
A semiotics-tinged investigation into the nature of images themselves: how the contents, arrangement, and manipulation of the frame all affect interpretation and help define meaning.
That the film also features SNL's Amy Poehler makes the proceedings' crushing mediocrity that much more frustrating.
A 1920s football saga that blends rusty screwball comedy and perfunctory romance under a period piece veneer.
Ayers' second straight overwrought and unfulfilling tale concerning a loco white boy knee-deep in the City of Angels' criminal scene.
Suspense is something foreign to Anamorph.

For a film about American freedom of expression and the necessity for open dialogue, it's hard to imagine Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed being more one-sided, narrow-minded, and intellectually dishonest.
Segel's script frequently enlivens pedestrian scenarios with sharp verbal back-and-forths and sudden cutaways to bizarre gags.
Like far too many modern horror films, All the Boys Love Mandy Lane flaunts its knowledge of classic genre fundamentals but fails to do anything very clever or surprising with them.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Romero's finest achievement may have been...[this] 1977 character study about a young, lonely man living in Pittsburgh who may or may not be a vampire.
No unnecessary authorial pushing and prodding is required on behalf of Kim and Scott's amazing story.

There's a patient attentiveness and inquisitiveness to Munyurangabo. that seemingly springs, at least in part, from the cultural divide between Korean-American filmmaker Lee Isaac Chung and his native Rwandan cast, milieu, and language.
Melancholic music and a torpid pace don't make In Bruges profound, but they are symptomatic of this phony, pretentious crime film's schizophrenia.
Provides a complex, compelling depiction of the intrinsic relationship between love for God and one's kin.
Cable TV-ready filler.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A trifling slice of winter season counter-programming.

One of the cinema's preeminent examples of gothic horror.

Reeves's film works hard to negate any noteworthy meaning from its mayhem.
Proves that Hollywood doesn't have a monopoly on ponderous, ersatz-thoughtful war dramas.

A breathtakingly bad Altman rip-off that seems like a wholly unintentional parody of multi-narrative films.

Only Uwe Boll would assume that the moviegoing public craved a trashy Lord of the Rings rip-off starring Burt Reynolds and Matthew Lillard, and only he could then manage to make such a potentially riotous endeavor so humorless.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's not half bad, largely because it places an absolute premium on brash, bawdy humor.

Joyously maintains the rhythmic syntax and considerate spirit of Dr. Seuss.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

Pure promo fluff.
movie_title: Meat Loaf: In Search of Paradise (2008)

movie_review_blurb: So obsessed with delivering a story about "mania" through overcooked narrative and aesthetic means that one ultimately feels as manipulated as enlightened.
Every line is a Big Statement, every character has exactly one defining quality, and every plot development is cornier than the last.
Flails about in search of poetry.

Roland Emmerich is partial to cutting-edge special effects and stone-age storytelling, meaning that 10,000 B.C., a dim-witted CG extravaganza set in prehistoric times, is something like his ideal project.

movie_review_blurb: Lacks any convincing magic or heart.

Uninterested in revolutionizing the documentary form, Blindsight instead proves the enduring potential afforded by straightforward verité filmmaking methods.
The directors sacrifice substantially investigating the four girls for Morgan Spurlock-ish populist gimmickry.
I give in. Regardless of his limited acting range and penchant for choosing the goofiest projects available, Jason Statham is pretty awesome.
Perhaps the feeblest entry in the Will Ferrell Sports Comedy canon.

The only message worth relaying about The Messengers is: Avoid.

movie_review_blurb: Fatherless children are the order of the day, but the film develops this theme no more than the absolute minimum, instead content to stage swordfights and races-against-time between its plucky child protagonists and their monstrous enemies.

movie_title: A Última Vez Que Vi Macau (The Last Time I Saw Macao) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It just sits there, in the process dispensing with so much leaden dialogue and half-formed narrative threads that it manages only to bring together lots of fine actors in the beautiful rural southern sunshine.
In search of answers for why a man and his surrogate son terrorized Washington, D.C., with a sniper rifle in October 2002, Blue Caprice proffers an intimate portrait devoid of sympathy.
A film that's in perfect sync with its subject.
The film -- even with its deliberately ridiculous, open-ended metro-mayhem finale -- is just so much tiresome Texas Chainsaw redux.
Bounty Killer proves a derivative science-fiction saga with even less flavor than the characters' rare favorite beverage, Pabst Blue Ribbon.
A concise portrait of not only the historic Bordeaux region of France, but also of the way its business has been impacted-for good and ill-by China's emergence as a superpower.
For a film about a killing machine who can see at night, it's fittingly ironic that the film itself is, both narratively and visually, a dark, muddled mess.
If you can't even deliver blatant car-nography, what's the point?
American Made Movie reveals itself as a superficial inquiry, substituting random anecdotes for genuine proposals about how the country might renew its manufacturing base.
The central conceit is impossibly contrived.
It's so clichéd that it stymies any narrative momentum, and so dreary that it negates any chance for unintentional comedy.
Spark: A Burning Man Story isn't so much a story as a feature-length commercial for the annual hippie-courting festival held in Nevada's Black Rock Desert.
A mannered, occasionally mesmerizing romance that frequently cops to its own artificiality.
Though nothing immensely consequential happens during the course of Drinking Buddies, Swanberg crafts a conversational atmosphere that compensates for a lack of momentous drama
A film that spends scant time fleshing out any various elements ...
[A] static, emotionless saga, which is defined less by zealous feeling than by a dull, decorous air of respectability.
The story overflows with reverence but is drastically short on passion or suspense ...
Fixates on the perils and panic of our modern surveillance culture while itself proving to be borderline unwatchable.
Drew makes a valid case for the artist as not simply an all-time great, but as a casualty of a business that prizes bottom-line cost management above unique creativity.
movie_title: Drew: The Man Behind The Poster (2013)

movie_review_blurb: [Presents] artistic creativity as an unpredictable, ever-flowing journey from one unconventional locale to another.
Fahey-who died in 2001 at age 61-is depicted as a unique explorer who was in constant search of his next sonic revelation.
movie_title: In Search of Blind Joe Death: The Saga of John Fahey (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Both amusing and acutely perceptive, it's a portrait of the way in which art is born from suffering, and how that pain can lead to both beauty and, ultimately, catharsis.
Still, despite its wealth of urgent footage...Tricked doesn't have anything new or particularly eye-opening to say about its subject.
Merely a one-note roundelay of angry name-calling.

Bolstered by performances that convey profound grief and remorse without look-at-me histrionics, The Past is steeped in the believable micro details of its scenario while also expanding to universals.
The Invisible Woman finds Ralph Fiennes proving as adept behind the camera as he is in front of it.
A captivating go-for-broke lead turn by Juri lends the film a poignancy to help offset the juvenile shock-tactic impulses.
A serial-killer saga that squanders its sturdy cast via torpid scripting and a nonstop stream of clichés.
[A] sobering wartime drama ...

Cursed with a vague, rambling script and an equally indistinct lead performance, the film is a scattershot series of vignettes about self-definition that, ultimately, never coheres into a lucid whole.

...Hernandez merely revels in his own pretentiousness, staging one dully limp encounter after another with self-conscious camerawork and absurdly stilted drama that renders the entire project a pseudo-porny slog.
...Found refuses to dig deeply into its chosen themes and consequently finds little reason - outside of servicing genre fans' gore fetishism - to exist.

...the film makes its primary point so early on that it soon finds itself with nothing much to say - and, consequently, winds up becoming little more than a tedious and meandering bit of psycho-hillbilly performance art.
Cabin Fever: Patient Zero ditches the nasty allegory of Eli Roth's original and Ti West's studio-butchered first sequel for far duller, standard-issue conventions.
Too slight to register as anything more than a stunted-adolescent trifle.
And So It Goes never goes quite far enough, in any direction.
Rocks in My Pockets posits depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia as conditions that, though potentially lethal, remain manageable, if only through persistent battle.
Awash in exposition-heavy dialogue, punctuated by the occasional Wizard Of Oz reference, the film provides no meaningful background on its characters, and even less drama.
Video Games: The Movie opens with a barrage of statistics before segueing into a sketchy history lesson-cum-industry promotion.
Tognazzi shoots her material with stately grace but a distinct lack of energy, which is also true of Buy's composed but inert lead performance.
An excessively whimsical romance that's undone by cartoonish performances and direction by Michel Gondry that practically bludgeons viewers via cutesy formal trickery.
A one-note on-the-lam saga that's primarily notable for its simplistic celebration of the outlaw life through endless shots of writer/director/star Jason Momoa in sunset silhouette.
A feature-length commercial for the Jay-Z brand.
A cheeseball B-movie about a woman and a girl combating arms dealers in the African desert that fails to generate suspense, excitement, or even unintentional B-movie laughs.
A film that's all airy, abstract pretentiousness.
Florid direction, lurid atmosphere, and reckless passions all contribute to the intoxicating deliriousness of Miss Lovely, a thriller set in 1980s India's B-movie industry.

An affecting rural Southern drama about a delinquent teen's descent into misery and mayhem that distinguishes itself from the indie pack through precise direction and superb lead performances by Aaron Paul and newcomer Josh Wiggins.
The story of a rural, working-class Mexican family torn apart by the drug trade, this indie is a gripping and increasingly horrifying descent into violence and despair.
Compellingly conveys how music - so intimately wedded to our emotions, and experiences - can help the severely ill elderly reconnect with themselves.
With its characters all sketched in single dimension and its story woefully light on surprise or intricacy, Berry's work proves less interested in nuanced drama than in merely forwarding an agenda.
The filmmakers profile the prolific Mark Landis with a non-judgmental straightforwardness that allows the sheer brazenness of his scams to generate both shock and amusement.
A grim '70s-style detective story whose narrative failures are overshadowed by evocative turn-of-the-millennium anxieties and a world-weary tough-guy performance from Liam Neeson.

Lavaine's midlife-crisis dramedy piles on dreary subplots involving Antoine's grating pals and their one-dimensional romantic and/or financial problems, but his material is unfunny and superficial to the point of inertia.
For the most part, writer-director Sophie Fillières' If You Don't, I Will strikes an engaging tone of melancholic humor through its portrait of a French marriage slowly falling to pieces.
At once a spoof of, and loving tribute to, '70s-era visions of the future, Space Station 76 nods to 2001 in numerous ways.
Stirringly conveys how a truly productive healthcare system-one that seriously addresses the ailments of the needy-would prize compassion, efficiency, and availability as highly as it does profit.
The Foxy Merkins would have made an idiosyncratic and amusing short film; at 80 minutes, it's a one-joke comedy that quickly overstays its welcome.
Content to stay on the surface, it's a puff piece posing as a real documentary.

From sudden zooms and abrupt freeze frames to lengthy tracking shots, slow-motion, and CG-enhanced fantasy interludes, Why Don't You Play In Hell? boasts an aesthetic insanity to match its uninhibited narrative.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Politicians-replaced-by-doppelgängers has long been a favorite comedy movie device - yet never has it been employed for more torturous faux-funny business than in Viva la Libertà.
Long, leisurely paced, wide-ranging, meticulously crafted, intellectually intricate, and touched with profundity.
Headlined by an unconvincing Daniel Radcliffe with a lame American accent, this sluggish and atonal fantasy saga awkwardly straddles the line between comedy and horror.
The director never provides any greater sense of what deeper, more twisted effects [Vandyke's] cinematographic project is having on surrounding events, or on Vandyke.
Has little new to say about its subject but nonetheless thrives courtesy of its seedy, nocturnal L.A. atmosphere and a magnetic, uninhibited lead performance by Gyllenhaal.
Marries trite coming-of-age pap with half-hearted murder-mystery suspense to create a work of staggering pointlessness.
Against all good sense, Exists plays its material straight, possibly proving itself the year's most laughably derivative and dreary film.
Conventional but rousing, Fury paints a bleak and brutal portrait of World War II combat through the turret of a battle-scarred American tank.
It's potentially juicy morality-play material, but Edgerton's script does nothing novel with it, so that most of Felony is a long, drawn-out slog
A flashy portrait of rebel "hacktivists" and their anarchist accomplices that opts for superficial, unconvincing glorification over in-depth analysis.
Has enough visual panache to compensate for the static, conversational nature of the work.
Just as egregious as its retrograde sexual politics, however, is the film's distinct lack of energy or wit -- shortcomings that ultimately render it merely a cruddy B-movie throwaway.
New York art-world hipsters get raked over the countryside campfire coals in Hellaware, a frequently hilarious - if ultimately somewhat predictable - satire about artistic exploration and pretension.
An alternately morose and quirky tale about a suicidal doorman that, despite a sturdy lead performance, fails to generate either droll laughs or poignant drama.
Save for a brief prologue, there isn't a pro-slavery Southern man to be found in this fantasyland vision of the Civil War ...
Oppenheimer throws into sharp relief the contrast between Adi and the murderers' perspectives, and thus the terrifying tension that engulfs the country as a whole.
[Gerster] affects a hanging-out mood that melds the slacker cool of Jim Jarmusch's 1984 film, Stranger In Paradise, to the dry, jazz-scored, melancholy-tinged comedy of early Woody Allen.
It's a film that's about as funny and/or scary as a lump of sod.
Rarely has the terminal seemed as interminable as it does in Lullaby, writer-director Andrew Levitas's tedious saga of a family reuniting at the deathbed of their paterfamilias.
A smart, sardonic, unpredictable morality play that gets the little things right.
[T]he story is a hopeless mess that from the outset seems to be missing key exposition that might help fill in some of its many gaps.
The camera swoops and whooshes about but never generates any compelling energy - Chow's film proves endlessly manic but devoid of much mirth.

Alas, listening to De Niro's criminal bigwig Dragna casually describe how he was motivated to take up his underworld profession by an episode of Full House isn't enough to salvage David Grovic's dreary directorial debut.
[The film is] content to merely celebrate, with wholly unwarranted glee, the ultimate triumph of a man who revels in his own awesomeness.
Short and sweet, it's an empathetic and affecting tribute to the great - and vital - artists who all too rarely receive a center-stage encore.

Mistakenly convinced that cuteness can compensate for a lack of basic believability, The Right Kind Of Wrong squanders its engaging leads and cheerful joviality with a plot of stupefying senselessness.
[Haunt] assumes [clichés] are all a horror audience craves, even if the events as a whole lack the slightest semblance of logic.
[D]espite [some] concessions to unrealistic Hollywood conventions, The Attorney's righteous anger at injustice [...] is delivered with effectively mounting urgency.
The way the film hews to tiresome conventions is itself a buzzkill, but worse is its sheer lack of energy[.]
...a dull do-over that ditches most of its source material's sharp social satire by reimagining its tale in more traditional superhero-style fashion.
...provides few answers to its central mystery but beguiles via a mood of oppressive existential dread.
Fairbrass proves a hulking wannabe ass-kicker without much distinctive charisma, and his leaden performance is matched by sleepy, one-note supporting turns by the slumming-it Patric and Caan.
A screenwriter tries to fall in love in order to lend authenticity to his script about a man falling in love in Cavemen, a tiresome film that itself knows nothing but other rom-com plots.

Shot with a high-def flatness that makes it look like a TV movie, the film indulges in much wannabe-funny wailing, shrieking, and flopping about by Nénette and Paul, only to then lace its buffoonish material with semi-serious undercurrents ...
Regardless of its true-story credentials, Summer In February seems to have been cobbled together from the moldy spare parts of countless Masterpiece Theater PBS movies.

It's a film that feels like it's simply going through the motions-not to mention one whose ultimate critique of trying to relive the past is, in light of its mass of clichés, more than a tad disingenuous
The program proves a study in the benefits and limitations of telling a story in a condensed format.
movie_title: Oscar Nominated Live Action Short Films 2014 (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, as with so many social-survey documentaries, the film's macro view comes at the expense of any microcosmic depth.
A chintzy, poorly acted origin story of the legendary Greek hero that blatantly mimics its genre ancestors while drenching its action in corny 3D and CG-enhanced slow-motion.
Sluggish storytelling and heavy-handed moralizing.
Beyond Outrage is the very sort of tiresome tough-guy retread that, with 2007's meta drama Glory to the Filmmaker! and 2008's darkly comic Achilles and the Tortoise, Kitano seemed to have outgrown.
Equally clumsy and lazy -- and thoroughly, unintentionally funny -- 47 Ronin combines samurai-sword clichés with Hollywood-style CG mayhem.
A smutty-minded rom-com that fails to gussy up its bland central romance with endless dirty talk by both men and women, and wannabe-scandalous scenarios
Dark House practically drowns under the weight of mismatched horror tropes, including a preponderance of loud-noise jolt-scares and idiotic character behavior.
It's a techno-thriller of brain-dead proportions ...
Hill comes across as a figure of tremendous resolve and courage.
A film as clumsy as the spelling of its title.

Led by a superbly composed performance from Jesse Eisenberg, Kelly Reichardt's portrait of three eco-terrorists intent on blowing up an Oregon dam thrillingly melds understated political inquiry and slow-burn suspense.
Amid its silly contrivances, the romance Words and Pictures manages to tap into middle-age regret, bitterness, and fears that the promise of youth has passed.
Ayouch film casts a sharp gaze on tragedy, and the larger socio-economic issues that beget fanaticism.
[...] When it isn't head-smackingly obvious, is clumsily rushed and incoherent.

A dull retelling of the original 1994 West Memphis Three trial that brings nothing new to the table but underwhelming performances and a wishy-washy refusal to state an opinion about the real killer's identity.
Eschews repugnant gore for a sly goofiness that makes Jaa come across like a real-life Looney Tunes character.
It proves an increasingly superficial affair, especially given that the director's attempts at suspense are largely facile and Raf Simons's creative process is barely investigated.
Chockablock with instances of characters not shooting, running, attacking, or sneaking away when they can or should, this thriller comes off like the world's most rigged game.
A film that ultimately comes across like the formulaic stepson of Frozen River, Winter's Bone, and countless other rundown-rural-community character studies.
Puenzo dramatizes her material with an overcooked sense of import that generates scant suspense, even once Israeli agents close in on their Nazi prey.
For No Good Reason details the famed wild-man cartoonist's career with a stylistic daring that doesn't quite match its subject's, but is nonetheless in keeping with his unconventional spirit.
The Machine brings little new to the subject save for an ominously ambiguous conclusion about the consequences of making computers more advanced than their human masters.
An unfocused mishmash that thrives only when it fixates on footage of actual bouts.
A mushy concoction that's not only unfulfilling, it's gag-worthy.
Nate comes across as an insufferably arrogant twerp stupid enough to believe there's loyalty in the underworld.
A concise and blistering indie that captures a sense of volatile madness via sharp handheld aesthetics and a commanding lead performance from Sheila Etxeberria.
A cleverly executed mind game that generates scares via structural ingenuity, Oculus suggests a world coming terrifyingly unmoored from its bearings.
Unfortunately, while the documentary's points are clear, its desire to articulate them primarily through contrasts neuters some of its persuasiveness.
A grim, formulaic saga in desperate need of some genuine B-movie fury and flair.
