At times a tad too oblique for its own good, Hide Your Smiling Faces nonetheless casts a potent spell, delivering a disquieting portrait of masculine rage and fear over lives perched on the precipice of an abyss.
Fisher's filmmaking, aside from a couple scenes ... that are nicely composed in long-take two-shots, is too consistently flat to make the material spark.
...The Raid 2 proves to be one of the most repugnant spectacles in recent memory, and one made all the more unpleasant by its epic pretensions.
Israel's fractured psyche is plumbed via narrative splintering in Policeman, Nadav Lapid's compelling drama about his homeland's burgeoning social unrest.
The film neuters any potential for the very type of stinging social commentary that was the original series' hallmark.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tobias Lindholm's hostage-negotiation drama wields its verité style for maximum tension.
A corny saga of social and generational conflict, it's ultimately yet another Chinese period epic that functions as a thinly veiled treatise on the nobility of socialist equality.
Ivin conveys both facts and emotions with efficient brushstrokes (a spied glance, an offhand comment) that are matched by an understated, evocative lyricism.
No mutation is necessary to clearly see that Marvel's "reboot" of their signature franchise is an unimaginative remake of Sam Raimi's 2002 Spider-Man.

Seth MacFarlane's comedic modus operandi is to shock with outrageousness and pander with TV and movie citations via one non sequitur after another, a strategy that leads to a few laughs but nothing approaching lasting humor.
Although Angèle's religious faith and Frédéric's belief in luck seem like strained attempts at adding heft to the material, the film nevertheless works up a potent dramatic restlessness...
Timor Bekmambetov doesn't need to make his material overtly wink at the audience because his conceit is itself enough of an obvious dim-bulb joke.
Kirby Dick's spartan use of graphics and statistics conveys arguments with little grandstanding.
That's My Boy lazily exists in a fantasyland of Adam Sandler's perpetual adolescence, even as it generates some moderate comic friction from Sandler and Andy Samberg's testy back-and-forth.
If the Adam Shankman film's debasement of its subject into campy kitsch is the unavoidable fate of all culturally dangerous art, that doesn't make it any less palatable.
Soling and co-director David Hilbert divide their screen into multiple visual quadrants, an aesthetic strategy that soon becomes a wearisome affectation ...

Polley's mature interest in emotional relationships should bolster the film's arthouse prospects, though an A-list cast isn't likely to help this understated indie make much mainstream summer box office noise.
It's predictably ironic that The Magic of Belle Isle champions the unparalleled power of imagination while displaying absolutely none of its own.
A coherent characterization of Robert Pattinson's striving schemer is nowhere to be found in this pedestrian period piece.
Unfortunately, mocking jibes and cutaways to Team America and Wonder Woman (among other movies and TV shows) establish a jokey attitude that weakens the overall case.
Despite referring to the tribe as "my people," Routh is wholly miscast, yet his ill-fitting presence is part and parcel of the plotting's general illogicality.
John Stalberg's film proves incapable of striking even a faint comedic spark.

With the faux-verité aesthetics of [Rec], the American-tourists-in-Eastern-European-hell setup of Hostel, and the brain of a mushy radioactive mutant zombie thingie, Chernobyl Diaries is little more than decomposed horror leftovers.
A narcissistic spectacle of male grief...
The mood is generally melodramatic and ends as mushy, aided by the soft-focus cinematography that drenches it all in melancholic nostalgia.

Weaver's story slowly begins to buckle under the weight of its own self-seriousness and familiarity, concluding with a showdown and resolution marked by one implausible and unsatisfying been-here-done-that twist after another.
Shamelessly mimics Michael Bay's larger-than-life dialogue, sweeping cinematography, cornball romance, and military fetishism.
makes a compelling case for games as not only clever hand-eye coordination exercises, but also as manifestations of their creators' emotional and philosophical viewpoints.
Fleet, funny, and smart enough to not overstay its welcome, it's a commentary-coated R-rated comedy with supreme box office potential.
The film treats its headline-ready topics as merely window dressing for a whodunit that's without intrigue or surprise.
The real scam was the filmmakers tricking Rebecca Hall (and a cameoing Amanda Seyfried) into participating in this blunt instrument of an indie.
There's no pact in The Pact, which is indicative of this faux spooky tale's guiding illogicality.
The film shrewdly opts not to proffer its own hypothesis about the true reasons behind the Gibson family buying Frédéric Bourdin's story.
Too derivative to be amusing and too earnest to be parodic, it assumes the form of countless other teen comedies minus any wit or drama.
Further confirmation that agitprop documentaries have become wedded to a template that undermines their very arguments.
The fact that Red Lights' action doesn't operate in a recognizable universe, however, is a constant problem.
Lucy's general unpleasantness is a hurdle the film can't clear.
An avalanche of unadventurous nastiness and moldy meta gags.
It's Langella ... who ultimately props up this borderline schmaltzy character study.
Juno Temple's Lily is a damaged creature trying to fly in Little Birds, a film of precious, romanticized misery and squalor.
A schizophrenic hybrid of tee-hee sex comedy and serious relationship drama, Hope Springs finds itself hopelessly adrift in a non-committal middle ground.
Potently expresses, both aesthetically and narratively, a sense of inclusiveness and diversity.
The director's DV cinematography can be rough and ungainly, but it provides sterling glimpses of both family intimacy and its larger social context ...
Compared to the successful over-the-top performances of the veterans, the three younger leads seem flat and lifeless.

Christopher Neil directs with a mechanical blandness made more tedious still by a score of gentle guitar strumming so aggravatingly benign it might inspire you to partake in one of Wendy's climactic, cathartic primal screams.
Pixar's 1995 Toy Story and its superlative 1999 sequel ushered in the supremacy of computer-generated animation.
While the Nitro Circus's many achievements are impressive, they pale in comparison to those of Knoxville and company's.

Fans of incessant flashbacks and endless whooshing zooms into close-ups will find much to love about Assassin's Bullet; less satisfied, alas, will be those with a fondness for lucid plotting, compelling intrigue, and credible performances.

Despite occasional lapses into showy expressionistic slo-mo, Guerrero's direction demonstrates a patience and attention to emotional detail that allows the two young leads' performances to develop naturally.
Chen's 126-minute film is stuffed with twisty-turny machinations that are difficult to untangle and not especially important to the story at hand...
Raunchy dude comedy is hardly the sole province of American cinema, as Klown all too dispiritingly reconfirms.
A rousing portrait of creative renewal.
Christopher Nolan's capper of his Batman trilogy is a summer blockbuster of grand inclinations in both form and content.
Grassroots disingenuously has it both ways, reducing politics first to a David-versus-Goliath adventure, and then to an everyone-is-cool bowl of mush.
[An] incoherent drama.
Even caped do-gooders couldn't save Supercapitalist...
It's the imposing Statham's badass grimace and combat acumen that primarily elevate Safe above your average direct-to-video genre work
Overlapping story threads, voices, and imagery result in an atmosphere of disquieting psychological confusion.
Unfortunately, its tale is so slight and simple that it ... fails to say anything particularly poignant about life.
[Cuts] through the clichés about "thug life" to capture how violence is an integral, corrosive part of inner-city life.
Morgan Spurlock has little to say about Comic-Con other than that its attendees value it on a par with Christmas.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Graceful cinematography captures the loneliness and isolation of these kids with understatement, even when the director succumbs to twinkling piano that pulls a tad too hard on the heartstrings.
If both good and evil characters don't behave in ways that make sense vis-à-vis their circumstances, any sense of terror quickly dissipates.
Wrath of the Titans delivers blockbuster bluster with single-minded blandness.
A true-crime documentary of invigorating analytical clarity and evenhandedness.

Olaizola pans across peeling building facades to subtly enhance her portrait of characters crumbling under the weight of self-destructive habits and solitude-a weight that might only be lifted through the selfless compassion of others.
Already buoyed by festival buzz, it's sure to be received with enthusiasm by genre devotees, and word of mouth has the potential to turn it into a bona fide box office sleeper.
A second-rate dude comedy in which an untalented knucklehead becomes a star through brute violence.
For all its heavy-handed gloom and stylistic unevenness, Fear and Desire has a certain fierceness that's hard to shake.
You can always go home again according to Jon Hurwitz and Hayden Scholssberg's American Reunion.
The schmaltzy and benign tale of a ballroom dancer who accepts and transcends her unexpected disability through the power of art and love.
The FP has a one-note joke of a conceit, and when that runs out, it has few actual jokes to fill the humorless void.
Now that Zooey Deschanel has taken a detour into TV land, is Audrey Tautou the most insufferable pixy presence in cinema today?
Horror cinema subversiveness need not preclude actual horror, a fact that's unfortunately lost on The Cabin in the Woods.
Alterman's camerawork, panning and zooming about Christiaan's ants, rabbits, birds, and other assorted mecha creatures, conveys a sense of ominous religious awe.

Playback posits cinema as a conduit for Satanic evil, but has nothing to say about the act of watching, except that its uniform horridness functions as an unintentional commentary on enduring pitiful horror-movie conventions.
Chris Renaud crafts his action with equal doses of surreal sweetness, silliness, and flair, and does so without ever feeling overly pushy and desperate to please.
Comedy and shifting-allegiances intrigue more than compensate for the dearth of rousing action in this 1920s-set film...
Art, politics, and craziness conspire to form a rather mechanical melodrama in Black Butterflies...
Like its title, Heist: Who Stole the American Dream? purports to ask a question but is only interested in forwarding its predictable agitprop answer.
movie_title: Heist: Who Stole The American Dream (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In the race to achieve unadulterated fourth-wall breakage, Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie is the new pack leader.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film's tossed-off look and clunky editorial construction are still secondary to the sheer silliness of its story.
Pablo Larraín keeps the army's brutality off screen to amplify a sense of oppressive malevolence.
Who cares about subpar computer-generated work when Guy Pearce is a one-man cartoon badass spectacle all to himself?
A work of slapsticky, accent-y gar-bage, The Pink Panther 2 is so brainlessly uninventive that it actually seems determined to sully the legacy of Blake Edwards and Peter Sellers's original series.
By wholeheartedly taking its main characters's side instead of complicating or censuring his homicidal vigilante crusade, it proves inanely one-note and preachy.
Never achieves either the seriousness or playfulness that it alternately seeks.
Girl in Progress operates like a training-wheels melodrama for genre-uneducated tweens.
A crime saga cobbled together from scraps of genre predecessors, Deadfall's unbelievable silliness escalates at every turn.
As precious as its prepubescent protagonist is precocious.
The result is a film that eschews in-depth insight in favor of easily digestible who's-going-to-win suspense...
Chris Fisher so over-directs his material that the action takes on the sheen of a parody or, at least, of a film that doesn't realize its clichés are being exaggerated to the point of absurdity.
Winds up turning itself into just a rote thriller about psychos learning that, appearance notwithstanding, every family has dysfunctional problems.
Guy Ritchie may have creatively moved on from his Tarantino-inspired debut, Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, but international crime cinema has not, as again evidenced by Jackpot.
The post-proposal blues strike a crushingly bland couple in The Five-Year Engagement, a romantic comedy lacking in both of the genre's signature elements.
The film's alternating talky torpor and frantic mayhem makes Warriors feel like it's operating in either fast-forward or slow motion...
movie_title: Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Piercing...
Its commentary on our fascination with law-breakers is virtually nonexistent, except to the extent that the film itself revels in the doomed romanticism of its own protagonist.
The paeans about national pride and brotherhood may be regional, but constant slow-motion battle scenes and squishy sentimentality are strictly wanna-be Tinseltown.
A romantic comedy whose quirkiness is complemented by italicized exposition.
Frequently scored to hip-hop heard through car speakers, Bluff's portrait of street life has a grungy off-the-cuff realism that's only compromised by some obviously staged incidents...
Lesbian desires, fears of mortality, and adolescent jealousies are all handled as bluntly as the unintentionally corny black-and-white flashbacks and gauzy dream sequences.
Whether to let go and follow your own path is a stock dilemma, and an implausibly hopeful conclusion winds up undercutting the realism of this immigrant song.
A documentary saga of heartbreaking concentration-camp horrors, Inside Hana's Suitcase attempts to preserve Holocaust memories through frustratingly fractured means.
A lost-dog drama so insufferable it makes one wish its human characters would also run off and never return.
Hong Sang-soo once again corroborates auteurist theory at the same time that he reveals the potential shortcomings of its practice.
Something happens here, but it isn't life.
Given the overarching structural messiness that defines its examination of elder financial abuse, the only thing Last Will and Embezzlement has in the right place is its heart.
The film is anchored and greatly bolstered by Bloom, who delivers a performance of quietly escalating madness.
Enduring this brainless kid's film is akin to witnessing the end of the world.
movie_title: The Oogieloves in The Big Balloon Adventure (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Delivers second-rate horror clichés unbefitting the imprimatur of producer Sam Raimi.
Child abductions plague a rural Washington State town, but the more pressing affliction in Pascal Laugier's film is the absence of chills, logic and coherence
Writer-director Boris Rodriguez's satire about artistic inspiration ...
A one-note hagiography, no matter how convincing and affecting its portrait of unimpeachable courage.
Hardboiled noir play-acting doesn't get more sluggish than in this leaden tale that blurs the line between reality and delusion in a way that's less intriguing than simply confusing.
Tyler Perry's insane, inane Old Testament-style morality tale.
Quirky indie hell, thy name is Family Weekend.
The CW version of the Vietnam War and the 1969 counterculture, Love and Honor hews to a mushy formula far older than its subject matter.
Park's direction is sleek and assured, but lacking the dynamism that might help energize a film that-its title notwithstanding-comes off as dully old-school.
Makinov's film expertly crafts a sense of dawning madness that hinges on its villains' unspoken fury at their elders.

The film is as lightweight as the ganja-puffing is plentiful, little more than a vanity project that allows its subject to wax philosophical on his past triumphs, tragedies, and spiritual development ...
Whether it was all a haunting or a hoax is left unanswered, but the film leaves little doubt that Amityville's greatest source of evil was, fundamentally, parental in nature.
Soon the wealth of exposition is accompanied by the appearance of hoofed CG wilderness she-beasts devoid of any terrifying personality.
A wannabe French-style infidelity farce that keeps indulging in unnecessary bathos and subplots.
Given its true-life basis, the story is already devoid of suspense regarding Hirohito's ultimate fate, and Fellers's inquiry is made more sluggish by dramatically inert conversations ...
A Hitchcockian stew of hothouse familial jealousy, sadism, and psychosis all tied together by one teenage girl's homicidal coming of age.
Though overstuffed, his film eschews pop-doc conventions by opting for in-depth analysis over superficiality.
Todd Robinson's film is a third-rate submarine-set drama until, in its final moments, it sinks to fourth-rate.
Another gorgeously shot document of nature's majesty, this one focusing on the life cycle-and interconnectedness-of all living creatures.
Gibney celebrates hockey's fisticuff traditions while also recognizing how such brutality ultimately takes its greatest toll on those who perpetrate it.
Shanghai Calling eventually reveals itself to be just another stale tale about the virtue of morality over ambition ...
Thompson assembles his footage with an expert's touch, but what his film lacks is its own perspective on these atrocities.
It's as though the director, like his subjects, was too comfortable in the safe familiarity of the surface to find the place where it betrays us.
movie_title: A Rubberband Is An Unlikely Instrument (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Without any engaging small-scale human drama or larger social or culture-clash import, the film comes across as trivial, and too often also indulgent and pretentious.
movie_title: A Rubberband Is An Unlikely Instrument (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's all so much turgid brooding, dialogue underlined with import, and leaden symbolism involving Rapace's white and red dresses, none of which is salvaged by a typically understated Farrell performance.
Even The Twilight Zone would have struggled with the cutesy conceit of The Brass Teapot ...
Stretches its runtime to a ridiculous 154 minutes ...
The film elevates the story of Jackie Robinson to that of cornball legend rather than just honoring his legitimately uplifting, heroic saga by telling it straight.
Alas, its argument against fear-driven orthodoxy is undercut by the fact that, as with so many of this subgenre's entrants, there are no substantial competing voices included in the mix ...

There's no creative spark to The Internship, just the depressing employment of a stale narrative structure and gags to promote an online behemoth whose name is either plastered on or uttered during nearly every frame of this dismal dud.
Douglas Tirola's documentary is an enthusiastic showcase for the many men and women responsible for the burgeoning cocktail revolution going on in metropolises around the world.
Even at a lean 68 minutes, it's a vanity project that's the very definition of insufferable.

Treating teenage growing pains with a sensitivity that frequently trips into singer-songwriter-ish mushiness, Tiger Eyes nonetheless stands as a respectable first cinematic adaptation of a Judy Blume novel.
A mildly intriguing drama of the often unavoidable and contentious intersection of intellectual analysis and personal prejudices.
The film rests on the desperate chemistry of a paunchy, weathered Owen and a tense, quietly ferocious Riseborough.
Ridiculousness played with a straight face, The History of Future Folk is endearing even if it's never quite hilarious.

Doin' It In The Park thrives simply via its myriad sights of nobodies juking and dunking their way past opponents, exuding an authentic for-love-of-the-game competitiveness that's as infectious as it is intense.
movie_title: Doin' It in the Park: Pick-Up Basketball, NYC (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The English Teacher reveals that a respectable cast and much noisy boisterousness isn't enough to generate a single laugh.
An intriguing tale of redemption and rebirth ... that eventually segues into a more conventional revenge drama.
Released comes off as a series of heartfelt testimonials that, despite their sincerity, have a limited scope beyond the usual don't-do-drugs and go-to-school cautionary tales.
A self-referential, insider farce about the hunger for Hollywood stardom, He's Way More Famous Than You is-like its leading lady-as unhinged as it is hilarious.
movie_title: He's Way More Famous Than You (2013)

movie_review_blurb: So little occurs, and so little seems to be at stake, that the action takes on the quality of a tossed-off, not-especially-melodic country-music ditty.
Java Heat's title refers not to hot coffee but to the Indonesian island, though caffeine is certainly recommended to make it through this tepid buddy-cop action flick.
Defined by Three's Company-grade humor, this attempt at male-anxiety cringe-comedy is little more than a sitcom writ large ...
Modest and affecting, it's a portrait of the possibility of finding peace, contentment and self through both music and spirituality.
movie_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't amount to more than a flimsy home-movie portrait of the creative process under time constraints.
The thrill of seeing women beat the snot out of each other is about all that Raze offers, though for a lean, efficient 83-minute genre picture like this, that turns out to be just enough.
Its portrait of foolishness and fallibility, and its atmosphere of inevitable doom, remain sturdy and captivating.
An outrageous based-on-real-life tale that's perfectly suited to director Michael Bay's insanely overblown stylistic and thematic temperament.
From a purely suspenseful vantage point, Big Bad Wolves is an efficient and effective beast.
Rob Zombie understands horror as an aural-visual experience that should gnaw at the nerves, seep into the subconscious, and beget unshakeable nightmares.

Ultimately nothing more than a decrepit vehicle for the moldiest of scary-movie clichés: screechy specters, inane character behavior and jump scares that a toddler could anticipate minutes ahead of time.
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As in the earlier installments, the climax comes across as merely one last cliché designed to please gore aficionados who've been schooled on past, superior horror efforts.
If unlikely to change anyone's mind about its subject, it's an effective primer on a voluble and charismatic mayor who embodied the spirit of the city he loved.
[A] modest but surprisingly deft indie ...
Roberto Faenza shoots his Manhattan-set action with a glossiness that's as bland as the soundtrack ballads.
movie_title: Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Ursula Meier uses a stripped-down, naturalistic aesthetic full of well-organized compositions that pay close attention to shifts in character mood, comportment, and behavior.
Escape Fire winds up feeling like only one half of a larger argument.
movie_title: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A scintillating neo-noir gem of existential quandaries and inescapable fatalism.
Tim Burton's sense of playfulness feels forced throughout, and as the film progresses, any humor or inventiveness takes a backseat to tumultuous set pieces that reference Frankenstein.
Fisher's use of POV shots overlaid with narrated readings from his father's diary poignantly captures his desire to consciously inhabit scarred spaces ...
It's Cristian Mungiu's staging and compositional skill that lends the material its true sense of dawning dread.
Just an extended dramatization of the 1980s anti-drug PSA that memorably cautioned "I learned it by watching you!"
The story places a premium on delivering its disreputable sex-and-violence goods with a minimum of fuss or pretention.
Just a voting-for-dummies primer.
Olivier Assayas's film is content to comfortably coast along the directionless courses charted by its characters.
An indie about-tell me if this sounds familiar-a brokenhearted sad sack who travels cross-country with a weirdo and a too-hot-for-these-dorks woman on a road trip of healing and self-actualization.
movie_title: The Brooklyn Brothers Beat The Best (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Straddling the line between celebration and vilification of its nasty protagonist, Arbitrage plunges into the world of corporate fraud with chilly detachment.
At once explosive and ramshackle, unpredictable and expertly modulated, it's a magnetic performance [by Phoenix].
A strong cast convincingly captures the many ways in which adulthood proves far more complicated than what's imagined at 18.
The Stand Up doesn't make up for [an] absence of humor with any legitimate drama.
Asks too much from a tale that argues gagging one's self is both a shameful sin and a useful skill
The film folds narratives on top of narratives in a vain attempt to mask the fact that there's nothing to read between its graceless lines.
Sachs creates an intensely intimate stew of fear, anger, longing, and regret.
[Its] poignancy is lessened by its awkward formal devices.
Its portrait of the grotesque über-privileged has considerable bite, bracingly reveling in the greed, selfishness, bitterness, jealousy, neurosis, detachment, and hunger for power and sex ...
Jirí Barta's film is a disturbing through-the-looking-glass reflection of traditional fairy tales.
An insufferable import indebted to Mrs. Doubtfire in which a man in prosthetics helps a family cope with, and overcome, divorce.
Plays like one long, slow descent into cloying moralizing and uplift that's well past its expiration date.
Proves a bracing and sometimes uncomfortable peek into private fears and regrets about mortality and missed opportunities.
Less inept than its worst-of-the-year title suggests, 3, 2, 1 . . . Frankie Go Boom nonetheless proves too ramshackle and aimless to ever achieve true absurdity.

Ambiguity enlivens the smart, knotty Resolution, which routinely nods to its own artificiality while positing storytelling as a constantly evolving beast apt to save your life one moment and consume you the next.
Quote not available.
Indies don't come blander than writer/director Tom O'Brien's Fairhaven ...
Diligently profane and inane ...
A monster from a familiar mother.
There's no deliberate Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2-style comedy to the film, just dim-witted gruesomeness retrofitted with gimmicky contemporary trappings.

Rosenberg's approach is heavy with archival footage and interviews, yet oddly features almost nothing from Way himself; his puzzling absence for most of the film turns the project into less of a biography than a one-note hagiography.
An aesthetic showcase whose repetitive nature winds up diminishing the excitement of its breathtaking feats of mountainous flight.
Any transformation feels like a device, and any modest hopefulness comes across as simply the unearned wishful thinking of the filmmaker.
Life of Pi manages occasional spiritual wonder through its 3-D visuals but otherwise sinks like a stone.
The film's interests are mainly relegated to wallowing in the frigid-starvation-suffering of its protagonists.

Director Arcel handles the material with a stately grace that compensates for the story's predictable trajectory, though humdrum period detail and monotonous pacing too often leave the proceedings feeling only partially aroused.
Wreck-It Ralph feels like so many modern AAA gaming titles-a promising starting point for an inevitable, improved sequel.
There's no heft to these supernatural suggestions, just a sense of stale horror tropes being trotted out to embellish otherwise routine indie material.
The film risks self-importance, but when Peralta admits through tears just how much he loves his skater charges, it imparts what every parent knows ...
Little girls never stop loving their daddies in Festival of Lights, a drama that never stops loving soap-opera-style melodramatics.
With horror altogether absent and a plot drowning in insipid convolutions, it's a film whose early warning to Heather should be heeded: "Don't go to Silent Hill."
Citadel is stripped down and no-nonsense, fixating on Tommy's emotional and psychological struggles with an intensity that's harrowing.
Nothing if not a well-executed bit of escalating craziness.
There are good intentions here, but too little nuance ...
Pusher faithfully mimics Nicolas Winding Refn's 1996 Danish crime saga while missing its nasty, grungy spirit.
Long Shot confirms that achieving one's goals is rarely possible without the staunch support of others.
movie_title: Long Shot The Kevin Laue Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Sex and love are both novel experiences for two high schoolers in this talky affair that suggests a hybrid of Before Sunset and Some Kind of Wonderful.
Álex de la Iglesia's film hammers home the opinion that family is more important than celebrity or wealth.
movie_title: La chispa de la vida (As Luck Would Have It) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Couching its commentary in a propulsive pulp tale, it's a genre triumph at once scary, silly, and deceptively sly.
It's the rare summer spectacle that, tacked-on coda notwithstanding, might actually warrant repeat viewings.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a carpe diem love story that overcomes its own faults, and earns its tempered hopefulness, by maturely recognizing that love and pain are equal, and often intertwined, parts of life.
Smoczynska's film swings and sways to its own eccentric beat, eventually branching out to also present portraits of adult longing and go-for-broke rebellion.
A cautionary tale of a man who sought to protect the world with an ingenious creation that could be used for ill as well as good.
Even when it strains too hard to be offensive, this buddy-cop comedy delivers its fair share of pitch-black laughs.
The Trouble with Terkel is not only destined to be 2017's worst film, but it also stands as one of the most singularly awful and incompetent productions in cinema history.

What emerges is a portrait of the internet as the birthplace of contemporary folklore -- a virtual campfire in which disparate users come together to channel, and distill, their fears, anxieties, and dreams into fanciful tales, à la the Brothers Grimm.
Goodman's gripping documentary ultimately comes across as a history lesson with all-too-relevant insights to impart -- and warnings to scream -- about our forthcoming Trumpian America.
My Father Die may boast a bizarrely graceless title, but that's the least of this revenge saga's shortcomings, which number in the dozens and conspire to make it an early contender for worst of 2017.
A paranoid portrait of individual and systemic corruption that leaves none of its characters unscarred.
A cursory affair that skimps on depth in favor of uplifting soundbites and chopped-up snippets of performance footage.
movie_title: Give Me Future (Give Me Future: Major Lazer in Cuba) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A multifaceted look at the intersection of big business and animal-rights protection.
John Wick 2 continues to prove that Stahelski's series is a superior big-screen killing machine. Bring on Chapter 3.
While Ben Lear's documentary is reasonably clear about its own position on the issue, the film's material is so thin that it provides few reasons to believe the conclusion it's selling.
A suspense-free stroll through rural landscapes where rarely-seen-onscreen dogs are the only real danger.
A shallow, context-free documentary about the effects of North Dakota oil drilling on Native American communities.

Bolstered by a confident fly-on-the-wall aesthetic and a suitably somber score by Michael Jacaszek, Fulton and Pepe locate both heartbreak and hope in their intertwined tales of people fighting to gain control of their (and others') lives.
Even more than its fanciful flourishes, however, The Brand New Testament is elevated by its consistent sense of humor.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Anonymous is riddled with shortcomings, but none is greater than its inability to provide a single reason to care about the plight of its protagonist.
Well-meaning but, on the whole, intensely inert ...

His was a career full of performances that combined stoic stillness and fiery animalistic expressiveness, and come next Friday, it'll receive a fitting tribute from a compelling new documentary, Mifune: The Last Samurai.
A hopelessly narrow and one-dimensional religious doc.

Headlining the sort of pulse-pounding adult thriller that studios rarely produce anymore, Jessica Chastain is a one-woman force of nature as a dominant D.C. lobbyist mired in a fierce political battle with her former firm.

If one ignores all the blather about "family" that vainly strives to imbue this corrosive sequel with some holiday-theme heft, there's quite a bit of pure, putrid nastiness to enjoy throughout this second go-round.

An ode to the counterculture's well-intentioned ethos and the dubious conduct it spawned, Mellen's film is the rare documentary to function as time capsule, philosophical inquiry, and rollicking thriller all at once
Unimaginative, retrograde pulp fit for the bargain bin.
Despite its familiarity, "Chapter & Verse" manages to make its material both fresh and authentic.
The film proves a rousing, and ravishing, call-to-engineering-arms for future generations, and should receive a welcome reception from its young target audience.
"House of Z" captures the way in which direct hands-on engagement is vital to an artist's continued relevance, and vitality.
Like the best illusionists, it knows that mystery is the key to its magic.
"A River Below" details the good and bad of modern media activism, with answers about the best way forward as scarce as the disappearing pink river dolphin itself.

A celebration of the courage shown by many in the LGBT community in the face of calamitous oppression and neglect, as well as a memorial for those who were lost in those fights for equality and basic human decency.
movie_title: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A conceptual exercise about the parallels between a director's life and his work that's as pretentious as it is turgid.

At once sorrowful and optimistic, Heal the Living captures the terrifying fragility of life, even as it also recognizes the strength derived from the many connections - organic, emotional, and associative - that bind and define us.
Anne Hathaway's alcoholic mess discovers she's linked to a giant South Korean monster in this fascinatingly uneven misfire.

It's a fascinating investigation into the burgeoning threat our (and all Western) nations face from radical Islamic belief. Because as it argues, our true enemies aren't just the messengers of hate - it's their message itself.

There was no escaping the profound loss experienced on that evening, turning I Called Him Morgan into a musical story of sorrow and regret that plays as if its abrupt, agonizing outcome blindsided everyone, even if it was never really in doubt.
So tasteful it's torturous, Despite the Falling Snow is a Cold War espionage thriller for those who like their period-piece action airless and derivative.
Comedies of misery don't get much more uncomfortably hilarious than On the Rocks.
There's no judgment to be found here, only an unvarnished look at its subjects struggling to figure out who they are, what they want, and how they might achieve their goals.

Lowe's film crazily reimagines the abortion debate as one that's out of both men and women's hands; rather, it's the prenatal tyke itself that's both in charge, and has a fondness for bloody butchery.
Heavy on gimmicks, light on revelations.
The message Burning Sands imparts about hazing's solidarity-through-sadism ethos is slyly multifaceted.
[An] insightfully open-ended inquiry into the role of humor as it relates to unspeakable tragedy.
Lynskey delivers a charming, captivating turn that roots the proceedings in everyday feelings of powerlessness, hopelessness, frustration and fury.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Drenched in darkness and routinely visualizing its characters behind bars and alone in the frame, Apprentice teases a climax of bloody revenge, only to take a far more somber, complex turn.
A fill-in-the-blanks effort that goes out of its way to repel at every winding turn.
movie_title: The Human Surge (El auge del humano) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Setting aside so much zombie fiction's dull repetitiveness (I'm looking at you, The Walking Dead), it charts a new course for the genre by miring itself in questions with only difficult answers.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A romantic drama that goes heavy on the cacophonous commotion and light on the romance or drama.
movie_title: You're Killing Me Susana (Me estás matando Susana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dark Night is fascinated by the phenomena of domestic mass shootings, but it's less an act of investigation than one of imagination.
"Live Cargo" is one of the most evocatively shot debut films in recent memory, which is why its shabby storytelling is such a crushing disappointment.
Arrival is the latest in a long line of "first contact" sci-fi stories, and yet regardless of its familiar premise, its achievements are unique.
Nicolas Cage headlines this lethargic, chintzy retelling of the tragedy that befell the USS Indianapolis during World War II.

Most likeminded films spend approximately 20 minutes on the same material covered by the entirety of Come and Find Me - a fact that leaves this mystery from writer/director Zack Whedon (brother of Joss) feeling insufferably drawn out.
[D]oesn't amount to more than its central conceit and the incessant cultural gags and profanities it uses as tiresome embellishments.
Fails to capture either the freewheeling, joyous spirit of the Caribbean or the heady euphoria of blossoming romance.
The Fourth Awakens proves merely another piece of dreary detritus to take up residence at the bottom of the pop-culture barrel.
A heartfelt, if familiar, portrait of four teenage friends mired in both poverty and criminal trouble.
One of the most powerful, poignant documentaries of the past decade.
Only faintly touching upon notions of intuitive collaboration and inspiration, "For the Plasma" wanders about as if it's in a fog, ultimately to the point of pointlessness.
Zero Days makes clear that we're already enmeshed in this terrifying new cyber-reality. And unfortunately for us all, we'll need more than John McClane to help avert forthcoming global disaster.

While it's touching that Mazzello has seen fit to celebrate his sibling's tenacious love of the national pastime, there's no escaping the fact that the dugout-and-diamond shenanigans are consistently tedious.
A repetitive, trivial compendium of extreme-sports feats.

It's a unique, associative blend of sounds and images that aims to convey details as well as underlying truths about Frank's life. Unfortunately, it also often leaves one feeling aesthetically pummeled to the point of exhaustion.
It allows Jeff Bridges to deliver what may be one of the most colorful, and yet nuanced, performances of his career.
A young man and an older married woman enter into an enlivening, then problematic, affair in Marc Meyers' incisive indie relationship drama.
This isn't to object to The Purge: Election Year's specific politics; rather, it's to balk at its simplistic monotony.
A consistently amusing, if slapdash, wedding comedy buoyed by raunchy star turns from Adam Devine and Aubrey Plaza.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A dog wanders through a quartet of miserable tales in this monotonous black comedy.
A scathing, highly stylized thriller of fashion-world monstrousness.

It proves a level-headed, borderline-detached stab at understanding how Germans, and by extension Germany as a whole, dealt with a still-fresh history of mass extermination and attempted world conquest.
A feature-length endurance test for anyone who's outgrown a nostalgic appetite for this particular blend of cheeseball comedy and spastic action.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Manages to be as cursory as it is intimate, skimming over so much of Cenedella's life and career that it imparts only a hazy impression of who he is and what he believes.
One can rarely sense that Cranston is acting, so fully does he inhabit his exceedingly well-written role.
A pitiful sequel that decisively sullies any goodwill one might have felt for these Disney-fied versions of Lewis Carroll's famed characters.
Thanks to attentive writing and sturdy performances, the director's characters are so compellingly realized that it's easy to succumb to the film's hopefulness.
Striking in its evocation of a demanding time and place, this intimate drama about individual and national transformation heralds the arrival of an arresting new filmmaking voice ...
"Never" may take place in the present, but its mopey low-fi indie character drama - set to earnest singer-songwriter tunes - feels as if it's been transported from the early '90s.
The life and untimely death of Arkansas football player Brandon Burlsworth is turned into a one-note sermon in David Hunt's leaden biopic.
Plodding, pretentious and painfully obvious at every turn.
Assured and understated even when going through its familiar teen-horror motions, it's the rare big-studio scary movie that doesn't seem to have been made by a committee.
A loving and slightly off-kilter homage that hits its genre-essential notes with aplomb.
An awkward hodgepodge of crime thriller, young-adult romance and religious sermon that [...] proves an ungainly mess of disparate tones.
Coming Through the Rye comes across as a cute conceit incapable of sustaining a substantial feature.
Goes about its noble-killer business with all the excitement of an IRS audit.
Plays like an actors' workshop exercise that doesn't know when to quit ...
A by-the-books YA affair that resembles X-Men: First Class retrofitted for the tween Hot Topic set.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Zach Galifianakis and Kristen Wiig's absurd lead turns help carry this uneven but amusing bank-robbery comedy.
Law-enforcement militarization is haphazardly addressed in this skimpy hot-button doc.
Even for a small-scale indie, the amateur-hour quality is enervating; if it were debuting onstage, Dick and Jack wouldn't make it to its second night.
A Man Called Ove - preaching tolerant togetherness as the key to happiness - earns its sentimentality by striking a delicate balance between barking-mad comedy and syrupy melodrama.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Andrew Neel's astute portrait of masculine insecurity, rage and desire for strength and security.
Proof that "the sky is falling" hyperbole exists on both sides of the political aisle.
movie_title: The Best Democracy Money Can Buy (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A film that - from its basic set-up to its dearth of tension - plays like the tedious inverse of Don't Breathe.

Dean and Butler breathe new life into their premise - based on real-life circumstances that plagued Tanna's tribes in the '80s - through loving attentiveness to their setting's verdant colors and bustling sounds.
This muted, moving small-scale tale of sorrow and faith will strike a chord with both the churchgoing crowd and aficionados of Malick's contemplative, theologically predisposed cinema.
Merely a collection of ominously framed images devoid of purpose.
While unique, this lumbering crossbreed never truly gains melodramatic traction ...
French townsfolk flee invading Nazis, and a father aims to reunite with his son, in Christian Carion's mawkish, one-dimensional WWII drama.
[An] egregiously clunky and phony coming-of-age story based on William Saroyan's 1943 novel The Human Comedy.
Despite a strong sense of its characters ... Kelly rarely generates much melodramatic or amusing momentum.
Something of a tease, raising intriguing topics and insights before turning frustratingly cursory and skimpy.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rachel Weisz is magnetic in this dreamy drama about an identity-shifting chameleon reuniting with a former flame.
Andie MacDowell and Chris O'Dowd are superb as a mother and son coping with grief in Russell Harbaugh's intimate, insightful indie drama.
From the outset, writer-director Liz W. Garcia's indie drama plays like a tag sale of cinematic clichés, each one piled haphazardly atop another.
There's so little substance or originality to this lurid, abstract affair that it comes off as simply a faded grindhouse collage.
Rambling in the best manner imaginable, it's an amusingly heartbreaking (and hopeful) portrait of misery's messiness.
movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The duo come across as abrasive and mirthless; for all their back-and-forths, they fail to land a single laugh-out-loud one-liner or comeback.
Zaniness has rarely been this obnoxious.
Only the most sentimental of sorts will be able to stomach the sappiness that ensues.
Even better than its offhand wittiness, its aesthetic splendor or its shrewd social commentary, however, is its headliner.
It is, in short, the ne plus ultra of crap. A trash masterpiece.
[The Breadwinner] is a harrowing-and spellbinding-exploration of life under Taliban rule.
Sebastian Lelio's A Fantastic Woman is mesmerizing thanks to Daniela Vega's powerful, award-worthy lead performance.
A compelling, infuriating documentary about the nuclear-waste crisis taking place in North St. Louis County, Missouri.
Enriching Thelma's chaos is the director's refusal to outright censure any of his characters, no matter the sometimes awful choices they make.
An accomplished and heartrending documentary comprised of testimony from men and women who made it out of the Nazis' concentration camps, or avoided them altogether by hiding from capture.
Daniel Day-Lewis performances are something to be richly savored-and that goes doubly for his turn in Phantom Thread.
It's thrilling and touching and absurd, sprawling and intimate and severe, and never less than uninhibited. In short: it's a mad Miike film through and through.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ruben Östlund's ('Force Majeure') latest feature is a blistering satire of the modern art world, and features a sequence that will make your jaw completely drop.
Jigsaw continues that trend, afraid to reinvent the conventions that first turned the series into a reliable moneymaker.
Jairus McLeary's stirring documentary is a riveting account of Folsom Prison's unusual way of rehabilitating inmates: through a group therapy akin to an exorcism.
The terror and trauma of fleeing fundamentalism is front and center in One of Us, a harrowing new documentary.
The only truly amazing thing about Carol director Todd Haynes' children's fable is its wholesale lack of authentic humanity.
Unfortunately, the film has nothing much to say other than that the enterprise is inherently complicated - which isn't point enough for 111 minutes of screen time.
By the time the mayhem truly transpires, Brawl in Cell Block 99 has so well-established Bradley's personality, motivations and rage that the barbarity lands with additional impact.
Lacking both fluidity and complexity, "Te Ata" is a functional but one-note tribute told through educational storytelling that, unlike its subject, doesn't manage to inspire.
It's a sermonizing work as entertaining as it is informative.
movie_title: Wasted! The Story of Food Waste (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This charming lo-fi indie from actor-director Kentucker Audley and director Albert Birney is attuned to its own eccentric wavelength, equal parts absurd and poignant.
Director Taika Waititi has transformed Chris Hemsworth's buff, brooding superhero into a comedy god in this highly entertaining threequel.
Steinberger and Vetter create a haunting atmosphere of mania and madness, as when they transition to photos of Derek and Nancy during Elizabeth's cold, eerie testimony.
It's an instantly classic moment of unhinged mania in the Oscar-winner Cage's career.

It's an affecting work that refuses to shy away from the vileness of ingrained Islamic intolerance, all of which, in this case, is targeted at women-making the film something like a wrenching live-action companion piece to The Breadwinner.
Like Reese's Peanut Butter Cups, The Hurricane Heist is two great cinematic tastes that taste great together...Rob Cohen's film ably lives up to its preposterous premise.
The doc is all talk and little action, with most of the first hour of this 75-minute pic focused on DiMaggio chatting about the good old days ...
movie_title: Where Have You Gone, Lou DiMaggio? (2018)

movie_review_blurb: As in the Bronson series, the new Death Wish is devoid of nuance, feigning "debate" (via talk radio sound bites) while depicting everything in figurative, and often literal, black and white terms.
An Outback crime thriller whose derivativeness is matched by its obviousness.
A period-piece action-horror effort with relevant sociopolitical thoughts on its bloodthirsty mind.
Even when the film's eccentricities feel too choreographed, it manages to deliver its preordained uplift with good-humored charm.
November is all-caps CRAZY in the best, funniest, most exhilarating way possible. A mere description cannot, I recognize, do its out-there-ness true justice.
Big-budget sci-fi doesn't come much more incisive, exhilarating and mind-blowing than this.
"Irreplaceable You" uses an assortment of slight incidents to impart a lesson that, from the outset, is patently obvious to everyone except the too-dim-to-be-believed person for whom it's intended.
Boasting stunt casting, dull backstories, and blander-than-bland performances, Eastwood's dramatization of the real-life 2015 Thalys terrorist attack is a stunning misfire.
It's difficult for a film to be charming when it's so busy being preposterous - although in the case of "Entanglement," a distinct lack of energy and tonal control are also to blame.
Double Lover proves a flamboyant funhouse of schizophrenic sexual turmoil, its minds and bodies entangled in ways that are all the more entertaining for being so outrageous.
Golden Exits makes one pine to escape the company of its second-rate Woody Allen characters.
Sorry on its own terms, The Cloverfield Paradox proves the limits of trying to salvage troubled movies via franchise-extending gimmickry.

The Ritual will feel like a trip to comfortably uncomfortable environs. And yet Bruckner's film has more meat on its bones than most, its mayhem splattered with not only blood but issues of guilt, regret and redemption.
Post-apocalyptic westerns don't come much more lethargic and unoriginal than this B-movie.

Eliciting outrage and shame in equal measure, Thank You for Your Service details the lack of mental-health support offered to the men and women of the United States Armed Forces-and the tragic consequence of that neglect.
The film's lack of a traditional narrative will no doubt alienate many, but for the more adventurous, it offers a uniquely weird take on loneliness and lunacy.
Equally entertaining and inspiring.
A bracing documentary that blends fiction and reality in ways that both complicate and enhance the material's core themes.
Dmitrii Kalashnikov's documentary is a uniquely amusing-and harrowing-snapshot of the lunacy that awaits people on modern thoroughfares and back streets.
As it stands, it's an efficient, diverting new entry in Neeson's ongoing action canon, albeit one which suggests his He-Man career route has finally reached the end of the line.
Happy End finds Haneke back in far more familiar terrain, operating in a wickedly disapproving vein.
Though its slow-burn narrative doesn't pay off in a wholly satisfying manner, this offbeat nail-biter should nonetheless be welcomed by those eager for something off the beaten genre path.
Manhattan Night's pedestrian style and affected atmosphere ... make it a routine descent into the black heart of a city and its shady inhabitants.
Gerald's Game ultimately argues that monsters are real, and that they can only be defeated (or, at least, "minimized") through direct confrontation.

Led by performances that channel, rather than imitate, their predecessors, Last Flag Flying embeds itself in the prickly emotions that come from facing one's own mortality, grief, regret and military service.

The pinnacle of blockbuster gigantism, Bay's latest is a chore except when its madness becomes so sensorially all-consuming -- blinding the eyes, deafening the ears, befuddling the mind -- that it achieves a sort of terrible abstract grandeur.
Cone's film has little more than its heart in the right place.
Compounding the action's lack of originality are both the amateurishness of every performance and the wobbly-camera aesthetics.
The film is buoyed by its sharp, witty lead performances, with Spall's holier-than-thou imperiousness clashing suitably with Meaney's more affable obstinacy.
Home is where good health isn't in It Comes at Night, a terrifying saga about the corruption of a clan's safe haven by both external and internal forces.
Often too clunky for its own good, and (ahem) doggedly apolitical throughout, this earnest feel-good tale nonetheless manages to pull on the heartstrings with sufficient gentleness.
A thriller whose genre moves are as precise as its underlying swirl of emotions are enigmatic.

Featuring a doggedly pretentious style, "They" also includes clunky scripting, with every conversational exchange coming across as a didactic information dump recited by actors rather than a natural chat between actual people.
A Suitable Girl proves a somber lament for a part of the world still clinging to its restrictive past, at great cost to (particularly) its female population.
For all its proximity, Poitras' film never gets beneath [Assange's] exterior.
Delivers enough obscene unholy absurdity to consistently amuse.
Hounds of Love is a sinister, psychologically screwy thriller that stands on its own merits, radiating a dreamy, deviant vision of female subjugation, and empowerment.
A tapestry of masterful performances that [...] push[es] past traditional boundaries in order to locate deeper, more authentic truths.
Grace's easygoing indie delivers a somewhat more melancholy performance than its droll exterior initially suggests.
A fascinating look at the way in which these memorials function as not only tributes to fascinating, influential, idiosyncratic lives, but also as crucial records about our society and culture.
Even without direct access to Carson, Walker's film solidifies the impression that he was out of his depth and thus, that his crash-and-burn in the primaries was an inevitability.
The director's approach casts a strange, despondent spell.
Velez and Pettengill's film is a work of found-footage commentary about the nature of our modern political paradigm.
A sobering, if less than comprehensive, portrait of a would-be NBA legend's rocky post-basketball life.
An ode to self-discovery and acceptance that's as funny as it is sweet.

A Gray State slowly peels back the curtain on David's private life to reveal an increasingly unstable individual, one whose suspicions about institutional systems quickly blossomed into distrust of everything and everyone around him.
Exploits its screwy premise for both unnerving laughs and volatile thrills.
At once superficial and overblown, this documentary also often feels downright phony ...
Too bad, then, that Good Fortune is such a doggedly hagiographic nonfiction portrait, reducing his entire saga and ethos to PR-style slogans.

It's a film about the universal desire for greater understanding (of ourselves, and the world around us) that itself is, in a sense, incomprehensible. Intrepid moviegoers would be wise to fall under its spell.
At the center of this tranquil nightmare stands Pugh, whose central performance is a thing of beautiful monstrousness.
Little more than a soundbite-heavy platform for its host's pre-existing message.

Before We Vanish rejects pat happily-ever-after answers to its dramatic dilemmas. Instead, Kurosawa's alternately amusing, disquieting and moving film recognizes that, when something vital is gained, something else is often lost.
There are shades of not only Stephen King in Super Dark Times, but also Spielberg, River's Edge and Donnie Darko. Phillips filters his material through a disarming aesthetic.

Breaking little ground but functioning as a handy primer on the event's century-plus ups and downs, as well as its efforts to rebound from the tragedy that befell it four years earlier, Jon Dunham's documentary gracefully achieves its admirable ends.
[Rat Film] draws damning parallels between how a city handles its rodent problem and its history of racism.
Ranks right up there with the very worst of 2017.
Employing intimate, evocative aesthetics to amplify their material's heart-wrenching power, the filmmakers craft a harrowing portrait of trauma, bravery and insular societal oppression.
Despite its frustratingly crude formal construction proves an equally sorrowful and stirring portrait of selflessness in the face of tragedy.
Empathetic and yet ultimately too draggy to elicit much engagement with its paper-thin story, "Elizabeth Blue" proves at once well-intentioned and inert.
Twenty-six years later, T2 has lost none of its thrilling power, feminist ferocity, and ominous foreboding-and seen on a big screen, it still puts most of its modern Hollywood progeny to shame.
Consider the action-movie escalation bar raised.

. . .this Friday brings with it Logan Lucky, a southern-fried caper of virtuosic showmanship that, beneath its easygoing exterior, also succeeds at tapping into larger s...[ END HERE ]ocioeconomic concerns

Beyond deadpan, beyond drollness, beyond absurdity, lies Lemon, a "comedy" so uniquely off-kilter that it's never exactly clear when, or why, one should laugh-and when one does, it often occurs long after a given gag.
It's rare for a film to make one swell with pride about something he or she had no direct hand in, but "The Farthest" accomplishes that feat with aplomb.
The Dark Tower feels as if it's playing by a tired fantasy-movie playbook, right down to its chaotic skirmishes full of anonymous villains and slow-motion acts of badassery.
Horror doesn't get much more paint-by-numbers.
"Armed Response" has less story than your average first-person shooter video game - and far fewer moments of exciting action or nerve-wracking suspense as well.
For those who cherish honesty, fair play, and upright athletic competition, the film is a must-see exposé about systematic corruption and failure on both sides of the doping issue.
A formally daring convention-defier that, in ways both bold and subtle, puts most of its genre brethren to shame.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Plays like a misbegotten validation of James', and its own target audience's, Peter Pan complex.

It works one's nerves over with skill, jumbling up its story's chronology in disorienting ways, and delivering a survivalist saga whose unnerving impact stems in large part from its refusal to shy away from the suddenness -- and ugliness -- of violence.

Heineman's doc is a stirring testament to valor and resolve in the face of tragedy and menace, and a case study in how wars are also fought, and sometimes won, on the battlefields of ideology and images.

Harrelson stares and sneers with fanatical relish, but War is ultimately a two-man show, with Reeves giving the material an aesthetic polish and pulse-pounding energy ... and Andy Serkis again bringing commanding complexity and grace to Caesar.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As amateurish as its 1990-grade VHS title graphics, Surviving Peace is possibly the clunkiest - and most one-sided - film ever made about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
A doctor travels to his hometown to rescue his nephew, in the process confronting his traumatic past, in Chinese director Bi Gan's aesthetically remarkable debut.
Hoover's style seems equally fit for a bleak documentary, suspenseful thriller, black comedy, dystopian sci-fi nightmare and grisly horror film.
Three Indian men involved with their country's traveling-movie industry face an uncertain digital future in this mournful, moving doc.
Shyamalan has recaptured his knack for tackling big subjects through nimbly formulated genre stories.
David M. Rosenthal's Internet-age thriller falls head over heels for cheesy cliches.
If it strives too hard for weighty import, Wolf Totem remains an occasionally stirring portrait of Mongolia's wolf population.
For long stretches, Time Out of Mind proves so attuned to its protagonist's haziness and his loud, busy, and yet lonely milieu that it proves a gripping example of experiential cinema.
So many amazingly absurd things occur during the course of "The Transporter: Refueled" that it's almost easy to forget that the basic idea driving this fourth installment is itself nonsensical.

There's plenty of goofiness to go around in this lavish production, awash as it is in CG sunsets, slow-motion shots of blades and arrows penetrating bodies and necks, and computer-assisted pans around the Silk Road and its surrounding desert.

[The film] confirms that Chris Evans, aka Marvel's patriotic do-gooder Captain America, is cut out not only for amenable superheroism, but for romantic-comedy stardom as well. Unfortunately, his second go-round in that genre is an uneven vehicle at best.
Ransone's tone-deaf performance helps validate this knuckleheaded story's portrait of cinema as a potential gateway to pain and suffering.
"The clunky plotting is matched by the film's pitiful political commentary."
Lycanthropy has rarely been more lethargic than in When Animals Dream, a dreamy Danish import about a young girl who responds to the discovery that she's a werewolf by pouting and brooding a lot.
A tale of survival that makes you wish everyone involved would quickly run out of food and water.
"Proves to be a film with mood to spare but nothing much to say."
Zobel's preference for long takes that fixate on his cast's faces helps elicit sharp turns from both Ejiofor and Robbie.
Ultimately content to be merely a survey, rather than an in-depth investigation.
This often incisive look at modern identity confusion and redefinition loses its dramatic momentum long before its finale.
Incisively intimate, it's a small but stirring snapshot of a gifted, hopelessly lonely soul.
The film tackles its issues with a furrowed-brow solemnity that eventually spills into outright sluggishness.
A lean, rugged neo-noir that tweaks genre conventions by putting two young boys at the center of its attention.
As formulaic as it is monotonous.
Jake Gyllenhaal's intense lead performance elevates this boxing drama's formulaic melodrama.

It's a film that always feels this close to being unique, and funny, and thrilling. Which is why when it misses its mark, over and over and over again, the sound of its failure resounds that much louder.
Dull body-swapping drama that barely bothers to exploit its out-there premise for moral drama or outrageous thrills.
It resorts to merely copying numerous genre predecessors with embarrassing shamelessness.
Like so much teen-targeting modern horror, it opts for dull angsty brooding over the very sort of grim-and-gruesome sleaziness that might have made its premise interesting.
An ode to cinema's birth that aims to both set the historical record straight and pay loving tribute to the magical medium itself.
movie_title: A Trick of Light (Gebrüder Skladanowsky, Die) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: The Armenian genocide and its aftermath are filtered through the eyes of a featureless man in The Cut, Turkish director Fatih Akin's laborious latest.

To watch Genisys is to see the franchise become a figurative embodiment of the Terminators themselves: convinced of its own superior vision of the future, it tramples upon the dusty skeletons of the forefathers it's slaughtered to achieve it.
A potentially sensational premise is handled with grace and incisiveness in Room, Lenny Abrahamson's adaptation of Emma Donoghue's best-selling novel.
An atypical serious performance by Sarah Silverman can't salvage this incessantly clichéd addiction drama.

A Most Violent Year resonates as the rare film to not simply take its superficial cues from The Godfather, but to truly understand its underlying ideas -- and, more impressive still, to re-work them into something thrillingly unique.
The most euphoric feel-bad movie of the summer.
An artist getting lost gazing into the unique composition and character of her own navel.

[The Assassin] operates as if it were a dream, employing Hou's trademark long takes and unhurried camera movements to lull one into a trance, the better to then deliver thrills through jolts of measured, expertly choreographed violence.

Fukunaga's film is thus mired in a hazy, nightmarish fugue of violence and degradation, the director presenting a landscape of hellish depravity and amorality through the eyes of one young boy unwittingly swept up in his nation's insanity.
A biopic that rejects typical genre conventions to the point of chasing itself down lame, tangential paths.
"Goosebumps," a film that assembles many of the R.L. Stine's most memorable creations with noisy, tossed-off sloppiness.
An immersive portrait of harmonious dialogue between not only East and West, but also man and nature, the past the present.
If you can get on its wacko wavelength, it's a uniquely crazed, compelling midnight-movie whatsit.
This is a swift and searing attempt to pull back the curtain on Jobs and, in the process, investigate the relationship between the myth and the man.
Channeling the spirit of its subject, The Walk assumes a clownish attitude until, during its finale, it switches gears to become a solemn, striking tribute to human ingenuity, ambition and daring.
Partisan's lack of interest in providing necessary context - especially about the ill-defined larger society that Gregori rejects - leaves it operating on a hazy psychological level.

An act of celebratory remembrance that's buoyed by a desire to understand the messy contradictions, motivations, and emotions of its subject, "Ingrid Bergman: In Her Own Words" proves a stirring and insightful biography of assemblage.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A charming coming-of-age saga in which Michel Gondry channels his usual preoccupations through the prism of a Truffaut-esque tale of iconoclasts in search of themselves and their place in the world.
"Pan" is a cacophonous assault on the senses, all computerized cinematographic mayhem and deafening noise, and its hurried pace extinguishes any genuine character development.
Hathaway and De Niro share a serviceable dad-daughter chemistry that makes much of "The Intern" passable.

Its plot comes across as just a rickety skeleton designed to prop up Sandler and company's litany of cornball punchlines and gags, only a few of which cleverly play off of these characters' iconography
There's enough fine acting in Mississippi Grind to make one wish it wasn't in service of such hoary clichés and fanciful sad-sack drama.
A documentary study of heartbreak whose empathy is drowned out by its tediousness and obviousness.
The specific details about 'The Scorch Trials' world, its protagonist's backstory, and its David-vs.-Goliath plot are of little actual consequence.
Cartel Land is the rare non-fiction work that routinely keeps one's nerves on edge.
Lino Brocka's portrait of familial treachery and societal abandonment channels its melodrama through the filter of neorealism.
Bland nonfiction aesthetics can't fully quell the outrage elicited by this documentary about the injustices surrounding a famed Chicago death-penalty case.
There's not much enlightenment to be found in this dreary slog of a drama.

Backcountry is simply another paranoid cinematic reminder that exiting the beaten path is a course best avoided - or, at least, one that also requires taking some basic, common-sense precautions beforehand.
A deranged pseudo-feminist fable, Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter takes its tedious time getting to its unrewarding destination.
The paeans about national pride and brotherhood may be regional, but constant slow-motion battle scenes and squishy sentimentality are strictly wanna-be Tinseltown.

Emitting the unpleasant stench of over-affectation, "Treading Water" slaps together its particular peculiarities with such randomness, it's as if the film were conceived from blindly throwing disparate elements at the wall.
[Shakespeare's Cymbeline is] given a distinctly contemporary sheen that almost makes it seem fresh, which is not-unfortunately-the same thing as coherent.
Unsurprising given its laughably affected title, Like Sunday, Like Rain boasts what may be the most insufferably precocious protagonist in cinema history.
Traitors operates according to a standard drug-smuggling-drama template, though it colors its familiar elements with just enough distinctive personality to allow it to stand on its own.

Those scenarios are all rooted in a particular brand of Hollywood desperation, though Carolla's stilted screen presence and groan-worthy zingers neuter any humor from Bruce's needy quest to return to the spotlight.
Two Bond villains and Eva Green walk into a western, and they emerge with a rugged - if far from revolutionary - old-school horse-opera throwback.
Behind-the-scenes portraits don't come much more superficial than My Life Directed by Nicolas Winding Refn.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A by-the-books B movie only notable for its energetic action choreography.
It's hard not to see "The Duff" becoming an instant teen classic.
The Rewrite talks a good game about second chances, but for Grant, it's merely more of the same old.
This Ryan Reynolds-headlined indie strikes an uneasy balance between bloody mayhem and mirth.
There's no coherent sense of DIRT's short- or long-term goals, which makes the film as amorphous as its individual subjects sometimes seem aimless.
A love story whose likable stars can't compensate for a story that tediously adheres to formula.
The titular pixie is a peripheral character in this colorful and cheery new franchise entry.
movie_title: TinkerBell and the Legend of the NeverBeast (2014)

movie_review_blurb: David Garrett's musical gifts far outstrip his acting chops in Bernard Rose's creaky 19th-century melodrama.
A lush lesbian romance that marries eroticized energy and relationship role-playing concerns to hypnotic ends.

Even as a promotional piece, Manny is too thin a nonfiction portrait of Manny Pacquiao, one of the greatest boxers of the modern era and the only one in history to win titles in eight different weight classes.
Throughout, Helberg's awkward-anxious routine proves insufferable ...

Earnestness doesn't fully excuse the low-key schmaltz peddled by Life Inside Out, the type of indie that your mother might politely describe as "touching" if she could manage to stay awake for its entirety.
A dull, insight-free portrait of a young teen who's driven to become a high-school shooter by all manner of clichéd forces.
"3 Holes and a Smoking Gun" proves that there's a chasm-wide difference between talking about what constitutes - and actually being - great writing.
Pretentious, talky final chapter in Hal Hartley's Henry Fool trilogy will only appeal to the series' most devoted fans.
Draggy and one-note, [Freetown is] an indie more interested in reaffirming Mormon dogma than in delivering compelling drama.
As uninterested in examining its chosen milieu as it is in fashioning anything approaching an engaging narrative.
It generates a modest amount of anticipatory dread.
movie_title: Masters of Horror: Chocolate: Mick Garris (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The omnipresent jokiness isn't enough to overcome the nagging pointlessness of this lighthearted monster movie lark.
If not as blatant as that found in last year's Homecoming, Family nonetheless boasts a sly political critique.
Ernest Dickerson's silken, sinister camerawork lends the material a dose of genuine tension all too often missing from the series.
Series architect Mick Garris should have his Masters of Horror membership card revoked after Valerie on the Stairs.
It's hard to see how Masters of Horror serves the genre it champions by resorting to this type of lackluster repetition of imagery and formulas far past their expiration date.
More assuredly directed than any of Don Coscarelli's prior features.
Tobe Hooper inaugurates the second season of Showtime's Masters of Horror by rotating, whirling, and shaking his camera with what feels like desperatio.
Gorgeous, thrilling bio-doc about the godfather of BASE jumping that's energized by its subject's personal peak-leaping movie footage.
John Carpenter's direction is not only languid but, worse for a series defined by its horror auteurs' idiosyncratic styles, lacking in distinctive personality.
Tom Holland manages to effectively take advantage of the show's widescreen aspect ratio, and his use of old-school gore effects is agreeably nostalgic.
Carpenter's creepy contribution regularly colors its foreboding investigatory narrative with swathes of crimson-stained gore.
A descent into a dank, rank hole of meta depravity (and doo-doo), The Human Centipede 3 (Final Sequence) follows in its 2011 predecessor's footsteps by turning inward on itself.
Dolph Lundgren and Tony Jaa star in this tedious, formulaic actioner.
The Seven Five has the look and feel of a made-for-TV production.

Proving that its chosen genre is best when its tropes are treated with a balance of sincere sweetness and wink-wink absurdity, Playing It Cool thrives through sheer liveliness, as well as the chemistry of its perfectly paired stars ...

Hyena's convoluted tale is given a fresh coat of grime by Johnson's direction, which favors handheld cinematography -- often tracking its protagonists from behind -- that gives the action a pseudo-vérité ruggedness.
Far From Men crafts a haunting atmosphere of alienation for its story of outcasts forging an unlikely bond.
A neo-western that operates in purely mythic terms, Slow West evokes an 1870 America steeped in isolation, heartbreak, suffering, and misery.
The story's magic realism is so torpid and affected as to make the film feel as if it, like Adaline herself, goes on forever.
A portrait of the Washington, D.C. punk-rock scene that's awash in affection but light on critical context.
Overstuffed with plot, Child 44 becomes no more lucid as it progresses from one development to another.
Soaked in Bleach is so heavily rooted in hearsay and circumstantial suggestions that the film-and its speakers-often seem to be grasping at straws.
Intimacy doesn't completely give rise to insight in this loving, if largely for-fans-only, posthumous portrait of Memphis-bred punk rocker Jay Reatard.
The film's disregard for basic plot lucidity either stems from contempt for its audience, or from post-production decisions aimed at making something, anything, out of nothing

Saoirse Ronan makes a grand case for herself as the millennial generation's finest leading lady in Brooklyn, an immaculately crafted, immensely moving character study about a 1950s immigrant struggling to find her place in the world.
A sporadically amusing, if unconvincing, film eager to imagine jocks as horndogs with hearts of gold.
Mistakenly thinks a lot of profanity, ugliness and bloodshed [...] are, in and of themselves, enough to sustain a satire about showbiz ruthlessness.
Though based on a real-life story, writer-director James Napier Robertson's film plays like a mash-up of Hollywood clichés.
Hock's documentary has a thrilling pop that should help it strike a competitive chord with anyone even remotely enchanted by our national pastime.
In that final, gracefully handled note, the film again proves itself a mature meditation on the ordeal of tragedy, and art's capacity for helping us process it.
Even at its conclusion, Holmer's film refuses to provide easy answers regarding its meaning, instead using poised formal techniques to impart that which is not spoken.
Shot like a typically ugly Adam Sandler effort and so clumsily stitched together that it feels as if large plot chunks litter the editing-room floor ...
There's only one joke here - GOP voters are bigoted, Stars and Stripes-wearing clowns - and it's handled with the sort of blunt, bludgeoning mean-spiritedness that it slams them for peddling.
movie_title: Ron and Laura Take Back America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An alternately entrancing and amusing documentary-fiction hybrid that marries existential questions with absurdist humor.
By the time quotes from Joseph Goebbels are used to explain Fox's methods, The Brainwashing of My Dad has resorted to the tactics of its targets ...
A torturous exercise in one-note proselytizing.
Waterworks are sparse in "Donald Cried," but there's plenty of anxious, cringe-inducing humor to be found in writer-director-star Kris Avedisian's comedy of discomfort.
Hyena Road runs two hours long, but its entire narrative could be wedged into a half-hour documentary.
This pious drama is a work of minimal imagination and even less subtlety.
Brash, brutal, and simplistic in equal measure, "London Has Fallen" is a retrograde work that, for better and worse, delivers its old-school mayhem with punishing precision and unrepentant glee.

By rooting the proceedings in a believable real-world context, Uthaug does much to amplify the what-if horror of The Wave, which spends its first thirty minutes establishing both its setting and its scientific circumstances.
... it's a spectacular mess that's shameless in its desire to entertain through sheer, misbegotten excess.
A simultaneously amusing and incisive panoramic portrait of our ever-developing New Weed Order.
Even when Keaton is transforming his character's stock issues into ones that feel unique and genuine, he's undercut by his director's flashiness, right up to an on-the-nose finale.
Buoyed by proficient nonfiction techniques, it nimbly captures, in both words and images, the spirit of Ephron.
