Only Wincott seems to fit in, exuding a poised, laconic cold-bloodedness that stands in stark contrast to the film's inert phoniness.
Plays like the faintest copy of a copy of countless superior films.
Cohen's willingness to do, or say, anything in order to elicit a chuckle at least somewhat salvages "The Brothers Grimsby."
Heavy on classic-car beauty and light on depth.
The most unabashedly videogame-ish movie in cinematic history, Hardcore Henry is a bold act of mimicry, a gimmicky stunt and a faithful adaptation of gaming's form and content.
In ... subtle touches, the filmmaker most quietly, and convincingly, affirms fashion's legitimacy as an art form akin to that of other expressive mediums.
A ribald south-of-the-border teen fantasy that's drunk on stale clichés.
Exorcisms, séances, scurrying phantoms, slamming doors, blood rituals, possessed children, upside-down crosses - The Offering leaves few horror devices unused.
While [director Jeppe Rønde's] preference for mood over plot occasionally results in repetition, the film [...] casts an eerie, increasingly nightmarish spell.
The most hardcore film of the year, Green Room, is 95 minutes of pure, unbridled Mosh Pit Cinema.
A highly personal portrait of the importance of embracing who you have while you still can.
No matter how valid [its] theory might be, there are surely more compelling ways to offer it than via a one-note, 88-minute-long joke.
Shadow World sells its argument about the West's criminality not with reporting but through paranoid propaganda.
This mirthless Eddie Murphy vehicle from the director of 'Driving Miss Daisy' is rife with hoary 'magical negro' stereotypes.
Gervais' script mistakenly assumes that its ever-more-troublesome plot twists are alone enough to prop up the proceedings. With each new development, though, the film becomes slightly creakier ...
A cheesy rehash of numerous stunted-adolescent dramedies.
While thrills are mitigated by convoluted plotting and suspect character behavior, the film's uniquely bleak twist on classic noir conventions is enlivening.
Newcomer Salima Koroma takes a good look at a handful of Asian-American talents trying to break into the hip-hop scene.
Mads Mikkelsen's weirdo performance helps prop up this Danish black comedy about the reunion of long-lost mutant brothers.

Neil proves compellingly gruff as a reluctant father figure, though it's the trash-talking, family-craving ten-year-old Dennison who steals the show, exuding a wacko, wounded attitude rooted in Ricky's backwoods Rambo-Scarface-Mad Max reveries.

The pitfall of a tantalizing set-up is that it requires a sterling payoff to match - a recipe for disappointment born out by "Rebirth," whose premise-establishing early passages lead only to underwhelming revelations.
It's a showcase for some fine acting and even finer basketball action, but neither are enough to cover for this story's enervating formulaic construction.
Another return to "return of the repressed" ghost-story terrain, "Lavender" unearths few new surprises yet reconfirms the efficacy of its genre's most hallowed conventions.

[The film] functions as a project of not only confrontation but resurrection, as Bill's sleuthing sheds new light on Kitty's personality, romances and career, and thus finally re-emphasizes her as a flesh-and-blood person rather than just a famous victim.
Equal parts history lesson, cautionary tale and nerve-rattling thriller, using all manner of nonfiction devices to elicit both horror and outrage over the precariousness of our deadliest arsenals.

Maudlin and mannered, this contrived indie squanders another fine late-career performance from Frank Langella, dousing its treatment of the subject in affectations until it's snuffed out any trace of genuine life.
Not even a Justin Timberlake score can lift this sodden collection of forced emotions and overripe indie cliches.

It's the absence of Dave's brother and athletic partner, Mark, that most glaringly sticks out in director Jon Greenhalgh's film. That incompleteness is a nagging issue throughout, though it shouldn't hinder this otherwise sterling documentary's appeal ...
Revels in the foulness of 21st-century pop culture, albeit to a degree that's ultimately both exhausting and redundant.
Amenábar's film can barely lay out its faith-vs.-science-vs.-reason conflicts, much less employ them for critical purposes.

'Jem' has less in common with its neon-drenched '80s source material than with the real-life Internet-to-red-carpet trajectory of Justin Bieber - a similarly generic teen idol with moves dully modeled on superior artistic predecessors.
A contrived indie rom-com that has the distinction of making the charming Rebecca Hall and amusing Jason Sudeikis thoroughly unlikable.
A slender but stirring celebration of 'America's Best Idea.'
A slog that plays like an unintentional parody of a Euro-arthouse drama ...

Aside from a few woeful jump scares, the film is too consumed with showcasing dreary digital effects, and photographing its players amidst gears and gadgets and funhouse-mirror glass, to bother crafting suspense.
Creed delivers predictable uplift but, ultimately, fails to make a unique name for itself.

Redmayne and Vikander are equally compelling, treating their characters' arduous attempts to transform themselves -- and, also, to reconfigure their ideas about each other, and the future -- with graceful precision.
It's as unsubtle as a boot to the head, but its dour-and-campy lo-fi style is far preferable to the spastic flash of its big-budget genre compatriots.
"Freaks of Nature" proves a lifeless combination of alien invasion saga, zombie thriller, vampire romance and high-school drama.
"Secret In Their Eyes" seems interested in making a point about the potential hazards of giving in to one's most ardent passions, bu such a notion isn't developed by the script.
Though at times too splintered by its various points of interest, Bernardo Ruiz's up-close-and-personal documentary is nonetheless harrowing in its details.
'Part 2' is so self-serious that it loses any sense of humor or adventure.
A piercing character study whose narrow view frustrates complete empathy.
A dreary direct-to-video-grade adventure that should have been terminated before it ever began.
Simultaneously vulgar, heady and heartfelt ...

After the umpteenth instance of characters slipping on, crawling through, or being coated in human sludge, one grows numb to such shock tactics, and it leaves the proceedings feeling not only inert, but downright juvenile.
Decked out in the usual tinsel-and-mistletoe trappings, the film lurches awkwardly between gloominess and giddiness, never hitting the boisterously bittersweet groove it seeks.
Robert De Niro lazily rehashes his Casino shtick in Heist, a genre retread without a believable bone in its bruised and battered body.
[Gregg Turkington gives] a magnetic lead turn that, like the rest of the provocative action, is designed to repulse.
A bracing documentary about an Israeli town where music is the coping mechanism for constant rocket-firing warfare.

Considering how well Cooper and Lawrence meshed in Silver Linings Playbook, Serena's inert central dynamic underlines the fact that chemistry is as much a byproduct of directorial stewardship as it is of actors' natural chemistry.

If John Wick is the best looking action film in recent memory, it's also bolstered by a phenomenal cast of actors who, be they in parts big or small, manage to craft three-dimensional characters out of stock archetypes.
...a successful bridge between the old and the new, and one that, no matter its emotional slimness, ultimately never loses sight of the fretful angst with which all kids must, at some point, contend.
The real calamity is the film's election of uplifting liberal-working-class fantasy over a truly damning indictment of the amorality coursing through current geopolitics.
Spectre's dearth of surprises proves a death knell for its drama, since it means that most of what occurs throughout its story is merely filler in service of telegraphed bombshells.

Its story is ultimately too familiar and chilly to truly hit the melodramatic peaks of Haynes's Far From Heaven, but it nonetheless boasts a commendable understanding of the complexities of human desire.
No matter his impressive appearance, however, [Krampus is] a rather ho-hum villain whose negligible personality and flair means that even the climactic pay-offs fall flat.
This Mother Teresa biopic offers Hallmark Channel-grade inspiration of the most sluggish sort.
The impermanence of life, the fragility of love, the persistence of desire: These are the issues that swirl around a Swiss spa and its luxuriating inhabitants in Youth.
Arab culture's misogynistic power dynamics are addressed with incisiveness, if too few specifics, by "Sand Storm," the promising first feature from Israeli writer/director Elite Zexer.
An old-fashioned tale of heroism in the face of insurmountable odds, "The Finest Hours" is never less than aggressively hokey and manipulatively sentimental - and, in the end, better off for it.
Spike Lee's documentary on this formative period in Michael Jackson's career derives electric, enlivening energy from fantastic clips.
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Its slapstick-y nonsense [is] stretched so painfully thin that the proceedings venture perilously close to becoming little more than a superpowered slog.
Cinematographer Kirsten Johnson delivers a uniquely insightful memoir-cum-critical-treatise on the nature and ethics of her craft.

Suggesting that modern cinema's most prescient work may be "Terminator," Werner Herzog's "Lo and Behold" takes a simultaneously curious, awe-struck and terrified look at the origins and future of the web and the interconnected reality it's begat.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Alien invaders behave intelligently before acting really, really stupidly in "The 5th Wave," a tween-oriented sci-fi adventure that synthesizes "They Live," "The Hunger Games," and countless other visitors-from-another-world sagas.
Robert De Niro hits rock-bottom opposite Zac Efron in this atrocious excuse for a comedy.
Oscar Isaac's over-the-top performance as a menacing drifter can't save this turgid neo-noir western.

Engaging and enraging but also, alas, consistently superficial, it's a hot-button work whose easily digested nonfiction methods will appeal to mainstream documentary audiences, even if they also leave viewers hungry for greater substance.
Has so little to say about miasmatic global conflicts that the film feels sketched rather than fully drawn.
Potential is buried so deeply within "The Forest" that is registers as mere ghostly whispers of a film far better than this ghoulishly graceless one.
Eytan Rockaway's generic chiller clings so tightly to conventions that it fails to even moderately raise one's pulse.
O'Brien's slow-motion-heavy staging is graceless, and his script is twice as unwieldy.
This ungainly B movie makes virtually no sense in terms of either mythology or basic plotting.
The result is a stunning audio-video hodgepodge that, in almost every case, captures some underlying essence of the Nirvana frontman.
If Son of Saul aims to disturb and repulse, it does so with the same sort of fierce, unwavering purpose that guides its protagonist.
With the lazy, misshapen "The Ridiculous 6," Adam Sandler robs his new Netflix benefactors blind.

Murray's co-stars provide just enough star wattage to keep "A Very Murray Christmas" mildly engaging, even as they do so little that it feels like they're just participating to humor their headliner friend's flights of fancy.
That's the film's first shortcoming-namely, that it doesn't really make a single, lucid point.
From the sound of it, The Revenant was an arduous chore to make. And as the final product proves, it was definitely worth the trouble.
No matter its cinematic derivativeness, "Stink!'s" outcry against continuing to use the American citizenry as chemistry experiment guinea pigs carries with it the unassailable whiff of common sense.
Despite an amusingly dirty-and-dour lead performance, this Yuletide indie can barely sustain its boozy comedic buzz.
This awkward hybrid of romantic comedy and ribald girls-just-wanna-have-fun romp is so scattershot that it never earns any of its eventual heartstring tugging.
The icy fatalism of film noir is turned to slush by Thin Ice, a crime saga that reduces its chosen genre to a series of atonal, old-hat clichés.

Mannered dialogue and a limited number of functional set locations (living room, classroom, bedroom) leave the material feeling stilted and claustrophobic, constricting any sense of genuine tumult or passion.

Not so much an actual movie as an assortment of Amerindie affectations, The Dish & the Spoon doesn't waste a moment on recognizable reality, consumed as it is with checking off various items from its list of clichés.

A cross between Greenberg and The Answer Man with a few extra helpings of quirk, Paper Man dully reconfirms that the new millennium's favorite indie-film cliché is the man-child struggling to grow up.
Hate mail for the hoity-toity art world, Boogie Woogie demonstrates the same mercy to its milieu that a flesh-eater might show a fresh carcass.
Zhao Dayong's Ghost Town paints a haunting trifurcated portrait of people set adrift by forced large-scale economic and cultural transformations.

Nude, hallucinogen-fueled jaunts on rooftops, revelations about same-sex relationships -- with a little person, no less -- and individuals covered in feces are all executed with verve by the typically misanthropic Neil LaBute.

As a subversive dissection of a genre, the film has no grit or imagination, and as a work of stock wham-bam entertainment, it's a sloppy trifle, merely the latest piece of disposable Friday night mainstream-cinema juvenilia.
Baseball movies generally lean toward the mawkishly uplifting, an inclination wholly embraced by The Perfect Game, which resorts to such corniness that one can practically hear the screen crunching.
A high-concept premise too-tidily comments on its underlying subject matter in The Joneses.
When it comes to what Exit is selling, buyers beware.
Provides riveting, intimate immersion in its twosome's sweet, sour, multifaceted union.

Steve Carell and Tina Fey's partnership as the lynchpins of NBC's Thursday night schedule is crudely translated to the big screen in Date Night, a creaky comedy only tolerable thanks to its stars' likeability.
Finely attuned to the disquieting realm of the irrational.
Benefits from a rollicking wise-ass performance from Kurt Russell but otherwise falls limp courtesy of too many corny gags.
Its attempts to intriguingly address issues of life and death are undercut by silly vagueness and sillier gratuitous T&A.
New Moon is only after the affectation of emotion, of swoon-worthy poses and faux-momentous aesthetics.
Truly undone by the dramatic void at its center.
The film is engineered to entice tween female moviegoers and repel everyone else.
An alluring blonde has spelled many a noir protagonist's doom, and that stereotypical femme is exploited for modest suspense and humor in writer-director Jake Goldberger's off-kilter tale.
Has substantial bite.
Falls back mainly on army squad clichés and rote conflicts, along the way delivering a group of protagonists woefully short on personality.
A series of barely tethered surrealistic shenanigans perpetrated by coasting A-listers.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Has verve to spare, not to mention a message ... refreshingly delivered with more blood and sweat than tears.
Whereas Chan's narrative (scripted by a whopping eight writers) settles into a standard rise-and-fall arc, his fight sequences exhibit a punchy vigor.
The Square has a toughness, gallows wit, and sense of impending tragedy amplified by its grainy, gliding aesthetics and an agitated performance by David Roberts.
Messy genre jumbling has rhyme and reason in Leaves of Grass, as it speaks directly to the film's portrait of life's unpredictability and uncontrollability.
The film colors its stale outline in ways both hackneyed and mundane.
Don't let Mercy's title fool you, as there's no clemency here, from cliché or pretentiousness.
Now here's a relatively new (if not necessarily welcome) idea: the sorta-kinda-not-really sequel.
Scraps of moderately inspired eye candy ... remain sparse and incapable of lending weight to such cash-my-paycheck-dammit material.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film that proves the concept "overwrought" is the same in every language.
It's ye olde clash of religion and science, though the real struggle is between coherence and cockamamy grandiloquence.
Micmacs is the logical next step in Jean-Pierre Jeunet's career, more or less completely doing away with narrative as a vital component and exalting mouse trap-style set pieces as a be-all end-all.

Christopher Browne's sturdy documentary... shows not simply the ability of sports triumph to inspire national unity, but also the far more difficult act of sustaining such hope once the afterglow of winning has faded.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The writer-director's interest in desire and longing is habitually channeled through quirky-quick brushstrokes that reduce the already borderline-pretentious proceedings into full-blown treacle.
Shrek Forever After isn't offensive, just innocuous and unnecessary, a supposed final chapter to a series that should have ended two installments ago.
Provides a fascinating glimpse into a cloistered culture even as it conforms to a rather stale narrative mold.
Like Taylor Swift's pop hit "Love Story," Garry Winick's Letters to Juliet references Shakespeare to prop up its cornball fairy-tale romanticism.
Ably achieves its goal of providing original, eye-scrub-required horror imagery.
A warm, jovial and decidedly uncritical look at both [Troll 2] and its rabid fans.
Little more than a generic medieval actioner.
Fatally eccentric.
TiMER is not only predicated on a ridiculous premise, but one with a surprisingly muddled message.
Princess Kaiulani is no The New World.
Upgraded with the latest CGI hardware but also more shoddy screenwriting software than its system can withstand, Iron Man 2 is an example of subtraction by addition.
Babies is barely more insightful than your average Flickr photo gallery or home movie clip: it's just infant porn for prospective parents.
The meaning of Multiple Sarcasms's title is a mystery, but then, so are many things in Brooks Branch's film.
It makes plain, from the outset, its position as an exposé-cum-condemnation of our political system as inherently flawed with regard to the relationship between lobbyists, politicians, and policy.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fails to mimic or update with any competence.
As amusingly stupid as advertised.
The big-studio romantic comedy has become so intractably set in its ways that there's no longer hope for true innovation; competent replication of clichés is now a best-case scenario.
Isn't clever or inventive enough to seem like a high-stakes game.
First and foremost, [Raimi's] gonzo aesthetics are interested in high-wire kicks, of which there are plenty throughout.
As it slogs through one hectic yet mundane set pieces after another, the film slowly drowns in its own pool of clichés.
This limp psychodrama proves woefully short on character development or narrative structure.
A tone-deaf odyssey of personal discovery striving to echo Dante's Inferno.
Legion has the good sense to mimic a classic but otherwise makes no sense at all.
Jon Amiel's portrait of Darwin's efforts to accept and acclimate to a new reality is mucked up by all manner of directorial flim-flam.
Eli is nothing less than a prophet-superman on a divine mission, and while he naturally saves the word of God and, thus, humanity at large, he's powerless to salvage the film from its derivativeness.
Following in Mr. Nanny and The Pacifier's turgid footsteps, Brian Levant's film mushifies Chan into a comedic parody of his rock-'em-sock-'em big-screen persona.

Ben is such a stock type, and his circumstances are so doggedly implausible, that his ultimate transformation and happily-ever-after are a preordained conclusion that one must dutifully await while enduring squishy dramedy.
The Spierigs' latest doesn't do much to carve out a unique identity.
The pessimism of Na's slick debut rings false.
Whiplash quick and twice as exciting.
A romantic comedy of such staggering ineptness that it actually makes one wish the filmmaker would redirect his attention back to the superhero genre he sullied.
Unsuccessfully attempts to fashion an actual story out of slapdash, seemingly improvised sequences awash in uneven CG effects.
With Avatar, a cinematic revolution doesn't begin so much as proceed into its next phase.
An unbearably taut, slow-simmering noir transposed to the vast countryside and its patient, drawn-out rhythms.
Requires more than incessant slow-motion and escalating orchestral music to pass as serious drama.
Gray-haired Gless grouches with embarrassing abandon while chatting with the young ghost of her soulmate and befriending a mysterious girl (Jackson).
Finds beauty, madness and outright bizarreness in the sight of a lost, slightly freakish man attempting to understand his altering reality.
Clint Eastwood's films are often termed "classical," a term that, with regard to Invictus, also suggests something close to stale.
The film isn't any uglier than its antecedents, but it is more lethargic.
Begins as merely intolerable and ends up borderline-reprehensible.
Eimbcke's Jarmusch-ian comedy is laced with something stronger.
An oppressive sense of brutality, loneliness and ennui remains visceral.
This is simply a showcase for Jeff Bridges, and a reasonably decent one at that even when the script thrusts Bad down tediously hackneyed roads.
The fight-the-power scenario operates as a rebel fantasy of empowered French multicultural youth, yet it's one that never rises above cartoonishness.
A stylized, scattershot inquiry into Italy's TV-dominated culture, Videocracy is a portrait of 21st-century media fascism.
It's the sort of Sundance-approved movie that takes place in a stereotypically bleak rural locale, while an acoustic guitar twangs mournfully over the soundtrack.
A fascinating, often fantastic, film, one simultaneously indebted to and self-consciously divorced from its acclaimed predecessors in ways both clunky and inspired.
Just about the epitome of '80s macho action.
So thoroughly coated in over-the-top blood and guts that even veteran genre fans will likely be astounded.
No serious subtext to be found here, just vigorous love and respect for the simultaneous horror and humor inherent to the genre.
Unsure of what it wants to be, The Eclipse winds up only being a mishmashed nothing.
Sluggishly paced, of minor consequence, and increasingly derivative in form and content.
Re-emphasizes the nagging impression that the director is stuck in a creative rut, making pictures that are a tad too well-suited for his idiosyncratic style.
A litany of humiliations befalls the protagonist, fitting given that this adaptation of Jeff Kinney's popular kids-lit series is itself a minor embarrassing misfire.
A stark example of misbegotten chemistry and its resultant pitfalls.
Marked only by clichés about broken homes, the primal sexuality of punk rock, and the dangerous allure of drugs and stardom.
Baumbach fails to create a compelling case for investing oneself in Greenberg's quest for self-actualization.
A dysfunctional family drama pitched like a Buñuelian black comedy laced with horror.
Its rage against the U.S. war machine is not only five years too late, but simplistic, its censure screamed with all the subtlety of Shock and Awe and its schematic layout of good and evil.
Bong's film is thoroughly entrancing, a strange, disorienting snapshot of motherly protectiveness driven to its self-destructive extremes.
A subtle visual stunner awash in creeping paranoia and anxiety.
The film's audio-video barrage ultimately just puffs up corny B-movie material to the point of distension.
Majestic animation fails to conjure a sense of enchantment in The Secret of Kells, a beautiful two-dimensional work devoid of dramatic vigor.
Twohy lets his story's central guessing game play out with patient tautness.
A testament to the value of understated genre craftsmanship.
A variety of scenarios provides ample opportunities for humor, yet most are lazily wasted.
A Prophet doesn't reimagine the prison movie so much as simply reenergize it through painstaking attention to particulars.
Succeeds only at suggesting the incompatibility of returning-home dramedy and surrealistic flights of fancy.
Harry Potter knockoffs don't come more transparent and slapdash than this wannabe-franchise jumpstarter directed by Chris Columbus.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What's limper than a self-referential indie about an aspiring filmmaker struggling to make a movie? One set in the superdirty porn industry!
A cautionary rejoinder to typical sports-movie uplift, elucidating how athletics remain a dangerously precarious foundation upon which to construct lasting peace.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [A] cacophonous, frivolous adaptation of Ubisoft's Arabian Nights-themed video-game series.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Though South Africa's racial strife is frequently invoked, sociopolitical inquiry takes a backseat to creaky gangster-cinema tropes.
Exhilarating, exasperating, inspired and redundant, Enter the Void is a film of equal parts greatness and silliness.
A multilayered portrait of immense physical, emotional and psychological change.
[The] Resident Evil saga continues to be one of the millennium's only adequate B-movie franchises.
Carries an overpowering scent of writerly affectation.
The film's conceit begins to crumble under the weight of unpersuasive details.
A dog in wolf's clothing, Lionsgate's drab, anthropomorphic animal saga does little more than reconfirm the preeminence of Pixar.
This doc is an 82-minute series of nonbombshells: Models are pampered! They have body-image issues! And sometimes they have to contend with the unwanted sexual advances of male photographers!
Promises what it has no intention of delivering.
An illuminating history lesson about the Kentucky metropolis's artistic vision and philharmonic orchestra.
movie_title: Music Makes A City: A Louisville Orchestra Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: All that's left to the proceedings are "well-duh!" revelations about the way modern mass-media affords opportunities for role-playing deceptions.
there's no revelation to these blunt, garish, perfunctory proceedings, only "timely" moralizing
All the self-awareness and saucy banter in the world can't make Easy A consistently funny, nor can the copious snark, tired '80s references, and glib Scarlet Letter parallels that define its story.
A down-home fable of familial healing that asks wrestling star John Cena to hold his weight opposite Patricia Clarkson.
Unlike Sarah Polley's superior kindred spirit Away from Her, Lovely, Still's portrait of late-life love is excruciatingly shallow and phony.
Katie Holmes's trademark smirk may make only one appearance in The Romantics, but this turgid faux indie compensates by eliciting plenty of sneers via its pretentious and phony romantic drama.
Basically a slice of formulaic Hollywood-style mythmaking, writ large and woefully empty.
Garrett and Erin meet cute over a game of Centipede, though their subsequent long-distance romance breeds mainly a desire to see them and their friends suffer Human Centipede-style torment.
Director Turner never musters the requisite manic energy that might get her proceedings off the ground.
Pretentious profiles in post-9/11 grief and confusion, Clear Blue Tuesday manages the not-inconsiderable feat of insulting both the memory of the World Trade Center attacks and the musical genre.
Considering its status as merely a puddle of regurgitated elements, The Winning Season is, to be as coarse as its protagonist, the cinematic equivalent of vomit.
When did Zhang Yimou start acting like Jean-Pierre Jeunet?
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Rodriguez loves exploitation cinema but his homages to the disreputable genre are defined by italicized self-consciousness that leaves his humor without any room to breathe.
A case study in pioneering feminist courage, ambition and individualism.
A classical heroic odyssey that boasts a spirit similar to that of The Secret of N.I.M.H., and is enhanced by such sumptuous 3-D CGI it would make Pixar blush.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely has a big-studio feature integrated real-world figures into artificial landscapes with this little grace.
An astonishingly multilayered portrait of a romantic relationship that doubles as a commentary on the value of reproductions - and, thus, the cinema itself.
Woefully creaky and corny.
A misbegotten jumble that clumsily synthesizes various incongruous elements.
Incapable of rising above mere pleasantness.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Both a powerhouse piece of docudrama-thriller filmmaking and a cannily politicized work.
Green’s nifty framing, dawning-dread pacing, and fixation on corporeal deterioration proves sturdy.
Clint Eastwood crafts a Babel all his own with Hereafter, a trifurcated tale of death, grief, and the great beyond that finds the director succumbing to eye-rolling corniness.
Modernizes its source material in only superficial, ho-hum ways.
A clever stunt that shrewdly wrestles with issues of fame, truth and self.
A film aimed squarely at making you stupider.
movie_title: GhettoPhysics: Will the Real Pimps and Hos Please Stand Up! (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Meek's Cutoff is an act of inversion, a western that reverses the genre's traditional forms and dynamics to create something new and startling, yet still familiar.

There's only one thing worse than a leaden moral fable that tackles issues of forgiveness with sledgehammer contrivances, and that's one that attempts to mask its manipulative corniness with an air of trumped-up gravity.
movie_title: Letters to Father Jacob (Postia pappi Jaakobille) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: From a bevy of cheesy jolt scares (alarm clock! barking dog!) to the embarrassing sight of Zellweger and Ian McShane treating this Orphan-style B-movie silliness with grave seriousness, the film proves to be one hokey-horror riot.
Documentaries warrant viewpoints, but they should also provide perspective on more than one side of a contentious issue.
The formulaic race footage itself is vigorous; the schmaltzy mythmaking script, on the other hand, deserves a one-way trip to the glue factory.
At odds with its own lofty and base instincts, Stone ultimately channels neither compellingly.
A snapshot of consuming obsession and the inspiring power of art that’s like falling into a bewildering, beguiling dream.
Treats its stock dynamics and themes with respectful professionalism.
Boden and Fleck's competent, bland aesthetics do little more than occasionally amplify their material's cloying sentimentality.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The gist remains the same, and in some cases improved upon.
Legend trumps fact in Ip Man, a kickass fictionalized biopic of the titular grandmaster of Wing Chun martial arts and mentor to Bruce Lee.
Petty's film devolves into a transparent and uninformative gimmick.
Intended to amuse younger viewers and send older ones to Urban Dictionary, Douchebag's title is, unfortunately, its most noteworthy aspect
Fincher segments and layers his material at a pace befitting the meteoric ascendancy of Facebook itself, and without the grandstanding that's sometimes marked his work.

A horror film for the Christian fundamentalist set, The Last Exorcism employs the aesthetic of The Blair Witch Project for a musty demonic-possession tale that promotes strict, anti-modern doctrinal faith as the most righteous path.
Pleasant enough in the moment but maintains considerable distance from actually plumbing the raw emotions of its central subject.
A treacly tweener saga of first love that drowns in nostalgia, Flipped furthers Rob Reiner's slide into irrelevance.
Below bottom-of-the-barrel.
A moody fantasia of barely repressed compulsions and desire.
Incompetent in every respect.
M. Night Shyamalan throws his hands up and sells out with The Last Airbender, an adaptation of the Nickelodeon animé series that boasts almost no sign of the director's idiosyncratic imprimatur.
Revel[s] in its seedier aspects ... while appropriating every aesthetic trope from the modern Hollywood thriller handbook.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Delivers what it promises.
Flounders in its stabs at epic action-horror grandeur.
A scenario ripped straight from a screenwriting computer program.
[Its] classic cinema shoutouts and gaggle of off-kilter characters feel like retreads.
Glossy exploitation cinema without guts.
Adam Sandler spends more time laughing at jokes than making them in Grown Ups, perhaps the slackest, shabbiest comedy in the star's increasingly dreadful oeuvre.
The film supplies a frighteningly limited, visceral perspective on unholy carnage.

The film retains a measure of tempered hope, born not simply from the father's command-cum-wish to his slumbering offspring but also from a final act of youthful compassion that binds Ozu's intensely human characters in glass-half-full solidarity.
movie_title: Otona no miru ehon - Umarete wa mita keredo (I Was Born, But ) (Children of Tokyo) (1932)

movie_review_blurb: Lacking any compelling style, attitude or storytelling.
A smug, swaggering piece of cacophonous mayhem.
A witty, inspiring portrait of a life in constant reinvention.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Can't overcome the fact that it's sending up a 007 series that -- with the exception of 2006's superb Casino Royale -- already plays like a parody of itself.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Jonah Hex definitely appears to be making itself up as it goes along.
So thoroughly indulging in baroque aesthetic gestures (especially with regards to the intrusive, overcooked score) that the film becomes a flamboyant caricature of itself.
Skillful but aloof, unable to truly burrow into and reflect its protagonist's psychosexual madness.
A [final] turn for the mundane doesn't negate the preceding, metaphorically sturdy B-movie thrills.

Jay and Mark Duplass inch closer to successfully infusing comedy-of-awkwardness with pained pathos in Cyrus, a big-studio mumblecore hybrid of Mr. Woodcock and the Martin Short-Charles Grodin vehicle Clifford.
Employs a conventional Amerindie template ... without ever feeling stale, forced or phony.
Balances rollicking adventure, personality-driven comedy and wrenching pathos with a deftness only surpassed by a handful of animation efforts.
The film's rough patches are ... considerably smoothed over by its performers.
Strained pulp awash in insincere you-go-riot-grrrl attitude.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Inception is Instruction Manual Cinema, a film that spends so much time explaining the rules of its narrative conceit that it fails to either emotionally engage or, except in a few notable spots, viscerally thrill.
Though seemingly content to be a B-movie director, Neil Marshall heads further into C-list territory with Centurion
Offers up neither clearly delineated characters nor any fundamental character of its own.
Piranha 3D proves a worthy heir to its brazen exploitation-cinema forefathers.
Far more surprising than the blinding preposterousness of The Switch's opening passages is the fact that the film smoothly recovers to become a passable character-driven rom-com.
Exists in an uncomfortable gray area in which Tillman's saga is at once respectfully dealt with and bestowed with a magnitude it doesn't quite warrant.
It's merely a compendium of photocopied elements, cartoonish special effects, and easy-bake happily-ever-afters.
Zach Clark's film posits a world in which finding and maintaining amour is anything but routine.
Salt's centerpieces are assuredly helmed but lacking in imagination
Animal Kingdom wrongly assumes certain characters deserve empathy simply because they're protagonists.
Adam McKay merely puts his big-studio budget on screen by embracing the car chases and slow-mo shootouts he should be mocking or, better yet, ignoring altogether.
Actual insight into these people's hearts and minds is replaced with skin-deep montages of cheery tour-bus road-tripping, hanging out with friends, and writing songs in the studio.
Their sense of superiority toward the petty SUV drivers and rude midlife-crisisers who frequent the lot is matched by introspective considerations of traditional social contracts.
Edgar Wright is cinema's most inspired mash-up artist, and Scott Pilgrim vs. the World may be his finest hybridization to date, a romantic comedy recast as a mêlée-heavy video game.
Samuel Maoz's portrait of four young Israelis manning a roving war machine on the first day of the 1982 Lebanon War is solely an experiential affair.
Quiet and precise, it's a character drama that treats modesty as a virtue in and of itself.
A PSA masquerading as an actual drama.
The schmaltzy spawn of The Sixth Sense.
The familiar plot structure is only the tip of the formulaic iceberg, a foundation for more stale conventions than any indie should dare embrace.
As the proceedings briskly fly, the silliness of the entire endeavor becomes more readily apparent.
A loose adaptation of Beverly Cleary's first novel in her beloved kid-lit series that's wholesome to the point of being dull.
As with Palindromes, Life During Wartime revolves around a casting gimmick, with its predecessor's roles now embodied by all new performers.
A big-budget B-movie made with some A-level flair.
Rockwell is the film's only consistently amusing presence.
Hickey's overarching arguments about war, diplomacy, and American intelligence aren't just muddled, but altogether nonexistent, leaving his comedically challenged film Iraqi-desert-level barren.
Captures the complex human face of modern warfare.
Michael Hoffman's biopic of Leo Tolstoy's final year filters its historical drama through a turgid coming-of-age experience.
It's the socio-cultural suggestions of this storytelling choice that's ultimately most troublesome.
The film's scenario unavoidably devolves into a treatise that, though timely, feels a tad too on the nose.
movie_title: Vegas: Based on a True Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The sporadic appearances by Ali hopelessly unbalance the proceedings, his fiercely outspoken interviews providing the only morsels of substance.
Through narration, interviews, and cinematographic fawning over their chassis, classic American cars are celebrated for their imperfect character, which makes them seem vibrantly alive.

Yet another of this year's homage-facsimiles, The House of the Devil forgoes campy self-awareness in favor of reverential faithfulness--and in doing so, implicitly critiques contemporary horror cinema.
Generally humorless and pointless, devoid as the film is of any commentary on the genre to which it's paying loving tribute.
With the exception of an adequate helicopter attack, the action is perfunctory and forgettable, albeit no more so than the script's range of cliches
The plot's eventual denigration of the single life and endorsement of soul mates and happily-ever-afters is predictably rote.
What ultimately prevents Eldorado from generating any serious comedic energy is absurdity ... that feels unduly strained and limp.
A bizarre, preachy pro-peace animated adventure.
Plods along with a self-seriousness that borders on parody.
Zonca's story is an unruly beast, lurching this way and that like a biker hopped up on mescaline and paint thinner, its unpredictable rowdiness in sync with its out-of-control protagonist.
Director Shill doesn't get fancy building tension from his nonsensical male-anxiety mayhem, allowing Knowles's beguiling fierceness and Larter's sexualized cunning to carry much of the prurient load.
Ultimately proves too subjective to truly get at the heart and mind-frame of its iconic subject.
Mix historical drama, nostalgic coming-of-age soap opera, and more cooking metaphors than even Julia Child would be able to stomach, and the resultant concoction is A Touch of Spice.

Fundamentally a condensed trailer for the BBC's portrait of the globe's myriad habitats, the film offers a skimpy but reverential portrait of the intertwined relationship between the environment and its inhabitants.
Like its predecessor, Crank: High Voltage is speedball cinema, a pure narcotized rush of blistering action, odious stereotypes, and shock-for-shock's-sake nastiness.
Culminates in an unconvincing finale whose hopefulness seems not only fanciful but, when viewed on the story's own terms, woefully short-sighted.
Achieves suitably swift momentum, the twists and turns coming fast enough to keep one distracted from the obvious, telegraphed denouement lying in wait.
It's a testament to Michael Caine that Is Anybody There?, a squishy drama about the friendship between an unhappy young boy and a regretful old man, is even sporadically palatable.
The nicest thing one can say about the film is that at least it's not The Suite Life of Zack & Cody: The Movie.
Though Morgan's non-fiction techniques are only serviceably straightforward, the director engagingly makes clear that Adams' most renowned image haunted him but did not, ultimately, define his work.
Effectively slimed everyone's fond memories of the original.
Fighting evocatively captures the texture of New York City
Authenticity is drowned out by an overarching don't-judge-a-book-by-its-cover message that long ago lost its luster.
If Egoyan's elliptical narrative flirts with pretentiousness, the director nonetheless encases his action in an affecting mood of regret and longing.
A largely thrilling surprise, its blend of humor, romance and action so kinetically orchestrated that calling out its shortcomings feels like excessive carping.
The portentous narration and manipulative horror-film aesthetics turn what might have been a portrait of a boogeyman myth's lingering societal role into merely a crude episode of 48 Hours.
Are Tony Scott's films actually directed by Google Earth?
Paul Devlin's documentary portrays its central locale as merely an interesting, uniquely situated outpost.
An assured, mesmerizing tale of intergalactic loneliness, self-inquiry, and man's innate, enduring hunger for life.
Ends up feeling like a tossed-off Judd Apatow photocopy.
Land of the Lost is halfway toward amusing, which means it's just as close to awful.
Serving merely formulaic find-yourself melodrama, the film coasts along lackadaisically.
Director Phillips wrings his scenario for consistent semi-dark humor, letting his odd-couple leads go for broke and wielding mystery as a comedic spur that keeps the proceedings from dragging.
A road-trip comedy in equal measures bittersweet and hopeful, Mendes's latest boasts few of his stuffy aesthetic trademarks.
A delirious haunted house carnival ride.
A flagrantly contrived piece of Hollywood-style hokum masquerading as serious drama.
Exudes a wit and wisdom that elevates it to the animated adventure apex.

Pontypool at least manages to amuse (a spur-of-the-moment on-air obituary is priceless) as well as consistently intrigue, right up to a bizarro post-credits epilogue that seems beamed in from Sin City.
It falls flat trying to muster up any mirth or suspense as it barrels from one set piece to the next.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Strives for bleak gravity with misguided fervor.
All the world's a financial transaction just waiting to be negotiated in The Girlfriend Experience, a handsome, frosty, rather one-note time capsule from October 2008.
The weirdness employed by Stephen Belber's amorous fairy tale is of a decidedly limp, half-hearted sort.
If the story isn't nearly as ridiculous as Da Vinci's, director Ron Howard still impeccably maintains the series's turgid mediocrity.
By protracting his set-up, Petzold ... achieves and maintains an effective level of intrigue.
Infinitely pleased with its derivative, fanciful writerly convolutions.
Oh, O'Horten, how wincingly affected you are.
By letting others do the heavy lifting, the filmmaker comes off as more than a little reticent, a quality in tune with the overall tone of his latest.
What Goes Up's point that Americans create icons to fulfill their own screwy needs is made through contrived and nonsensical plotting.

A European tour fraught with shady venue owners, missed trains and in-fighting, and subsequent efforts to record their 13th studio album are misadventures that a less compassionate filmmaker might have wrung for cheap Spinal Tap-ish humor.

Jody Hill takes Ben Stiller's comedy-of-awkwardness to painfully uncomfortable, extreme realms, offering up unrepentantly disagreeable characters who confront their deep insecurities through psychotic displays of machismo.
Frequently outlandish and far from profound, it's nonetheless a box-office bomb that, like its horror-maestro director, deserved quite a bit better.

Gone is the original's early campiness, here replaced by eye-of-the-storm calm that portends tragedy, as well as its later over-the-top grindhouse gore, now swapped for taut suspense punctuated by visceral brutality.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Big Chill-ish enterprise whose serious intentions aren't enough to compensate for the two-dimensionality of its stock archetypes.
Mark Weber's Explicit Ills has a tenderness that belies its fiery left-leaning political views about urban poverty and social injustice.
A reverential photocopy of a superior original, it's often close to perfect, if also, to some extent, perfectly pointless.
In this surprisingly rich anthology, it's not merely location that proves the primary connective tissue, but a sense of individuals struggling to cope with detachment.
Charts the contrived awakenings of two caricatures.

Nikita Mikhalkov's 12 reconfigures Reginald Rose's 12 Angry Men for contemporary Russia, adopting the basic premise of the legendary source material while thoroughly grounding it in his homeland's current condition.
What little plot exists here is of the embarrassingly shallow sort.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Far be it from me to deny that girls just want to have fun, but I hope they realize that once this latest teen idol fad has run its course, a mighty, mortifying hangover most surely awaits.
A multi-strand saga whose contrived, inane narrative threads have been stitched together with Frankenstein ungainliness.
So awful as to make heterosexual men actively loathe Playboy.

Miring itself in both the sound and troubling aspects of Blecker's views, as well as the honesty and hypocrisy of his actions, Schillinger's portrait unobtrusively allows its zealous, self-reflective subject to speak for himself.
A Cinemax skin flick without the skin.
A severely limited affair, one whose appeal will likely be relegated to those already familiar with McCarroll's prior escapades.
Single-minded and suitably rough around the edges.
Intimately, poetically evokes the banal tragedies of one family's 1960s Hartford, CT life.
So dynamically careens between set pieces of elation and dread that one hardly has time to soak in all the twirling, tumbling visual marvels enveloping the screen.
Fired Up plays like a direct-to-video American Pie sequel.
Friday's jolting scare tactics barely make a dent.
If you gave Bernie Madoff custody of your life savings mere days before the FBI knocked on his door last December, your timing still wouldn't be as wretched as that of Confessions of a Shopaholic.
Focuses so intently on character details and setting that the gradual development and resolution of the plot seems not rote but fervent, prickly, alive.
Leave it to Woody Allen to muck up a threesome involving Scarlett Johansson and Penelope Cruz.
Not as frightening as it should be, but still better than the average Hollywood scare-a-thon.
The film's portrait of bank-robbing as a solution to twentysomething aimlessness seems quaint when viewed through the filter of today's economic hardships.
If Great Buck Howard is formulaic and only mildly funny, however, Malkovich is nonetheless magnificent.
This collage ... all too frequently succumbs to moralistic clichés, and never coheres into a rousing, affecting whole.
A project with the ingredients for greatness that nonetheless came out half-baked.

Removing the "the" from its predecessors' title not once but twice, Fast & Furious's abbreviated moniker harkens back to the series's 2001 original while simultaneously expressing a tough curtness that marks it as its own model.
Neither more nor less than a solid prison-break thriller.
A borderline insufferable trifle that dispenses quirkiness with its every gesture and breath.
Writer-director Broinowski's foremost achievement was convincing the discredited Norma Khouri to sit down and defend herself on camera.
It's a homily about the ethically and spiritually corrupting influence of the city, and of that milieu's capitalist ethos, straight out of an Industrial Revolution-era sermon.
The filmmakers' confidently modest helming ... allows events to feel, if not fresh, then at least real.
Saavedra's performance has an unwavering intensity that serves the film well.
Anarchic craziness makes the revolutionary message go down smoothly in Louise-Michel.
A mumblecore-ish debut feature from writer-director Bob Byington that's far less interested in oblique conversational navel-gazing than in dry humor.
Merely coasts along limply, lacking ribald tongue-in-cheek humor as well as the unironic self-seriousness that epitomized its spiritual predecessors.
A superficial, clichéd jumble that illustrates what might happen if you threw Moulin Rouge and Amélie into the same high-speed blender.
Harjo poeticizes the open road with increasing redundancy, yet his identical scenic panoramas remain preferable to his dramaturgy, which mistakes silence for pensiveness.
Cold Souls is a skillfully shot, well-acted, thoroughly unconvincing, and unaffecting put-on.

Haunting of Connecticut doesn't have to worry about line-straddling, its crummy scares and laughable stabs at a faith-restored narrative granting it permanent residence in the realm of C-grade cheese.
A lightweight saga about not being a doormat to egomaniacal men and embracing your, um, inner superpowered 50-foot-tall monster?
Absorbing yet lacking.
Bohdan Sláma's direction for The Country Teacher, a film characterized by beautifully long, languorous takes, has an assured expressiveness that's at odds with the story's bumpy narrative.
A work of tremendous poise and poignancy that assumes and articulates the perspective and emotional tenor of its two juvenile protagonists.
Solo confronts a less-than-jolly existence with a perpetual smile and helping hand, his upbeat, selfless attitude a means of repelling the harsh realities that threaten to break his spirit.
A rather pedestrian, hollow cat-and-mouse contest.
Super Capers doesn't ever come close to justifying its existence.
The promise that Alex Proyas showed with 1998's Dark City is only very sporadically evident in Knowing, the director's second sci-fi saga.
Comes across as a prologue teaser for a yet-to-be-established franchise.
The director's triumphant return to form.
Humor and romance are interspersed so predictably it's as if screenwriter Pete Chairelli were working from a rom-com checklist.
Unevenly replicates Sam Raimi's whirligig blend of terror and comedy.
In its best moments, the film exudes an almost Miyazakian love of flight, notably during the hero's maiden soar through the clouds.

At the very least, such triteness will dredge up a desire to keep the Weitz family -- brother Chris was responsible for the leaden Golden Compass debacle -- away from the first chapters of big-budget franchises.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Exhibits an almost pitch-perfect balance between condescension and compassion.
a shabby substitute for its original.
A mature, striking exploration of the way that kids feel.
Only sporadically feels like an effort interested in grappling with the miserable fallout from tragedy.
Has all the get-up-and-go of a dead battery.
Ultimately comes off as merely an excuse for stars to take a vacation on the studio's%u2014and moviegoing public's%u2014dime.
Never congeal[s] into an emotionally coherent or compelling whole.
[A] stilted, affected term-paper treatise on the human condition.
Amelia attempts the yeoman's task of recounting a tale about which it has virtually nothing to say.
Feels like an overly deliberate meta-Bressonian prank.
The parallel-tracks structure smoothly reveals cause-effect relationships even as it sometimes feels designed to gussy up the narrative's straightforward rise-and-fall arc.
Bronson is a fast, ferocious, wickedly funny portrait of one man's acceptance of his bone-deep animalism.

The Invention of Lying sets its sights high before settling for comfortable lovey-dovey convention.

This intertwined tale of people struggling on society's fringe plays like bad community theater.
Ultimately seems just as calculated and mechanical a pose as Dumont's previous efforts.
Says so much that's familiar if not downright clichéd, it winds up saying nothing at all.

Neither blue teeth nor virgins make appearances, but Russell Brown's torpid indie does deliver plenty of ponderous chitchat about truth, deception, criticism and artists' motivations.

For High School Musical fans unwaveringly devoted to Corbin Bleu, Free Style provides ample opportunity to swoon over the former East High basketballer's big floppy hair and Disney Channel-grade emoting.
[A] dim-witted, aesthetically clunky Tarantino clone.
Saw VI plays like the last gasp for relevance of a heavy-metal series that has not only gone regurgitation-rusty but seems lacking much of a will to live.

movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So wretched that it should be unceremoniously put down.
A cinematic adaptation at once faithful and superior to its source material.
May not result in a coherent whole but nonetheless delivers bursts of random, inspired madness.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Staten Island has the stench of meat left on the counter for too long.
The film's shortcomings have less to do with Woo's orchestration of his ambitious tale and more to do with the Frankenstein hatchet job enacted against it.
Ruspoli's scenic cross-section L.A. travelogue conveys a strong sense of milieu even as his wannabe-Strung aesthetics reveal the project's underlying style-over-substance concerns.
The defining entrant in, and the nadir of, the disaster porn genre.
Isn't drawn in one-to-one cause-effect lines, its obliqueness lending suspense and interpretative depth to the Job-like suffering of Larry.
Another of the Funny Games auteur's unpersuasively rigid portraits of man's venality.
