The same old thing dressed up in very slightly different clothes.
Moverman's scripting is subdued and emotionally authentic.

Writer-director Richard Curtis is about as rock n' roll as the average great-grandmother, so it's no surprise that Pirate Radio, his ode to the irrepressible spirit of '60s classic rock, has all the electricity of a knitted sweater.
Content to occupy that middle ground where insights are authentic but far from revelatory and comedy is more amiable than riotous.
Though his narrative's morality-play suspense and Bernard Herrmann-esque score recall Hitchcock, Kelly seems to have selected the '70s so that he can fully channel early-years Steven Spielberg.
A clear step in the right direction for Zemeckis and his pet techno-project, the film nonetheless ultimately sabotages itself by prizing the hectic over the heartfelt.
Despite positioning itself as a Napoleon Dynamite-style comedy about a spazzy social retard, Splinterheads seems to have misplaced most of its jokes.
Smith's subject Michael Ruppert never registers as much more than an eloquent but largely untrustworthy quack.
A teen-targeted public service announcement.
Daniels and screenwriter Geoffrey Fletcher pile tribulations onto their protagonist not to inform but merely to exploit.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So blatantly nonsensical that the action quickly tips over into campiness.
A true-life tale of prejudice that hinges on a unique anomaly.
A promotional film best suited for broadcast in an office lobby.
With rugged reverence, Sweetgrass depicts the final sheepherder drive into Montana's Beartooth mountains.

It not only crucially fails to address the cultural forces that might have spawned the country's prime musical export but it also neglects to include more than cursory snippets of the tunes themselves.
Old-hat tropes under a superficially stunning veneer.

Fontaine dramatizes Coco's struggles respectfully if mundanely, crafting believable period detail for her procession of key-life-moment scenes, all of which employ serviceable but far from groundbreaking psychologizing.
Its shallowness is nonetheless in tune with its subject: the gory, violent, sex-crazed Australian exploitation films of the '70s and '80s.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A quite stirring call to arms against the senseless, copious murder of animals.
Dreams figure prominently in You, the Living, which posits reveries as articulations of--or refuges from--deep-seated fears.
Its prime directive is to inculcate young viewers with the gee-whiz tropes of producer Jerry Bruckheimer's teen-oriented fare.
Despite director Jaume Collet-Serra's apt use of running children's laughter for jolt scares, the suspense generated from Esther's early lunatic behavior is of a mild, amusing variety.
A penetrating, deceptively sly interior portrait.
A razor-sharp farce that imparts insights from all directions.
As with Marsh, the state of Ukrainian medicine, and his topic's underlying issues of morality and mercy, director Smith merely presents them in all their heartrending complexity.
A dreary tale spun out of bland cliches and so many coincidences that one begins to believe its titular guru perhaps does have a direct line to the Almighty.
Often feels fruitful thanks to diligent concentration on the romantic plights of its three pubescent protagonists.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The cerebral horror of Wendigo and The Last Winter is nowhere to be found in Glenn McQuaid's meandering 19th-century supernatural gothic tale.
With empathetic reserve only sullied by occasional lapses into cross-cutting and musical italicizing, The Way We Get By equates the sadness of war and aging.
Blood is borderline incomprehensible.
Brüno is like Milk, but with a talking penis.
Public Enemies fizzles at the moment of detonation.
No giant robots urinate on humans in Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen.
Harrowing and horrifying, The Hurt Locker delivers the visceral, heart-in-throat action goods, and in doing so, gets at more truths about Iraq than its preachy ... brethren.
The Stoning of Soraya M. functions as a message-movie slasher film.
Does little except reinforce the notion that Allen's creative well has long since run dry.
A nasty little slice of backwater depravity.
Year One is a slapdash film in desperate need of more authoritative stewardship.
Even those with a soft spot for The Dancing Outlaw will likely have a hard time warming up to The Wild and Wonderful Whites of West Virginia.
movie_title: The Wild and Wonderful Whites of West Virginia (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately devoid of anything much to say about sexuality or friendship.
Basically Team America: World Police played straight and minus the political edge.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Myriad obvious ancestors prevent the film from feeling as revolutionary as some have claimed, though there's nonetheless vitality to Blomkamp's expert implementation.

To swoon over the lovely Rachel McAdams or hunky Eric Bana is easy, but doing so during The Time Traveler's Wife requires willful blindness to the sloppy nonsensicality of their across-the-years love story.
Narratively and grammatically dim redemption pap.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It may not have the heart or subtle artistry of Up, but then again, Pixar's 3-D outing didn't feature a mustache-tearing monkey, a manchild encased in a giant cooked chicken, or a beefy, bounding cop voiced by Mr. T.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A period piece typified by restraint, delicacy and the romantic spirit of its renowned subject.
Klapisch's "It's a small world" plotting is sunk by both bland artistry and dull insights into his milieu.
Another fervent call-to-arms from one side of the aisle.
Depicts everyday details and conveys overarching emotional upheavals with a compassion and gentleness that's quietly devastating.
It's a wonder Whiteout isn't in 3D, what with its initial onslaught of in-your-face flying propellers, crashing planes, and a lingering close-up of Kate Beckinsale stripping to her skivvies.
For his remake of Fritz Lang's last American film, Peter Hyams retains the German Expressionist's narrative conceit but otherwise ratchets up the sleek car-commercial flashiness.
Casting its south-of-the-border setting as a dingy, nightmarish hellhole of hookers and red neon lights, Not Forgotten is a feature-length anti-tourism campaign for Mexico.
Beautifully designed but short on depth or novelty.
Gamer is a laborious bit of sci-fi grimness that dully updates The Running Man for the 21st century.
The only laughs elicited by the film are those of incredulity.
Manages to be pleasant without ever eliciting much in the way of laughter.
Without a new path for its central trio, Halloween II merely rehashes in quick, distracted swipes.
A feeble follow-up punch to Japan after The Cove.
movie_title: At the Edge of the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It acutely illustrates how excessive sports fanaticism functions as a strain of insanity that, as posited by the "happy" coda, recommences with every new season.
Its sincere consideration of its characters' longing for acceptance and approval rings true.
Narrated with overblown rhetoric by Emile Hirsch, Steve Lawrence's feature-length commercial only feigns interest in the backstories and motivations of its chosen subjects
Something close to an ideal Tarantino flick, an impertinent and often tasteless epic that rewrites WII history as a fairy tale for gonzo genre kicks.
More dull calamity than stirring triumph.
A wretched dramedy about the depths of twentysomething careerist self-absorption.
In its home stretch, Funny People's action drags so unnecessarily that it ... drains any impact from its refreshingly pragmatic view of second chances.
To a greater extent than Sleeping Dogs Lie, it clumsily straddles the line between comedy and drama, its story neither outrageous enough to be funny nor substantial enough to be moving.
Underlit and generally shot with an eye toward unattractiveness, Beer in Hell also goes for ugliness in its dialogue.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Koppelman’s script is awash in phony scenarios.
From human to beast, old to young, and living to dead, Weerasethakul's characters are in constant evolution.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a surprisingly understated movie that poignantly posits death as a therapeutic force for the living.
Like most of Ridley Scott's medieval adventures, the film subscribes to such a stark good-versus-evil setup that it's devoid of any nuance or suspense.
So totally surpassing its aggro-testosterone dictates that it plays out like an assault or, more precisely still, like a final conquering salvo.
Selena Gomez may have shot to stardom as a bratty wiseass on Wizards of Waverly Place, but it's her featureless dramatic chops that best benefit Monte Carlo.
A musty shadow of the filmmaker's smart and stylish classics.
Hopelessly benign but still boisterous enough to deliver a mild buzz.
Wilmer Valderrama and George Takei's reaction shots are the only feeble sources of humor in this dramedy.
While Love Etc. shows restraint in its broad look at the universal desire for companionship, it remains a frustratingly thin affair.
A tedious hodgepodge of rote conflicts and character hang-ups.
Oliver's oddball earnestness and desperation [come] across as wan affectations.
What truly needs abolishing is the notion that the wretched Twilight saga is worth emulating.
On the frat-comedy tolerance scale, this noir-comedy just about breaks even.
Almada's attention to sound-the wind blowing across the foliage creates immediate, almost spiritual engagement with her milieu and its inhabitants.
Vainly strives for outrageousness via dry-humping, nude-pic blackmail scams, and desperate cracks about blacks, Jews, and "Orientals."
Self-aware narcissism has rarely been this unjustified-or insufferable.
A sturdy bit of subculture-tweaking silliness.
Shining an intimate light on an individual in order to reveal greater truths about life and the world, Raw Faith focuses on progressive-minded Portland, Oregon, Unitarian minister Marilyn Sewell.
Notwithstanding John Turturro's amusingly smug Italian F1 speedster and a few lighthearted jabs at Japanese TV and technology, Cars 2 generally remains stuck in neutral.
Defines itself through sustained mood, otherworldly intrigue and deep, abiding humanism.
Wilson and Sudeikis make an amusingly goofy pair.
Captures an aura of existential despondence that's married to a far less evocative (and durable) strain of counterculture romantic doom.
Comes off as a vanity project aimed at giving O'Brien another platform to express his frustration and fury over the NBC fracas.
Isn't anarchic and invigorated but sloppy and limp.
Anthropomorphizes its shelled protagonist in a manner so melodramatic as to make one cringe.
If not for its lack of self-awareness, The Art of Getting By would seem to be a spoof of ennui-inflicted teen dramas.
A comedy whose cliché-embracing stupidity borders on the surrealistic.
Salvation Boulevard doesn't simply pander to its choir; it practically accosts it via all manner of grotesque characterizations and situations.
By valuing the complexity of individuals' stories over superficial competition drama, Born and Bred bucks the unwelcome nonfiction trend fostered by Spellbound.
As with Submarine, The Hedgehog proves that Rushmore's influence has now completely spread across the Atlantic.

Following in the live-film footsteps of Miley Cyrus and the Jonas Brothers, Glee: The 3D Concert Movie transposes its flash-in-the-pan teen-pop phenomenon to three-dimensions with mundane, for-fans-only results.
Nasrallah's artistry is ultimately incapable of matching his narrative's social significance.
Álex de la Iglesia holds back nothing, a strategy that generates a compelling sense of the phantasmagoric nightmarishness of Franco's Spain.
Senna is a stirring snapshot of a charismatic, immensely talented man driven to be the best, even if the risks of chasing such success were fatal.
This middling R-rated effort doesn't transcend its groan-worthy Freaky Friday setup.
Compensates for its under-occupation familiarity with poignant performances, confident direction and an impressively sober sense of how the era's tragedy kept expanding exponentially.
Though two late plot developments are borderline-contrived, Green's direction is marked by mature dramatic and aesthetic understatement.

Scott Rosenbaum's film is 10 tracks of clichés, dutifully trading in drugs, daddy issues, attempted suicide, gunfights, hotel trashings, regret, artistic and romantic jealousy, betrayal, ecstasy, and tragedy.
movie_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Morris' lightest, most amusing film since 1997's Fast, Cheap & Out of Control.
The messiness of Kesey's trip is reflected, for worse more than for better, by Magic Trip, which fails to provide much insight into any of its subjects.
Gosnell directs as if every scene must be either a nauseating roller-coaster ride or a syrupy melodrama.
A direct-to-video-quality actioner distinguished primarily by its star's blatantly deteriorated martial-arts prowess.
The Jon Favreau film brandishes a literal-minded title as laughable as the rest of its action.
Evokes far more childlike Spielbergian wonder than this summer's similar Super 8.
A story comprised of pretentious meditative fragments.
A capable, if somewhat unremarkable, affair, beset by the same origin-story shortcomings that plagued another U.S.-virtue-via-army-weaponry fable, Iron Man.
Riley shrewdly maintains focus on how the players co-opted the merciless tactics of their invective-hurling adversaries for their own, and the region's, self-actualization.
The film apparently intends to be a dramedy, but with next to no humor materializing, the story quickly bogs down into earnest indie bathos.
Characterized by a consistent scarcity of both drama and suspense.

Part 2 is a magnificent finale for this fantasy opus, one that pays ample justice to Harry's long-in-the-making showdown with He Who Must Not Be Named, a battle in which life and death, the past and the future, precariously hang in the balance.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Heartache is the gasoline and betrayal is the spark that ignites it in Bellflower, an apocalyptic powder-keg tale of love, treachery, and flamethrowers.
The director captures a sense of hazy, harrowing obsession that's amplified by his immaculate camera set-ups and pans.
A rather straightforward supernatural-heroism tale straining oh-so-very-hard to be indecent.
Must every subculture competition receive a pop documentary?
Comprised only of half-hearted melodramatics and schmaltzy bromides, the film offers nothing new but plenty of things that are old, borrowed, and apt to make one blue.
Accomplishes its small-scale goals with aplomb.
Stateliness begets inertia in Empire of Silver, a turn-of-the-century Chinese epic whose reserved tone and regal atmosphere is suffocating.
Todd Phillips directs with increased confidence, but in every respect, The Hangover Part II is a cowardly cash-in, devoid of novelty or daring.
A fleeter, funnier beast than its 2008 predecessor.
Strings together characters and twists with amateurishly chaotic abandon.
Muntean's obsessive gaze might border on the emotionally exploitative were it not accompanied by deep empathy for the plights of all involved.
So similar to the recent Queen to Play that one half-suspects that the two films' directors shared notes before going into production.
Merely adheres to the very convoluted whodunit formula that it outwardly addresses via a from-the-grave video recording by Jamie Kennedy's genre know-it-all.
Its self-awareness has a brashness that can be enlivening.
A familiar if nonetheless enraging slab of agitprop.
Remains a highly polished piece of meta-slasher mayhem.
The cosmic is the microcosmic in The Tree of Life, as Malick conflates the ethereal and the everyday into a spellbinding panorama.

At once a disturbing vision of escape, a cautious portrait of liberation, and an exploration of authenticity and artificiality, it's a documentary that trades not in absolutes but unsettling ambiguity.
Exactly the type of inner-city crime drama that HBO's The Wire so expertly exposed as facile fantasy.
Has a beauty, a frothiness and a wink-wink sense of humor that's enlivening.
In the way it unimaginatively regurgitates familiar genre elements in service of preachy piousness, director Scott Charles Stewart's cinema is the equivalent of Christian rock.
Mickey Rourke recently made headlines for dubbing Passion Play "a terrible movie," a proclamation that's ultimately most notable for its understatement.
Ultimately concerned less with specific tactical maneuvers or combat suffering than with the grand contradictions of life.
Malick's film, full of striking cutaways to the burning-sun horizon and the harsh landscape's solitary creatures, comes to operate at an overpoweringly chilling remove.
Dax Shepard delivers an I'm Still Here-style mockumentary of staggering incompetence with Brother's Justice.
In countless over-the-top set pieces, Yuen delivers striking combat clarity without sacrificing the visceral editing and crazy digital effects of modern bloodbaths.
Rarely has a sequel followed its predecessor's exact template like this thoroughly imitative follow-up.
Somnambulistic from start to finish, it's a film whose title clearly refers to its paying-customer audience.
Goldwyn blunts every potentially sharp edge from his film.
Folklore undercurrents that prove initially spry and intriguing are soon rendered ... leadenly obvious.

Fervently panders to an under-10 audience with Carrey's main requirement only to mug in a variety of reaction shots to his beaked sidekicks' mischievous hijinks and to provide name-brand legitimacy to a dim and unfunny project.
Whereas Vivas's aesthetic is initially intimate, a raft of split-screens and circuitous tracking shots soon call undue attention to themselves.
Expands [the trilogy's] overarching vision of underworld nastiness, the universal yearning for escape, and the cruel hand of fate.
movie_title: Pusher III: I'm the Angel of Death (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't so much carve out new ground as merely provide jolt after electric jolt.
movie_title: Pusher II: With Blood On My Hands (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Refn's electrifying debut soon morphs into something far more opaque and unsettling than a mere genre retread.
Its characters' behavior eventually becomes so implausible as to be insulting.
In a manner similar to Gus Van Sant's Psycho, it's merely a high-resolution photocopy devoid of its revered predecessors' soul.
Laced with a fatalism as romantic as its Beantown milieu is damp and grungy.
A masterful melodrama whose aesthetic beauty works in service of a stinging social critique.
A mini-Michael Mann effort populated by one-dimensional clichés.
A rambling stream-of-consciousness quest that - in its final, self-conscious act - celebrates the primacy of the filmed image.
At the risk of being a Debbie Downer, watching Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer is akin to being trapped in the ADHD-addled mind of an adolescent hopped up on too much Ritalin.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A conceptual stunt without much substance beneath its initially enticing exterior...
Serviceable but seems more dutiful than dynamic, and is muddled by all sorts of random false notes.
Has lost little of the maddening, bewildering weirdness that made it a seminal midnight-movie phenomenon.
Parades about with a self-seriousness at odds with a second-half dominated by veiny-faced, limb-contorting special effects and screaming, screaming, screaming.
A suspense-free snark-fest desperate to turn its protagonist - vampire slayer Jack Crow (James Woods) - into a Snake Plisskin-style icon of supernatural-badass cool.
Most depressing is the overriding desire to confront the complexity of Arab-Western relations through feel-good platitudes.
Almost never takes thrilling flight.
Brings absolutely nothing new to the table.
Aside from a brief split-screen sequence and a few deft special-effects, there's almost no sizzle to this goofy take on superheroics.
A feast for the senses that fails to satisfy the heart, libido or mind.
Mikkelsen verifies that, even without saying a word, he's an unnervingly unhinged presence.
What really keeps Fright Night's pulse throbbing is a trio of vigorous performances that compensate for a general dearth of terror.
Laying out the means by which Harry Markopolos exposed Bernie Madoff isn't enough for Jeff Prosserman, who spends inordinate energy deifying Markopolos.
A weighty topic receives lush but eventually contrived treatment in Circumstance.
Like its predecessors, a tediously cartoonish candy-colored rollercoaster.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Heavy on tedious convolutions and depressingly light on character depth, suspense or political-economic intrigue.
Buried Prayers is a nonfiction work that confronts Holocaust atrocities from a piercing ground-level view.
The documentary makes slightly more than token gestures toward presenting both sides of an issue.
Rarely has a tale been more thoroughly ugly in every respect, and to no meaningful end.

Al Pacino romantically pursuing a cross-dressing Adam Sandler around a medieval castle should be stunningly surreal, so it's a not-inconsiderable failure that Jack and Jill manages only dim, desperate outrageousness instead.
The Greening of Whitney Brown is content to be a typical piece of tween rural-versus-urban fluff from the old Hannah Montana: The Movie mold.
Old-school holiday goodwill trumps modern high-tech impersonality in Arthur Christmas.

Cohabitation "commandments" and talk of "chick flicks" further send the material into a cutesy tailspin, with the script's low point an egregious scene featuring Nate sneaking a peek at a silhouette of Jenny undressing behind a curtain.
Rarely has Werner Herzog seemed less capable of infusing a nonfiction inquiry with poetic depth than with Into the Abyss.
After two uneven predecessors, this threequel finally elevates its titular duo to the realm of ganja-comedy icons.
Barriers both transparent and persistently present encase the characters of A Separation, constricting them in ways social, cultural, religious, familial, and emotional.
In Time coasts by on stolid convention, indulging in us-against-them conflicts free of genuine danger or consequence.
A TV movie-grade romantic farce that's practically medieval in its cornball conventionality.
The activity is pretty normal in Paranormal Activity 3, at least relative to its predecessors.
The director is uninterested in truly plumbing the more painful, confusing emotions and thorny educational and social issues that confront her subjects.
Anybody throwing the word revenge around right now is being a tad premature.
A saga whose clichéd corniness (marriage isn't everything! athletics save the school!) would be practically sinful if not for the mighty Gugino...
The resultant smorgasbord is a misshapen mess, short on humor, tension, or chemistry among its bickering protagonists.
Is Josh "Skreech" Sandoval the least deserving documentary subject ever?
Though the film's feel is pure Iraq and Afghanistan, Fiennes doesn't push those parallels unduly, and his central performances prove clear, nuanced, and incisive.
By staking out only one side of the issue, The Big Fix inadvertently calls into question virtually every one of its contentions.
It's an aesthetic assault notable not just for its belligerence, but also for its tedious excess.

From its opening white-letters-on-red-background credit sequence to its diligent focus on a wayward loner drifting about the outskirts of society and sanity, Bad Fever has the empathetic soul of '70s American filmmaking.
Just another faux-kinky vanity project in which its creator's neuroses are placed on an undeserved pedestal.
With every landscape cutaway and twinkling note from its xylophone-heavy score, it begs to be taken as a dreamy slice of countryside profundity.
with Awakening, the vampires-vs-werewolves Underworld franchise has finally decayed beyond the point of repair.
The apparent byproduct of watching too much Bad Boys II, The Viral Factor is a cops-and-criminals saga slathered in glossy Michael Bay-isms.
Nearly every scene is clunky...
movie_title: Watching TV with the Red Chinese (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Tethers together numerous indie-rock musical numbers with a backwoods-horror-film framework that's the definition of an afterthought.
If ingeniousness is a foreign concept to Contraband, so too are time and space.
Loosies has a bevy of colorful character actors -- from Michael Madsen and William Forsythe to Vincent Gallo and Joe Pantoliano -- but little character.
Roadie takes its characters' suffering seriously without ever properly justifying said misery as enlightening or unique.
Consequently, despite regularly jumping forward in time with sudden rapidity, this wannabe-serious film comes off as not just unenlightening, but borderline-interminable.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film can't locate the bone-deep sense of tragedy of Leslie Schwartz's novel -- it just keeps belching out empty, grief-stricken histrionics devoid of insight.
Flails about in search of a creative reason to exist.
Guy Ritchie goes for tedious commotion over cheeky comedy or cleverness in this depressingly flaccid follow-up to 2009's Sherlock Holmes.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Subpar material gets a tonal and aesthetic - and, by extension, thematic - boost from directorial virtuosity in David Fincher's American remake.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Bolstered by a superb cast and ... a very subtle, sly black-humor drollness, Tinker Tailor generates tension from both its aesthetic and narrative stillness.
Spielberg takes full advantage of not only CG's anything-goes potential but also of 3D.
Wants to be mature but can't help shortchanging its drama through constant reliance on its protagonist's unimpeachable nobility.
Cook County trades in a particular type of backwoods grime that might be dubbed "redneck junkie chic."
Clichés and contrivances and corniness, oh my! With We Bought a Zoo, writer-director Cameron Crowe dives headfirst into the schmaltzy slop barrel.
A feeble stab at topicality from that master of overripe Gallic melodrama, Cédric Klapisch.
Palmer's grainy, handheld camerawork won't win any aesthetic prizes, but it's in tune with his subject.

Reprinting its entire script would be the only way to properly convey the unintentionally hilarious awfulness of Red Hook Black, which complements its stilted and goofy writing with equally inept performances.
Taking the notion of toilet humor literally but incapable of delivering its promised religious satire, The Catechism Cataclysm is more muddled than its tongue-twister title.
The film's primary message is of a painfully obvious sort.

Failing even to attempt genuinely humorous gags or scenarios, and incapable of conveying the thrill of its obsessive pastime or the majesty of the animals themselves, this feel-good male weepie remains comedically and dramatically grounded.
Wears its convictions about deception, creativity, and the importance of being a really good daddy on its shopworn sleeves.
Finlay's handheld style is as casually intimate as her subjects, and the film stirringly posits music as a path to communal bliss.
A reasonably muscular popcorn film with a surprisingly tender soul.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Pap in service of wistfulness about a time period now thoroughly mocked to death.
[Refn's] stewardship is as precise and magnetic as Gosling's performance.
Rarely gets deep enough under [its characters'] skin to make them seem like more than devices in a socio-political thesis.
A portrait of the terrifying fragility of the tangled biological, social and emotional networks that govern our lives.
A pleasant-enough trifle that ensnares itself in the uneasy middle ground between indie drama and dumb-guy comedy.
A work of off-putting bathos and lovey-dovey nonsense that inspires not just the titular agitation but stomach-cramping, eye-rolling antipathy.
Frequently gripping and featuring a surprisingly spry supporting turn by Jackie Chan, it's a sturdy if unremarkable effort.
As uninspired as its generic title, Creature works hard at being a direct-to-DVD-quality monster movie.
The lack of new insights on the subject of National Socialism's wickedness ultimately reduces a well-staged film to a historical footnote.
[A] tale of teenage rivalry, forbidden romance and other musty coming-of-age concerns.
Grave Encounters can't even pretend to be anything other than hopelessly derivative.
Reconfirms that most entries in the "found-footage" horror subgenre should remain lost.
A thoroughly shabby attempt to piggyback on the success of last year's Piranha 3D.
Even more than its overwrought music-video numbers and needlessly complicated finale, Khan ups the movie's ridiculousness.
A squishy Hallmark Channel-level melodrama that rarely bothers to mask its propagandistic intentions.
Luc Besson's pulp-fiction assembly line churns out another adequate ass-kicker with Colombiana, which boasts many of the French producer-director's favorite tropes.
Jason Sudeikis completes his 2011 dude-comedy trilogy with A Good Old Fashioned Orgy, a genial film of good old-fashioned humorlessness.
In terms of suspense, The Debt is an efficiently gritty saga, as workmanlike in its mood and pacing as its aesthetics are suitably gray and grim.
Delivers a deluge of memorable moments.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Over-stylized and narratively undercooked, The Caller treats its Twilight Zone-style conceit for dim thrills.
With Miracle and now Warrior, Gavin O'Conner can lay claim to being the finest sports-drama director working today.
There are only so many times you can watch a camera panning and zooming over still photos before your tolerance for the Ken Burns effect reaches its limit.
Doggedly faithful and yet soft around the edges.
A loving, gracefully crafted retrospective that shrewdly eschews Behind the Music conventions at most turns.
Like Shlain's hand-written diagram in which lines twist and knot while linking various subjects, the film resembles not a coherent thesis but a tangle of semi-related ideas.
movie_title: Connected: An Autoblogography About Love, Death & Technology (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Hot Dog... The Movie and its disreputable ski-comedy ilk might have been a low point in cinema history, but at least their unbridled crassness had energy; Chalet Girl embraces similar '80s tropes for a lethargic you-go-girl fairy tale.
Despite an A-list roster, the performances are universally one-note, a fact largely attributable to a script overflowing with blunt dialogue and heavy-handed symbolism.
On more than one occasion, scenes just don't seem to fit right, as if an editing-room scuffle had left some crucial connective tissue on the floor.
Will Sylvester Stallone receive residuals from Real Steel?
Corny, preachy and tedious.

If occasionally a tad dry, it's a doc that successfully inflames one's righteous indignation at government-sanctioned anti-intellectualism, even as it leaves slightly open the question of its deceased subject's actual guilt.
[The] dramatically inert, spiritually generic The Way seems like it was far more fun to shoot than it is to endure.
Offsets its familiar thematic arguments with deliciously nasty wit and fractured, tension-wracked visual framing.
Fails to answer the more pressing question of why religious sagas such as this treat subtlety as a sin.
Trying isn't doing, however, and Melancholia is ultimately beset by the same nagging problems that plague all of von Trier's more subdued works.
Sheridan's tale soon segues into an unevenly paced whodunit pockmarked with lame CG nightmare sequences and populated by hollow ciphers whose every word and action is less believable than the last.
Ugly characterizations and simplistic preachiness negate the terror in Red State-a film that eventually proves horrific in ways unintended by writer/director Kevin Smith.
Nichols' formally assured direction exhibits dawning-dread restraint through slow zooms and tense framing.
Recognizes that sometimes, happily-ever-afters are more complicated than uplifting Hollywood films can manage.
This subversion of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Wrong Turn tropes is reasonably clever and delivered with requisite tongue in cheek.
A mega mash-up in the vein of Sucker Punch, Bunraku jumbles together elements with a self-consciousness that's as turgid as its story proper.
A bloated hagiography that affords less insight the longer it goes on.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: David Cronenberg's focus remains, as always, on issues of mind/body invasion, corruption, and rebirth.
As squishy as the ocean is deep, yet as far as feel-good family films go, this inspired-by-true-events saga exhibits a general refusal to unduly manipulate.
Its lethargic plotting and quirky affectation are -- wait for it -- strictly for the birds.
Defined by simplistic philosophizing and rampant narcissism.

Even at 78 minutes, White Wash pads its material through repetition but remains a proficient portrait of how increased social, economic, and geographic opportunity fosters diversity -- in life and out on the waves.
Mistakes pretty-kid pouting, long silences, and heavy-handed environment-reflects-character symbolism for actual insight.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Definitely a formulaic bit of portraiture, but given its engaging, pioneering subjects, gimmickry is hardly needed to spice things up.
A perfunctory and unintentionally goofy attempt to keep the series running without its stars Vin Diesel and Paul Walker.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A merely adequate introductory saga coated in hammy regality by director Kenneth Branagh.
It's The Crucible, except with real magic creatures, copious Cage bon mots, and the incomparably ridiculous sight of Perlman head-butting Beelzebub.
[The] ostensible archival footage proves so clunky and transparently phony that the entire gimmick collapses.
Its story's third-act inversions still provide a pointed rebuke to superhero narratives' set-in-stone dynamics.
Attempts to walk a delicate tightrope, simultaneously parodying and indulging in outrageous super-spy action, and fails in both endeavors.
Ineffective red herrings contribute to an overarching sense that the film isn't sure about what destination to choose.
Far too often for True Grit to quite overcome, [Wayne's] larger-than-life turn flirts with, if not outright topples into, self-parody.
The director's ploys are stymied by the very national illusion he contends masks death camps and a citizenry's consuming fear.
A punishingly contrived and deterministic saga.
Magnificent performances elevate mundane Cassavetes-esque material.
Doesn't break new ground so much as till familiar soil to potent effect.
A subtly touching religiously oriented saga of compassion, conviction and absolution.
Celebrates togetherness and bravery as much as binary-mathematics expertise.
Despite its title, Little Fockers barely features children. Other things it's lacking include laughs, coherence, and a reason to exist
After three consecutive films fixated on the absurd cruelty and randomness of life, Joel and Ethan Coen adopt a slightly more heartening perspective with True Grit.
A sumptuously stylish and moderately affecting mood piece.
Draws one in both empathetically and suspensefully.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Without the rosy filter of nostalgia, it's a virtually unwatchable virtual-reality saga.

[A] B-grade genre flick, which feigns interest in post-Communist Eastern European power dynamics but favors listlessly staged shoot-outs and heists devoid of emotional, psychological, or sociopolitical substance.
Far too spic-and-span orderly for its own good.
When not simply functioning as a sorry excuse for a thriller, The Tourist also operates as the Angelina Jolie Ego Trip Show.
Joseph Kosinski's would-be franchise restarter is, if nothing else, aesthetically striking.
A work that radiates a boozy, Bukowski-esque downward spiral, all alcohol-fueled anger and aimless sadness.
Proves mired in an adult sense of melancholic loneliness and loss.

Krantz has a penchant for stylization that quickly slides into a velvet-painting cheesiness, which-along with the script's pseudoprofound Philosophy 101 maxims-renders the atmosphere less noirish than ridiculously cartoonish.
That these amorous proceedings adhere to genre conventions isn't nearly as problematic as the film's strained outrageousness and all-around sloppiness.
Army of Darkness' story is so perfunctory and lame that there's nothing to tether its bits and pieces of loopy madness.
A gorgeously wrought fable trading in subtle, if nonetheless unmistakable, social commentary.
A turgid experiment in elliptical lyricism.
Less a definitive historical account of American polygamy than a study of a very particular strain of post-traumatic stress disorder.
Reflects on issues of remembrance, life, and death with a heartfelt lyricism bordering on affectation.
Little more than an ethnographic sketch.
More than its intellectual topics of interest, Dassin's intricately scripted tale is a showcase for his deft gift with the camera.
A one-note moral lesson devoid of dialogue with the very hot-button topics it feigns interest in.
Everything's surface, in a manner at once moment-to-moment engaging and yet inevitably slight.
A wryly morose and achingly romantic portrait of a man and world torn asunder by love.
movie_title: Les derniers jours du monde (Happy End) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The problem is one of familiarity.
movie_title: Like You Know it All (Jal aljido mothamyeonseo) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Boasts tonal cohesiveness but also a dispiriting lack of bite.
The film, like the director's prior Cargo 200, is a grim vision of deterioration.
Though positioned more as one man's private investigation than as a definitive survey of current global anti-Semitism, the film somewhat falters on both counts.
Boasts the neorealism of contemporary Iranian cinema, a mode that lends its story authenticity even during excessively didactic moments.
Bridgham's overarching portrait of political upheaval is compassionate and insightful.
Ramos's tack isn't to condemn but to simply lay bare.
The film has a structural pedestrianism that undercuts the courage, determination and eloquence of its amazing subject.
movie_title: Promise to the Dead: The Exile Journey of Ariel Dorfman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Mechanical through and through.
Too frequently settles into a comfortable travelogue groove.
movie_title: Traces of the Trade: A Story From the Deep North (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A crude episode of 48 Hours.
It's a portrait of stunted middle-aged maturity that comes off as a performance of self-gratification.
An exercise in shrill reductiveness.
Not simply Steven Spielberg's most prescient sci-fi work but also one of his finest.
An exemplary examination of coping that expands to entail questions of morality, absolution and faith.
If more dutiful than dynamic, it does fix what was previously broke, making over its subpar predecessor into a generic yet serviceable Statham vehicle.

Russell choreographs and shoots scenes of interpersonal squabbling and in-ring fisticuffs with competent but unremarkable efficiency, leaving the proceedings devoid of distinctive authorial personality.
An exhaustively infuriating recap of the causes and effects of our country's three decade-commitment to financial deregulation.
The Next Three Days refuses to puff up its action with message-movie sermonizing.
Heartless is as witless as its protagonist, whose willingness to make a pact with Satan is so knuckleheaded that his subsequent torment feels deserved.
Eventually racing at upward of 80 mph, 777 loses its initial designation as a "coaster," but Denzel? In Unstoppable, he's coasting.
The film gets at the pitiful need and loneliness that drives fame whores. Nevertheless, it remains most compelling when bursting Kostabi's self-important bubble.
It cogently and persuasively lays out its obvious, and yet far-from-embraced, thesis.
The film's portrait of disaffected urban teens proves an evocative tribute to the vitality of youth.
The director refuses to allow a minute to pass free from intrusive embellishment.
May be the year's least amusing comedy.
A reasonably comprehensive tribute to athletics as the great melting pot.
movie_title: Jews And Baseball: An American Love Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to swallow such a dubious message when it's made via schematic, preposterous plotting that stacks the deck in favor of its protagonists' happily-ever-afters.
The film plays like Cloverfield redux, except with less personality and tension.
Has all the excitement (and less of the depth) of a Wikipedia entry on the subject.
Four Lions would like to be scandalous; the best it can manage is being intermittently amusing.
The same old putrid corpse.
Unwittingly provides a glimpse of the unhealthy and potentially damaging parental desire to preserve and memorialize every second of family life.
Throughout, Chastain delivers a full-bodied debut performance, but she's ultimately stuck taking her wandering-soul protagonist far more seriously than it -- or the film -- deserves.
Alfredson's empty aesthetics mimic Hollywood conventions but merely exacerbate the hollowness of this entire affair.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Allegories don't come much more leaden than Monsters, a transparent fusion of Cloverfield and District 9 that posits its alien-invasion tale as a parable about illegal immigration.
Illegal organ trafficking is undeniably serious; this tawdry message movie about the subject, however, most unequivocally isn't.
If a WWE-produced film can't get squared-circle action right, what can be expected of it?
3D is stupid, and Jackass is stupid, so Jackass 3D should be a marriage made in stupidity heaven.
Red instead exhibits all the get-up-and-go of a grandpa on the verge of an afternoon nap.
The film's visual splendor is undercut by the nagging realization that it's in the service of a tepid snapshot of happy-go-ditzy ciphers.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An overall lack of adventurousness negates any genuine sense of surprise, but credit this Indian-themed indie for spicing up a familiar and routine dish with reasonably tasty flavor.
[Follows] a familiar path that's energized by subtle lead performances.
More like Harry Potter and the Torturous Moping.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Barney's Version's inconsistent conception of its protagonist is exacerbated by a larger unevenness of tone.
With uneven if generally charming results ... [it] straddles the fine line between outrageous farce and heartfelt romance.
A film dreamily in love with the equally inspiring and tedious work of art.
A visually ravishing, structurally beguiling portrait of post-colonial race-conflict as a hallucinatory apocalyptic dream.
An unconvincing ending doesn't derail the otherwise nuanced complexity of François Ozon's latest investigation of female alienation, sexuality and maternity.
Bhutto conveys a forceful sense of tectonic social and geopolitical shifts, as well as the courageous, heartbreaking personal sacrifices its subject made in service to both her homeland and ideals.
[Offers] merely tantalizing speculation from afar rather than up-close-and-personal character and thematic insights.
Santa is one bad mamma jamma in Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale, a yuletide fable that's equal parts sincere, silly, and scary.
In terms of tone, character and fatalism, an American rendition of Jean-Pierre Melville's seminal existential Euro-noirs.
A long-form sitcom overly pleased with its own progressiveness.
Duplicates the style and hothouse psychosexual passions of its '70s predecessors with such self-consciousness that little unsettling emotion emerges.
A dreadfully pretentious genre-bender about the pain of unrequited love.
May be aesthetically rough around the edges but it nonetheless offers an empathetic view on a stunningly unique figure.
A film that recognizes life as a tumultuous mess of both noble and base intensions and actions, as well as one that understands the thorny tragedies such chaos often leaves in its wake.

Lilien proves wholly uninterested in investigating his human subjects' habit of vigorously anthropomorphizing, and projecting their personal hopes, dreams, fears, and Daddy issues onto the striking hawk.
A consistently gripping bit of operatic lunacy.
May not break any new ground, but for better and worse, it's the most inoffensive Princess affair to date.
[An] aesthetically and tonally controlled knockout.
[An] intensely raw, empathetic non-fiction portrait.
Crafts a symphonic sense of time and place, and in doing so locates the profound in the prosaic.
Understated in its subversion of, and then canny adherence to, its chosen folklore
Konchalovsky's holiday fable confirms its chosen technology as not simply a gimmick, but a veritable crime against both cinema and moviegoers' wallets.confirms
The King's Speech remains a decorous bit of middlebrow mush.
Doesn't so much blend disparate genres as collapse them into a uniquely evocative collage.
A redundant if nonetheless occasionally thrilling follow-up bolstered by star Donnie Yen's precision combat skills.
movie_title: Ip Man 2: Legend of the Grandmaster (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Addresses [its] weighty concerns with such delicacy that they barely make an impact.
The Roommate is Single White Female for the CW set, but even more so, it's a naked depiction of beauty as the key to attaining everything, and thus something to be coveted with murderous tenacity.
Makes up for a dearth of scares with cheeky self-referentiality.
The filmmaker's red herrings prove depressingly incapable of hiding the real fiend's identity.
The film's characters are stick figures articulating and acting out rote issues of monogamy, loyalty and betrayal.
Another faux-verité action-horror effort that manages to be clever without being actually terrifying or thrilling.
If it maintains a superficially manipulative façade, the film remains committed to addressing the harsh realities of existence on the plains.
A reverential ode to Kubrick, Argento, Cronenberg, Altered States, John Carpenter synth scores, '70s sci-fi and '80s fantasy, and mind-boggling, hyper-stylized madness.
Rabies' ideas about mankind's penchant for hostility are generic and monotonous.
David Lowery's debut feature is long on silence and laden with a mood of oppressive dread.
The good ol' child-in-peril gimmick is the only new thing offered by Tod Williams' follow-up to Oren Peli's 2007 hit.
Rehashes the satiric and character-based concerns of its superior predecessor.
Nothing more than a cheapo regurgitation of its predecessor.
As slow as molasses and just as exciting.
A rather sturdy modernized mash-up of Assault on Precinct 13 and Escape from New York.
Conveys the intensity and introspective horror of its subject's extreme life-or-death circumstances far more authentically and grippingly than the similar, flashier and shallower 127 Hours.
The film benefits immensely from a Carell lead vocal turn that's loopy and droll.
Has a surprisingly measured pace, its set pieces choreographed with a deliberateness at odds with the frantic nature of Snake's quest.
The film works its tired conceit with maximum patience and minimal inventiveness.
Fails to convey the influential reach of the photographers' work and shows disinterest in engaging with the charges of exploitation and complicity leveled at them.
A run-of-the-mill slasher film whose central gimmick is setting its action on a train.
Nonsensical to the point that every element doesn't hold up to the least bit of scrutiny.
As an example of sexist, racist sleaze, Pieces is an inadvertently amusing relic of early '80s grindhouse.
Proves Carpenter's mastery of both mood and the widescreen frame.
Exudes a surreal sense of deranged domestic privilege.
Narratively and aesthetically addresses the traumatic fissures born from exiled existence.
Legend of the Fist primarily functions as a rah-rah nationalist fable, and other than the sleek choreography during a WWI prelude and a ferocious finale, it's largely devoid of creative combat.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: When not indulging in nostalgic flipbook-style flashbacks, director Keach shoots his material with sub-sitcom flatness, and regularly returns to the indie-balladeer well to amplify the mawkishness.
Silliness and sexiness are comfortable bedfellows from the outset of Bridesmaids.
The High Cost of Living is yet another example of the high cost (for moviegoers) of lowered production barriers for aspiring filmmakers.
If Will Ferrell's charisma is directly proportional to his absurdity, then it's little surprise that he fares relatively poorly as a sad sack in Everything Must Go,
It's hard to fathom why director Luke Greenfield agreed to give his film the too-apropos title Something Borrowed.
Sonic Youth should sue.
Jessica Alba gets plain-Jane crazy for An Invisible Sign, a syrupy A Beautiful Mind redux.
The film treats its dystopian vigilante saga with just enough of a straight face to get at the underlying insanity of its righteous-avenger protagonist.
McDonagh's direction is smooth, but it's his writing that carries the day, treating genre elements with both seriousness and subversive humor.
Accurately rehashes genre conventions, even if it chooses not to be the least bit scary.
Just another Tarantino photocopy without unique style or verve.
Mateo Gil certainly can be held responsible for turning the iconic outlaw into a paper-thin Clint Eastwood-Unforgiven cliché.
Marred by second-rate 3-D and the sort of cornball one-liners that even a fairy godmother couldn't love, it's a tolerance-testing tale that puts the grim in Grimm.
Far less interested in vehicular craziness than the wisecracking repartee of its supporting specialists.
A morass of melodramatic romance, torture, and suicide.
When Russia needs sitcoms, it looks to the U.S.A. for material, and as confirmed by the success of overseas adaptations of The Nanny and Who's the Boss?, crap translates.
As with all of Herzog's nonfiction efforts, it's spellbound by the wonder of man's relationship to his surroundings.
That tension between a servant's duty and moral responsibility forms the crux of 13 Assassins, and proves a standard dynamic that Miike handles without subversive humor or irony.
Nothing more than a moderately engaging for-fans-only tour diary.
Marries the real and the unreal with charming bizarreness.
The absence of true danger and, thus, suspense, proves a constant narrative obstacle.
A shrewd, scintillating work rooted in an investigation of varying degrees of masculinity and extremism.
The film's chief interest isn't plumbing philosophical questions of fate, providence and autonomy but, instead, wallowing in skimpy fairy-tale romanticism.
Gutierrez's story is structurally clichéd ... but, worse still, his characters are uniformly unbelievable and two-dimensional.
The most telling aspect of this latest film is its conspicuous refusal to address the bottom-line cash-grab motivations of most slasher-saga follow-ups.
Too timid to be either inspired or outrageously inept, Rio is merely a bird of a familiar feather.
A hollow poser through and through.
Billy Corben's doc boasts little intoxicating energy or compelling drama.
movie_title: Square Grouper: The Godfathers of Ganja (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite embroiling its characters in thorny ethical and legal quandaries, Win Win is after only uncomplicated tidiness.
Bill Cunningham is astutely defined by Bill Cunningham New York as not simply a traditional photographer of clothing, but an anthropological historian.
Not a single arresting image is found amid the sci-fi rubble, though unintentional laughs eventually arrive.

Foreign Parts engages in sociological inquiry without narration or contextual handholding, utilizing incisive, striking aesthetics (a panorama of hanging side mirrors, worn shoes trudging through grimy puddles) to elicit potent subcultural immersion.
Few sequels are less warranted than Elektra Luxx, a follow-up to 2009's multi-character mess Women in Trouble.
A mind-numbingly familiar saga of thuggish tough guys, dapper mafioso, and urban warfare that, despite a based-on-real-life pedigree, proves indistinguishable from its imitative brethren.
Grim aesthetics and an even grimmer worldview define Black Death, in which ardent piousness and defiant paganism both prove paths toward violence, hypocrisy, and hell.
[A] tin-eared, corny attempt at fairy-tale interpretation.
So arch you can practically hear its back breaking.

A rollicking, surreal, and existential kids' Western that worships at the altars of Sergio Leone, Hunter S. Thompson, and Chinatown, Rango drowns under the weight of discordant objectives and influences.
The most egregiously off-putting treatise yet on modern media addiction
Another Korean revenge fantasy that negates its moralizing by wallowing in the ghastliness it nominally asserts is unfulfilling and destructive.
Nothing but a million little pieces from prior superhero series and the Twilight saga.
This evocative National Geographic production proves to be both an inquisitive nature documentary and an activist call to arms.
As with its protagonist, Unknown boasts tantalizing issues buried deep beneath its frantic exterior, but little idea how to unlock or address them.
This hulk-with-a-heart-of-gold fable embraces banalities with a vigor matched only by its lack of imagination.
If Brad Anderson never conjures a truly iconic image, he still delivers a raft of mildly striking ones.
Considering the sorry state of American romantic comedies, Just Go with It's wholesale predictability is a moot point.
A Disney toon seemingly born solely from a bad pun, this computer-animated trifle pieces together its Bard adaptation from the spare parts of superior Shakespeare-for-kids predecessors.
[Trapero's] stylistic showmanship eventually pays off in a bravura single-take climax, his camera navigating physical and emotional spaces with the fatalistic urgency and despair of film noir.
Director Icíar Bollaín mixes Even the Rain's various storytelling modes with an obviousness that ultimately negates enlightening intellectual or emotional discovery.

Rife with classic-cinema shoutouts, the film is a cutesy, toothless variation on Mulholland Drive, one whose attempts to pay tribute to movie magic are ultimately undercut by stagey aesthetics and narrative theatricality.
[This] extraordinarily witless movie operates as a checklist for cultural and racial clichés.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Geek is its own language, and Paul speaks it fluently.
With originality an alien concept, the film proves to be the equivalent of sci-fi-cinema training wheels.
Couching clichés in self-conscious nostalgia does nothing to lessen their corniness in White Irish Drinkers, a coming-of-age saga notable only for its staleness.
The film's recognition of its (and its makers') own failings doesn't stop them from being unbearably accurate.
Clocking in at only 40 minutes, the film has no time to thoroughly explore the issues at the heart of its bifurcated tale.
Tackles the ancient and the unknown with such repetitive and increasingly unenlightening means that the documentary soon morphs into an overlong travelogue.
From dirty-movie parodies to the achieving of one's misfit dreams, Keith Bearden's coming-of-age dramedy adheres to the flaccidest of formulas.
Uma Thurman is as nuanced as her preposterous role allows, which isn't much
Without a complex thought about narcissism, merit, or addiction, Limitless is content to be an empty, one-note, satire-free fairy tale of avarice and corporate-political ambition.
A gonzo, if somewhat gimmicky, approach to advocating healthy living; it's like Super Size Me in reverse.
A third-generation Tarantino rip-off distinguished only by its equal-opportunity nudity.

Despite its scattered frenzy, Hop -- thanks to its fondness for smushing together seemingly incongruous elements and Marsden's goofy, bug-eyed mugging -- is just demented enough to deliver a fleeting sugar rush.
By the time the absurdly deflating finale rolls around, Wan has managed to not only botch his own film, but sully the one cool element of Star Wars Episode One: The Phantom Menace as well.
A hollow genre variation on 127 Hours.
The bleak, crazy, postmodern superhero saga Kick-Ass aspired to be, which doesn't prevent it from being sluggish, derivative, and beyond obvious.
[Its intriguing] notions are drowned out by deafeningly creaky conventions of cutesy self-discovery.
Describing or discussing Rubber, a film about a telekinetic killer automobile tire, is apt to make it sound like an inspired bit of absurdist lunacy.
Source Code has a velocity that helps alleviate nagging questions about the logic of this time-space conundrum.
Regrettably, both the condemnation of capitalist avarice and violence and the sanctification of nature and youthful innocence are dramatized only in simplistic black-and-white terms.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Robust emotion and cultural detail offset slight plotting and characterizations.
Hit So Hard never coheres into anything other than a collection of rock-star clichés.
Tyrannosaur offers up a kitchen-sink vision of suburban England in which women and children cower at the feet of masculine fury.
Copacabana proves that Isabelle Huppert can do anything, including starring in a trivial mother-daughter dramedy that's beneath her considerable talents.
Avoids fantasyland boardroom heroism while lucidly assessing the indomitable persistence of unchecked greed.
Director Zach Snyder offers a peek inside his head, which turns out to be a vomatorium of pop culture's every geeky element.
The problem, as before, is that it's rarely as lively and funny as it should be.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Even as a nascent example of a now-burgeoning trend, however, this initially intriguing doc never manages to justify its own superlative praise for Ray and Peter.
Relying on gross-out and shock in place of smarts or suspense, it's a film that reeks of talented people deliberately miring themselves in low-rent schlock.
A film erupting with ideas, ambition and intelligence, one that credits the viewer with the capacity for some mental heavy lifting.
The first Clash Of The Titans had considerably more charm than this. Money can buy you technology but it can't buy you magic.
An effective slice of occult high adventure, a sombre swashbuckler that pays its pulp source material a flinty, tight-lipped respect.
Each CGI blow-out feels progressively more synthetic and wearing.
Wasting the chance to be a great, resonant SF metaphor, Surrogates ultimately proves as bland and empty as its pretty mechanical protagonists.

While the viral campaign and mockumentary style primed us for something in the vein of Cloverfield, District 9 ultimately proves to be in a much older tradition. This is pure body horror in the lineage of Alien, The Thing and The Fly.
A modestly entertaining chiller, one that momentarily halts M Night Shyamalan's career tailspin.
Duncan Jones's intelligent, hugely moving debut deftly resurrects a mutinously old-fashioned style of SF.
No amount of flash can camouflage the career-low performances, the scaffolding where characterisation should be, the pitiful cod '40s dialogue, the monstrously fumbled comedy.

We're soon mired in a predictable tale of revenge, an escalating series of empty tragedies occurring to half-sketched characters that ultimately packs all the emotional resonance of a night on the Xbox.

It's not a bad film. It's actually coldly, technically brilliant. And it honours Moore and Gibbons only too well. But it's monumental and slab-like, an exercise in cinematic taxidermy, in need of a lightning strike to animate its parts.
This is a kindly, sweet-hearted film, filled with some truly touching stuff about impermanence, love and loss. But at a languorous 165 minutes it's old before its time.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A sturdy piece of heritage horror, as tasteful and handsome as any Brit movie with bustles and frock-coats on its agenda.
The choice of Seth Rogen to topline this crimebusting bromedy proves an unlikely but ultimately shrewd one, plugging the void at the heart of the character with an outsize comic persona.
Freewheeling, endlessly engaging, funny as hell, Guardians Of The Galaxy is a relentless crossfire of zingers and crazy visuals.
A droplet of vintage Bond DNA, a molecule of Mad Men cool, fused with the vibrant, adrenalised spin on superheroics he injected into Kick-Ass
Captain America is a medal-worthy joy, the best Marvel movie in years. Top that Joss.
Motors on quips and star charm and the primal Top Trumps thrill of assembling its protagonists. But there's no compelling reason for it to exist, no burning tale it needs to tell.
Fittingly for a tale where chemistry saves the day, it's the chemistry of the TARDIS crew that saves it.
Faced with the Curse of the Threes - the ancient jinx that sabotages quality control in the final chapter of any big screen superhero trilogy, Christopher Nolan arms himself with the power of myth.
For all the pre-release chatter of Skyfall being 'Bond with a capital B', steeped in 'a magical Goldfinger feel', it's a film that fights surprisingly shy of the franchise's time-honoured rites.
There are moments where Man Of Steel feels too earnest, too in thrall to the gravity of its own mythology. And then Superman punches Zod through a city block and all is forgiven.
An odd, chilly resetting of Doctor Who that plunders body parts from Quatermass and The Avengers, it feels like a pilot for a series that never quite came.
A movie that tries hard to carve a smarter, fresher niche in the superhero canon.
A prime piece of pop candy, a witty, flashy, unflaggingly entertaining addition to the Marvel canon, light on its feet in spite of its cosmic sprawl.
Fundamentally, this is a superhero movie with something to say. In fact it's the first Marvel entry with a truly topical sting.
If the waking scream of an ending doesn't shred your ganglia you may have no functioning nervous system.
The script never quite matches the laser-sighted wit of the visuals.
Packs enough firm-jawed, flag-rippling machismo to make Michael Bay look like some mumbling pinko pussy.
A slick, bloody, fast-paced, and ultimately enjoyable B-movie.
Whew boy.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is gorgeous, funny, fun, and engrossing in a way that a lot of movies aim for but few achieve.
Like the original, Iron Man 2 is a good time from start to finish.
Machete runs out of steam pretty early.
When your movie is nothing more than a cheap and uninteresting homage, best not to call attention to that fact with a ten minute opening scene to that effect.
Nope! I'm sorry, this won't do.
Not every filmmaker can be the next American Idol.
The surprisingly twisty plot skates along with zero friction, giving new meaning to 'Disney on Ice.'
Less a film, more a series of ragtag gags.
It certainly threatens to succumb to hero worship, but Jorge Hinojosa wisely subverts Slim's mythos by pulling the curtain back on it in the doc's second half by revealing the man beneath.
movie_title: Iceberg Slim: Portrait Of A Pimp (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Nathan Silver's film is a quiet and affecting micro-budgeted drama, its condensed frame evoking the claustrophobic feeling of the household it examines.
Yet another limp spy spoof that fails to make any interesting critiques about the genre, let alone construct a humorous gag.
The doc doesn't take the time to examine why Burning Man inspires such a level of fanaticism, overshadowing human interest with a gluttony of B roll.

But while Gilbert may not break ground with its angle, its contemplative take on what separates Gottfried as a performer from Gottfried as a person is interesting enough to drive the film, even if you may not particularly like his stand-up.
However you interpret the flick, at the very least it will have you talking.
Pride and Prejudice and Zombies is fun and funny, if lacking the zombie element that garnered its source novel so much attention.
There's something for everyone here, but especially people who want to see weird jokes using Carl's empty eye socket.
movie_title: The Robot Chicken Walking Dead Special: Look Who's Walking (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A solid directorial debut, and one of the year's most unique genre films.
Pays its respect to the genre and is ideal for a drive-in experience where the popcorn butter flows like blood.

It's a powerful film - not because its story of a vengeful female will shine a light on social injustices, but simply because it grips viewers and doesn't let go until the credits are rolling. Maria Bello is a pain-stricken wonder.
Funny, zany, violent and surprisingly smart.
As the title of the film hints, Maloof's discovery is only half of the story -- and it's only half the fun.
The cinematography is wonderful, but the plot is too vague. There could be a message here, but it's buried too deep to dig out.
So long as you're happy to suspend your sense of reality and turn a blind eye to the lack of depth in the story, you'll still find some enjoyment with our favourite fab four.
